webTitle: In times of stress call for Gazza

fields.headline: In times of stress call for Gazza
fields.trailText: Future historians will be able to pinpoint periods of turmoil for the national team by the amount of times a possible return for Paul Gascoigne is mentioned by the England coach.
fields.body:
Like most European countries Britain still has its share of caves where leaving gifts is believed to bring good luck or simply stave off misfortune. You might think such pagan practices would have ended long ago but, according to an archaeologist friend, even today people turn back to the old pre-Christian rituals in times of extreme stress. As a consequence experts are still able to determine from the volume of offerings in the caves the times when the local community has been in crisis.

It is my belief that in future centuries historians will be able to do a similar thing with English football, pinpointing periods of turmoil for the national team using the frequency with which the England coach mentions the possible return of Paul Gascoigne.

Like the caves, this gauge of the national mood might have appeared to have outlived its usefulness many moons ago. After all, it is not a month since Gazza was being ridiculed by Norwegian club officials ("We are not a summer rehabilitation centre," chuckled the chairman of Valerenga when asked about the possibility of taking the then Middlesbrough midfielder on loan) and appeared on the verge of joining either Motherwell or Miami Fusion - possibly the only football club ever to have provided vocal backing for a Gloria Estefan CD. Instead the Gateshead wonderboy fooled everyone by moving to Everton.

This neat sidestep was enough to stir folk memories in Kevin Keegan. Currently besieged by the Four Horsemen of the Footie Apocalypse (Defeat, Elimination and the Neville brothers) the England coach performed the sporting equivalent of laying a silver coin in a sacred cave. Just as the national boss's forebears might have sought to ward off evil spirits by talking up a possible return from injury of Bryan Robson, so he felt moved to pronounce: "The door is still open for Gazza."

Anyone who witnessed Gascoigne's infrequent performances at the Riverside Stadium last season might have been forgiven for thinking that the only door the England boss should keep ajar for Gazza is in an aircraft flying at 35,000 feet. Certainly that would be the one surefire way of increasing the 33-year-old's acceleration, even allowing for a parachute. Besides, Gazza is never a man to come in through an open door, not if he can risk severe injuries by entering headfirst through a plate-glass window.

Huffing and puffing about the pitch over the past eight months, he has looked less like a potential saviour of English football than an actor auditioning for a part in Thomas the Tank Engine -The Movie.

When reports said that Northern Spirit had expressed an interest in signing him it was hard to know whether they meant the Australian football club or the railway company. But with the pestilence of Euro 2000 just behind us, and the World Cup qualifiers looming like the Mongol horde, this is a time when logic offers little comfort. Instead we must seek succour in the ancient ways.

The England coach is not the only one to do so. Gascoigne had no sooner arrived at Everton's Tuscan training camp than wistful articles were being secreted in little nooks across the sports pages. Many reported that he was now slim, fit and wearing what Keegan's predecessor Glenn Hoddle would no doubt describe as his sensible head.

English football is not alone in its irrational adherence to unearthly lore. In Germany's darkest hours they have shown much the same irrational faith in Lothar Matthäus. Playing ability is not the issue here, however. Matthäus is a talisman and, if Jens Jeremies's legs and lungs have to be sacrificed to him, then so be it.

Speaking of the cave offerings the archaeologist said: "I'm not sure if people necessarily believe in it. But I think it does give them the feeling that they are doing something about whatever it is that's afflicting them." We can only hope Kevin Keegan is practising some similar form of comforting psychological self-deception.

webTitle: Toyota warns on pound but says it won't leave Britain

fields.headline: Toyota warns on pound but says it won't leave Britain
fields.standfirst: Sterling's strength hurts manufacturer's profits
fields.trailText: The head of one of Japan's leading car manufacturers warned yesterday that the strength of the pound was hitting profits at its British-based operations - but he played down the possibility that his group might consider pulling out of the UK because of sterling's strength compared to the euro.
fields.body:
The head of one of Japan's leading car manufacturers warned yesterday that the strength of the pound was hitting profits at its British-based operations - but he played down the possibility that his group might consider pulling out of the UK because of sterling's strength compared to the euro.

Toyota president Fujio Cho said: "It is true that the pound's strength is hurting profitability.

"It is unlikely that we would withdraw from the country as our British plant is the centre of our European production," he added.

Mr Cho's concerns echo those of other leading manufacturers - including fellow Japanese car maker Nissan and steel maker Corus - and the strength of sterling against that of the euro has led to calls from some industrialists for the government to set out a timetable for British entry into the single currency.

The head of the European Central Bank, Wim Duisenberg, said recently that the UK had a window of opportunity for joining the euro.

However, in an interview to be published today, the governor of the Bank of England, Sir Eddie George, took a different view.

"I have to confess that when people start talking about windows of opportunity, it makes me nervous because what is involved is a judgment about the sustainability of convergence," he said.

"We must put the emphasis on sustainability rather than transient opportunity," he told the journal, Central Banking.

The UK is not the only region in which car makers are finding life an uphill struggle.

Shares in Stuttgart-based DaimlerChrysler fell sharply yesterday after a report in the Wall Street Journal that the group would put out a profits warning alongside its second quarter figures which are due to be released tomorrow. They fell almost 3% to euros 57.36.

The Wall Street Journal also said that the Japanese manufacturer's treasurer, Thomas Capo, had told his colleagues that he intended to stand down because of frustration over the direction the company was taking.

Yesterday DaimlerChrysler declined to comment on what it described as "speculation".

However, industry sources suggested that the group may sound a cautious note about its second-half prospects when it publishes its latest figures, but will stop short of a full-blown profits warning.

"The problems are mainly in the United States, where they have been having more trouble than in recent years," said one London-based analyst, commenting on the company's likely performance.

The group is expected to report first-half sales of more than €80bn well ahead of the same period last year but profits are being hit by heavy spending on marketing and incentives to promote its Chrysler model range.

Although automotive sales in the US are holding up well, domestic manufacturers are facing increasing challenges from Japanese and European rivals in sectors which the big three US car makers have traditionally been dominant.

According to the Wall Street Journal DaimlerChrysler's American arm has been told to cut costs in order to make up for the company's heavy spending on promotion.

webTitle: DTI stalling on directors' pay curbs

fields.headline: DTI stalling on directors' pay curbs
fields.trailText: The government is backtracking on its promise to allow shareholders to vote each year on directors' pay, according to City investors.
fields.body:
The government is backtracking on its promise to allow shareholders to vote each year on directors' pay, according to City investors.

They are convinced that the Department of Trade and Industry is delaying an announcement over the pledge, made last year. The hold-up comes amid increasing controversy over boardroom excess, highlighted this weekend by news that the boss of soon-to-be-merged drugs group Glaxo SmithKline stands to make more than 20 times his salary from share options.

The government had been expected to make an announcement before the summer recess - this Friday - about its plan to insist on a vote on companies' remuneration reports at every annual shareholders' meeting. The DTI would only say last night that an announcement would be made "in due course".

City sources, who refused to be named, are growing restless over the lack of progress on the issue.

Some leading investors believe that an annual vote on directors' pay could help put the brakes on a move towards multi-million pound American-style pay packages in which share option packages dwarf directors' basic salaries and bonuses.

David Gould, investment director at the National Association of Pension Funds, said: "It is the American influence. On the back of globalisation, US-style share options, which are more generous, are likely to become more widespread."

Other observers, such as the corporate governance watchdog Pirc, said there was a worrying trend of companies breaking a convention that annual share awards should not exceed the value of each director's salary.

Pirc's head of research, Stuart Bell, said: "There have been a number of cases in the last year of companies driving a coach and horses through the established guidelines."

Among the culprits have been Chris Gent of Vodafone AirTouch, Barclays' Matt Barrett and BP's Sir John Browne. SmithKline's Jean-Pierre Garnier has been the latest to attract criticism. One fund manager said he was "disappointed" by the size of Mr Garnier's package.

The Association of British Insurers has sounded a note of concern about Mr Garnier. So has the NAPF, although it has agreed not to oppose the scheme because it contains some performance criteria.

fields.headline: Brokers glean iX windfall
fields.trailText: Partners at some of the long-established City stockbroking firms were last night thought to have cashed in windfalls of over £5m after selling their shares in the demutualised London stock exchange at their first opportunity to do so in its 200-year history.
fields.body:
Partners at some of the long-established City stockbroking firms were last night thought to have cashed in windfalls of over £5m after selling their shares in the demutualised London stock exchange at their first opportunity to do so in its 200-year history.

Early yesterday the exchange, which is battling to win support for its controversial plans to merge with its German rival, Deutsche Börse, was valued at over £800m.

By the end of the first day of trading - which does not take place on the stock exchange itself but through the offices of investment bank Cazenove - the valuation had fallen back to closer to £600m.

Just under 300,000 shares were traded, which City sources said was an indication that much of the activity came from the privately owned stockbroking firms who were allowing individual partners to sell their shares.

Each of the 297 member firms of the stock exchange received 100,000 shares, which meant that the 296,381 traded yesterday represented a small portion of the 29.7m available to trade under the exchange's plans to demutualise and merge with the Deutsche Börse to form the iX exchange.

Angela Knight, the chief executive of Apcims, the trade body which represents private clients and stock brokers, said that the vast majority of smaller firms who have voiced opposition to the merger were "hanging in there".

The selling, she said, was most likely by firms where partners were retiring, for instance, or where partners wanted to sell some holdings.

The first day of trading in the stock exchange's shares coincided with a move byCRESTCo and the London Clearing House to reduce the behind the scenes costs associated with settle share transactions - a move which was intrepreted as aiming to grab a lead for London as competition intensifies between Europe's stock markets.

The exchange needs to win backing of 75% of its shareholders for its merger at a vote on September 14. There has been speculation that larger firms, seeking reduced dealing costs, will try to buy up as many shares as possible to achieve the 4.9% single ownership threshold in an attempt to push through the merger.

fields.headline: A map of desire
fields.standfirst: All's Well That Ends Well     BAC, London ***
fields.trailText: Simon Godwin is not the first director to take the title of Shakespeare's awkward romance with a large pinch of salt. But there is something about this production that really gets you where it hurts. It concludes with the heroine Helena, a lonely figure, left hugging a tailor's dummy rather than the husband she has won, lost and won again, yet whose heart she can clearly never possess. The gap between desire and reality has seldom gaped so wide.
fields.body:
Simon Godwin is not the first director to take the title of Shakespeare's awkward romance with a large pinch of salt. But there is something about this production that really gets you where it hurts. It concludes with the heroine Helena, a lonely figure, left hugging a tailor's dummy rather than the husband she has won, lost and won again, yet whose heart she can clearly never possess. The gap between desire and reality has seldom gaped so wide.

This sensitive, clear-eyed production renders Shakespeare's story as fresh as a daisy. In a week that has already seen Thea Sharrock's fine revival of Caryl Churchill's modern classic, Top Girls, in BAC's Studio 2, it is a reminder of the quantity of young directorial talent in this country. It also reminds us how badly we need a nurturing venue such as BAC and why it should be not just adequately funded (which it isn't), but munificently funded.

Godwin brings to the play the same simplicity and simmering energy that marked out Deborah Warner's early attempts at Shakespeare. If Gemma Fripp's dazzling white design sometimes works against real passion and the sense of autumnal despair that marks this play, it does at least give it a modern feel.

There appears to be some Cambridge cronyism at work in the casting and Godwin might have done better to throw his net wider for some roles. He surely could not have found anyone better than Rosanna Lowe as his Helena, however. Lowe is a potentially first-rate Shakespearean actress with an expressive face and the rare ability to make every line sound as if she has just thought of it and make perfect sense. But, for someone who has studied with mime and movement guru Jacques Lecoq, she is surprisingly physically constrained and hunched.

Neil Auster's Bertram is nicer than most, but never really explains whether his antipathy to Helena is based on snobbery, petulance, indifference or simple immaturity, while David Mitchell's Parolles is neither foolish enough nor dangerous enough to be either funny or totally convincing.

If this sounds like carping, it is only because this production is so close to being really special. Godwin will undoubtedly go far. But only if the lottery of our daft funding system gives him and deserving others the chance.

Until August 6. Box office: 020-7223 2223.

fields.headline: Music to take to heart
fields.standfirst: Mestre Ambrosio/ Bebel Gilberto       Barbican, London *****
fields.trailText: Great bands reach a stage where they become invincible, and Mestre Ambrosio (from Recife, north-eastern Brazil) must have reached it some time before their UK debut last Friday.
fields.body:
Great bands reach a stage where they become invincible, and Mestre Ambrosio (from Recife, north-eastern Brazil) must have reached it some time before their UK debut last Friday.

They create a musical universe dominated by multiple percussion and underpinned by Mazinho Lima's tirelessly inventive bass guitar. Hyperactive Helder Vasconcelos plays sanfona (a small eight-button accordion) and percussion, donning masks or costumes to dramatise the odd song (for one he races around the auditorium disguised as an old woman). The cooler Siba plays rabeca, a kind of rough violin. Dreadlocked "O" Rocha has a trap set and a double-headed drum from which he conjures a constant, effortless rhythmic racket while skipping around the stage. Percussionists Mauricio Alves and Sergio Cassiano complete the line-up.

All six musicians move in a wild choreography that merges with all the musical gestures necessary to play their magical, raucous songs. And these guys are loud, whatever the PA level, playing a thundering lattice of cross-rhythms and elliptical chants that is clearly difficult to contain on an album.

Bebel Gilberto had the opposite problem - that of recreating a superb studio album on stage. Gilberto's Tanto Tempo is easily in the same league of grown-up pop as Moby and Macy Gray, but her band, relying too much on multitrack-derived backing tapes for the subtle shadings of the album, would have sounded better in a small club. A bassist would have helped, too. Still, Gilberto has a fantastic repertoire, including So Nice, Samba e Amor, Mais Feliz, Bananeira and August Day Song. Despite her professed nerves, she performed with all the confidence of an artist on the brink of international stardom.

Mestre Ambrosio returned the following day to fill an early evening slot on the Barbican's FreeStage and the audience greedily lapped up every moment. In the last number the band headed into the dancing crowd, creating a swaying procession that halted near the mixing desk where, hushed and still playing, they sank to their haunches and bid the rest of us do the same before rising to stomp back on stage with a flamboyant crescendo. It was great theatre and terrific music.

There's nothing quite like seeing a band at the height of their powers, willing their audience to take their music into their hearts. Mestre Ambrosio's vitality comes from modernity and tradition, from skilful composition and improvisation, from anarchy and creative discipline, and they were genuinely unmissable.

fields.headline: Relentless and divine
fields.standfirst:
Berlioz's Requiem

Royal Albert Hall, London ****
fields.trailText: "The terrible explosion carefully prepared with combinations and proportions never attempted before or since," was how Berlioz described the Dies Irae from his Requiem in his memoirs, thus fixing for posterity the idea of the work as the ultimate experimental enormity. His remarks weren't, in fact, quite true. Vast ceremonial works, with colossal forces seemingly piled on top of one another, were the order of the day in contemporary France. What was new in the Requiem was the placing of those forces at the service of a dramatic enactment of the end of time and a depiction of the awesome, pulverising majesty of God.
fields.body:
"The terrible explosion carefully prepared with combinations and proportions never attempted before or since," was how Berlioz described the Dies Irae from his Requiem in his memoirs, thus fixing for posterity the idea of the work as the ultimate experimental enormity. His remarks weren't, in fact, quite true. Vast ceremonial works, with colossal forces seemingly piled on top of one another, were the order of the day in contemporary France. What was new in the Requiem was the placing of those forces at the service of a dramatic enactment of the end of time and a depiction of the awesome, pulverising majesty of God.

Putting on the piece is still a formidable undertaking, and the Proms used it to combine two of the themes central to this season's programme - music and religion, and youth and music. Chorus and orchestra included students from London's Guildhall and the Paris Conservatoire, augmented by the Philharmonia Chorus. The conductor was Colin Davis, a Berliozian par excellence.

There were a few flaws: the chorus took a while to settle, with the sopranos at first seemingly unable to sing quietly. The men were excellent throughout - I've never heard the taxing tenor line so immaculately sustained. But the tenor soloist, Stuart Neill, struggled gracelessly, with the result that the Sanctus remained earthbound rather than wafting heavenward.

Even so, no one gets to the heart of Berlioz's music quite as well as Colin Davis, nor to the essence of the work's disturbing spiritual vision. Berlioz was an agnostic and the Requiem - more about doubt than faith - counterpoises God's might with human terror, offering little consolation in Christian revelation. The Dies Irae is not so much a "terrible explosion" as a relentless divine procession which, like some monstrous juggernaut, crushes everything in its path. Mankind is left quailing in the resulting void, and it is in such moments of quiet sparseness that Davis locates the emotional centre of the work. Even the brief flash of hope in the transcendental close of the Offertorium proves illusory when the barrenness of the Hostias disrupts it.

The ending, with its repeated Amens undercut by remorseless drum beats, expresses exhausted resignation to the inevitability of death and the possible perpetuation of suffering. It's an overwhelming experience, and you emerge from it all feeling emotionally battered.

webTitle: Smart Alec has Graveney's ageless quality

fields.headline: Smart Alec has Graveney's ageless quality
fields.trailText: It had been a heck of a week and it wasn't over yet. Alec Stewart's successive centuries for England at Edgbaston and Trent Bridge had not so much tired the veteran as stimulated his restlessness, and now, on the eve of the final, he lay fretful in his hotel bed unable to sleep.
fields.body:
It had been a heck of a week and it wasn't over yet. Alec Stewart's successive centuries for England at Edgbaston and Trent Bridge had not so much tired the veteran as stimulated his restlessness, and now, on the eve of the final, he lay fretful in his hotel bed unable to sleep.

He found even a new cricket book co-authored by his captain Nasser Hussain induced no shuteye, so spent the darkest hours propped up on his pillow watching the live satellite transmission of the New Zealand v South Africa rugby match from Christchurch.

"And I bet you scored four tries in that an' all," his thankful captain was to chide matily next day when Stewart displayed no semblance of bleariness with a match-winning innings as rosy-ripe and full blown as the high summer's day itself. Simply, the 37-year old turned this final into an exhibition match after the England bowlers had strangled Zimbabwe and, to all intents, the game itself with another mercilessly spot-on morning show.

Already, only the Monday morning after, this tournament seems no more than a diversionary mirage. Like the Giant's Causeway, or the Boat Race or the Dome, I suppose it was worth seeing, if not actually going to see - except for the colour, warmth and inspiration of Stewart's batsmanship at the head of England's parade. Lord's, as clean cut and tidy trim as Stewart himself, dozed benignly in the sunshine as the 37-year-old went about his afternoon work, each little passage prefaced with his unceasing and compulsive Ranji-like twirl of the bat and a readjustment, just so, of his shirt collar. When he runs he carries his bat lovingly and two-handed, as if it was precious to him. As, to be sure, it is.

The ancient rose-red pavilion, indeed the full-up Saturday swirl of the whole arena, stood to acclaim Stewart's glistening gem. On 97 and the game well won, his eyes had popped out on stalks at gallant Heath Streak's offside long-hop and, astonished, he edged it into the gauntlets behind him. He could have clocked it anywhere - and it would have taken him to a third successive hundred with three successive fours.

Stewart is by far the nearest thing we have to a modern-day Tom Graveney - a right-hander with the left-hand classically in charge of a light bat, which he can use almost like a wand. He played a series of front-foot pulls over midwicket on Saturday that were as pure Tom as they were theatrically dismissive. And all with the golfer's follow-through held, for that split-second, for the photographers.

Alec, in a way, is a throwback - all his county and country partners play with bottom hands and heavy bats, not to say heavy hearts. Stewart has never, ever, done the latter.

His batting this midsummer has been ripe glory to behold and his work behind the stumps remains exemplary too. He half-boasted on Saturday night about "going out to celebrate", but you knew that just meant a couple of cold Budweisers. He has already said pre-summer and pre-tour fitness will be the key to his game from now on, as well as a good "plain-eater" diet - "I've never been a curry-shop bloke".

"Sure, I can go on into my 40s," he says, "But there's 30 Tests and 50 one-dayers until the next World Cup . . . let's concentrate now on the West Indies in August."

Way back in the mid-70s, his father Micky introduced me to his son at the Oval. The boy, just in his teens, had long, flowing golden hair - "because he wants to be a footballer like Rodney Marsh," said Micky, almost apologetically. Thank the Lord he went for cricket.

Alec will play his 100th Test match in 10 days time - so will his mucker, rival and so different blood brother, Michael Atherton. It will be a famous dual centenary for sure.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Somerset moved to within two points of the fixtureless National League Division One leaders Worcestershire with a nail-biting victory over Yorkshire at Scarborough.
fields.body:
Somerset moved to within two points of the fixtureless National League Division One leaders Worcestershire with a nail-biting victory over Yorkshire at Scarborough.

In trouble at 74 for seven, they had Ian Blackwell to thank for their narrow win. He scored an unbeaten 50 to carry the visitors past Yorkshire's 141 with two wickets in hand.

Gloucestershire, also now two points behind the leaders, saw off Kent by five wickets at Cheltenham. Jack Russell and Mark Alleyne took them home with an unbroken sixth-wicket partnership of 91 after Kent had set a target of 199.

Division Two's big game at Guildford turned out to be a mismatch as the leaders, Surrey, eased to a 127-run win over Nottinghamshire, who remain second despite their defeat. A second-wicket stand of 139 between Graham Thorpe (126 not out) and Ian Ward (51) proved decisive.

Sri Lanka crushed South Africa by an innings and 15 runs in 3 days of the first Test in Galle. It was South Africa's first ever loss to Sri Lanka and only their third innings defeat since returning to international cricket.

Muthiah Muralitharan finished with match figures of 13 for 171, the best return against South Africa since Clarrie Grimmett took 14 for 199 for Australia at Adelaide in 1931-32. After their first innings 238, South Africa were all out for 269 in reply to Sri Lanka's 522.

Indian tax inspectors today begin examining the contents of 60 safe deposit boxes seized in raids on the homes and offices of leading cricketers and cricket officials. The nationwide swoops were carried out to establish if anyone has amassed assets disproportionate to known sources of income.

webTitle: Hussain sees buzz replace the boos

fields.headline: Hussain sees buzz replace the boos
fields.trailText: Nasser Hussain looked down upon a contented crowd, on a blissful summer's evening, with the NatWest series safely gathered in, and surely reflected that, as balcony scenes went, this was mightily preferable to the last one.
fields.body:
Nasser Hussain looked down upon a contented crowd, on a blissful summer's evening, with the NatWest series safely gathered in, and surely reflected that, as balcony scenes went, this was mightily preferable to the last one.

Few England captains have ever been booed so resoundingly as was Hussain less than a year ago when a series defeat against New Zealand condemned his side to the label of the worst Test team in the world.

Hussain, a fresh and dedicated leader, appointed only a matter of weeks earlier, had been deeply shaken. He even conceded that there had been a hint of a tear. He had long become immune to those who cast English cricket as a music-hall joke, but even in English cricket, it appeared, the age of the music hall really was dead. The howls of the Oval crowd came from bitter anger.

Few of the capacity crowd present here on Saturday, on the other side of the Thames, would claim that England's six-wicket defeat of Zimbabwe, achieved with 28 balls to spare, had been the most exhilarating spectacle. Indeed, Alec Stewart's absorbing, and wretchedly unrewarded, search for three successive one-day hundreds apart, it was quite pedestrian.

But England this time were winners, highly competent ones at that, the upbeat mood created by victory against West Indies in the second Test, also on this ground, had been maintained, and that was all that mattered.

"To be on that winners' balcony taking the plaudits was a reward for a lot of hard work," Hussain said. "It's been a pleasure captaining this lot and they have now got their just rewards. The country now has a bit of a buzz about it with this win following the Lord's Test. We have to keep that buzz going."

England have developed, under the guidance of Hussain and the coach, Duncan Fletcher, from music hall to Comedy Store. In the mood of the modern stand-up, they have now become something more endearing - openly confessing their flaws, but inviting sympathy as they strive to develop their self-esteem in the face of life's daily absurdities. It's not perfect, but it's a start.

If Fletcher has some grand design, he has yet to reveal it. He sticks to the nitty-gritty of the dressing room, concentrating more on the basic strengths of an individual player than any ambitious wish-list about a grand restructuring of the game. If he has a philosophy, it is to avoid too much philosophising, especially in public.

Darren Gough is one player who has returned to his best under Fletcher's guidance. All the talk of hamstring disorders has been forgotten.

After England won an influential toss, Gough and Andrew Caddick had set the pattern of the game by noon, cutting Zimbabwe down to 31 for four by the 15th over. Gough was at his most upbeat, needing only one ball to see off Guy Whittall, who edged a rising ball to third slip, and then fooling Murray Goodwin with a slower ball.

Caddick caused Neil Johnson to drag on, Alistair Campbell spooned Alan Mullally to cover and for the next two hours the Flower brothers tried to take root in grudging soil. Grant's first dozen runs took 58 balls, and although the pressure lifted after that, it was only when Heath Streak twice carved over cover for six in Craig White's final over that Zimbabwe mustered an aggressive posture.

Gough has always looked like a winner; and after the match, now that he was one, he was appealingly uppity, dismissing England's previous dalliance with specialist one-day all-rounders as "ridiculous", pronouncing that "you are either top class or you're not" and rightly insisting that the best three bowlers should always be picked.

Bursting with fulfilment, he referred to Gough, Caddick and Mullally as one might link Trueman, Statham and Tyson, and vowed: "We'll all go on to the next World Cup if you want us to."

It was a wonderful reminder of the day that he promised a Headingley crowd that he and Dominic Cork were going to win the 1999 World Cup, and even if the wheels fell off horribly on that one, he deserves admiration for forever trying to rev up the engine.

"I've loved a few England coaches in my time [Keith Fletcher, Ray Illingworth, David Lloyd and now Fletcher] and they are all different, that's for sure," Gough said. "But, no messing, this one stands apart. The others would work on my failings, but this one makes a real difference cos he calls you aside and talks about not only what you are lacking but about your qualities."

England's batsmen stuttered at first as Streak, who has striven manfully on behalf of his side all summer, whipped out Marcus Trescothick and Andrew Flintoff in his first over.

Trescothick managed only a single before Campbell held a fast, high catch at first slip; Flintoff, unwisely maintained at No3, a decision influenced by the fact that the pitch had largely flattened out, was bowled for nought, fourth ball.

The stage instead fell to Stewart. His cover drive, on the up, against Streak to reach 93, was exceptional; the next ball, clipped to the square leg boundary, a gimme. The rush to glory was irresistible; he cut at the next and was caught at the wicket, missing the chance to join the Pakistanis Zaheer Abbas and Saeed Anwar as the only batsmen to make three consecutive one-day hundreds.

For Zimbabwe, defeat finally ended a long and traumatic tour. Merely to compete while political agitation raged back home was an achievement. They return home to an uncertain future knowing that to protect their international status in such challenging circumstances may prove an even greater challenge.

fields.headline: England's newest sensation awaits call-up
fields.standfirst: Trescothick appears set to get the nod today to replace Ramprakash
fields.trailText: One limited-overs tournament into his England career and at least one supposedly responsible newspaper has already referred to Marcus Trescothick as a "legend". Instant fame has come so quickly that he would be best advised not to sing too loudly in the bath, because if he does he will surely have to miss next week's Old Trafford Test against West Indies while he is showered with recording contracts.
fields.body:
One limited-overs tournament into his England career and at least one supposedly responsible newspaper has already referred to Marcus Trescothick as a "legend". Instant fame has come so quickly that he would be best advised not to sing too loudly in the bath, because if he does he will surely have to miss next week's Old Trafford Test against West Indies while he is showered with recording contracts.

Trescothick's clumping strokeplay was one of the delights of the NatWest series. Here was a player who wandered into international cricket, saw nothing to fear and bashed the ball to all parts. Nearly 300 runs at an average of 48, including two half-centuries, and all scored at a healthy lick, convinced England's inner sanctum that he was blessed with an ideal international temperament.

Trescothick lives in the same Somerset digs once frequented by Ian Botham and, such are the expectations already surrounding his likely Test debut in Manchester on Thursday week, that he should launch an immediate search at the back of the murkiest cupboards for some leftover Botham fairy dust.

England's selectors announce the third Test squad today, and the time has come for more sober reflection. Countering fast-medium bowlers who are not allowed to bowl short in a one-day tournament is one thing; conquering Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose for long periods, even this late in their West Indies' career, is quite another.

Trescothick's unfazed approach is welcome, especially when compared to the mental turmoil of Mark Ramprakash, whose experimental role as an opening batsman has brought only 95 runs in seven innings and further bouts of soul-searching on dressing-room balconies. After 74 Test innings, and an average of 26, even Ramprakash's most adamant admirers must reluctantly conclude that, if the shots have not flowed by now, they probably never will.

That Trescothick will play in Manchester is inevitable. England's lack of runs in the first two Tests has been so stark - they are still awaiting their first half-century of the series - that to overlook his claims would be madness. But there is a powerful case for Michael Vaughan to be the latest player to open with Michael Atherton, with Trescothick accommodated down the order.

Vaughan's gutsy partnership with Atherton in the second Test victory at Lord's had the air of master and pupil; here at last was Atherton's successor. Their similarity, their stolidity even, makes them an imperfect opening partnership, but when did England last enjoy the luxury of rejecting a composed start to their Test innings on the grounds that it came a little too slowly?

Vaughan's No4 position is vulnerable anyway because of the return from injury of Nasser Hussain, presumably at No3, with Graeme Hick the likeliest man to follow. That would leave Alec Stewart at No5, with Trescothick displacing Nick Knight at six. Graham Thorpe, although his one-day return was solid rather than spectacular, will also have his advocates.

Craig White's ability to reverse-swing the ball away from the succession of West Indies left-handers should guarantee his return, especially as a dry Old Trafford square will hasten the roughing up of the ball. The obvious route would be to include him ahead of Andrew Flintoff, but England will also be tempted to omit a specialist spinner and bat White as low as No8.

Robert Croft made a solid return to Test colours at Edgbaston and the West Indies' left-handed bias makes it likely that the Glamorgan off-spinner will make the squad ahead of Warwickshire's left-arm spinner Ashley Giles, a combative cricketer but one who slips in and out of favour seemingly on little more than a whim.

Instant fame has come so quickly that he would be best advised not to sing too loudly in the bath, because if he does he will surely have to miss next week's Old Trafford Test against West Indies while he is showered with recording contracts. Trescothick's clumping strokeplay was one of the delights of the NatWest series. Here was a player who wandered into international cricket, saw nothing to fear and bashed the ball to all parts. Nearly 300 runs at an average of 48, including two half-centuries, and all scored at a healthy lick, convinced England's inner sanctum that he was blessed with an ideal international temperament. Trescothick lives in the same Somerset digs once frequented by Ian Botham and, such are the expectations already surrounding his likely Test debut in Manchester on Thursday week, that he should launch an immediate search at the back of the murkiest cupboards for some leftover Botham fairy dust. England's selectors announce the third Test squad today, and the time has come for more sober reflection. Countering fast-medium bowlers who are not allowed to bowl short in a one-day tournament is one thing; conquering Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose for long periods, even this late in their West Indies' career, is quite another. Trescothick's unfazed approach is welcome, especially when compared to the mental turmoil of Mark Ramprakash, whose experimental role as an opening batsman has brought only 95 runs in seven innings and further bouts of soul-searching on dressing-room balconies. After 74 Test innings, and an average of 26, even Ramprakash's most adamant admirers must reluctantly conclude that, if the shots have not flowed by now, they probably never will. That Trescothick will play in Manchester is inevitable. England's lack of runs in the first two Tests has been so stark - they are still awaiting their first half-century of the series - that to overlook his claims would be madness. But there is a powerful case for Michael Vaughan to be the latest player to open with Michael Atherton, with Trescothick accommodated down the order. Vaughan's gutsy partnership with Atherton in the second Test victory at Lord's had the air of master and pupil; here at last was Atherton's successor. Their similarity, their stolidity even, makes them an imperfect opening partnership, but when did England last enjoy the luxury of rejecting a composed start to their Test innings on the grounds that it came a little too slowly? Vaughan's No4 position is vulnerable anyway because of the return from injury of Nasser Hussain, presumably at No3, with Graeme Hick the likeliest man to follow. That would leave Alec Stewart at No5, with Trescothick displacing Nick Knight at six. Graham Thorpe, although his one-day return was solid rather than spectacular, will also have his advocates. Craig White's ability to reverse-swing the ball away from the succession of West Indies left-handers should guarantee his return, especially as a dry Old Trafford square will hasten the roughing up of the ball. The obvious route would be to include him ahead of Andrew Flintoff, but England will also be tempted to omit a specialist spinner and bat White as low as No8. Robert Croft made a solid return to Test colours at Edgbaston and the West Indies' left-handed bias makes it likely that the Glamorgan off-spinner will make the squad ahead of Warwickshire's left-arm spinner Ashley Giles, a combative cricketer but one who slips in and out of favour seemingly on little more than a whim. fields.headline: Eli Wallach: strength of character
fields.standfirst: He's played Mexican bandits, Sicilian lovers, Jewish elders  and Mafia bosses. And his approach to acting hugely influenced Brando, Newman and Monroe. Michael Billington meets Eli Wallach - 84 and still preaching the Method
fields.trailText: He's played Mexican bandits, Sicilian lovers, Jewish elders and Mafia bosses. And his approach to acting hugely influenced Brando, Newman and Monroe. Michael Billington meets Eli Wallach - 84 and still preaching the Method.
fields.body:
Some people think there is madness in the Method. But Eli Wallach - a superbly versatile character actor and a founding member of the New York Actors' Studio - has spent a lifetime proving you can apply the systematic realism of the Method to movie-acting.

If he is still, at 84, recognised by cab drivers wherever he goes, it is because his mean heavies in films like The Magnificent Seven and The Good, the Bad and the Ugly had a veracity you don't expect to find in stereotype Western villains.

Wallach is in London, on his way back from shooting a new movie in Prague, to take in a few shows, in particular Lucy Bailey's fine production of Baby Doll at the Albery - for it was in the heated, fury-raising film version of that Tennessee Williams play that Wallach made his screen debut back in 1956. He played the Sicilian, Silva Vaccaro, who aroused Carroll Baker's thumb- sucking heroine to a state of sexual excitement. He now looks back on the moral panic the film produced with amused wonder.

"I was shocked and surprised," he says. "I thought the film was rather biblical, in that my character sought revenge on the heroine's husband for burning down his cotton-gin. Elia Kazan once asked me if I thought Silva seduced Baby Doll. I pondered it and later told him I might have wanted to but, as a Sicilian, I'd have led her to the point and not done it: part of my revenge would have been to establish the husband's complicity in the arson, but to leave him with an unsatisfied wife.

"People also made a lot of fuss about a scene in which I apparently stroke Carroll Baker's legs while she's on a swing. What they don't know is that we were shooting in Mississippi in late November and it was cold as hell. We were sucking on ice cubes and spitting them out when the director called 'Action' so you couldn't see our breath. And if my hand goes out of shot during the scene on the swing it was probably because I was warming it on the radiators at our feet."

It's significant that Kazan cast Method actors such as Wallach and Karl Malden in the movie's lead roles: they even insisted they play scenes straight through without the familiar fragmentation of movie-making. But did Wallach have any problem working with Kazan who, after testifying to the House Un-American Activities Committee in 1952, was seen as the quintessential informer?

"I was dismayed by what Kazan had done," says Wallach, "and he knew that. At the same time I respected him as a director. Actors also have to live. Richard Dreyfuss was once asked if he'd make a film with Kazan. He said, 'Absolutely not,' and then paused before adding, 'unless it was a good role.' Kazan had the great gift, like many directors, of not directing too much. When I did The Misfits with John Huston, I found he directed by indirection. One day I had a drunk scene with Clark Gable and Huston told me about the drunkest he ever was: it was the previous day when he'd ridden a camel in a race against a horse. I told him he'd looked perfectly sober. And I realised what he was saying was you don't have to act drunk to make it real. In the same way Kazan would say, 'Did you seduce her?' and walk away leaving the actor's imagination to do the work."

If Wallach's conversation is fuelled by famous-name anecdotes, it is largely because he has worked with everyone in the business over the past 50 years. But you feel the New York Actors' Studio and the Method (largely an attempt to bring the Stanislavsky system and its belief in emotional memory to the preparation for a role) lie at the heart of his beliefs. Wallach and his wife, Anne Jackson, were part of the core group of 25 who joined the Actors' Studio in 1947. And Wallach has actively proselytised for the Method: in 1958 he wrote a pugnacious article for the theatrical magazine, Encore, saying that it "was, and is, in rebellion against posturing, singing orators and technically accomplished and emotionally empty actors".

It's a myth, Wallach argues, that the Method is only applicable to naturalistic drama and stunts an actor's versatility; and he cites, as his trump card, Marlon Brando: "He's eccentric and odd but a brilliant actor. If you look at his movie work you find him as a Nazi in The Young Lions, an English fop in Mutiny on the Bounty, an ex-prizefighter in On the Waterfront, a Mexican revolutionary in Viva Zapata. He could do everything.

'He also had a sense of danger. He and I were once doing an improvisation at the Actors' Studio in which I was an FBI man searching his apartment for drugs. I remember the door burst open and he cried out - and this was in the days before everyone swore - 'What the fuck are you doing?' I tried to explain that I'd been given the key by the janitor and had a licence to search, but it all ended with Marlon picking me up and throwing me bodily out of the room. I was criticised, in the post-scene discussion, for failing to carry out my intention of finding the drugs. But I was pretty helpless in the face of a human tornado like Brando."

Though never a full member, Marilyn Monroe was a frequent observer at the Actors' Studio. Wallach remembers her doing a scene from Eugene O'Neill's Anna Christie with great beauty and telling him, rather sadly, that the people who laughed at her for wanting to play Grushenka in the film of Brothers Karamazov had probably never, unlike her, read the book. But what strikes one is how people who attended the Actors' Studio - such as Brando, Paul Newman, Kim Stanley and Wallach himself - applied its emotional reality to their work in Hollywood.

Wallach found it highly relevant even when playing a Mexican bandit in The Magnificent Seven. "I'd seen the Japanese original," he says, "and wanted to play the Mifune part of the crazy samurai, but they told me that character was the love-interest and had to go to Horst Buchholz. When I was cast as the head bandit, it struck me that in Westerns the villain holds up the bank, robs the train or steals the cattle - but you never see what he does with the money. So I went to a Mexican dentist and got him to put in two gold caps, wore silk shirts and got a great horse with a beautiful saddle: for me it was a way of defining the character's objective and giving him reality.

"Something similar happened when I did The Good, the Bad and the Ugly. I was struck by the way Sergio Leone, who said he wanted the whole movie to look like a Vermeer painting, made the costumes authentic to the last detail. But I also noticed that he was a big man who wore both belt and braces and so I adopted that for my own character."

Finding the character, defining the intention, giving it physical life: these have always been Wallach's watchwords in a career that has seen him playing Sicilians, Mexicans, Greeks, Mafia bosses and Jewish elders. He's also stuck to his belief that he was basically a New York stage actor - "when I went to California to do a film, I wouldn't unpack" - and that even villains have to be played from their own emotional viewpoint. He's living proof that America's strength lies in its character actors. And, still happily working at 84, he embodies the ideals expressed by Lord Byron in one of his favourite plays, Tennessee Williams's Camino Real: "Make voyages. Attempt them. There is nothing else."

webTitle: Making money count in the arts and sport

fields.headline: Making money count in the arts and sport
fields.standfirst:
Labour is embarked on its road to the manifesto - and so is the Guardian. In a unique experiment in British journalism, Guardian specialists draw 'blue sky' sketches of what should form Labour's programme for a second term. Readers add their thoughts, and the material is submitted to a 'reality check' by a former Whitehall mandarin, Sir Peter Kemp. Today we look at culture, media and sport

Special report: Road to the manifesto
fields.trailText: Labour is embarked on its road to the manifesto - and so is the Guardian. In a unique experiment in British journalism, Guardian specialists draw 'blue sky' sketches of what should form Labour's programme for a second term. Readers add their thoughts, and the material is submitted to a 'reality check' by a former Whitehall mandarin, Sir Peter Kemp. Today we look at culture, media and sport
fields.body:
Forget the obligatory luxury, or even the complete works of Shakespeare, if you find yourself dropped on a desert island tomorrow ask for only one thing - an artist.

Quite simply there is no more voracious species of survivor on the planet. Fringe theatre could teach the most Darwinian of neo-liberals a thing or two about natural selection.

Artists are used to improvisation, that's their business after all; begging, borrowing and cannibalising are second nature. But there is a limit to how long even they can live on thin air. You cannot mime money forever. Eventually you need the real thing.

And never has this country needed to invest more in its imagination. We might daydream of classlessness, but Britain is still a hidebound society which smothers the potential of many of its children. Art frees, and we have never needed more to escape the shackles of our history.

So what should Labour do for the culture in its second term? The first task is to shift spending away from institutions and into individuals and art itself.

What is the point of having some of the most well-appointed theatres and galleries in Europe if there is nothing to put on in them? Throughout the Thatcher years arts bureaucracy grew while the work withered.

That has to change. Education, education, education was Tony Blair's pre-election mantra and it should be the guiding star of Labour's arts policy, too. Sending every child in the country to the Lion King would unlock more minds than a century of literacy hours.

Sure it's Disney, but it's direction and design is the very essence of theatre - and it's a moon landing to the imagination of a 10-year-old.

"Theatre in education," emasculated in the 1980s' witchhunts for Marxist cells of actors supposedly corrupting young minds, could be cheaply revived, rescuing regional theatres and ensuring that there is more to school than SATs. It even might reduce the number of exclusions.

Don't forget too that Ray Davies and countless other rebels got their first break in the school orchestra. Remember them? The arts need to get them young. With so many theatres and concert halls playing to 60 or 70 per cent capacity every night, Labour should offer empty seats to students and young people at £1 a time from 6pm every evening.

The real problem, of course, is that the poor don't go. The solution is for a second-term Labour government to throw open the doors of every subsidised company in the country for a National Free Arts Day. That would create a buzz and queues akin to the January sales - drawing in big crowds from the estates.

That's why Chris Smith's failure to deliver free universal entry to national museums seems so criminal. A tiny, limited adjustment of the VAT rules will solve the problem and cost the Exchequer nothing.

Libraries are the final and in some respects most important piece of the jigsaw. Rather than be left to mould away, they should become the cultural powerhouse of every small town in the country. By opening late into the evening, when people actually might use them, providing books people want to read and proper net access as well as staging small-scale arts events, they have the potential to revolutionise lives.

Labour should invest the resources needed to make that happen. After all, the arts have the imagination: all they need is the money.

The same goes for sport. In England, we spend only 77p per head on sport - a fraction of the investment in most European countries.

That has to change. Not just because sport is fun, though it is, but because sport can improve the nation's health, its standard of education and even combat crime. To demonstrate how seriously Labour takes sport, it should should give the sports minister cabinet rank.

Take health. Repeated studies have shown that the more active we become, the healthier we will be - placing an ever lighter burden on the National Health Service. That's why all public health policies should be checked to ensure they include a sports component. Experience shows sport is also a handy way to keep young offenders out of trouble.

For that reason, Labour should call an immediate halt to the sale of playing fields, used by both schools and communities. It should introduce legislation in the second term protecting any playing field that has been used for sport for 20 years or more from being sold.

The government should also establish a UK Sports Institute, with regional centres - similar to the ones operating in Australia. With government backing, it could provide state-of-the art facilities, training and expertise to ensure the best for British athletes. The Institute will specialise in a number of sports, particularly those outside the mainstream which have traditionally been underfunded.

Labour also needs to improve sports in schools. Head teachers need to set aside more time for sport, no longer allowing pupils aged 14 and over to ignore it.

The priority of any cabinet level sports minister has to be a close examination of the current state of football, our national game. This will of course prove unpopular with the professional clubs, particularly those in the Premier League.

But Labour should take heart from France. There the government regularly intervenes in the game at all levels: and now the French are world and European champions. A Football Bill should establish a statutory, independent football regulator to ensure that clubs are not allowed to exploit yet further their fans.

The regulator would hear complaints from supporters, with power to regulate everything from ticket prices to merchandising. The regulator would have the power to impose sanctions on clubs, investigate them and even to make recommendations on how they should be run.

A Football Bill should also move to help those smaller clubs currently losing out on talented players.

Many sides do not benefit from the young players they have spotted and developed, particularly when they leave for a bigger club.

This is killing the lower league teams and depriving them of much needed revenue. A football bill should allow small clubs to demand financial compensation when they lose new talent to the larger, big-money teams.

This would contribute towards the survival of the country's less fashionable clubs - and let our national game be what it should be: the property of the nation.

Pledges

1 Sell empty theatre seats to students for £1

2 Free universal entry to museums and galleries and national free arts days

3 A ticket to the Lion King for every child in the country

4 A cabinet-level minister for sport and a new football regulator

5 Halt the sell-off of playing fields

webTitle: We don't care where you come from because it's where you are going that counts

fields.headline: We don't care where you come from because it's where you are going that counts
fields.trailText: As a small company, the people we deal with expect a fairly homogenous group of people. In fact Rools - that's all 10 of us - has the cultural make-up of a global corporation. We already have seven different nationalities and the number is rising.
fields.body:
As a small company, the people we deal with expect a fairly homogenous group of people. In fact Rools - that's all 10 of us - has the cultural make-up of a global corporation. We already have seven different nationalities and the number is rising.

We have recruited two people who could have walked into practically any company: our marketing director, who used to work for one of the world's leading fast moving consumer goods manufacturer, and our operations director, who worked for one of the UK's biggest banks. Neither is British; one is Lebanese and the other a New Zealander.

They came to the UK because of opportunities both in the new and old economy. Of course, international finance has built a home here and that helps attract top talent, too.

One member of the team is an American. A question we often ask ourselves is why he is not working in Silicon Valley. The short answer is lifestyle.

He came to Europe because he thought he would enjoy the easier-going culture here. It's hard work, but perhaps the business environment is less uptight than that in the US. Anyway he liked it so much he stayed.

We like to think Rools offers him the excitement of a Palo Alto start-up company, but with a European-style atmosphere.

From the start, we knew that we wanted an international team. Rools needs the diversity of background and culture to enable us to expand effectively into other markets. However, we have surprised ourselves at the level of ethnic diversity we have already achieved.

Given our multicultural make-up, we like to think Rools would not indulge any national stereotypes. Working here gives you a globalised outlook.

Sometimes, however, national traits do shine through. The marketing director has surprised everybody in the office by her rather vigorous negotiations with one of our creative agencies. "I'm Lebanese," she tells us, "I have to feel I have got value for money."

Perhaps, surprisingly, it has not been a huge challenge to manage the diversity of cultural backgrounds in our small team. The team's international outlook coupled with their relaxed personalities means that we all get on. There is conflict, but it is the healthy kind that helps resolve issues.

Rools has two new members joining the technical team on Monday, both of whom are British. Where you come from is not going to bother us, it is where you are going to that counts.

webTitle: Hong Kong pollsters feel official chill

fields.headline: Hong Kong pollsters feel official chill
fields.trailText: There is growing evidence in Hong Kong of apparent efforts by the government to influence the operation of opinion polls whose results have shown popular criticism of its performance.
fields.body:
There is growing evidence in Hong Kong of apparent efforts by the government to influence the operation of opinion polls whose results have shown popular criticism of its performance.

This is a sensitive time because Hong Kong votes for a new legislative council on September 10. The election is widely seen as an opportunity for the public to give its verdict on how Tung Chee-hwa's government has performed since Britain handed Hong Kong back to China in 1997.

A close adviser to Mr Tung, who was picked as Hong Kong's chief executive by Beijing, has admitted approaching the vice-chancellor of the University of Hong Kong to discuss the activities of an academic pollster on the staff.

The vice-chancellor, Cheng Yiu-chung, said this weekend that Mr Tung's special assistant, Andrew Lo, who requested the meeting, "raised questions" about polls conducted by Robert Chung, saying he believed that there was a conflict of interest because Dr Chung also wrote political commentaries.

The incident has brought accusations of government interference in academic freedom.

Most people in Hong Kong are well aware that no university on the mainland would be allowed to carry out a survey of public attitudes towards President Jiang Zemin.

A researcher at another institution, Hong Kong's Chinese University, says that he too was approached by Mr Lo to discuss a survey on Mr Tung's popularity. Mr Lo is said to have made suggestions on how to improve the polls to "make them more objective and scientific".

Last month the Chinese leadership delivered heavy hints that they would like Mr Tung to have a second term of office when his mandate expires in 2002.

Mr Tung does not have to face the people's judgment in September: he is chosen at a later date by a special election committee for which most people cannot vote. But Hong Kongers are showing increasing impatience with his administration, and his popularity rating has fallen from 50% last year to 38%.

Mr Lo, who has no qualifications in the field of public opinion polling, says he met Professor Cheng so that he could gain "a fuller understanding of opinion polls in general".

Mr Tung's office has denied that he was acting on the chief executive's behalf.

Critics of the government say it is resorting to the kind of indirect pressure habitually used to stifle dissent on the mainland, whose officials are expert in sending out signals of their bosses' displeasure.

fields.headline: Deliberations, Debts and Developments
fields.trailText: HILLSBOROUGH JURY FAIL TO REACH DUCKENFIELD VERDICT
fields.body:
HILLSBOROUGH JURY FAIL TO REACH DUCKENFIELD VERDICT

The jury was today discharged at Leeds Crown Court after failing to reach a verdict on two charges of manslaughter brought against David Duckenfield, the police officer in charge at Hillsborough on the day of the 1989 FA Cup semi-final disaster which saw 96 fans crushed to death.

The eight men and four women had to decide whether Duckenfield was guilty of the manslaughter of John Anderson, 62, and James Aspinall, 18, in a private prosecution brought by the Hillsborough Family Support Group. During a period of deliberation that lasted over 22 hours, the jury cleared Duckenfield's deputy, ex-superintendent Bernard Murray, but were unable to reach a second verdict on the man in charge.

The trial judge, Mr Justice Hooper, told the jury: "Not withstanding your very best efforts I understand you are not going to be able to reach a verdict in this case. In these circumstances I will discharge you. That will be the end of your involvement in the matter. You have approached the case with obvious interest and enthusiasm. Sadly you have not been able to reach a verdict but these things happen."

Former chief superintendent Duckenfield, 55, of Bournemouth, Dorset, had pleaded not guilty to the charges. A court hearing will be held on Wednesday when legal representatives for the families who brought the private prosecution are expected to announce whether they will ask for a re-trial.

ADVERTISEMENT

Planning to shop, eat, drink in the city? Simply click here to enter the e-street.com fantasy night out competition and use e-street to plan a dream night for you and your friends.

FIGONE

You can't have pleasure without pain (so the Fiver's been told while being strapped to a gym horse) and Barcelona's Juan Gaspart will understand the aphorism more than most. The director of Spanish hotel chain HUSA - as in "pretty boy, then" - was elected president of FC Barcelona last night, winning 55% of the vote in a turnout of around 45,000 club members. But this morning his club's most popular player was chipping off to join their deadly rivals for a world record fee. It's the sort of stress that has persuaded the Fiver to steer clear of executive positions.

Top obsessive Spanish football publication Marca has been running a minute-by-minute update of Luis Figo's transfer to Real Madrid throughout the day on their website (www.marca.es). Alongside such essential nuggets of information as "[new Madrid president] Florentino Perez leaves his offices" and "Luis Figo is now in hospital", Marca have confirmed that Real will pay for the transfer today, and Figo will be unveiled to the press at just about the time you are reading this. The fee is expected to be in the region of £40m, breaking the world transfer record set by Hernan Crespo's move to Lazio only the other week.

So, a couple of months after being the biggest club in the world beyond any doubt, Barca aren't even the biggest in Spain any more. As stocky full-back Sergi put it this afternoon, "I can't imagine what Barcelona will be like without Figo." If there's one bonus for Mr Gaspart, it's that his club is now £40m richer while their rivals (even by Sr Perez's own estimates) are now over £200m in debt. But what will he do with the money? The Fiver isn't certain, but it might suggest that Arsene Wenger doesn't wander too far from his phone in the next few days.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"If Gareth wants a move, then his best chance of getting it is by playing well. But if he can't or won't, then I would have no problem dropping him before the Premiership season begins" - A red-faced John Gregory (angry) lays down the law to a red-faced Gareth Southgate (embarrassed).

CHRISTIAN FAITH

It's the worst kept secret in football! No, not the fact that Alan Curbishley is a KGB sleeper agent primed to go off in the year 2008. Nor the one that Andy Cole is set to replace Alan Titchmarsh when his Ground Force contract runs out next year. Nor even the one about Kelvin Koogan and his little sleep in a lay-by many moons ago no, it's the 'Liverpool want Christian Ziege and there's this clause in his contract, and he wants to play with Didi Hamann, and his wife's allergic to the North East' one, and it seems like something might actually be about to happen.

The Reds have this afternoon tabled a £5.5m bid for the 28-year-old German international, according to reports. Ziege's contractual innovation is believed to allow him to talk to any club that makes an offer of £5m or more. Boro have refused to comment on the offer, which may well mean that they are resigned to losing Ziege, despite previously insisting he would stay. It also means that Bryan Robson will then have to spend another six months pretending he is going to invest in a world-class replacement, only to end up funding a retirement plan or two.

If Ziege does sign for Liverpool, it will take Gerard Houllier's spending during his time in sole charge of the club up to £50m (or the cost of last week's G8 summit, anti-capitalist fans). It would also mean the old heave-ho for Dominic Matteo, who had looked like keeping his left-back berth by stealth. Any deal is unlikely to be completed before Liverpool and Gerard Houllier return from their pre-season training camp in Switzerland. By that time, of course, Matteo will probably have taken up his role as the new Speaker of the House. Or so we've heard anyway.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Bordeaux are resigned to losing Sylvain Wiltord - and might offload him to Arsenal in a swap deal for Kanu, according to Planet Football. But Internazionale are also interested in the French striker, and could offer Ivan Zamorano as a makeweight to tempt Bordeaux.

According to the Mirror, Internazionale are eyeing a £30m double swoop for Coventry's Robbie Keane and ex-Villa man Savo Milosevic.

Aston Villa are considering a move for unsettled Rangers defender Lorenzo Amoruso.

AC Milan have made Real Madrid midfielder Fernando Redondo their number one target, according to Planet Football. They say the 31 year-old Argentinean is "reportedly valued at a cut-price £10m".

NEWS IN BRIEF

Chelsea defender Celestine Babayaro has accepted undisclosed libel damages and a public apology from the Daily Star after the headline "Babayaro Rape Case" appeared on the newspaper's internet site last year. The defender was facing much lesser charges, of which he was acquitted, and the paper has now apologised for any distress, anxiety and embarrassment caused.

Manchester City could be without Shaun Goater for the first month of the season after he injured his knee during Saturday's 4-0 win over Linfield.

Paul Gascoigne is set to make his Everton debut tomorrow night in Maurice Malpas's testimonial at Dundee United.

Burnley have signed midfielder Kevin Ball from Fulham on a two-year contract.

The draw for the first round of the Worthington Cup is as follows: Mansfield v Wrexham; Bolton v Macclesfield; Wigan v Scunthorpe; Oldham v Huddersfield; Tranmere v Halifax; Port Vale v Chesterfield; Stockport v Blackpool; Shrewsbury v Preston; Rochdale v Blackburn; Sheff Utd v Lincoln; Crewe v Bury; York v Stoke; Hull v Notts County; Darlington v Nottingham Forest; Burnley v Hartlepool; Grimsby v Carlisle; Rotherham v Barnsley; Watford v Cheltenham; Luton v Peterborough; Gillingham v Torquay; Barnet v Wycombe; Colchester v QPR; Northampton v Fulham; Wolves v Oxford; Crystal Palace v Cardiff; Swansea v West Brom; Brighton v Millwall; Norwich v Bournemouth; Leyton Orient v Reading; Southend v Birmingham; Cambridge v Portsmouth; Bristol City v Brentford; Walsall v Kidderminster; Plymouth v Bristol Rovers; Swindon v Exeter. The first legs are to be played week commencing August 21 and the second legs are to be played week commencing September 4.

Ronaldo, currently recovering from a knee operation, has said that a loan move to Brazilian club Flamengo may be the best way for him to rediscover his full fitness. "The loan idea is something to be looked into," said Ronaldo. "If I make my return in Italy where the tension is high, I am sure that after the first applause, the first seconds, Ronaldo will be like all the others. The game is hard in Italy, they will challenge hard, without holding back."

Controversial administrator Charlie Dempsey is to be replaced as Oceania's representative on the Fifa executive by Fiji's Sahu Khan.

Tony Yeboah, facing tax evasion charges in court next month, has agreed on a settlement in which he will pay German authorities 400,000 marks. The former Leeds striker, who plays for Hamburg SV, allegedly failed to pay tax on 2.3m marks he received after extending his contract with Eintracht Frankfurt in 1993.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Beach Soccer (9pm, 12midnight)
Watch some fat old sportsmen accidentally stand on jellyfish, broken glass, turds, etc.

International Football (1.30am)
The official film of the 1954 World Cup, lovingly restored from the original Zoetrope drawings.

Sky Sports 2: World Football Show (6.30pm, 10.15pm SS1, 1am SS1)
The earth: it's not round, it's rounder. As Louis van Gaal might say.

The European under-18 final: it's not dull, it's duller.

fields.headline: Yahoo! enters international legal minefield
fields.standfirst: A French court is considering whether ISPs should carry the can for offensive material on the net. Not before time, argues David Hearst in Paris
fields.trailText: 24 July, 12.45pm: A French court is considering whether ISPs should carry the can for offensive material on the net. Not before time, argues David Hearst in Paris.
fields.body:
It is being seen as a fight between David and Goliath. Two French anti-racist groups, the Union of Jewish students and the International League Against Racism and Anti-Semitism have today got Yahoo!, one of the world's leading internet service providers, before a French judge.

The issue is whether the California-based web portal is going to comply with a court judgment made two months ago in Paris, barring French internet users from access to a US site which auctions Nazi memorabilia. That a site selling bayonets, medals and even canisters purportedly used in the gas chambers, is offensive is beyond question in California and in France.

The problem for international internet lawyers is that the auction site is legal in the US under the first amendment, which guarantees freedom of speech, and illegal in France under a section of the penal code which prohibits the sale of goods inciting violence or racism.

American case law is quite clear: The US supreme court ruled in May this year that internet service providers (ISPs) have full protection against libellous or abusive messages over the web. It upheld a ruling against former boy scout Alexander Lunney, who sued the ISP Prodigy after an imposter used his name to send threatening messages to his neighbours in Westchester county.

This ruling, and the quashing of a conviction by a German court of a former head of CompuServe in Germany who had been given a suspended sentence for aiding the spread of child pornography, caused some relief to a worried dot.com industry about the international liability that it faced.

The supreme court and the Bavarian ruling judged that an ISP was as responsible for the material it carried as a telecom company was for an abusive call. ISPs were carriers, not purveyors.

Besides, the technical specialists argued, even if an ISP were held responsible for the active internet links that it has on its page, it is virtually impossible to bar access to it. All Yahoo! sees is an address, and virtually anyone can set up a proxy. There is no way to map an incoming connection.

There is also an argument of principle. Yahoo! France, the French subsidiary of the US site, has banned access to the Nazi auction site in line with the court ruling in Paris two months ago. Why should a US site in the English language, which it is argued is not specifically targetted at French, Italian or German users, have to comply with French, Italian or German law? Because, the French court argued, it is available in France.

Here is the real international legal minefield opened up by this case. Unlike previous cases which pitted a German court versus CompuServe in Germany, this case is holding a US website responsible for material under French law, which it advertises in the global market. If a company based in Santa Barbara can be fined by a French court - the figure it could be liable for is more than £100,000 a day - what liability does a British internet bank have for complying with banking laws of any other country round the world?

Do global markets require global laws ? The American Bar Association spent two years trying to disentangle the legal implications of internet services and came up with a set of vague recommendations.

A meeting of international internet lawyers in London this month recommended the creation of a global standards commission with jurisdiction over cyberspace. Yahoo!'s general counsel, John Place, told the meeting: "The biggest impediment to the development of international e-commerce is the rapid increase in the efforts by countries to regulate outside their borders."

But are the issues raised by the worldwide web really so new? They are reminiscent of the fears that satellite television would disseminate pornographic material which would not be subject to the laws of countries targetted by the signals's multinational footprint. In the end, satellite feeds and their cable distributers were deemed to be as vulnerable to the laws of the land in which they operate in, as are all other programmes.

There is all the difference in being able to hunt out the knowledge you need to make a bomb on unofficial websites, and actually being offered the information on a link on an official page. If the idea of an international commission is dead in the water, then the major ISPs have to clean up their act. If not, what chance for the rest?

This is all about what the majority will tolerate. Extremists will always exist on the sidelines, but a line has to be drawn, and a court in Paris is a good place to start.
