All Yahoo! sees is an address, and virtually anyone can set up a proxy. There is no way to map an incoming connection. There is also an argument of principle. Yahoo! France, the French subsidiary of the US site, has banned access to the Nazi auction site in line with the court ruling in Paris two months ago. Why should a US site in the English language, which it is argued is not specifically targetted at French, Italian or German users, have to comply with French, Italian or German law? Because, the French court argued, it is available in France. Here is the real international legal minefield opened up by this case. Unlike previous cases which pitted a German court versus CompuServe in Germany, this case is holding a US website responsible for material under French law, which it advertises in the global market. If a company based in Santa Barbara can be fined by a French court - the figure it could be liable for is more than £100,000 a day - what liability does a British internet bank have for complying with banking laws of any other country round the world? Do global markets require global laws ? The American Bar Association spent two years trying to disentangle the legal implications of internet services and came up with a set of vague recommendations. A meeting of international internet lawyers in London this month recommended the creation of a global standards commission with jurisdiction over cyberspace. Yahoo!'s general counsel, John Place, told the meeting: "The biggest impediment to the development of international e-commerce is the rapid increase in the efforts by countries to regulate outside their borders." But are the issues raised by the worldwide web really so new? They are reminiscent of the fears that satellite television would disseminate pornographic material which would not be subject to the laws of countries targetted by the signals's multinational footprint. In the end, satellite feeds and their cable distributers were deemed to be as vulnerable to the laws of the land in which they operate in, as are all other programmes. There is all the difference in being able to hunt out the knowledge you need to make a bomb on unofficial websites, and actually being offered the information on a link on an official page. If the idea of an international commission is dead in the water, then the major ISPs have to clean up their act. If not, what chance for the rest? This is all about what the majority will tolerate. Extremists will always exist on the sidelines, but a line has to be drawn, and a court in Paris is a good place to start.

webTitle: Michael Stone: From prisoner to politician?

fields.headline: From prisoner to politician?
fields.standfirst:
Michael Stone is the first high-profile prisoner to be released from Maze prison. The question is, what will he do now? asks Northern Ireland writer John O'Farrell
Audio report from John Mullin
fields.trailText: Michael Stone is the first high-profile prisoner to be released from Maze prison. The question is, what will he do now? asks Northern Ireland writer John O'Farrell.
fields.body:
Today saw the release of the most formidable loyalist icon of the troubles. Michael Stone shot his way to fame in 1988 when he made a lone assault on an IRA funeral, killing three mourners with a handgun and grenades.

He was due to remain in prison until 2007 for the three he murdered at Milltown cemetery, and three other sectarian killings, but he has instead become the first high-profile prisoner to be freed this week from the Maze prison - the high-security gaol housing some of the most notorious terrorists thrown up by the Troubles - under the terms agreed on Good Friday 1998.

By the end of this week, another 80 prisoners will be freed early. 16 others sentenced for various scheduled offences less than two years ago will be transferred to nearby Magaberry prison, to be released before October.

Stone will emerge from the car park of the Maze - or Long Kesh as it is known to its remaining and former inmates - into a world where everything has changed.

Stone's appearance - in particular his greying Mullet hairdo - reflects the cruel certainties of the late 1980s, when he achieved worldwide fame for the attack on the funeral of three IRA members killed by the SAS in Gibraltar. His intended targets were Sinn Fein members Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness - two men whose positions have altered dramatically over the past decade.

These days, Mr Adams is treated as a world statesman in the salons of the great and the powerful, from the White House to Whitehall. Mr McGuinness is the minister of education in the power-sharing executive in Stormont.

In contrast, the world inhabited by Stone since 1988 has been the Maze prison, eight grey H-blocks separated by grey corrugated iron, surrounded by a 12ft grey wall. Aside from grey, the only colour to be seen is the red doors on the cells, open 24-hours a day since 1994, or the lurid murals inside the segregated wings which the prisoners run as little fiefdoms.

A few months ago, the International Red Cross successfully forced the replacment of the corrugated iron around each of the eight H-blocks with wire fencing. They were concerned about the eyesight of prisoners who never saw anything beyond 50 feet as they looked from their cells. Now, traces of greenery are visable, the tops of trees just over the walls.

Another perceptual problem faced by released prisoners is the sight of buildings over one floor, but somehow they cope.

Help is at hand. The EU is paying for programmes run by ex-prisoners to help them integrate back into society. These projects are run by ex-prisoners themselves on their own terms. For example, they do not use terms like rehabilitate, as such terminology is for "common criminals". Republicans and loyalists see themselves as "politically motivated" or "prisoners of war". 10 IRA prisoners died on hunger strike to achieve political status in the early eighties. The preferred slogan of loyalist prisoners is "our only crime is loyalty", a term coined in the sixties by Gusty Spence.

Spence was found guilty of killing a catholic barman in 1966, the first sectarian killing of the Troubles. He now owns a pub in Groomsport, along the "gold coast" of North Co Down.

Stone is rumoured to have had a home bought for him in Groomsport. It is unclear if he will get involved in politics, although he might prove a vote winner among a certain constituency. The political front of the Ulster Freedom Fighters, the Ulster Democratic Party, would have mixed feelings. Just before the referendum on the Good Friday Agreement, a UDP rally was upstaged when Stone arrived while on temporary leave. The Ulster Hall went into raptures, but "middle unionism", which is embarrassed or ambivalent about the slaughter carried out in the name of the Union by people like Stone, was revolted by the sight. More pro-Agreement votes were lost than gained by the Ulster Hall shenanigans.

Stone sees himself as a political thinker, his cell bookcase groaning with Marxist classics. Whether his peculiar charisma will be seen on the new political stage of post-conflict Ulster is a question that is giving some unionists nightmares.

fields.headline: Six found dead in Wales
fields.trailText: Police have confirmed that six bodies were found in a family home in Barry, south Wales. It appears that the father may have killed his own wife and children before taking his own life.
fields.body:
Police have confirmed that six bodies were found in a family home in Barry, south Wales. It appears that the father may have killed his own wife and children before taking his own life.

Robert Mochrie, 49, his wife Catherine, 45, and their children Bethan, 10, Luke, 14, Sian, 16, and James, 18, were found dead at 8.30pm yesterday. The motive behind the killings remains unclear.

Mr Mochrie was found hanging from the landing of the five-bedroom home in Rutland Close at 8.30pm yesterday. The other five were discovered with injuries consistent with being struck with a blunt instrument, in the upstairs bedrooms.

A friend of Mrs Mochrie contacted police because she had seen nothing of them for a long time. Police confirmed that that the family had not been seen for 10 to 11 days and that the bodies had been in the house for a considerable period of time.

Mr Mochrie was a former civil servant, who left the profession five years ago. He owned several licensed properties in the area. Neighbours described them as being "just a normal family".

Detective Superintendent Kevin O'Neill said that officers would be continuing examinations of the house over the next two days.

"The investigations into this tragic incident are ongoing but we are not looking for any other persons in connection with the incident at this time," he said.

Superintendent Colin Jones said the scene inside the house was particularly distressing for his officers and he would be offering counselling. "Our feelings are those of utter disbelief. It defies logic. It is not very often that you come across a house where there are six bodies," he said.

Police are now appealing for anyone who has been in the area during this time or who has any other information to contact them.

webTitle: No deal yet on Jerusalem as peace talks resume

fields.headline: No deal yet on Jerusalem as peace talks resume
fields.trailText: Plunging into talks immediately upon returning to Camp David, the US president, Bill Clinton, today held back-to-back meetings with the Middle East leaders and was conferring with his own team. Both sides were pressing their competing claims to Jerusalem.
fields.body:
Plunging into talks immediately upon returning to Camp David, the US president, Bill Clinton, today held back-to-back meetings with the Middle East leaders and was conferring with his own team. Both sides were pressing their competing claims to Jerusalem.

President Clinton arrived back at the presidential retreat yesterday evening after a four-day trip to Japan for the G8 economic summit. He held separate talks with the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, then headed into a mid-morning meeting with his negotiators, a White House spokesman said.

As the contentious talks entered their 14th day, President Clinton was deciding whether it was worthwhile to continue the quest for an elusive peace deal. "A lot depends on his meetings and how he wants to move forward," said state department spokesman Richard Boucher.

The Israelis concurred that the talks were at a critical juncture. Senior negotiator Shlomo Ben-Ami told Israel's army radio today that "the outcome ... will become finally or almost finally clear during the next two days."

The main point of dispute remained Jerusalem, the holy city claimed by both Israel and the Palestinians as a capital. Israeli hardliners cautioned Mr Barak against deviating from Israel's pledge that the city will never be divided. "No prime minister has the right to make concessions over Jerusalem," opposition politician Ariel Sharon told Israel radio. "Jerusalem is the birthright of the Jewish people."

On the Palestinian side, senior aide Tayib Abdel Rahim said that Mr Arafat stood ready to provide all faiths with access to Jerusalem's holy sites - as long as that was part of a sovereignty pact. "The solution is very simple - give full sovereignty of east Jerusalem to a Palestinian state," Mr Abdel Rahim said. "We are ready to have Jerusalem as an open city for all religions."

On the explosive question of Jerusalem, Mr Arafat must answer not only to his own people, but also to other Arab and Muslim leaders.

After the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, travelled to Saudi Arabia yesterday for talks with King Fahd, Saudi officials said that the two leaders were anxious to ensure that at least part of Jerusalem would come under Palestinian sovereignty. President Mubarak was also expected to talk in coming days with Syria's new president, Bashar Assad, and King Abdullah II of Jordan.

fields.headline: Games with a political pawn
fields.standfirst: Pressure put on Jack Straw's son reflects poorly on the Sunday Times, says  Roy Greenslade
fields.trailText: Pressure put on Jack Straw's son reflects poorly on the Sunday Times, says Roy Greenslade
fields.body:
Let me start by making it clear that I don't have a vendetta against the Sunday Times. I am not, as one of their reporters claimed, "waging war" on their stories. Nor do I have a political agenda. As I stated in my article in last week's Media Guardian ("Mind the credibility gap"), I have received more complaints about that paper's newsroom activities than any other.

The paper's notoriety may well stem from its willingness to take risks, chasing hard-edged stories that embarrass the government and which are justifiable as being in the public interest.

A further example of the Sunday Times's methods - and its mindset - has since come to light, which surely undermines its claim to the moral high ground. At the end of last month, as he was worrying over the results of his crucial first-year exams, the home secretary's son, Will Straw, found a letter in his pigeonhole at New College, Oxford.

Intrigued by the Sunday Times-headed notepaper, he was amazed, and then shocked, by what he read in the five handwritten (and misspelled) pages, signed by one of the paper's reporters, Adam Nathan.

It suggested that Will Straw had "prepared" a letter that was critical of chancellor Gordon Brown's controversial Laura Spence speech about Oxford's alleged elitism. He had been intending to send it to the Times, but his hand was stayed, Nathan alleged, because of "very strong pressure" from Tony Blair's press secretary, Alastair Campbell.

Nathan then outlined three "options" for Straw to consider. First, he could "speak to me freely", but this was unlikely, as it might mean "going back on your assurances".

Second, he could deny the letter's existence, but that wasn't a good idea "as it would enteil [sic] lying". Third, he could confirm he had written the letter with "a simple 'yes' ", which, Nathan advised, "is your most advisable course of action".

Straw says: "Quite apart from every allegation being untrue, it was a most unpleasant and aggressive letter to receive. I couldn't believe what I was reading." This is understandable, since it was totally false. Straw immediately contacted Campbell, who fired off a fierce letter to Nathan, condemning him for putting the teenager under pressure and also suggesting that he had been defamed by Nathan.

Yet Nathan is far from cowed by that criticism and can't see why there should be a fuss. "I think it was a fair letter. On reflection, I suppose it could be said to have exerted a little bit of pressure on him, though it was far from threatening.

"I was just checking a story and he should have called me. Instead of choosing [from] my options, he went back through the Downing Street machine, which is ironic because, essentially, that was what my piece was about, news management."

In other words, Nathan was using a 19-year-old student, who just happens to be the home secretary's son, to try to debunk the prime minister's press secretary.

Should a politician's son be used as a pawn for a newspaper to make political capital? Do we really believe that the views of a home secretary's son - whether in favour of Brown or against him - are of such public interest that they merit this effort by a leading national newspaper?

It is hardly surprising that Straw took up his grievance with Downing Street. A couple of years ago, Will Straw suffered from a welter of publicity when a Mirror journalist induced him to buy drugs. No wonder he is wary of the press.

I have to say that Nathan isn't generally regarded as a bad lad. His tutor at the London College of Printing, Chris Horrie, thought him "one of the best reporters" he had taught. But Nathan is far from experienced. After leaving college, he worked briefly in television, and his contract position at the Sunday Times is his first in newspaper journalism. He is full of energy and ideas and known for his determination.

Doesn't this episode suggest that what he needs, apart from a sense of proportion, is guidance, training (and a dictionary)? It shows once again that the Sunday Times is too reliant on junior reporters who feel under pressure to come up with stories they believe fit the paper's political agenda.

But Sunday Times managing editor Richard Caseby says: "It's pretty bizarre to criticise the paper, or one of its reporters, for checking out a story which wasn't published."

One last, baffling point: why did Nathan feel so confident about his story? In his letter to Straw he claimed that his source was "a senior government official who dissaproved [sic] of Mr Campbell's actions."

Yet he told me: "I can't tell you exactly where I got it, but I can say that it came from personal contacts at a social occasion." The former must be untrue, because Straw hadn't written a letter, so there had not been any Campbell "actions". The latter, which is more likely, suggests it stemmed from a piece of party gossip. Some source, eh?

 Roy Greenslade was a senior executive on the Sunday Times from 1986 to 1989

webTitle: National Magazines's acquisition of G+J creates an odd marriage

fields.headline: Dawn raid in magland
fields.standfirst: Just as National Magazines looked set to focus on the posh end of its output, it snapped up G+J, securing a bunch of less swanky titles in the process.  Jessica Hodgson  reports
fields.trailText: Just as National Magazines looked set to focus on the posh end of its output, it snapped up G+J, securing a bunch of less swanky titles in the process. Jessica Hodgson reports
fields.body:
Even by the frenzied standards of current media consolidation, the National Magazine Company's dawn raid on Gruner and Jahr (G+J), which was snatched from under the nose of IPC, seems to create an odd marriage.

NatMags, always second fiddle to Condé Nast in the silver spoon stakes, was busy positioning itself to fight a war for posh hearts and minds. G+J, a German company part-owned by media conglomerate Bertelsmann, launched in the UK in 1986, and has carved a niche in the lower-end "tea-break" market. Its top two titles, Prima and Best, are targeted primarily at women with children.

Just weeks ago, NatMags announced plans to concentrate its more upmarket titles - Esquire, Harpers & Queen and Country Living - in a dedicated business division and has been bullish in claiming it can now take on Condé Nast on its own terms. The G+J purchase - understood to have cost NatMags £43m - seems particularly odd in the light of this development. One wag at IPC wondered whether NatMags "would have the front to create a business unit called Downmarket Magazines" to sit alongside its Affluent Magazines division.

The jewel in G+J's crown is Prima, a broadly focused, popular magazine aimed at women aged 25 and over. Despite a 17.4% fall in sales in the last ABCs, Prima's cocktail of home help, true life stories and some general interest - notably an exclusive interview with Tony Blair - means it's still shifting 413,000 a month. NatMags also buys Best, which sells 462,000 a week, Your Home, parenting magazine Prima Baby and science and technology title Focus. Some 180 staff will transfer to NatMags.

NatMags' deputy managing director, Duncan Edwards, shrugs off widespread surprise at the move. "We have had talks with G+J in the past but they never really got beyond the conversation stage," he says. "But G+J's decision to pull out of the UK market meant a business of some scale had become available. It also offers us, with Best, an opportunity to get into the women's weekly sector."

For G+J, the UK market was always a sideline. Despite the fact that Prima and Best have had consistently high sales, the company still only held a market share of 3% and its UK managing director, Holger Wiemann, says it now wants to focus on the US. When it became clear that G+J was to pull out of the UK, IPC put out feelers. Though IPC has not commented officially, insiders say the company was chiefly attracted to G+J because of Prima and the need to consolidate its hold over the women's and home interest sectors. But after the deal with IPC was soured by a high-profile wrangle between G+J and Tesco over distribution, NatMags stepped in with a better offer that IPC was not prepared to match.

Britain's largest supermarket is pushing magazine publishers to move from existing distribution networks into a single deal with WH Smith's wholesale department, and is alleged to have threatened to drop Prima Baby, Your Home and Focus if the publisher did not do as it was told.

Tesco denies adopting such "bully boy" tactics. But corporate affairs manager, David Sawday, confirms that the supermarket has been pressuring magazine publishers to overhaul distribution relationships that, he claims, are based on a creaky infrastructure dating back more than 100 years. Tesco has warned certain publishers that, if they do not play ball, the chain will "reassess the magazine brands we carry". IPC - weighing up the value of G+J - felt that renegotiating a raft of distribution contracts with a disgruntled Tesco was more trouble than it was worth.

NatMags' Edwards is unworried by the situation with Tesco, saying he's confident that their contract will be honoured. But many in the industry feel the retailer would not have been able to strong-arm a larger pub lishing house in the same way. The Periodical Publishers' Association is threatening to report Tesco to the office of fair trading, accusing the retailer of anti-competitive behaviour, and publishers are planning to go on the offensive. But the dispute shows the increasing power of the supermarkets in magazine marketing and sales, and highlights publishers' absolute need for size.

NatMags says it is too early to give a clear strategic outline for the future of G+J. Edwards stresses that the company is "in the business of building magazines, not closing them down". webTitle: Roy Greenslade on the case of the News of the World journalist and the police officer

fields.headline: Too close for comfort?
fields.standfirst: A News of the World journalist and a police officer have been cleared of having a corrupt relationship, after sharing information.  Roy Greenslade  claims the case shows a police force keen to stifle the public's right to know
fields.trailText: A News of the World journalist and a police officer have been cleared of having a corrupt relationship, after sharing information. Roy Greenslade claims the case shows a police force keen to stifle the public's right to know
fields.body:
No expense was spared to nail the suspect. Seven policemen raided his home at dawn to arrest him. After he was released on bail, pending trial, the police kept him under surveillance in an operation codenamed Guatemala. For two years, he was followed through London, into hotels and on the underground. His phone was bugged. His pager was cloned. A watch was put on his bank accounts.

So what did this man do to merit a cloak-and-dagger operation estimated to have cost close to £1m? Dealt in heroin? Planted a bomb? Hacked into Downing Street's main-frame computer? None of these. He had, wait for it, "shared information" with a policeman.

Last week, in a judgment of stunning clarity and with far-reaching implications, Neville Thurlbeck, the News of the World's chief crime reporter, was finally cleared - in the most emphatic terms - of any wrongdoing.

He and his alleged accomplice, Detective Constable Dick Farmer, stepped from the dock of Luton crown court after the judge halted a case which, frankly, had descended into farce.

Thurlbeck and Farmer had been charged under the 1906 Corruption Act, facing up to three years in jail if found guilty. It was claimed that they had a corrupt relationship because Thurlbeck had paid Farmer for supplying him with confidential information. Both men vehemently denied this claim and the prosecution was unable to produce a jot of evidence to show that any money had changed hands between them.

Both men have cheerfully admitted having a close friendship from which they mutually benefited, as the NoW did with various police forces. Sometimes Thurlbeck provided Farmer with information useful to the police. Sometimes Farmer, a member of the National Crime Intelligence Service (NCIS), gave Thurlbeck information he required.

Crucially, the judge ruled that what Farmer told Thurlbeck was "not confidential or sensitive... but information principally about criminals' previous convictions". Mr Justice McKinnon considered their relationship to be "perfectly legitimate and appropriate", adding: "There is no suggestion supported by any evidence that Mr Farmer in any way behaved improperly in conducting the Police National Computer checks."

During the case, which could not be reported while it was in progress because of legal restrictions, the court was told that Farmer made scores of computer checks on people's criminal records for Thurlbeck. Prosecuting counsel Stephen Kramer QC cited 36 stories published by the News of the World which were said to have contained information supplied by Farmer.

These included a case of an unnamed Labour MP with a conviction for committing an obscene act; an alleged threat to the Queen from stalkers; a priest previously convicted of sex offences; and a sex offender who raped a child shortly after being released from jail.

But it wasn't one-way traffic. One instance cited by Thurlbeck concerns the case of a drug-dealer who he discovered had been supplying PCP, nicknamed angel dust. With his help police were able to arrest the man who was later sentenced to five years.

Perhaps the turning point in the trial came when another News of the World story was mentioned in which Thurlbeck had received information from Farmer about a taxi driver who had previously been convicted of rape. The paper warned readers in its headline to beware of getting in his cab, and six months later the man was found guilty of murdering a passenger.

When it was suggested to a police witness by Thurlbeck's counsel, Roy Amlot QC, that such a story must surely be in the public interest, he replied: "No." There was an audible groan from the jury.

As for the allegation of money changing hands, the prosecution depended on "unexplained cash deposits" to Farmer's wife's bank account in 1996. First, this pre-dated the allegations of the conspiracy and second, the police never attempted to discover why that money was paid in. I understand that these relatively small sums were in fact earned by Mrs Farmer, a cookery teacher, while she was working occasionally as a pastry chef.

With the police unable to show that any money had changed hands, the judge commented: "I am entirely clear that there is no evidence whatever against Mr Thurlbeck that he made any payments to Mr Farmer." As Thurlbeck says: "The only currency which flowed freely between Dick and myself was information."

All in all, the outcome of the trial after a two-year wait, and with Farmer suspended on full pay throughout that time, has been a devastating indictment of the police's decision to prosecute.

So what are we to make of this odd saga? Despite the waste of public money and the distress suffered by Thurlbeck and Farmer (whose future remains in doubt), the case isn't without its merits.

First, the judgment that what police hold on their computers about people's convictions isn't confidential is an eye-opener. Like many journalists, I have become so imbued with the culture of secrecy in our society that I, too, presumed it was secret.

Second, by highlighting the Farmer-Thurlbeck relationship, it illustrates the reality of police-press relationships. Too many people are willing to believe that there is always a money nexus. In fact, payments by reporters to policemen are incredibly rare.

Third, the fact that police decided to arrest and charge the pair shows the level of hypocrisy that exists in many forces. In my view, the vast majority of the nation's most senior policemen, at chief constable level, wish to promote better relations with the press. On the ground, among the ranks, friendships between officers and reporters are common. Most of the hostility towards journalists arises from the middle ranks, among sergeants and inspectors who jealousy guard their information, hiding behind professional PRs who provide almost no information.

When the front door is shut, it isn't surprising that enterprising reporters such as Thurlbeck will test whether the back door is locked. If they find a friendly face of welcome, especially if they are willing to offer help, so much the better.

The sad truth is that many police forces, which have long had a history of refusing to disclose all sorts of matters that the public have a right to to know, are now hiding behind the data protection act to prevent even more information from getting into the public domain.

In such circumstances, crime reporters who have always depended on forming personal relationships to get information are bound to redouble their efforts to beat official bans.

What we need is clear guidance on what should and shouldn't be freely available, and then the machinery to ensure we get it. At the moment, the system forces hole-in-the-corner deals.

As Phil Hall, the former News of the World editor who championed Thurlbeck's case, says: "I feel that not only has Neville has been vindicated, but so has the cause of investigative journalism."

Thurlbeck, 38, certainly hasn't suffered at his paper. New editor Rebekah Wade has promoted him to deputy head of a new investigations department. It will be a scandal if Farmer becomes the scapegoat for his bosses' mistaken prosecution.

webTitle: David Hencke looks at the surreal world of political leaks

fields.headline: A little mole told me - honest
fields.standfirst: Those men feeding the ducks, one with a notebook, the other with a P45, are probably talking government secrets. After a damaging couple of weeks for Tony Blair,  David Hencke  looks at the surreal world of the leaker
fields.trailText: Those men feeding the ducks, one with a notebook, the other with a P45, are probably talking government secrets. After a damaging couple of weeks for Tony Blair, David Hencke looks at the surreal world of the leaker
fields.body:
It was 10 minutes before lunch in the sweaty, airless Guardian office in the parliamentary press gallery when the telephone rang. "Can you come over to my office? I have a piece of paper which I think you would find very interesting," said the caller.

When I arrived, I was handed four sheets of photocopied paper headed "Confidential Memorandum by the Comptroller and Auditor General". The succinct Whitehall document became known as the "Rover sweeteners" - the disclosure that British Aerospace had been given £38m hidden aid to take the ailing car company off the government's hands. The information had been withheld from the sale statement to parliament - and led, years later, to BAe being ordered by the European court to pay back the cash, with interest.

The disclosure was expensive for ministers. It both exposed them as double-dealers and forced the return of taxpayers' cash. It also led to a ferocious inquiry into the leak - and the Guardian's then editor Peter Preston and I were dragged before the powerful Commons privileges and standards committee, for breaking parliament's rules.

But the leaker was never unmasked. Now, 11 years later, the person has been promoted to higher things in Whitehall and Westminster. Fortunately for others, the person has never again (to my knowledge) leaked such damaging information. But like last week's highly damaging leaks of Tony Blair's and Philip Gould's memos on spin, the timing was impeccable. It came the day after parliament had published a critical national audit office report showing that Rover had been sold "on the cheap". The leaker looked at that morning's papers. "I was going to give the document to the Independent but I saw the Guardian gave better coverage, so I contacted you," the person said.

As a leaker, the person may not have been atypical but the motives were - nearly all really damaging leaks come because the person involved is angered by hypocrisy or by what they see as a serious "cover up". They are almost always looking for an outlet where the issue will be treated seriously - and only then are they prepared to take a risk that could wreck their career or public standing.

Occasionally the leak could be motivated by more deadly sins, such as malice, envy, or (if money was involved) greed and sometimes sexual jealousy - but most of these types of story come from low-life lobby gossipmongers around parliament, not from highly placed sources. (One gay Tory MP was once shopped to the News of the World for having an affair with a young civil servant, simply because his less handsome partner was furious that the MP had taken his mate rather than him on a Caribbean holiday).

The serious leakers fall into two categories. They are the "once in the lifetime" person and the "serial leaker". Occasionally an issue arises that leads a mole to become a personal contact of a journalist for a period, and then when the issue is resolved the source dries up.

The atmosphere in Whitehall and parliament also either facilitates or deters leakers. When Whitehall was under fire from the Tories with the prospect of huge job losses, the number of leaks rose correspondingly. Indeed at one stage the threat of large-scale redundancies and privatisation of the property services agency led to almost systematic leaking of ministerial letters designed to embarrass junior ministers John Redwood and Christopher Chope, and undermine their positions. Correspondingly Tony Blair's first two years in office - and the end of threats to many Whitehall jobs - led to a decline in leakers from contented Whitehall mandarins. The trouble Blair is currently in almost certainly coincides with disillusionment in Whitehall at the lack of change.

Once a journalist has a leaker, the two biggest issues are the protection of the source and ensuring the veracity of their information. In the first instance - the Rover sweeteners story - it was instantly clear that the document was genuine and, as the source was known to me, it was easy to establish whether the person would have had access to such information.

Other leaks are not so easy to verify but, despite the popular myth, "brown envelope" journalism is rare. Information is hardly ever sent to people "on spec". Most of it is suggested by known sources, making it easier to check where it has come from and examine the motives behind the leak.

Once the source can be trusted, protection is everything. Sources are not there to be used and abused, then discarded once the tale has gone cold. They have to be cherished. There also has to be discretion: venues for meetings have to be chosen and the information released. This doesn't mean that every meeting has to be a Watergate-style tryst in the local underground car park. But it does mean that there has to be some imagination: it's not too clever to meet Home Office moles in a pub opposite their Queen Anne's Gate office. Better to bump into someone while feeding the ducks in St James's Park, or meet at a working-class cafe or pub a long way from Westminster. Even a crowded railway station, where everyone is rushing to catch a train, can be a good cover for an illicit encounter.

Even better is to have a network of moles: one of the most scary things for putative leakers is that they alone are the source and their career will collapse if they are found out. They feel much more confident if they are supplying only part of the picture. Then when they see the story, they can say truthfully that they have not leaked everything. It is amazing how much better that makes them feel, and how much more information they are then prepared to leak. The detail about the dubious lobbying tactics of the now defunct Ian Greer Associates came not from one person but some dozen people, many of them unknown to each other and of varying political views. It is rarely the work of one "Mr Big".

What should also not be under-estimated is the "excitement" factor in the leaking process. Not everybody wants a bit-part in a John le Carré novel, but there is a certain thrill in finding out what is really happening in Whitehall and this can rub off from the journalist to the leaker.

One of the Guardian's award-winning lead stories was leaked by a very senior person in the heart of government, who has been ennobled by Tony Blair. The only thing is that he does not know that he is the source of the Guardian story. All he did was talk to one of my top Whitehall contacts and give the person highly confidential information. The person involved needed to find out the information anyway but was so trusted by me that he moved from leaker to investigative reporter. The name of either party - or even which story it was - can never be revealed, or it would blow apart how to get into the centre of government without ever being detected.

Even a crowded railway station, where everyone is rushing to catch a train, can be a good cover for an illicit encounter. Even better is to have a network of moles: one of the most scary things for putative leakers is that they alone are the source and their career will collapse if they are found out. They feel much more confident if they are supplying only part of the picture. Then when they see the story, they can say truthfully that they have not leaked everything. It is amazing how much better that makes them feel, and how much more information they are then prepared to leak. The detail about the dubious lobbying tactics of the now defunct Ian Greer Associates came not from one person but some dozen people, many of them unknown to each other and of varying political views. It is rarely the work of one "Mr Big". What should also not be under-estimated is the "excitement" factor in the leaking process. Not everybody wants a bit-part in a John le Carré novel, but there is a certain thrill in finding out what is really happening in Whitehall and this can rub off from the journalist to the leaker. One of the Guardian's award-winning lead stories was leaked by a very senior person in the heart of government, who has been ennobled by Tony Blair. The only thing is that he does not know that he is the source of the Guardian story. All he did was talk to one of my top Whitehall contacts and give the person highly confidential information. The person involved needed to find out the information anyway but was so trusted by me that he moved from leaker to investigative reporter. The name of either party - or even which story it was - can never be revealed, or it would blow apart how to get into the centre of government without ever being detected.

fields.headline: My big break: Gary Younge
fields.trailText: I was a student unionist in Edinburgh, running a rent strike, complete with megaphone, stickers, posters and attitude, which Donald MacLeod, the then education correspondent of the Scotsman, came to cover. We chatted, I can't remember what about, and I didn't see him again for about seven years when he popped up at the Guardian. But in the meantime, and unbeknown to me, he had suggested to Cathy Milton, who was editing the Scotsman's student supplement for the year, that I might be a good person to write for it. Four months later, out of the blue, Cathy called and asked if I had any ideas for the supplement.
fields.body:
I was a student unionist in Edinburgh, running a rent strike, complete with megaphone, stickers, posters and attitude, which Donald MacLeod, the then education correspondent of the Scotsman, came to cover. We chatted, I can't remember what about, and I didn't see him again for about seven years when he popped up at the Guardian. But in the meantime, and unbeknown to me, he had suggested to Cathy Milton, who was editing the Scotsman's student supplement for the year, that I might be a good person to write for it. Four months later, out of the blue, Cathy called and asked if I had any ideas for the supplement.

I had no idea what career I wanted to follow at the time, but it wasn't journalism. Between the ages of 12 and 21 I had at various times wanted to be a doctor, a professional revolutionary and an interpreter. But I had never contemplated writing for a living, and Heriot-Watt University did not have a student newspaper worth talking about, so there was little opportunity to try it even if I had.

On the phone to Cathy, I rattled off a series of pompous polemics. Judging by the long silence at the other end of the line, I decided I was incriminating myself, and promised to write down some ideas and send them. I heard nothing for a couple of months and presumed failure. Then came another unexpected call from Cathy, saying that she liked two of my ideas.

She had chosen the only non- worthy suggestion I had made - a piece about the perils of flatsharing - and another about the first black female sabbatical in Scotland. It was the summer holidays and I worked on the articles all day, every day for a week. When I handed them in I was incredibly nervous and Cathy was incredibly supportive. She could have said nothing and either rewritten or spiked them. But she took me for a coffee and gently explained the difference between an essay and an article; how the most interesting stuff, rather than the most logical, should go at the top, that the style should be simple and the vocabulary accessible. She let me do the rewrites myself. "The most important thing is that you can write," she said. "The other stuff you can learn."

On an hourly rate, I would have done better if I had taken a summer job at Burger King. But the thrill of seeing those two articles in print was priceless.

Over the next couple of years, I kept learning by writing the occasional piece for the Scotsman and reading from a wider range of sources than I had previously done. I still didn't know what I wanted to do when I left university. Then I saw an advert in the Guardian for bursaries to study newspaper journalism at City University, which specifically urged ethnic minority students to apply. That encouraged me because I had always considered journalism a profession so dominated by white middle-class people - which it still is - that it would be virtually impossible to get into, which it wasn't. Even after the Tories had won the 1992 election and the Berlin wall had crumbled, working on a national paper still seemed a more remote possibility than being a revolutionary.

I applied, got an interview and was awarded a bursary. There was no job attached, since its aim was, and still is, to improve diversity in the media in general. But this is where I ended up. Trying to be polemical without being pompous; worthy without being dull.

 Gary Younge is one of the judges of the Guardian Student Media Awards. They also include Alan Rusbridger, Piers Morgan, Jon Snow, James Brown, Mark Thomas and Jeremy Vine. The closing date for applications for the awards is July 28 2000. Call 0808 100 4878 for an application form.

webTitle: TV that's right up your street

fields.headline: TV that's right up your street
fields.standfirst: One in four adults in Oxford tuned in to watch news and local issues debated on their local TV channel every week. So why did the new owners sack most of the staff and start showing cartoons?  Roddy Mansfield  reports
fields.trailText: One in four adults in Oxford tuned in to watch news and local issues debated on their local TV channel every week. So why did the new owners sack most of the staff and start showing cartoons? Roddy Mansfield reports.
fields.body:
On May 4, as most of the country went to the polls to vote in the local council elections, something unique in community television history was taking place in Oxford. It was one of the most exciting local elections the city had witnessed. The Labour party was fast losing control of the city council for the first time in 20 years - and it was losing its leader, too.

As the results poured in from wards across the city in the early hours of the morning, they were flashed live across the screens of those tuned to the Oxford Channel - a local television station which was carrying the news six hours ahead of BBC Radio Oxford and without the regional baggage carried by Newsroom South-East. Oxford's viewers had also been treated to a televised local-election question-time special, in which party leaders had fielded political salvoes from members of their own community.

Mind-rot if you happen to hail from Southport, say, or Skegness; but riveting and relevant if you live and vote in Oxford. For the first time, local viewers were able to gain immediate live access to the political results and analysis that mattered most to them. It was public-service broadcasting at its best; a salad of local democracy, public accountability and viewer participation, tossed and transmitted to an enlightened electorate. It epitomised the raison d' tre of the restrictive service licence (RSL).

Two weeks ago, the Oxford Channel sacked almost all of its 40 production and affiliated staff and gave them minutes to leave the premises. Stunned employees, many of whom had played a pivotal role in the channel's launch and development and had worked tirelessly to create a role for community television, looked on in disbelief as security codes were altered and locks on the doors were changed; many were in tears. Within 24 hours, normal transmission had ceased and a test card was aired, stating that alongside local output, a new schedule of lifestyle features, tele-shopping and international news was to be introduced, offering viewers "a mix of quality programmes from around the world". Viewers who tuned in the next morning hoping to catch up on the burning local issues were instead served a feast of cartoons.

What had happened? Rewind a few days to a crisis board meeting convened by the directors of Oxford Broadcasting, who were pondering the company's financial position. In the 12 months since it had launched, the channel had failed to attract significant interest from local advertisers, sponsors or investors, despite the fact that one in four adults were tuning in at peak time on a weekly basis. Although the station had been run predominantly by unsalaried trainees, the company had accrued losses totalling £500,000; they had simply run out of money. With just 12 minutes to go before the receivers were to be officially called in, control was ceded to the Milestone Group, a private media concern with interests in radio and newspapers, but one that has not previously held any local television broadcasting licences. Within hours, the new managing director proudly introduced himself to his staff and promptly sacked them all.

For outgoing managing director and former social justice campaigner Thomas Harding and his wife Deborah Cackler, it was the end of a bitter struggle to retain control of a very personal project, the details of which had first been scribbled on the back of an envelope.

The channel had been beset by problems from the start. Just two days before the official launch, the key advertising partner pulled out of the project. The directors later ran into hot water with the National Union of Journalists, which had publicly expressed deep concern regarding trainees working 60-hour weeks without pay and the requirement that staff waive their right to claim for unfair dismissal. Also, poor picture reception due to uneven topography in parts of the county meant that some viewers couldn't view at all.

Their problems weren't unique. TV12 on the Isle of Wight was the first RSL to begin broadcasting last June. Chairman Graham Benson, formerly controller of drama and arts at TVS, understands the complex dilemmas and cashflow problems experienced by Harding.

"It's an uphill struggle and you have to run on very, very low overheads indeed. You're competing with local newspapers and radio for advertising and until you've built up a head of steam, which sometimes takes three to four years, it is difficult to get the confidence of the smaller business people," he says.

Benson hints that consolidation may be the only way to secure the future of the RSL community: "I don't think that one station standing alone can survive. We've survived for quite a long time, we'll probably survive for a little bit longer, but our plans are to consolidate and try to acquire other stations and become a series of mini-networks which can do a certain amount of programme exchange. If that all happens then I think that there is a rosy future for local television."

Concerns are also being expressed about the threat posed by the switch-off of the analogue signal and the frenzied dash to digital. At the moment there is no guarantee of a digital future for local television.

"Legislation must be introduced to provide sufficient dedicated spectrum throughout the entire UK, enabling a dense network of over 1,000 local digital TV stations to exist," says Geoff Bush, controller of Herts TV. In a recent submission to the Department of Culture consultation on the communications white paper, he stressed the opportunities that needed to be seized to ensure the successful continuation and development of the RSL network: "Current RSL licences are too short-lived, over-restricted, and suffer from an unreasonably low position in the pecking order for the allocation of broadcast spectrum. The local television opportunity could be missed if appropriate policies are not put in place to ensure that the new television landscape ushered in by the act is not simply a digital replica of that created 50 years ago."

Support has already come from the Independent Television Commission (ITC), which revealed that the RSLs can only survive if they are an integral part of the jigsaw puzzle that is the digital future. In its white paper contribution, the ITC declared that legislation will need to address "the establishment of a digital successor to the analogue RSL system for local TV services", and that "switching off the analogue TV broadcasts will provide a unique opportunity to re-deploy the spectrum they vacate".

Assuming that the digital divide can be bridged, Milestone director Andy Craig maintains that local programming will still form the core of their output: "The Oxford Channel is the real jewel in the crown of local television and it has a terrific future ... 'Localness' is at the top of our list."

What future then for truly independent local television? One wonders how the growing trend for consolidation, imitating the national networks, can enable the RSL community to retain its most valuable asset - independence. Although it was originally built on principles of probity, it is clear that the restricted service needs to be de-restricted because, in an unpredictable age of digital media, RSLs may well become the last outpost of public service broadcasting.

At a time when technology is moving people away from their communities, the need to bring them back home has never been stronger.

webTitle: Gould's leaked memo: New Labour is a 'contaminated brand'

fields.headline: When brands go bad
fields.standfirst: Philip Gould's leaked memo last week revealed that New Labour is a 'contaminated brand'. What is that? And is there any way back? Chris Powell writes...
fields.trailText: Philip Gould's leaked memo last week revealed that New Labour is a 'contaminated brand'. What is that? And is there any way back? Chris Powell writes...
fields.body:
It was a dictum of Mrs Thatcher that voters could easily become bored of politicians, and periods of withdrawal were necessary to give more impact at the important moments. There is an odd notion among those addicted to politics that the public constantly wants to be involved, be asked to participate, be consulted and vote. Actually, the public wants you to get on with the job they elected you to do and they'll let you know how you're doing later.

Outside elections, governments have the advantage of being able to be slightly above the fray, making the opposition seem like overexcited but ineffectual minnows. Daily battling for hearts and minds militates against this appearance of concentrating on the important national issues; you can easily seem more concerned with re-election than with the public good.

If this is true, then it's important not to overreact to daily, or even weekly, events and to keep the language calm and proportionate. (I had a colleague, once, of a rather nervous disposition who - as his level of panic rose - added up to four verys in front of his importants and urgents, which, of course, cancelled themselves out).

I don't, for instance, recognise "brand contamination", but assume it means tarnished reputation. But then I didn't recognize the Americanism "focus groups" initially and still prefer the more objective British terminology of "group discussions". I think this language is intended to sound more military and strategic.

Brands do, indeed, get tarnished by untoward events, as do people's reputations. Even the mighty Coca-Cola has had trouble - leading it to lift products from stores in Europe and run into legal and sales difficulties in the US - and will have to build its way back.

The prospects for re-establishment depend, in the main, on how central to the brand's core the problem was. Perrier water became contaminated years ago and never recovered its dominant market position, I think because purity is the essence of bottled waters. In the spate of blackmailing attacks on brands, where a few cans or bottles were poisoned by the blackmailer, the fact that this was an outside act and the brand owners took speedy action to defend the public left their reputations and sales unscarred. And the complaints about Virgin trains seem to have had remarkably little effect on Virgin's standing, I suspect because the trains are seen as a peripheral (and especially difficult) part of the Branson offering.

The "new" in New Labour isn't really tarnished. The Labour Party bears remarkably few of the inevitable dents that come from being in government. New has served its purpose, which was to flag the difference between a Blair-led Labour and the strong residual image of the Labour of the "winter of discontent" days. Everyone sees Labour these days as the Blair model, so New is merely redundant.

The endless promotion of the hyperactivity of the government obscures the concentration that is going on to create real improvements. This may have led to some cynicism and irritation among both the public and the media. But this is a view of Labour on its own. In the inevitable comparison of an election, the important stuff of prospective financial well-being, of leading personalities and almost all policy areas will strongly favour the government.

 Chris Powell is chairman of BMP DDB and led Labour's 1997 election campaign advertising.

fields.headline: Need to know:Tim Wright
fields.trailText: Age? 36.
fields.body:
Age? 36.

Who is he? Writer/ co-founder of XPT, an interactive digital entertainment company originating dramas and spoof services online. Former journalist and new media producer.

What's the clever idea? "Virtual gift giving. Go to IT3C.co.uk and select the person you want to send the gift to. It throws up the gifts we think appropriate, and you select one, with a message to send with it. It's a sort of enhanced greetings card service, full of funny gifts and incidents, and it triggers a four-day narrative, a spoof of a dot.com package delivery. A way of communicating with people, providing entertainment. Also a digital glue for sticking people to our products - the more information you give, the more tailored the characters and plot lines."

What's the thinking behind it? "IT3C started as a gift-giving service inside our online drama, Online Caroline, as a way to send her virtual gifts which she would acknowledge. We then thought, wouldn't that be a service other people might like?"

How does it work? "Click the 'send' button at the front of the website, give the name and email address of the recipient, select the gift you think appropriate (anything from a fire man to the planet Neptune), plus the wrapping and local depot you want. Attach a tag with a message. The order is wrapped up and ready to go. You get email reports of how the package is getting on around the world. Over the next four days something weird happens to your package - you see a picture of it in London or Greenland or wherever it's got to. Each day you can send personalised emails about it to the other person. On the fourth day your package doesn't get through, but your message tag does, so your feelings of goodwill and personal messages are communicated. A picture of the item is shown with your message tag."

Possible shortcomings? "Reliance on public email systems, which go wrong quite regularly. People might feel IT3C is a real service and be disappointed that their gift hasn't arrived. Others may not realise a friend sent the gift and feel their privacy has been invaded by an anonymous company sending junk mail."

What's next? "Online Caroline will appear in more online dramas. Applying IT3C to mobile phone messaging. Virtual online holidays - instead of booking a holiday online you can have a holiday online. A vast online catalogue of virtual objects people can select and organise into personal gift-sets. When broadband technology allows, music and video as well as static image gifts, across a range of technologies and media."

fields.headline: Reading between the online perks
fields.standfirst: Special report: Time Warner/AOL merger
fields.trailText: Walt Disney may be screaming blue murder at the proposed merger of America Online and Time Warner, but the combination of the world's largest internet service provider and one of its biggest media companies can claim News Corporation as its first victim.
fields.body:
Walt Disney may be screaming blue murder at the proposed merger of America Online and Time Warner, but the combination of the world's largest internet service provider and one of its biggest media companies can claim News Corporation as its first victim.

Let me explain. Earlier this month, Time Warner's book-publishing arm bought the north American rights for a book by Jack Welch. Interest in the revered head of the US conglomerate General Electric is such that four publishers fought over the contract, pushing the final amount to a record $7.1m (£4.7m). Not even the Pope could top that.

But the right to publish the words of the management wizard did not just go to the highest bidder. Welch, who is to hand over his share of the advance to charity, decided to stop the bidding at just over $7m. He then had further discussions with the salivating agents and finally chose Time Warner over HarperCollins, the book publisher owned by News Corp.

Why? The obvious explanation, confirmed by insiders, was that Time Warner won because it was able to offer an unbeatable array of marketing opportunities. Publish with Time Warner and you not only gain access to some of America's most popular magazines but to AOL's 23m online subscribers.

The publishing deal, a record-breaker even before worldwide rights are discussed, could be the first concrete example of the much-hyped synergies expected from the proposed merger.

Opponents of the blockbuster deal, which has still to be agreed by US regulators, have jumped on this example of the overriding power of the combination. Just think, the merger of AOL and Time Warner makes News Corp look like the underdog, albeit in the tiny part of the media galaxy that is publishing. Rupert Murdoch's sprawling empire, which encompasses UK news-papers, Hollywood film studios and satellite television operations, does not have access to an internet business of any meaningful size.

None of the huge media empires can compete with AOL's clout on the web, of course. The two other bidders in the race for the Welch book - Bertelsmann's Doubleday and Viacom's Simon & Schuster - dropped out at $6.5m, but they too would not have been able to offer the same coverage.

The deal poses the question of how the internet is going to be used by book publishers. The advantage of Time Warner's family of magazines is obvious. About 1.6m hardback copies of the book need to be sold to justify the record advance. A tie-in with business bible Fortune, general interest magazine Time or the popular People - all owned by Time Warner - will help to sell a book which the about-to-retire Welch insists will be more management manual than autobiography.

Time Warner's publishing arm has not spelt out how it could use AOL. While much has been written about the impact of online distribution on the publishing world through websites such as Amazon.com, for example, less is known about the uses and advantages of online marketing. Advertising slots on the home page, or related chat room tie-ins? Industry insiders are keen to see whether the combined AOL-Time Warner will go beyond existing ideas.

The issue also raises interesting competitive issues. How far can discounts for related parts of a multi-media empire go? Should Time Warner be able to pay half what its competitors have to for banner ads on AOL or a full-page in Fortune?

These questions are likely to be discussed in Washington where the federal communications commission and the federal trade commission are considering the merger on both industry-specific and competitive grounds.

Any discussion of competition and the new AOL-Time Warner will, of course, be seized on by Disney. The media and entertainment group, no stranger to aggressive business tactics, is urging Washington regulators to curb the power of the media alliance by actually splitting up parts of it. Scared by its own spat with Time Warner earlier this year when the cable group pulled the plug on Disney's ABC television network, Disney has suggested that its rival's cable TV business should be separated from the combined group's various content assets.

Preston Padden, Disney's chief lobbyist, has said: "There are just a million ways that a company that controls the pipeline, the set-top box, the operating system, the menus, and the navigation ... can discriminate and limit and skew consumer choice."

Such concerns are likely to be put to Steve Case and Gerald Leven, the heads of AOL and Time Warner respectively, when they appear before a public hearing held by the FCC this week.

In the meantime, Michael Wolff, who writes a column for New York magazine, has been commissioned to write a book about the impact of the AOL-Time Warner merger. The publisher? HarperCollins.

fields.headline: New media diary
fields.trailText: * A few tears were shed after the final of Channel 4's E-Millionaire Show, in which two winners, Jo Rajko of youreable.com, a service for the disabled, and Colin Robinson of schoolsforschools.com, a network that links schools to businesses, were presented with £1m apiece. It was an emotional time for all the finalists - especially when some of them learned that they didn't actually own their own domain names. It turned out that only Andrew Pearce, founder of beepboutique.com, had had the foresight to register his domain before making his application.
fields.body:
* A few tears were shed after the final of Channel 4's E-Millionaire Show, in which two winners, Jo Rajko of youreable.com, a service for the disabled, and Colin Robinson of schoolsforschools.com, a network that links schools to businesses, were presented with £1m apiece. It was an emotional time for all the finalists - especially when some of them learned that they didn't actually own their own domain names. It turned out that only Andrew Pearce, founder of beepboutique.com, had had the foresight to register his domain before making his application.

After choosing the finalists, Princess Productions apparently registered all five domains "on behalf of the contestants", but they evidently overlooked youreable.co.uk (registered by the entrepreneurial Mr A Hughes as late as July 10) and com-poser. co.uk (registered by one Tim Luke). According to Princess, the names have since been given to the contestants, but no one felt able to comment on whether any ransom money had changed hands.

*The announcement last week that First Tuesday had merged with Yazam, a leader in seed-stage investing and business development, puts an end to rumours that the networking agency had plans to become an incubator. First Tuesday will maintain the brand and operate as a subsidiary. CEO Reade Fahs: "Entrepreneurs will have more fertile ground on which to learn, grow, and create relationships." And investors? "They will benefit from new alliances that create more successful investments." Yazam's own companies, of course, will also be beneficiaries.

*United News and Media's Xilerate has unveiled plans for allaboutparents.com, a parenting portal due to go live on August 2. The venture, backed by Debenhams, is primarily an e-commerce vehicle for both parties, but contains all the usual fare: news, columns and articles taken from the Daily Express and Express Parent stable.

*US portal iVillage has been pawing at the UK women's market for a long time. In February it even appointed editors and a CEO, but everything was put on hold amid rumours of a cash crisis. Three cheers for Tesco, then, which has galloped in with $18m to launch the "online community" at the end of this year. Beme.com's Hilary Burden wishes them luck but says they can expect "stiff competition".

*Those heading to Ibiza this week might like to check out Worldpop.com's hilarious new Mobile Ibiza service, which messages you with opportunities such as "Get on the guest list and hang out with Kylie at Pacha!" or "Meet Geri at Manumission!" To get on the VIP list, you have to phone a premium-rate UK number (the Ibiza one didn't work) and then wait in a virtual queue. Realistic, eh?

fields.headline: Performance related pay
fields.standfirst: Over the past decade clients have forced advertising agencies to justify their costs.  James Curtis reports that moves for payment by results could benefit the industry's reputation and its future
fields.trailText: Over the past decade clients have forced advertising agencies to justify their costs. James Curtis reports that moves for payment by results could benefit the industry's reputation and its future
fields.body:
There's a story about a marketing director who went to his advertising agency for a meeting. As he parked, he nosed his company Vauxhall into a space between two gleaming Aston Martins. Noticing that the rest of the car park was liberally dotted with yet more expensive motors, the marketing man's first comment to his agency that morning was: "I think I'm paying you lot too much."

The question of how much advertisers pay their agency has always been contentious. Ad agencies may be experts in creating beautiful and often very effective commercials, but they are also masters of the art of spending their clients' cash. Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO spent £1m making the "Surfer" ad for Guinness, complete with computer-animated horses, and Saatchi & Saatchi famously draped an entire island in silk for the benefit of British Airways.

Not surprisingly, clients who invest millions every year in advertising are increasingly keen to make sure they're getting their money's worth. Rising media costs - inflating at a rate of more than 10% per year - and the relative cost-effectiveness of rival media, such as the internet and direct marketing, are all putting clients under more pressure to justify their advertising expenditure.

So there is a growing trend for companies to link agency pay to the effectiveness of their advertising. Roughly speaking, if the ads help to boost sales the agency gets more. If they don't there's a penalty.

This harsh regime would have caused agency folk to choke on their champagne in the freewheeling 80s, when remuneration was generally linked to commission paid on media spending. Under this system, agen cies were paid a flat 15% of whatever they spent on media. They also slapped a 15% charge on to their production costs. So, the more extravagant the ads, the bigger the profit for the agency. This system didn't exactly encourage a penny-pinching culture in the streets of Soho.

In the early 90s, some agencies tried to change things by charging clients a flat fee. This was fine, but critics argued that it didn't provide a sufficient incentive for the agency and made them feel like their services were being bought in the same way as you'd pay a plumber. Opponents of commission said it made ad agencies behave like estate agents. Each system was flawed.

But now things are changing again. According to a new report by the Incorporated Society of British Advertisers (ISBA), called Paying for Advertising, more and more companies are now paying agencies according to results. There has been a steady drift towards this system for three or so years now, but the report shows that payment by results (PBR) is fast becoming accepted practice.

In its study of 16 of the UK's biggest advertisers - many of whom spend more than £10m above-the-line per year - ISBA found that PBR now features in 34% of all agency remuneration agreements. Commission-based agreements are rapidly going out of fashion, only included in 22% of contracts, compared to 33% in 1997. Debbie Morrison, director of membership services at ISBA, says PBR is a healthier system for both client and agency. "With commission, clients didn't know what they were buying - there was very little accountability. But PBR encourages the client and agency to have a more open dialogue and doesn't prejudice the agency towards using one type of media over another. If pay's linked to effectiveness, not media, the agency is more likely to use whatever channel gets the best results. That's better for everyone."

However, the big problem with paying by results is establishing what measures to use. Procter & Gamble, the world's biggest advertiser, shocked adland last year when it announced it planned to link agency remuneration to global brand sales.

As Gary Cunningham, director of public affairs and media at P&G, says: "However involved we become in the excitement of the advertising world, we need to remember that companies don't advertise for advertising's sake, no matter how great the creative work. Companies advertise to sell their products."

This may sound logical but P&G's is an extreme step, as even the most rigorously measured advertising is hard to link to products shifting off the shelves. You can track brand awareness and customer loyalty, but sales are a different story.

James Best, group chairman of the ad agency BMP DDB, says: "Brand sales are connected to a totally arbitrary range of factors which agencies can't be expected to control. Not many agencies could survive on that basis alone."

Although P&G blazed the PBR trail, most companies have taken a broader view of what is meant by "results". An increasingly common approach is to measure agency performance according to three sets of criteria. These combine hard goals such as client sales and profitability, with harder-to-measure objectives - anything from the quality of the agency's ideas to the transparency of its financial reporting.

Although PBR will undoubtedly put the onus on agencies to prove themselves, many welcome its introduction. For some years now the industry has been working very hard to prove advertising's effectiveness. Schemes such as the effectiveness awards run by the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising (IPA) have helped create a new culture of accountability, encouraging agencies to demonstrate the effect of their work on clients' business performance. As long as they can do this, many agencies say PBR can only improve their lot.

Stephen Woodford, chief executive of WCRS, argues that his agency's work for Orange has been instrumental in building the value of the company. This is an important claim, considering that France Telecom recently acquired Orange for an eye-watering £31bn.

Woodford says: "Our ads contributed hugely to the value of the company. When Orange was sold, all the analysts said its key asset was the resonance of its brand, and we helped create that. On the whole, agencies are paid a tiny proportion of the value they help create, and PBR will hopefully bring some focus on to what we do."

WCRS won an IPA advertising effectiveness award for its work for Orange in 1998. At the time, independent analysts valued Orange at £6.3bn, but said that without its brand, the company would only be worth £2.9bn. That was one of the key factors which won WCRS the IPA award.

However, clients are far too smart to leave PBR agreements open-ended. The last thing they want is to owe their agency millions in bonus payments if an ad campaign works wonders for their brand.

This is something that Bartle Bogle Hegarty may consider when it reflects on what it did for Levi's in the 80s and 90s. Its unforgettable campaign in 1985, featuring Nick Kamen stripping off in a launderette, kicked off a series of classic ads which are estimated to have boosted sales of Levi's 501s by 800%. More recently, Levi's has suffered from blue jeans falling out of fashion, but for a good 10 years BBH had Levi's surfing a wave of astonishing success.

BBH's group managing director, Simon Sherwood, wishes PBR had been around a bit sooner. He says, wistfully: "If we'd negotiated a dollar for every pair of 501s sold, we'd all be bobbing around in large yachts now, smoking fat cigars."

In practice, PBR is a far more modest reward. In the ISBA report, an example is given of how it works for an anonymous food and drinks company with an annual advertising spend of £5m. Based on a package which combines a fee-paying and PBR model, the advertiser pays the agency a flat percentage of its annual ad spend, in this case £500,000 per year. A range is then set for results, based on an upper and lower limit of 15%. This means that the agency will be rewarded or penalised, but only according to a 15% upturn or slide in the client's business. For this agency, that means its £500,000 fee will either grow or be cut by £75,000.

This is probably a good example of how the new system will work. It shows that PBR is unlikely to be adopted by clients as a true results-driven system. For a start, most agencies would not be able to expose themselves to the level of risk that would entail, especially as their key resource is people, which means their fixed costs are high.

Andrew Marsden, marketing director at Britvic Soft Drinks, says agency executives willing to lay their heads on the block in a pure results-driven agreement would be "bloody brave", if not suicidal. "The reality is that most agencies can't afford to operate on that basis. If they did, they'd all be down in the pub having a large gin. It'd be scary."

But the fact that the advertising world is prepared to stand by its results to any degree is a big improvement on how things used to be. With the ISBA report showing that 33% of all advertisers using PBR end up paying their agencies more, it is clear that advertising is managing to prove its worth. And at a time when investing in alternative media such as the internet is all the rage, that's no mean feat.
