For this agency, that means its £500,000 fee will either grow or be cut by £75,000. This is probably a good example of how the new system will work. It shows that PBR is unlikely to be adopted by clients as a true results-driven system. For a start, most agencies would not be able to expose themselves to the level of risk that would entail, especially as their key resource is people, which means their fixed costs are high. Andrew Marsden, marketing director at Britvic Soft Drinks, says agency executives willing to lay their heads on the block in a pure results-driven agreement would be "bloody brave", if not suicidal. "The reality is that most agencies can't afford to operate on that basis. If they did, they'd all be down in the pub having a large gin. It'd be scary." But the fact that the advertising world is prepared to stand by its results to any degree is a big improvement on how things used to be. With the ISBA report showing that 33% of all advertisers using PBR end up paying their agencies more, it is clear that advertising is managing to prove its worth. And at a time when investing in alternative media such as the internet is all the rage, that's no mean feat.

webTitle: David Teather discusses the future for United News & Media and ITV

fields.headline: Celebrity deathmatch
fields.standfirst: Will Lord Hollick end up the big loser in the ITV power struggle, now the government has railroaded his bid to merge with Carlton? Being one of Tony's cronies should be more rewarding, says David Teather
fields.trailText: Will Lord Hollick end up the big loser in the ITV power struggle, now the government has railroaded his bid to merge with Carlton? Being one of Tony's cronies should be more rewarding, says David Teather
fields.body:
In hindsight, it looked like a last-gasp attempt to avoid the cut in a consolidating ITV market that was getting ready to move from three to two players. And it almost worked.

Lord Hollick, the Labour peer who runs United News & Media, the smallest of ITV's big three, had brokered a deal to merge with Michael Green's Carlton Communications, leaving the larger Granada in the cold. By the end of last week Hollick had raised the white flag and invited offers for either the entire company or the television interests, which include the ITV franchises for Meridian, HTV and Anglia. Hollick, as those who know him will tell you, is at heart a pragmatist.

Some adroit manoeuvring by Granada - and particular praise should be given to the company's lobbyists during the competition commission investigation into ITV - has left it and Carlton ready to feed on the United carcass. The only question that remains is whether a hostile bid for United will be necessary or whether the three sides can engage in the smoky room scenario - horsetrading of assets through the fug of Green's trademark cigar.

There is little doubt that Granada's tenacious chief executive Charles Allen would prefer a behind the scenes agreement. Advisers close to Allen suggest he is gunning for Meridian and Anglia which would leave HTV for Carlton.

What now follows is much rattling of sabres. United advisers are keen to stress that this is not a firesale and that a number of other players are out there including TF1 of France, RTL - in which Pearson has a stake - and Mediaset of Italy. Advisers to Granada, equally as keen to get the price down, are cynical.

"Our options appear to be getting wider and theirs appear to be diminishing," said one Granada source. "I would take any suggestion that other bidders are lining up for United with a huge pinch of salt. The game in ITV is consolidation, so why anyone would want to come in, compete with a buyer that can extract synergies, and, at best, end up as the number three player in the market is beyond me."

RTL, the pan-European TV business in which Pearson has a significant stake, is not believed to be interested in anything more than taking full control of Channel 5. RTL currently has 65% and United the other 35%.

Granada is sitting on a pile of cash after the flotation of its media assets earlier this month and may be prepared to pay what it takes to win the licences it wants. What might appear to be overpaying would cause some handwringing in the City but would clearly be worth it for the longer game.

If Granada were to buy United wholesale it would be forced to dispose of HTV as well as United's stake in Channel 5 and its own share of GMT to comply with the 15% limit on television audience share.

Carlton remains a wild card in the negotiations. Clearly it couldn't own Meridian, the south coast and south east licence, but is it prepared to settle for HTV?

Much would seem to depend on how well Allen and the more unpredictable Green can get on. If, as now seems certain, they emerge as the two prime players they will prove an interesting double act.

Granada's capacity for surprise could mean it will still either do an agreed deal with Carlton or go hostile. That would though allow a third, potentially strong player into the game assuming there is another bidder for United, which Allen may be keen to quash now.

Aides to Hollick are keen to steer clear of emotive terms such as "defeat". This, they point out, is about that trusty old favourite, shareholder value. If the best way of achieving maximum value for the investors who own the company is breaking it up then so be it. "United won't be sentimental about this," says one insider. "This is a cold and calculating decision to deliver value to their shareholders".

But even the most steely-hearted can't doubt that Hollick must have been bitterly disappointed at the outcome of his attempt to stay in the game. United is said to have been keen to still pursue the merger with Carlton despite the verdict from trade secretary Stephen Byers 10 days ago.

Perhaps what will have been most galling is that the Labour peer's hopes were railroaded by the government - which put Granada in the driving seat by demanding the sale of Meridian as a condition of approving the United/Carlton deal. More than one diarist was pointing out yesterday that being one of Tony's cronies should be more rewarding.

Hollick is said to prefer a clean break by attracting an offer for the entire business. If the TV interests are bought then he is left refocusing a company whose assets include technology publishing business Miller Freeman CMP, the Express titles and the Daily Star. It also has a growing new media division.

There would doubtless be buyers for the other assets if he is in the mood to sell. The Barclay brothers and Trinity Mirror could be players for the national newspaper titles. Whether Hollick has the appetite for rebuilding his empire around publishing and new media only he knows.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 Spare a thought for the former ITV chief executive Richard Eyre, now at Pearson. The poor man is so hard up that he is forced to travel several times a week to his former corporate home at Gray's Inn Road and sneak his way into the building's gym to pump some iron, while a car waits outside. As they can't find a replacement, former colleagues at ITV could be forgiven for locking him in the sauna and refusing to let him out until he gives them a digital strategy. Talk about making your assets sweat.

 Last week's shocking news that Mohamed Al Fayed has hired Max Clifford to consult on media developments including the possible acquisition of a newspaper throws new light on the future of the Express group. Could the Barclay brothers and Trinity Mirror face an unexpected rival for United News and Media's print interests, ending in the joyous spectacle of (Uncle) Max editing the Daily Express? Oh we do hope so...

 Hard for Wapping inmates to know whether to cheer or jeer, as an understandably sheepish management memo has floated a plan for the gradual phasing-out of Hermes, the recently-installed, much-loathed News International-wide computer system. Guesstimates of the cost of changing over the Sun, News of the World, the Times, the Sunday Times and the Times supplements to the clunky system known to suffering staff as "Herpes" run up to £50m. Assistant heads will roll, as they say at the BBC whenever such a stonking fiasco occurs.

 As the News at Ten row rolls on and on, we are too bored to say anything about it this week. In fact, we have the greatest sympathy for Trevor McDonald whose picture is splashed everywhere with every twist and turn in the endless battle and was recently spotted in an ITN corridor clutching his head in his hands groaning: "It'll never go away..."

 Guardian Edinburgh International TV Festival staff are planning to install webcams in all the sessions this year and are discussing the possibility of installing a live webcast from the George Bar. We can only assume that the sight of the TV industry at play will be a global ratings triumph and that the festival chair, Dawn Airey, will be signing it up for Channel 5.

webTitle: MPs call for closure of high security hospitals

fields.headline: MPs call for closure of high security hospitals
fields.standfirst: Commons health select committee
fields.trailText: A committee of MPs today recommended the closure of top security hospitals Rampton, Broadmoor and Ashworth.
fields.body:
A committee of MPs today recommended the closure of top security hospitals Rampton, Broadmoor and Ashworth.

The Commons health select committee's report said that the high security hospitals - which house psychologically disturbed patients such as the Moors murderer Ian Brady and the child killer Beverly Allitt - should be replaced by eight smaller regional centres. It said the smaller units would provide better security for the public, patients and staff than the "existing unwieldy old estates where security is inevitably difficult to manage".

The report urges the biggest shake-up in mental health policy since the Conservatives' "care in the community" initiative, which led to the closure of numerous mental hospitals.

It states: "A decision to retain the existing system would, we believe, be prompted more by political expedience than by any genuine attempt to achieve the most appropriate and most secure provision."

The report also criticises the practice of forcing patients to accept treatment stating that "the refusal of a competent patient to refuse treatment should be taken very seriously".

Further recommendations include the merging of health and social services departments into one entity and better training on race awareness for all front-line NHS staff.

The report also criticised plans to detain people with severe untreatable personality disorders who had not committed a crime. The government says there are some 2,400 people who fall into this category and is expected to respond shortly to a consultation exercise on a change in the law.

But the committee expressed concern that the term "dangerous people with severe personality disorders" could be stigmatising - and it questioned the figure of 2,400. The MPs want it made clear that offending behaviour and not mental disorder should form the basis for the orders.

The MPs visited the Ashworth and Broadmoor hospitals, concluding that the benefits for a regional focus to secure care was "overwhelming". The report stated that despite the millions of pounds spent on the hospitals by successive governments, their reform and improvement was "probably not workable".

There are more than 1,300 patients being held in the three special hospitals - 450 at Ashworth, Merseyside, around 440 in Rampton, Nottinghamshire, and around 440 in Broadmoor, Berkshire.

The mental health charity Mind, which submitted evidence for the report, highlighted the disproportionate number of women and black and ethnic minority patients in high-security hospitals. The health secretary, Alan Milburn, admitted to the committee that these hospitals "have got probably quite a large number of people who could be accommodated and treated in a more medium secure or low secure setting".

A spokeswoman for Mind said that about half of the patients at Rampton, Broadmoor and Ashworth did not need such high security: "There are people with learning disabilities in them, women who self harm... By their very natures these places seem outside the rest of the society - run behind huge walls out of the public gaze, which has meant that very often no one knows what is going on in them."

"We have been saying for a long time that the special hospitals are not providing the appropriate care and support for the mix of patients. They would be a lot more manageable if they were broken down into smaller units."

Compulsory treatment was proposed by the government after the conviction of Michael Stone, who murdered Lin Russell and her six-year-old daughter in Kent in 1996. He had a severe personality disorder but could not be held under the Mental Health Act because his condition was deemed untreatable.

The Royal College of Nursing welcomed the publication of the report. But a spokesman said: "The issue is not whether we close the special hospitals but what we do with people who are currently living in them, because some of those individuals have been living there for many years, and simply to close them and not have some options for what we do with them is frankly short-sighted."

In evidence to the committee, health minister John Hutton described the issue of compulsory treatment for mental patients as "very, very sensitive".

He told the committee: "Patients should be treated on the basis of consent where that is possible. There is absolutely no possibility of us getting to a situation where we do not have those powers to compulsorily treat a patient. If we were not to do that it would not only be inhumane, because we would be denying a patient access to appropriate care, but it would be dangerous - not only for the patient themselves to go untreated, but dangerous for the community, their families, the carers and staff who work in the NHS and social services too."

But the Mind spokeswoman said that the charity had "tremendous concerns" about the proposed changes to the Mental Health Act. "We need to be looking after people before their condition starts to deteriorate and they start to go into crisis, which can often mean they stop taking their medication.

"Forcing them to take their medication will destroy the therapeutic relationship between the patient and the person treating them. ... [The plans] will also mean that disproportionate numbers of black and ethnic minority people will be placed under these enforcement orders, because that is what we have seen happen before."

fields.headline: Hopeful dance with destiny
fields.standfirst: Broadband is the net entrepreneur's new hope. Imogen O'Rorke looks at efforts to woo backers.
fields.trailText: Broadband is the net entrepreneur's new hope. Imogen O'Rorke looks at efforts to woo backers.
fields.body:
'London, UK, July 17 2000. Fifty hopeful broadband entrepreneurs aim to leave a central London hotel with projected deals worth between $1m and $10m...," puffs the press release from First Tuesday, the match-making club which new media types love to slate (but still be invited to, of course).

Why should we care this time? Is it because broadband - the bandwidth technology which will enable video and film to be streamed down the phone line to our PCs and mobile phones - is the new path to profitability? The word that can throw the lifeline to floundering dot.coms and launch a flotilla of new start-ups in an otherwise suicidal market?

Surely Channel 4's E-Millionaire Show, which culminated in a spectacular dot.bomb, was proof enough of what happens when an immature industry is over-hyped and sold to the public as lottery tickets? After its growing pains, the market has matured, as has, so we are told, First Tuesday which has announced a merger with Yazam, a first-stage investor, and is preparing for a relaunch in the autumn.

So Thursday's event in the Park Lane Hotel was not the cattle market it used to be. The "young pretenders" have been put through two screening tests (only the top 10% to 15% of the 300 entrepreneurs who applied were chosen) and only half of the venture capital firms who registered have been invited.

Lines of numbered tables are laid out with refreshments in the ballroom at which the hopefuls wait attentively for the VCs to sign their "dance cards". They have 10 minutes to entice their dates to a further meeting before the gong is sounded and everyone moves round one place. Almost civilised. "Thank God. I was starting to feel too old for all of that networking stuff," confides David Phillips, 30-something CEO of music portal iCrunch. He is about to go into the third of his 10 pitches that day.

After introducing his team, he launches into the routine. iCrunch, which aggregates and exploits digital music rights in the alternative European market, sees "a natural extension from dance music to dance culture and being able to go deep and vertical in terms of the music and the lifestyle", he explains. "We then add value to it by bundling it with editorial, content and community."

Phillips, a former AOL executive, is no web wannabe. Just 16 months old, iCrunch is working with 50 music labels, and has deals with HMV and EMusic. It is talking to "everyone" from telecoms companies to magazine publishers, including a major music channel with whom it is discussing "a branded channel distribution deal".

The pitches are slick and seamless. Phillips disarms a question about competitors by comparing Peoplesound.com to the "meat market" of the early First Tuesdays. "This is a more mature, filtered environment... We are getting in the new acts, breaking in the new talent."

So where are the wannabes? Sometimes you can tell them by their overly-austere suits. DataKlick online marketing research's managing director, Lisanne Davie - aged 23, with punk red hair and a chin stud but tucked into a smart outfit - and her portly director of strategy, David Liley, could fit the description. Davie approached Liley with her idea nine months ago when he was running a web design agency and she was a junior telemarketing officer. He gave up his job to join her.

DataKlick, however, is a serious contender. Its vision for making market research "fun" for its "cohort of willing consumers" is by paying them to take part in market research surveys (from 50p to £3 for a few minutes) and using broadband multimedia streaming. Their company's competitive edge, they maintain, is that it is 20% cheaper than its rivals and can get results within two hours. The second VC they met today offered to write a cheque out for several million if they fulfilled certain criteria which they believe they can meet within six months. Flushed with excitement, they don't want to count their chickens but at this rate they could be floating in 18 months.

By far the wackiest pitch was IndiaGeek.com, a broadband channel which according to a co-founder, Farrukh Dhondy, will provide "satirical and innovative" programming for the Indian diaspora. Dhondy, a columnist on the Asian Age and former Channel 4 commissioning editor, formed AMI Net last year with Shekhar Kapur, director of Bandit Queen and Elizabeth, and the CEO, Mohan Chopra, backed by money from "friends and fools". It has offices in London and Delhi.

"We are building for the day when the computer becomes the TV screen. Whatever John Birt says, the TV is never going to run successful interactive shows," says Dhondy. Despite the postmodern name, IndiaGeek claims to be coming up from grassroots. "There's a new consciousness. Indians are obsessed with Bollywood and yet only one in 100 films succeeds - people are looking for something new." The web channel will stream short films, animations, drama, comedy and "tasteful erotica". "Nothing is sacred. We're going to slaughter a lot of holy cows. We are going to do revelations, to take the cover off: corruption, cruelty, slavery, oppression, wife-burning - give India its first burst of investigative and observational documentary films." Free from government censorship, IndiaGeek can go where the Asian networks fear to tread.

Dhondy believes they have no competition, "because no one knows what to do with broadband. They see it as a dumping ground for Bollywood films or old TV shows. They are not exploiting the grammar of the net."

IndiaGeek is hoping to close a deal for $3m in the next few months for a spring launch. From an investors' perspective, too, the day has been fruitful. "I've seen six companies," says Thomas Kenney, of Nokia Ventures, who is over from the US to "check out the cool technologies, applications, services for 3G mobile internet - investing at an early stage". He has arranged second meetings with four start-ups. Kenney is "surprised" by the 2% brokerage fee that First Tuesday has introduced. "In the States, if a VC agency asked for that it would be 'get outa here!'." But in Europe, he concedes, it is a different market.

At the end of the day, no one is exactly walking out with a deal. If they performed well, they have a handful of business cards and invitations to meet up. The next generation of net entrepreneurs crawls into the lobby, exhausted, with their mobile phones beeping, but encouraged that when it comes to broadband a bit of the old dot.com fever still exists.

"We then add value to it by bundling it with editorial, content and community." Phillips, a former AOL executive, is no web wannabe. Just 16 months old, iCrunch is working with 50 music labels, and has deals with HMV and EMusic. It is talking to "everyone" from telecoms companies to magazine publishers, including a major music channel with whom it is discussing "a branded channel distribution deal". The pitches are slick and seamless. Phillips disarms a question about competitors by comparing Peoplesound.com to the "meat market" of the early First Tuesdays. "This is a more mature, filtered environment... We are getting in the new acts, breaking in the new talent." So where are the wannabes? Sometimes you can tell them by their overly-austere suits. DataKlick online marketing research's managing director, Lisanne Davie - aged 23, with punk red hair and a chin stud but tucked into a smart outfit - and her portly director of strategy, David Liley, could fit the description. Davie approached Liley with her idea nine months ago when he was running a web design agency and she was a junior telemarketing officer. He gave up his job to join her. DataKlick, however, is a serious contender. Its vision for making market research "fun" for its "cohort of willing consumers" is by paying them to take part in market research surveys (from 50p to £3 for a few minutes) and using broadband multimedia streaming. Their company's competitive edge, they maintain, is that it is 20% cheaper than its rivals and can get results within two hours. The second VC they met today offered to write a cheque out for several million if they fulfilled certain criteria which they believe they can meet within six months. Flushed with excitement, they don't want to count their chickens but at this rate they could be floating in 18 months. By far the wackiest pitch was IndiaGeek.com, a broadband channel which according to a co-founder, Farrukh Dhondy, will provide "satirical and innovative" programming for the Indian diaspora. Dhondy, a columnist on the Asian Age and former Channel 4 commissioning editor, formed AMI Net last year with Shekhar Kapur, director of Bandit Queen and Elizabeth, and the CEO, Mohan Chopra, backed by money from "friends and fools". It has offices in London and Delhi. "We are building for the day when the computer becomes the TV screen. Whatever John Birt says, the TV is never going to run successful interactive shows," says Dhondy. Despite the postmodern name, IndiaGeek claims to be coming up from grassroots. "There's a new consciousness. Indians are obsessed with Bollywood and yet only one in 100 films succeeds - people are looking for something new." The web channel will stream short films, animations, drama, comedy and "tasteful erotica". "Nothing is sacred. We're going to slaughter a lot of holy cows. We are going to do revelations, to take the cover off: corruption, cruelty, slavery, oppression, wife-burning - give India its first burst of investigative and observational documentary films." Free from government censorship, IndiaGeek can go where the Asian networks fear to tread. Dhondy believes they have no competition, "because no one knows what to do with broadband. They see it as a dumping ground for Bollywood films or old TV shows. They are not exploiting the grammar of the net." IndiaGeek is hoping to close a deal for $3m in the next few months for a spring launch. From an investors' perspective, too, the day has been fruitful. "I've seen six companies," says Thomas Kenney, of Nokia Ventures, who is over from the US to "check out the cool technologies, applications, services for 3G mobile internet - investing at an early stage". He has arranged second meetings with four start-ups. Kenney is "surprised" by the 2% brokerage fee that First Tuesday has introduced. "In the States, if a VC agency asked for that it would be 'get outa here!'." But in Europe, he concedes, it is a different market. At the end of the day, no one is exactly walking out with a deal. If they performed well, they have a handful of business cards and invitations to meet up. The next generation of net entrepreneurs crawls into the lobby, exhausted, with their mobile phones beeping, but encouraged that when it comes to broadband a bit of the old dot.com fever still exists.

fields.headline: Murdoch junior damns media regulation
fields.trailText: James Murdoch, son of the head of News Corporation, has attacked the British media regulatory system as draconian and biased towards the Murdoch group's competitors.
fields.body:
James Murdoch, son of the head of News Corporation, has attacked the British media regulatory system as draconian and biased towards the Murdoch group's competitors.

In an interview with the Guardian, Mr Murdoch, chief executive of Star TV, News Corp's Asian satellite television operation, said the BBC licence fee was exorbitant and he criticised government policies.

"The things that stick out [in the UK] are a draconian regulatory regime and a subsidised, horrific - how shall I put it - evil taxation scheme, subsidising competitors with no accountability," he said.

Mr Murdoch, 27, who is to deliver the alternative MacTaggart lecture to the Guardian Edinburgh international television festival next month, has managed News Corp's interactive business for almost three years and is to sit on the board of Sky Global, the company to be formed from the media group's international satellite television assets, including BSkyB.

He said he was still working on his state of the nation address in Edinburgh, which usually focuses on new media issues. But his comments - based on his belief that companies should be "free to compete" - show that he shares the views of his father, Rupert, on the UK regulatory system.

James Murdoch criticised the commissions that have considered the rules concerning ownership. "You have commission after commission, and finally the UK government gives its approval to do something and they toss you over to Brussels. Is it a sovereign nation or not?"

News Corp, which owns the Times, the Sunday Times and the Sun, has long run into regulatory problems related to its dominance of the newspaper industry in the UK.

Mr Murdoch insisted that he was simply demanding a more open system, rather than addressing a particular issue.

His lecture will be delivered before the deadline for contributions to the communications white paper. Chris Smith, the culture secretary, is open to consultation on questions such as regulation, cross-media ownership and consolidation.

Mr Murdoch's comments come after government restrictions on the merger of the ITV companies Carlton Communications and United News and Media scuppered the deal and paved the way for a fresh shake-up of the industry.

Eleven years ago, Rupert Murdoch lambasted British broadcasters for their complacency and warned that Sky, his then fledgling satellite operation, would take business away from them. The company confirmed how far it had fulfilled his prophecy last month when it secured the rights to televise Premier League football for another three years.

Two years ago Elisabeth Murdoch, James's sister, heralded the onset of digital broadcasting.

fields.headline: Hillsborough jury dismissed
fields.trailText: The jury considering two manslaughter charges against former chief superintendent David Duckenfield, the police officer in charge at Hillsborough on the day of the 1989 FA Cup semi-final disaster which saw 96 fans crushed to death, was today discharged at Leeds Crown Court after failing to reach a verdict.
fields.body:
The jury considering two manslaughter charges against former chief superintendent David Duckenfield, the police officer in charge at Hillsborough on the day of the 1989 FA Cup semi-final disaster which saw 96 fans crushed to death, was today discharged at Leeds Crown Court after failing to reach a verdict.

The eight men and four women had to decide whether Duckenfield was guilty of the manslaughter of John Anderson, 62, and James Aspinall, 18, in a private prosecution brought by the Hillsborough Family Support Group. They deliberated for a total of 22-and-a-half hours since first retiring last Tuesday, clearing Duckenfield's deputy, ex-superintendent Bernard Murray, but were unable to reach a second verdict on the man in charge.

The trial judge, Mr Justice Hooper, told the jury: "Not withstanding your very best efforts I understand you are not going to be able to reach a verdict in this case. In these circumstances I will discharge you. That will be the end of your involvement in the matter. You have approached the case with obvious interest and enthusiasm. Sadly you have not been able to reach a verdict but these things happen."

Former chief superintendent Duckenfield, 55, of Bournemouth, Dorset, had pleaded not guilty to the charges. A court hearing will be held on Wednesday when legal representatives for the families who brought the private prosecution are expected to announce whether they will ask for a re-trial.

fields.headline: Clearing the asylum backlog
fields.standfirst:
Special report on refugees in Britain

The Home Office is to receive an extra £600m to clear a backlog of 150,00 asylum cases in the next eight months. Mark Tran looks at the latest initiative and Patrick Barkham explains Britain's asylum laws.
fields.trailText:
Special report on refugees in Britain
The Home Office is to receive an extra £600m to clear a backlog of 150,00 asylum cases in the next eight months. Mark Tran looks at the latest initiative and Patrick Barkham explains Britain's asylum laws.
fields.body:
What is the government's plan?

The Home Office is to get an extra £600m to recruit more staff, from about 6,500 earlier this year to 11,000 over the next two years. By next January, the government wants 70% of all new asylum claims to receive an initial decision within two months. The extra money comes on top of the £400m a year over the next three years announced in the comprehensive spending review.

Why the urgency?

In his leaked memo, Tony Blair identified asylum as one of the two "touchstone issues" on which the government was seen as being too "soft". A boched computerisation project and an ill-timed move of the immigration and nationality directorate's headquarters led to a massive bureaucratic breakdown. At one point, the number of decisions taken each month fell to 800 and the backlog soared from 50,960 in February 1998 to a peak of 104,000 earlier this year.

How is the right to asylum determined?

Asylum seekers are granted residency in Britain if they meet the 1951 UN convention's definition of a refugee. They must have a "a well-founded fear of persecution" on the grounds of "race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion". Nations such as the UK, which have signed the UN's 1951 convention and 1967 protocol, are obliged to receive and formally recognise those fleeing persecution if they meet one of the five UN criteria.

What first happens when an asylum seeker lands in Britain?

The government's new immigration and asylum act, which came into force on April 1, makes it nearly impossible for a genuine refugee to reach Britain legally.

Anyone who carries an asylum seeker into Britain is liable to a £2,000 fine. In 1998, 1,000 migrants were thrown overboard and drowned at sea by European ship crews anxious to escape punishment for harbouring illegal immigrants. If a person seeking asylum actually reaches a British port, he or she can make a verbal application for asylum to immigration officials. Depending on the availability of an interpreter, the applicant is interviewed about their history of persecution. Asylum seekers are given five days to collect evidence to substantiate their claim following their first interview. "As the nature of any asylum application is complex and the determination procedure complicated, it is imperative that asylum seekers seek competent and specialist legal advice," says the Joint Council for the Welfare of Immigrants.

This can prove daunting for asylum seekers who do not speak English or have friends and family in the country. The lord chancellor recently announced an extra £23m to provide more and better legal advice to asylum seekers.

The application is then sent to the Home Office's immigration and nationality directorate for a decision. If the asylum seeker is refused asylum he or she can appeal. Immigration officials first consider any grounds of appeal they receive from the claimant. The presenting officers' unit then reviews the file and the appeal is heard. If a point of law arises, the case might be referred to the immigration appeals tribunal. If the asylum seeker is still refused he or she is deported.

Where do asylum seekers go when they reach Britain?

If asylum seekers are not immediately deported, they are fingerprinted and released on "temporary admission". The immigration and asylum act forcibly disperses asylum seekers around the country to prevent concentrations overloading local services, as Kent council has claimed.

What do they live on?

Under the government's immigration and asylum act, asylum seekers are given the equivalent of £35 for a single person or £104 for a family of four, which is considerably less than the benefits available to British citizens. Of the £35, £10 is given in cash as "pocket money"; the rest is given in the form of food vouchers.

This controversial new system, administered privately by the US firm Sodexho, means that asylum seekers can only buy food in certain supermarkets, which may not be as cheap as street markets.

Jack Straw has also instructed participating shops not to give change for the vouchers. The home secretary says he is aiming to keep down the cost of asylum seekers, but estimates suggest that the cashless system could cost three times as much to administer as a more straightforward benefits set-up.

How long does this process take?

The new immigration and asylum act says that most cases will be decided within six months by April 2001.

But many asylum seekers wait for as long as 18 months for their cases to be decided. A backlog of 102,870 people seeking asylum is steadily growing. In December, 7,180 new applications were received, with just 2,320 asylum decisions made.

Why?

Sheer numbers are rising. Last year, there were 71,160 asylum seekers, compared with 46,015 in 1998. But botched administration must take much of the blame. The home secretary has blamed the computer company Siemens for a chaotic installation of a new computerised administrative system for the asylum procedure.

But a leaked report by consultants hired by the government last year also revealed a computer "black hole", with more than half Britain's ports still unable to get online and access key Home Office files.

It is likely to get worse before it gets better under the new immigration and asylum act, with the cashless payment system proving complex to administer.

The fact that there have been four asylum acts in a dozen years is testimony to the failure of previous legislation to sort out the muddle that is the asylum procedure. While Mr Straw's latest piece of legislation looks set to fare no better, the Tories will continue to seek electoral advantage from proposing even harsher measures.

fields.headline: Trescothick handed England test debut
fields.trailText: Marcus Trescothick has been named in the England squad to face the West Indies in the third Test at Old Trafford next week - and he will definitely play, according to chairman of selectors David Graveney.
fields.body:
Marcus Trescothick has been named in the England squad to face the West Indies in the third Test at Old Trafford next week - and he will definitely play, according to chairman of selectors David Graveney.

The Somerset left-hander, named in a squad that also includes a Test recall for Graham Thorpe, has been rewarded for his outstanding one-day international performances in the last fortnight.

Trescothick replaces Mark Ramprakash at the top of the order in a 13-man squad, which sees Nick Knight and Andrew Flintoff make way for Nasser Hussain and Thorpe.

"Deciding on our batting line-up for this match was very difficult because we had nine batsmen to choose from," said Graveney. "Mark Ramprakash has stated a case for opening in international cricket this summer and has had to play against two world-class fast bowlers in Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose on wickets that haven't been straightforward.

"But after his impressive performances in the NatWest Series, we have decided that Marcus Trescothick deserves a chance in Test cricket - and he will open the innings with Michael Atherton at Old Trafford.

"With regard to Nick Knight, it was a difficult decision between him and Graham Thorpe, but Graham's improved form over the last month tipped the scales in his favour."

Thorpe played the last of his 57 Tests against New Zealand at The Oval nearly a year ago but opted out of the winter tour to South Africa and has been overlooked for the four Tests played so far this summer.

But, after bringing him back for the NatWest Triangular Series success, the selectors have now decided to call the Surrey left-hander into their Test plans as one of seven batsmen in the party set to play on an Old Trafford surface expected to favour spin.

"We could opt to play seven batters or six batsmen, an all-rounder, a specialist spinner and three seam bowlers," said Graveney. "Our final decision will depend on our analysis of the pitch and the weather conditions, but it is unlikely that we will play five seamers as we did at Lord's." Should England decide to pack their line-up with all seven batsman, it will be the first time since the second and third Tests against Australia in Perth and Adelaide they have decided on such a tactic - when they lost by seven wickets and 205 runs.

Glamorgan's Robert Croft has fought off competition from Ashley Giles for the solitary frontline spin position and, if selected, is expected to be helped out with the slow bowling workload by fellow off-spinners Michael Vaughan and Graeme Hick.

A delighted Trescothick is already relishing the challenge of facing what is still one of the most feared pace attacks in world cricket.

He said: "It's going to be a little bit different playing Test cricket. But I feel I've been playing well for England in the NatWest Series and also for Somerset - so hopefully I can carry that on.

The 24-year-old added: "I've played against Walsh, Ambrose and (Franklyn) Rose in county cricket before and I also faced Reon King at under-19 level. But playing against them at Test level will be a new challenge, and I'm looking forward to it.

"It will be nice to partner Michael Atherton in his 100th Test, and you can only learn from batting with someone like him who has got so much experience at this level."

England squad: N Hussain, MA Atherton, MP Vaughan, ME Trescothick, GA Hick, GP Thorpe, AJ Stewart, C White, DG Cork, AR Caddick, D Gough, RDB Croft, MJ Hoggard.

webTitle: July 24: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Ford flick tops US box-office, Macaulay Culkin set for fatherhood, Spielberg's 'nephew' convicted, Keanu Reeves to wed, and Martin Lawrence bags bumper pay packet
fields.body:
 DreamWorks' What Lies Beneath (pictured) topped the US box-office on its first weekend of release. The Harrison Ford and Michelle Pfeiffer flick, directed by Robert Zemeckis, took a cool $30.1m. Last weekend's box-office smash, X-Men, which opened with $54.5m, claimed second spot with an estimated $23.7m. Pokemon: the Movie 2000 debuted in the third spot with a $21.5m estimate.

 Home Alone hero Macaulay Culkin is preparing himself for fatherhood. The now 19-year-old child star is reported to consider himself old and wise enough to have a baby with his wife Rachel Miner. "I feel I can do it right," Culkin told friends. "Children need family and Rachel and I will be great parents."

 A man who posed as Steven Spielberg's nephew has been sentenced to two years' probation for forgery. Jonathan Taylor Spielberg, who enrolled in a Catholic high school under the assumed identity, was also ordered to receive mental health counselling, perform 100 hours of community service and avoid contact with anyone under the age of 18. 'Spielberg' was born Anoushirvan Fakhran in Iran, but changed his name two and a half years ago. For more than a year, the 27-year-old attended high school classes, driving to school in a BMW with 'SPLBERG' license plates. Officials discovered the ruse when they tried to contact Steven Spielberg about Jonathan's absenteeism.

 Matrix star Keanu Reeves is to marry the former presenter of Channel 4's The Word, Amanda De Cadenet, according to reports in that dubious paper The National Enquirer. The tabloid asserts that Keanu popped the question on the San Francisco set of his new movie, Sweet November. The Bill & Ted star shared a house with the 27-year-old actress some years ago, although the two claimed at the time to be just good friends.

 Martin Lawrence, star of the box office hit Big Momma's House, is poised to receive his highest payday to date for Black Knight, a 20th Century Fox film about a theme-restaurant employee who is transported to medieval times. Lawrence is said to be bagging $16m for the role.

Jonathan Taylor Spielberg, who enrolled in a Catholic high school under the assumed identity, was also ordered to receive mental health counselling, perform 100 hours of community service and avoid contact with anyone under the age of 18. 'Spielberg' was born Anoushirvan Fakhran in Iran, but changed his name two and a half years ago. For more than a year, the 27-year-old attended high school classes, driving to school in a BMW with 'SPLBERG' license plates. Officials discovered the ruse when they tried to contact Steven Spielberg about Jonathan's absenteeism.  Matrix star Keanu Reeves is to marry the former presenter of Channel 4's The Word, Amanda De Cadenet, according to reports in that dubious paper The National Enquirer. The tabloid asserts that Keanu popped the question on the San Francisco set of his new movie, Sweet November. The Bill & Ted star shared a house with the 27-year-old actress some years ago, although the two claimed at the time to be just good friends.  Martin Lawrence, star of the box office hit Big Momma's House, is poised to receive his highest payday to date for Black Knight, a 20th Century Fox film about a theme-restaurant employee who is transported to medieval times. Lawrence is said to be bagging $16m for the role.

webTitle: Martin Bicknell on rewriting the record books

fields.headline: Martin Bicknell on rewriting the record books
fields.standfirst: Every Monday wisden.com gets the inside story of the week's top county performance. Today we get the lowdown on one of the best performances of the last 50 years: Martin Bicknell's haul of 16 wickets for 119 against Leicestershire at Guildford.

At 21, he was taken on England's 1990-91 Ashes tour, when he played in seven one-day internationals. His match figures of 16-119 are the best by any bowler in this country since Jim Laker took 19-90 against Australia in the Old Trafford Test of 1956. We spoke to Bicknell less than two hours after what was to prove a match-winning performance, while Surrey's openers were knocking off the 119 required for victory.
fields.body:
Martin Paul Bicknell is one of the leading swing bowlers in England. He was born in Guildford in 1969 and made his Surrey debut at the age of only 17. At 21, he was taken on England's 1990-91 Ashes tour, when he played in seven one-day internationals. He played two Tests against the Australians in 1993, perhaps bowling better than his four wickets for 263 runs suggested. Last year he was Surrey's spearhead as they advanced to their first County Championship for 28 years. This season he is the leading first-class wicket-taker, with 52 scalps at 16.42. His match figures of 16-119 are the best by any bowler in this country since Jim Laker took 19-90 against Australia in the Old Trafford Test of 1956. We spoke to Bicknell less than two hours after what was to prove a match-winning performance, while Surrey's openers were knocking off the 119 required for victory.

"It is always a very good pitch at Guildford - we were pleased to limit them to 300 in their first innings and were disappointed ourselves to be all out for 280-odd. Yesterday was just one of those days when absolutely everything goes right for you. They missed the straight ones, every edge went to hand, and every catch was held. The ball did swing a little out there, which obviously helped, but I feel I bowled some good balls as well - the ball which dismissed Darren Maddy swung in late and took out his off stump. I was pleased with that.

I didn't really think about beating my previous best bowling figures [9-45 v Cambridge University, 1988]. It wasn't something I ever expected to beat, but I suppose that when you get so close it's a shame not to improve upon them. Obviously I'd have loved to take all ten, but I'm not disappointed in any way: I'm very, very happy about the way things went today - I certainly can't complain! It was very important for us to do well against Leicestershire [County Champions in both 1996 and 1998].

To be honest, I try not to think about the whole Test thing - I've been so close so many times and after a while you start to think that if they haven't picked you by now, they never will. Taking 16 wickets in the match doesn't really make a lot of difference. I've been bowling as well as this all season, and I still haven't been called up. But I'm only 31, which is about the same as most of the bowlers in the Test side, and I'm going to keep on going for a good few years yet. I guess I've just got to keep performing well for Surrey and see what happens. Curtly Ambrose and Courtney Walsh [aged 36 and 37] are the benchmark for fast bowling today: they have been bowling so well for so long, and show that fast bowlers can still be effective into their 30s.

When I did finally break into the Test side in 1993, I got injured and missed the last Test match, and that was it. I couldn't get back into the squad again. After that I had two bad years with injuries, and ever since then I've either been written off as too old, or not fast enough to trouble Test-match batsmen - an argument I've never really understood or agreed with. It seems that I've always been in the wrong place at the wrong time, but as I say I'm happy to be performing well for Surrey.

Surrey are in a good position for the Championship again this season - we've got five matches left and if we win them, we'll win the Championship. There's a long way to go yet, but we've got a couple of good home games coming up at The Oval, which has been turning this season, and I suppose we must be favourites. Saqlain Mushtaq has been brilliant again this season, but Surrey aren't a one-man team like people try to make out. At times this season, Ian Salisbury has bowled even better than Saqqy and Ali Brown, Ian Ward and Mark Butcher have all chipped in with some really important innings. As a team you're only as good as your weakest link and Surrey don't really have a weak link, everyone contributes.

Martin Bicknell was speaking to Tom Bowtell. To read Bicknell's appearance in wisden.com's My Winter slot, when he was setting up his own golf business back in January, click here. And to read last week's My Day in the Sun, in which Northamptonshire's Anglo-Australian batsman Jeff Cook talks us through his maiden first-class century, click here.

fields.headline: Hillsborough jury dismissed
fields.standfirst: More about Hillsborough
fields.trailText:
Jury fails to reach verdict on former senior policeman.
More about Hillsborough
fields.body:
The jury considering two manslaughter charges against the Hillsborough match day commander former Chief Superintendent David Duckenfield was today discharged at Leeds Crown Court after failing to reach a verdict.

The jury in the Hillsborough disaster trial had earlier resumed considering its verdicts on charges against Mr Duckenfield, the police officer in charge at the ground.

Former Chief Superintendent Duckenfield, 55, of Bournemouth, Dorset, denies the manslaughter of two of the 96 Liverpool supporters who died at the FA Cup Semi-Final between their team and Nottingham Forest in April, 1989.

Before being sent home from Leeds Crown Court on Friday the jury cleared Duckenfield's deputy, ex-Superintendent Bernard Murray, 58, of Pontefract, West Yorkshire, of the same charges.

The jurors had deliberated for a total of 22-and-a-half hours since first retiring last Tuesday.

fields.headline: Trash wars
fields.standfirst: Bitter about litter, soaring on sea air, showing their steel and a sordid secret in the shed
fields.trailText: Bitter about litter, soaring on sea air, showing their steel and a sordid secret in the shed
fields.body:
Refuse to budge
Bin bags at dawn have brought the residents of a West Yorkshire cul-de-sac into conflict with the town's dustmen. Neither side will budge.

The trouble started when the council introduced wheelie bins to Fairway Crescent in the Bronte sisters' picturesque home town of Haworth. The homeowners, who had been leaving their rubbish on their doorsteps, were told to move their bins to the end of the road. They refused and the rubbish looks set to reach wuthering heights.

The dustmen say they cannot collect from outside the houses because parked cars make it impossible for them to reverse their wagon down the crescent. They moved the wheelie bins to the end of the road and gave them "red cards" announcing that this was the new collection point.

The residents are not impressed. "I think most people in the road are just sick of doing their job for them," Hazel Scriven told the Keighley News. The council's cleaning department says it gave adequate warning of the new regime and insist that Fairway Crescent has brought the misery on itself: "We have leafleted residents asking them not to leave their cars there on collection day and put stickers on the cars. Unfortunately some residents have ignored this."
Keighley News

The power of Skeg
The secret of rock legend Tina Turner's success has been identified as the bracing sea air of Skegness.

A crucial moment in rock history has been unearthed by Skegness News, who report that Turner performed with husband Ike at the Sands showbar under the pier in the mid 70s.

According to the paper, while "no one quite knows what happened to Tina that famous night something in our bracing sea air must have made her rethink her destiny". A solo career followed as she split with Ike "soon afterwards".

Skeg hotelier Jo Dunsdon, who witnessed the Turners' seaside show, said: "It was a very good night out."
Skegness News

Arson display
Lincolnshire firefighters have become the latest group to bare all for a charity calendar.

Civilian firemen at RAF Cranwell were persuaded to strip to raise money for charities including Great Ormond Street hospital in London, where fireman Shane Cook's daughter Emma underwent heart surgery last year.

Their poses went down so well with public that the calendars are close to exhausting their 2000 initial print run but, as yet, the men have no plans to become full-time models.

"They may not have had the barefaced cheek of the Women's Institute or the pertness of a Pirelli model, but our firemen certainly proved hot stuff in front of the camera," a spokesman for RAF Cranwell said.
Newark Advertiser

Feline a fake
Suffolk journalists sent on the trail of a much feared big cat, if not exactly chasing paper tigers, soon discovered themselves to be tracking down a plywood panther.

News of the animal, dubbed the Beast of Brockford, had been terrifying residents ever since an amateur photographer captured the sleek outlines of the cat lurking in a distant field. Many feared that the creature, most likely escaped from a zoo and now living wild, would hunt and kill their own pet animals.

Reporters from the East Anglian Daily Times caught up with the photographer and found the Beast in his garden shed. The father of three, who asked to remain anonymous, said that he had a taken a photograph of the cut out cat for "a bit of fun" and had not meant to frighten anyone.

The Beast's only previous public appearance was on stage in a children's play.

"I shall be keeping him locked up in future. I didn't mean to upset anyone. It was just a prank," the hoaxer confessed.
East Anglian Daily Times

Letter of the week
Sir,
I would just like to thank the shopkeepers on the Bennet Precinct at Longton for providing shop doorway toilets.

The City Council obviously rely on you for the service as they now close the ladies and gents public toilets at 6pm.
Bill Patterson, Longton

webTitle: Hollywood looks to Chechnya for new bad guys

fields.headline: Hollywood looks to Chechnya for new bad guys
fields.trailText: Hollywood has been somewhat at a loss since the end of the cold war. The movies have groped around for a new baddie to replace the Russians as prime foes, with the Arabs and the English the two most notable recent candidates. Now, however, Hollywood appears to have found itself a new villain: Chechnya
fields.body:
Hollywood has been somewhat at a loss since the end of the cold war. The movies have groped around for a new baddie to replace the Russians as prime foes, with the Arabs and the English the two most notable recent candidates. Now, however, Hollywood appears to have found itself a new villain: Chechnya.

According to Hollywood.com, EdTV helmer and former Happy Days star Ron Howard (pictured) is preparing a film with the working title The Chechnya Project, while the third film in Tom Clancy's Jack Ryan series - The Sum of All Fears - is also to be set in the rebel province.

Howard's thriller is to be adapted from a series of features in the LA Times, and concerns an American oil baron whose brother is kidnapped by Chechen bad guys. The hero abandons his oil career to return to Chechnya to persuade his native village into paying the ransom. In an indication of how politically sensitive the film is likely to be, the screenplay is being penned by the man who wrote Species 2, Chris Brancato.

Director Phillip Noyce's third Clancy adaptation - after Patriot Games and Clear and Present Danger - also features the maverick state. In The Sum of All Fears, the Chechen government is involved in a present-day doomsday threat.

fields.headline: Gaspart wins Barca hearts
fields.trailText: Juan Gaspart completed the merry-go-round at the summit of Spanish soccer today when he was elected to the presidency of Barcelona. Gaspart, who had worked on the board under outgoing president Josep Lluis Nunez, won 55% percent of the vote, 12% ahead of his only rival Lluis Bassat.
fields.body:
Juan Gaspart completed the merry-go-round at the summit of Spanish soccer today when he was elected to the presidency of Barcelona. Gaspart, who had worked on the board under outgoing president Josep Lluis Nunez, won 55% percent of the vote, 12% ahead of his only rival Lluis Bassat.

Attention will now be focussed on the promises Gaspart made in order to win the election. Like his counterpart at Real Madrid, Florentin Perez, Gaspart had assured fans that his appointment would be accompanied by the arrival of top-name players. At the head of this list were Emmanuel Petit and Marc Overmars, and Arsenal will now be nervously awaiting a call from the club that beat them 4-2 at Wembley last season.

Gaspart, who is also chasing Spanish international Perez Alfonso and former favourite Ivan de la Pena, still hopes to persuade Luis Figo to stay at Camp Nou. The Portuguese star was the trump card in Real president Perez's campaign, and many Spaniards expect him to join Barca's deadly rivals for a world record £40m fee this week. But uncertainty surrounds the nature of Figo's deal with Real, some reports suggesting he only signed a pre-contract agreement in order to help his contract negotiations at Barca, and Figo may yet stay at the club.

Gaspart, 55, and a director of hotel chain HUSA, will also be expected to bring about changes off the field too. "As president I will represent everyone", Gaspart said on hearing of his victory. "I promise to work for the unity of the club. I will give my life for Barcelona," he said.

His commitment to the club is unlikely to be doubted. Before the 1992 European Cup final at Wembley, Gaspart promised to swim in the Thames if Barca beat Sampdoria. Beat them they did, and Gaspart duly took a dip, decked out in a replica shirt.

webTitle: The best fraternal scene: Stuart Little

fields.headline: The best fraternal scene: Stuart Little
fields.trailText: New York. Mr and Mrs Little (Hugh Laurie and Geena Davis) return from the city orphanage with a new baby brother for their son George (Jonathan Lipnicki). After school, George rushes in the front door, then into the living room, his excitement obvious.
fields.body:
New York. Mr and Mrs Little (Hugh Laurie and Geena Davis) return from the city orphanage with a new baby brother for their son George (Jonathan Lipnicki). After school, George rushes in the front door, then into the living room, his excitement obvious.

"Mom! Dad! I'm home! Is he here? Is my brother here?"

"He certainly is," his mother smiles.

"Where? Where is he?"

She turns him around until he faces a table in the corner of the room. Standing on top is a small mouse in dapper shirt and tie: Stuart Little (voiced by Michael J Fox).

"Stuart, this is George. George, this is Stuart. Your new brother."

George looks blank.

"No, really?"

"Really, George," Mr Little explains. "This is your new brother."

Stuart waves timidly at George. George peers back at him.

"You look somewhat like a mouse."

Stuart gives a nervous laugh.

"I am somewhat like a mouse."

"I see," says George. "I have to go."

He walks out of the room, slamming the door behind him. Stuart flinches.

"Is it me, or did he seem a little disappointed?"

See also: Dead Ringers, Festen, Face/Off

Don't see also: Rain Man

Pointless trivia: In July 1999, Geena Davis reached the semi-finals of the US Olympic Archery Trials.

fields.headline: The last chance saloon
fields.standfirst: It looks like a boiled sweet and is aimed at fiftysomethings, but at this price the Chrysler Neon has no rivals, says  Giles Smith
fields.trailText: It looks like a boiled sweet and is aimed at fiftysomethings, but at this price the Chrysler Neon has no rivals, says Giles Smith.
fields.body:
Say what you like about the Chrysler Neon, it's cheap. Also, for an American car, it's emphatically finless. Like so many vehicles in this rounded age - even, sad to say, ones designed and built in Illinois - the Neon has much in common with the outline of a boiled sweet.

But mostly it's cheap. In the UK, no 2.0 litre car in its class comes cheaper. It's a big-ish four-door car with a big-ish engine that can be bought for a little under £11,000, in basic form, which makes it, in its price range, the last chance saloon.

The Neon was the first car Chrysler launched in the UK, and it seems to have done its job in, as it were, setting down a marque. In the three years since then, 10,000 people have bought one and Chrysler has further sold 12,000 of its space bus, the Voyager. Meanwhile, Chrysler Jeep products have been nudging into the Range Rover market, making the unlikely transition from all- terrain combat vehicles to posh city run-abouts. (Jeeps seem to be popular with mothers who prefer to be bullet-proof during the school-run.)

Time, you might have thought, for Chrysler to capitalise on that performance and launch something risky and go-ahead, like a three-wheeler that uses rocket fuel or the world's first nuclear-powered convertible.

But that's not really what the legacy of Walter Percy Chrysler demands, connecting, as it does, more obviously with American ideals of affordability and the grand democratisation of driving: cheap cars running on cheap gas. So Chrysler chose to rework the Neon instead.

It has done this, it seems, in line with some very pertinent statistics about the 10,000 people who bought the first generation model. Apparently, the average Neon buyer to date is 53 years old, which is one of the reasons why you haven't seen the new car advertised in Loaded.

Arrestingly, 86% of Neon owners are married and 75% fall into the demographic subgroup known movingly as "empty-nesters" - people whose children have left home. Here, then, is a vehicle to capture the mood and needs of people who have recently discharged their major parental duties. It's an important niche that, up to now, has been principally the job of Rover to fulfil. Or, in certain extreme cases, Ferrari. But now Chrysler is lending a willing, transatlantic hand - and becoming thoroughly middle class and English in the process. You might purchase a Neon, these figures suggest, in the same quietly celebratory spirit in which you might book a short cruise, order a conservatory or arrange to re-turf the lawn.

Some traces of America remain. The gentle bong of the interior alarm that tells you you're not wearing your seat belt or that you are trying to leave without switching off the lights will be familiar to anyone who has hired a car in the US. Other faintly exotic foibles include the need to depress the clutch in order to get the engine to turn over and the button beside the ignition that you must push in order to remove the key. Otherwise, the Neon feels about as American as Newport Pagnell services.

For a vehicle designed to ferry you gently into retirement, the Neon looks pretty racey from the outside. It tips forward from the back, which makes it appear keen and feline, though this is an expectation it rather disappoints when you come to drive it and realise that the 2.0 litre engine will only pull you along politely and decorously.

First, however, on your way into the front seat, you should stop to applaud Chrysler's boldly retro persistence with a totally silent remote controlled door locking device. You press the button on the pad and nothing happens - no cocky wink from the indicators and no electronic belch, burble or yelp. It's the same when you lock up afterwards. The downside is you find yourself neurotically checking the door manually to be sure that the lock has actually engaged - which can defeat the whole remote-control idea. But your neighbours will be happier with you.

Generally it's the function of car re-thinks to be unashamedly cosmetic - the introduction of, say, a new gear-fob or a slightly squarer cigarette lighter serving as an excuse for an advertising blitz on the same old car with knobs on. On its way to offering what the manufacturers refer to as "a more mature overall package", the new Neon certainly has its share of these half-hearted twists. The badge on the front, for instance, now has a pair of long, eagle-like wings, in line with the recently up-dated global Chrysler logo. Are empty-nesters in the market for additional chrome detailing? I reckon that little additional feature could drag the average age of the customer down - who knows? - maybe all the way to 51.

But there's more room in the interior than there used to be and there are expensively researched gimmicks on board to make the car smoother than the original. The slightly more pricey LX version has part-leather seats and wood grain trim - hints of a world in which cars cost twice as much as this. These days even the personable but fundamentally tinny Ford Ka comes with power-steering, electric windows and a CD player: we are all executives now. Even so, the provision in the Neon seems bountiful.

Today, then, the cheap car; tomorrow the cheap petrol.

The lowdown

Chrysler Neon 2.0LX Price on the road: £13,495

Top speed: 124mph

0-62 mph: 10.8 seconds

Fuel consumption: 35.8mpg

On the stereo: Kiri Te Kanawa

At the wheel: Peter Alliss

En route for: the daughter's for Sunday lunch

fields.headline: Converting the facts
fields.trailText: John Vidal (Bowing before the weight of tradition, Saturday Review, 22 July ) asserts that the French revolutionaries instituted a 10-month calendar. The Republican year in fact contained 12 months.
fields.body:
John Vidal (Bowing before the weight of tradition, Saturday Review, 22 July ) asserts that the French revolutionaries instituted a 10-month calendar. The Republican year in fact contained 12 months. The remaining five days of the solar year (six in a leap year) became a series of Republican festivals. The calendar was in use until 1806.

The law was also applied locally with a certain amount of discretion. Newspapers could be sold on the tenth-day (the Republican equivalent of Sunday), but not fish, since this was associated with religious fasting. Perhaps such flexibility could be applied today: British beef flogged by the pound, French beans by the kilo?
Matthew Shaw
London
mjs110@yahoo.com

Can John Vidal have missed the point? By all means celebrate the diversity of measurement scales. Rejoice at the utility of some older measures. Three cheers for our ability to work happily and simultaneously in multiple scales.

But every boundary between these economies generates the kind of problem that the "standardising control freaks"attempt to address. You have to convert between the units of one into the units of the other. This is an opportunity for somebody to rip you off. Although it's more usual to effect such chicanery by rounding up or down, it's often the case that conversion warrants an "administration charge".
Paul Sampson
Newcastle upon Tyne
paul.sampson@tradezone.co.uk

fields.headline: Welcome words from free thinkers
fields.trailText: When you advise your readers to vote Conservative, says Ann Waters (Letters, July 22), she will start buying the Guardian. I would not buy any newspaper for advice on how to vote. I have a mind of my own. That is why I buy the Guardian.
fields.body:
When you advise your readers to vote Conservative, says Ann Waters (Letters, July 22), she will start buying the Guardian. I would not buy any newspaper for advice on how to vote. I have a mind of my own. That is why I buy the Guardian.
Phyllis A Holroyd
Fareham, Hants

 Readers of the rightwing press often preface their remarks with "I must confess" I read the Daily Telegraph, etc. Guardian readers are proud to say "I read the Guardian". Our loyalty is enhanced by your recent policy of wherever possible sourcing your quotes and articles.
Patricia Rowan
Ross-on-Wye, Herefordshire

 The danger for Ann Waters is that if she continues to read the Guardian, she may actually come to believe that she has a free choice at election time, rather than having to vote for the party her newspaper dictates.
Dave Neale
Wakefield
dave.neale@btinternet.com

 Ann Waters should be sure that if Messrs Hague and Portillo did form a government the Guardian would be tough on conservativism and the causes of conservativism.
David Prothero
Harpenden, Herts
davidprothero@hotmail.com

 Ann Waters's spoof letter, where she pretends to be a Telegraph reader pleased with the Guardian for slagging off the government, is a perfect example of New Labour trickiness. As an old Labour supporter of many years, I can't tell you how relieved I was when, some months after New Labour were elected and euphoria had begun to give way to disillusionment, the Guardian re-engaged its critical faculties.
J Hewson
Berkhamsted, Herts
jeanhewson@psychol.org.uk

 Please think carefully about publishing congratulatory letters from Telegraph readers (or Mail/Sun readers, for that matter), if only out of concern for the blood pressure of your readers who would still prefer an imperfect Labour government to an extremist Tory one.
Jim Caris
London
j.caris@virgin.net

fields.headline: Debts and high living
fields.trailText: It cost £500m for the G7 countries to agree that they might get around to fulfilling their commitment to cancel £100bn of the debts owed by the developing countries.
fields.body:
It cost £500m for the G7 countries to agree that they might get around to fulfilling their commitment to cancel £100bn of the debts owed by the developing countries, so that the developing countries might afford a modicum of housing, education and health provision (Not a crumb from the G7 table, July 22). Include the cost of the Birmingham and Cologne summits, and we have quite a large proportion of that debt squandered in high living.

Add the fact that the cost of running No 10 has risen from £6.4m a year to £10.4m during Tony Blair's tenure, while old age pensions have this year risen by 75p a week, and it is clear that we must devise a way of electing people who wish to serve, not be served.
Eileen Noakes
Harbertonford, Devon
eileen.noakes@talk21.com

 There have been complaints about those who have questioned the appropriateness of the media response to the death of Sarah Payne. The evil of paedophiles has been stressed and is something that most of us agree with.

But isn't it a greater evil that 19,000 children die each day because of third world debt? At least the tragedy and horror of Sarah's death has been acknowledged.

These 19,000 die unknown except by their families and unacknowledged by us in the rich countries who cause their death. Meanwhile our leaders enjoy their sushi.
Lindsey Pearson
Leeds
Lindrew@pearley.fsnet.co.uk

"They have no bread." "Then let them eat cake." Marie- Antoinette, 1789. "They have no food." "Then let them have computers." G7 leaders, 22 July 2000. Plus ça change...
Antony Dowd
Nottingham

webTitle: In defence of the D notice

fields.headline: In defence of the D notice
fields.trailText: Rear Admiral Nick Wilkinson writes: It is not for me to comment on the accuracy and balance of the criticisms made by a UN special rapporteur (UN report scorns UK human rights record, July 20). But his comments about the D notice system do require some factual correction.
fields.body:
It is not for me, as the secretary of the independent and media-heavy defence, press and broadcasting advisory committee, to comment on the accuracy and balance of the criticisms made by a UN special rapporteur (UN report scorns UK human rights record, July 20). But his comments about the D notice system do require some factual correction.

Far from being "incompatible with media freedom", one of the functions of this voluntary system is to enable editors, broadcasters and others to publish stories about national security matters, having decided whether to exclude a few specific details and after taking into account the guidance in the five short standing advisory notices. The system is not allowed to "stifle debate about politically sensitive matters" per se, a comment which also implies limited acquaintance with Britain's editors and publishers.

It is unfortunate that before writing his report, neither the rapporteur, Abid Hussein, nor any of his assistants, contacted the D notice secretary for information, nor apparently attempted to verify how the system actually does work by looking at our website (www.dnotice.org.uk).
Rear Admiral Nick Wilkinson
Secretary
Defence, press and broadcasting advisory committee

fields.trailText: DD Guttenplan writes about anti-semitism entrenched in Westminster and Whitehall around the time of the second world war (Right little, tight little island, Saturday Review, July 22).
fields.body:
DD Guttenplan writes about anti-semitism entrenched in Westminster and Whitehall around the time of the second world war (Right little, tight little island, Saturday Review, July 22). Yet if any politician or civil servant wanted to know how Jews were faring in Hitler's Germany, there was a famous British reference book that would tell them. There was nothing unequivocal about the following: "Within Germany itself, Adolf Hitler has achieved his aim... by ruthless oppression of the Jews and of all political opponents, who have been thrown into concentration camps where many of them have been beaten, robbed, and murdered". These words appeared in the Children's Encyclopedia (1939 edition).
Sandy Mullay
Edindurgh
ajmullay@yahoo.co.uk

 A pivotal sequence was indeed cut from my film, I Was a Slave Labourer, following the threat of an injunction by Prof Hans Mommsen - author of a major report on Volkswagen and one of Germany's most prominent historians (Comment, July 19). However the cut was made immediately prior to the second German broadcast on January 9 2000 - not November of last year.

For the November broadcasts the dramatic scene featuring Prof Mommsen's violent outburst at Oxford's Centre for Hebrew and Jewish Studies, had already passed legal scrutiny for transmission by Arte in Germany and France. BBC2 had already screened the film, without cuts, in October.
Luke Holland
London
lukeholland@usa.net

fields.headline: Now let's nail Railtrack
fields.trailText: John Prescott's announcement of billions in new public money for the railways is, hopefully, the biggest nail yet in the coffin of privatisation (Prescott's £180bn traffic upheaval, July 21).
fields.body:
John Prescott's announcement of billions in new public money for the railways is, hopefully, the biggest nail yet in the coffin of privatisation (Prescott's £180bn traffic upheaval, July 21). It blows out of the water the Tory argument that private sector companies would get all the investment funds they needed from the "market" and public support would disappear.

The next step should be the abolition of Railtrack's plc status and its conversion to a non-profit making trust, with a new chief executive and directors appointed by the Strategic Rail Authority, followed by the booting out of the more useless train operating companies. With any luck we might then be on the way to building a half-decent, semi-public railway service.
Robin Wendt
Chester

Your analysis of the government's 10-year transport plan is not entirely fair on Mr Prescott and his colleagues. You say the plan relies "heavily on grand figures and targets" but is "short on detail, particularly on what the government will do in the next few years".

You might at least have credited the government with those announcements that were more tangible. In particular, you failed completely to report the commitment to give more support for community transport, especially in remote rural areas, and the extension of fuel duty rebate to a sector which is increasingly being seen as having a key role to play in extending the reach of public transport to areas where the large commercial concerns are not very active.

The government's target of 500 new community transport schemes in three years is certainly achievable if the money is made available, and could have a dramatic impact on provision both in rural areas and those parts of our towns and cities that suffer greatly from economic and social deprivation.

You may be right to highlight the shortcomings in the 10 year plan but at least give the government credit when it is due.
Dai Powell
Chair, Community Transport Association

Your report perpetuates the trendy mistake of confusing road pricing with congestion charging (Ministers give green light to city trams, July 21). If you are charged to use a road or to enter a city, that is road pricing, and is designed to tilt the balance of costs in favour of public transport. Congestion charging is when a meter in your car starts charging you when you hit congested traffic. Once considered, then rejected, for Cambridge, its likely outcome was increased rat-runs, queue jumping, or, most likely, many quick u-turns to avoid the jam.

The former is an economic measure of arguable benefit; the latter isn't.
Andrew Probert
Cambridge

 Scope, the national disability charity, is disappointed to see little mention of the importance of an accessible transport system in the coverage of John Prescott's transport strategy. If the UK's 8.6m disabled people are to play a full and equal role in modern society, surely ensuring they are able to use Britain's transport system must be a priority?

A recent survey for us showed that 74% of businesses and services pose entry problems for disabled people. Many participants commented on the difficulties they faced just simply getting to theatres and cafes, let alone getting in. The lack of access to public transport means that disabled people often have to rely on taxis, which is inevitably very expensive.
James Ford
Campaigns officer, Scope

If you are charged to use a road or to enter a city, that is road pricing, and is designed to tilt the balance of costs in favour of public transport. Congestion charging is when a meter in your car starts charging you when you hit congested traffic. Once considered, then rejected, for Cambridge, its likely outcome was increased rat-runs, queue jumping, or, most likely, many quick u-turns to avoid the jam.
