fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours thumped down the 18th fairway, chipped to within 10 feet of the flag and slotted home for an easy birdie
fields.trailText: Gerard Houllier has quashed speculation that Michael Owen is set for a £26m move to Real Madrid. The Liverpool manager said: "As far as I know they have made no contact with us and there's no chance of Michael going to Madrid."
fields.body:
Gerard Houllier has quashed speculation that Michael Owen is set for a £26m move to Real Madrid. The Liverpool manager said: "As far as I know they have made no contact with us and there's no chance of Michael going to Madrid."

Bordeaux are resigned to losing Sylvain Wiltord - and might offload him to Arsenal in a swap deal for Kanu, reports Planet Football. But Internazionale are also interested in the French striker, and could offer Ivan Zamorano as a makeweight to tempt Bordeaux.

But who would replace Zamorano? According to the Mirror, Internazionale are eyeing a £30m double swoop for Robbie Keane and Savo Milosevic.

Meanwhile, AC Milan have made Real Madrid midfielder Fernando Redondo their number one target, according to Planet Football. They say the 31 year-old Argentinean is "reportedly valued at a cut-price £10m."

Fulham have launched a £4m bid for George Weah. Managing director Michael Fiddy said: "Initial steps have been taken but the player is still contracted to AC Milan. We will now be discussing matters to see if he is interested in coming to Fulham."

Dele Adebola's £1.2m transfer from Birmingham to Primera Liga side Las Palmas will be completed today.

Crystal Palace manager Steve Coppell wants to bring 22 year-old Chinese defender Sun Jihai back to Selhurst Park.

Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale has hinted that Michael Duberry could leave for Charlton in a £3.5m deal - providing David O'Leary can find a replacement.

fields.headline: Blockbuster pilots movies on-demand
fields.trailText: In a move that may herald the future of home entertainment, video giant Blockbuster has announced a new deal which will allow movie fans in select US cities to access - from their TV or computer - the movies they want when they want them
fields.body:
In a move that may herald the future of home entertainment, video giant Blockbuster has announced a new deal which will allow movie fans in select US cities to access - from their TV or computer - the movies they want when they want them.

According to E Online, to take advantage of the service, prospective users must install a set-top box and a high-speed internet connection and may be charged either a monthly fee, or payment per movie. If the pilot scheme goes well, Blockbuster says it will extend the on-demand service to other cities in America, and even to international markets.

The announcement comes after a series of moves by the video store to reposition itself in a movie world of fast-changing technology - last year, Blockbuster signed deals with America Online web service and the pay-per-view channel DirecTV. "We said a year ago that we would transition Blockbuster from a retail powerhouse to a multichannel powerhouse in the delivery of home entertainment," said John Antioco, chairman and CEO of Blockbuster. "This is the deal that will make it happen."

webTitle: Maze releases: Michael Stone walks free

fields.headline: Maze releases: Michael Stone walks free
fields.standfirst: Memories of the Maze
fields.trailText: Loyalist assassin Michael Stone was among the first prisoners released this week under a scheme which will see the high security Maze prison virtually emptied.
fields.body:
Loyalist assassin Michael Stone was among the first prisoners released this week under a scheme which will see the high security Maze prison virtually emptied.

Supporters cheered him as he left the prison this morning.

The Ulster Freedom Fighters member killed three people in a gun and grenade attack in a Belfast graveyard at the funeral of three IRA members killed in Gibraltar in March 1988.

Some of Northern Ireland's most infamous paramilitary killers are being freed today under the terms of the Good Friday Agreement.

The other paramilitary prisoners set to benefit from the release scheme this week include:

 James McArdle, who has served two years of a 25-year sentence for planting the London Docklands bomb which marked the ending of the IRA ceasefire in February 1996. The attack killed two people and injured 40 others.

 Sean Kelly, who was part of the IRA team behind the fish shop bombing in Belfast's Shankill Road in October 1993 which killed nine Protestant civilians as well as his comrade, Thomas Begley.

 Torrens Knight, who was part of a UFF hit squad who killed seven people - six Catholics and one Protestant - in the "Trick or Treat massacre" in the Rising Sun pub in Greysteel, County Londonderry, exactly one week after the Shankill bombing.

The prisoner releases have prompted protests from Conservative and unionist critics of the Good Friday Agreement.

Ulster Unionist MP Jeffrey Donaldson said the release of around 80 republicans and loyalists was "deeply frustrating" for those who had had relatives killed or maimed by the prisoners.

"People are deeply depressed and frustrated that the paramilitaries have reaped the benefits of the agreement without a single bullet or a single ounce of explosives being decommissioned," the Lagan Valley MP said.

"They are also concerned that the paramilitary groups are continuing to exert influence and engage in violent activities."

Democratic Unionist Party justice spokesman Ian Paisley Junior laid the blame for the releases with Northern Ireland First Minister David Trimble because of his support for the Good Friday Agreement.

The North Antrim MLA said he was "utterly disgusted that the only tangible legacy David Trimble has left Northern Ireland is the mass release of killers on to the province's streets".

The Conservatives' Northern Ireland spokesman Andrew MacKay also claimed in the absence of any decommissioning, it was wrong for the Government to go ahead with the prisoner release scheme.

The shadow Northern Ireland secretary argued: "Peter Mandelson should not release these prisoners until a credible and verifiable process of putting all illegal arms and explosives beyond use has actually begun.

"The Government was prepared to let the timetable for decommissioning slip. It should be prepared to do the same on the release of prisoners."

However, the prisoner releases were defended by the Progressive Unionists who are the political representatives of the loyalist group, the Ulster Volunteer Force.

East Belfast Assemblyman David Ervine, who was sentenced to 11 years in 1975 for transporting a loyalist bomb in a stolen car, said while he understood people's concerns, the scheme was for the greater good.

The Progressive Unionist MLA told BBC1's Breakfast with Frost programme: "There are hundreds and hundreds and hundreds of people who are alive that might be dead were it not for changing circumstances in Northern Ireland.

"Next week for the first time in my lifetime, there will be no political prisoners in Northern Ireland. Now that has got to be a watershed."

fields.headline: Why women make better publishers
fields.trailText: It used to be the profession for gentlemen. Now it's women's work. Two publishers are in the limelight at the moment: Victoria Barnsley who, having built up Fourth Estate, is taking over as CEO at HarperCollins; and Alexandra Pringle, editor in chief at Bloomsbury. I knew both as students...
fields.body:
It used to be the profession for gentlemen. Now it's women's work. Two publishers are in the limelight at the moment: Victoria Barnsley who, having built up Fourth Estate, is taking over as CEO at HarperCollins; and Alexandra Pringle, editor in chief at Bloomsbury.

I knew Barnsley and Pringle as students. As an undergraduate Vicky was difficult, as I recall. It was the late 70s. She was extremely smart and deep into film theory, which I didn't much like and didn't entirely understand. She was also dangerous. In collaboration with one of my colleagues (the rat) she wrote an underground satire on the department: who was sleeping with whom, who was a lush, and worse. I was very polite to Ms Barnsley thereafter.

With the same colleague she started up Junction Books in Clapham in 1980. I did a book for them. It was fun. Junction was a cheap, cheerful, go-ahead outfit. What did it for them was the Falklands war. They put out a book by a serviceman who was killed. The Tinker Letters sold massively.

When they strike it rich, publishers expand fast. But cash flows back slowly: from author's advance to books in the shop takes on average four years. Success and Margaret Thatcher's high interest rates killed Junction Books.

They went under and rose again from receivership in 1984 as Fourth Estate - an older and wiser firm. Barnsley was now in charge. She is not, I think, a great originating publisher but brilliant (or lucky) at spotting long-shot winners and buying overseas rights (most famously Longitude, The Perfect Storm and E Annie Proulx). Her business style is force 10, blow-the-man-down. I put money into her firm and shall get a bit out, I hope.

Pringle has a quieter style. I knew her as a graduate when she was doing a thesis on Rebecca West. She was working, on the side, for Virago - a hand-to-mouth firm run by women and dedicated to reprinting forgotten great books by women.

She once told me the pittance that Virago paid her. You couldn't have kept a hamster alive on it. She went on to a regular job at Hamish Hamilton. Then, after one of their cleansing bloodbaths, Pringle became a literary agent. Famously, she saw a bestseller in Amanda Foreman's PhD thesis on Georgiana, Duchess of Devonshire.

Pringle acted for me and secured terrific deals with Kate Jones at Viking-Penguin and Rebecca Wilson at Weidenfeld. I was (by hamster standards) rich, thanks to Alexandra. When she left literary agency to succeed Liz Calder at Bloomsbury she wrote me a letter saying that she was sorry to move on but it was, after all, the best job in British publishing.

As an author, I'm contracted to do a book (on booze, by October!) for Rebecca Nicolson, whose Short Books will hit the shops next spring. At OUP, I've done four books in the last six years for Judith Luna. And I owe her boss, Kim Scott Walwyn, a big companion to popular fiction.

Petticoat government the Victorians called it. There are a number of reasons why women rule 21st century British publishing. It has always been a "career open to talent". Most of these women started as entry-level gofers: stuffing jiffy bags and asking men in Savile Row suits if they took milk and sugar.

There are other reasons for the rise of the publishing superwomen. Creative publishing is a mixture of nurturing and nagging. Authors are babies. Women handle them well.

Above all, publishing is about making the right difficult choices. Look at a woman and a man in a clothes shop. The woman picks the article up and "thinks" about it. The man can't wait to get outside into the real world and "do" something.

I miss gentlemanly publishing - those long expensive lunches, the old boys' network, the patriarchy. But matriarchy works better.

The big issue at the moment in the British book trade is whether Waterstone's will go down pulling the whole industry with it. My solution? Let the women take over.

fields.headline: Obituary: James Barrie
fields.standfirst: Publisher who put folios before farming
fields.trailText: James Barrie, who has died aged 86, was one of those adventuresome but inadequately funded publishers who set up shop in postwar London. He was more obviously commercial than some of his contemporaries, and his firm published Herman Wouk's first novel, Aurora Dawn (but, sadly, not his next, The Caine Mutiny). Barrie also published a collection of LP Hartley's stories, although his novels, including The Go-Between, were published elsewhere.
fields.body:
James Barrie, who has died aged 86, was one of those adventuresome but inadequately funded publishers who set up shop in postwar London. He was more obviously commercial than some of his contemporaries, and his firm published Herman Wouk's first novel, Aurora Dawn (but, sadly, not his next, The Caine Mutiny). Barrie also published a collection of LP Hartley's stories, although his novels, including The Go-Between, were published elsewhere.

Barrie admitted to missing one of the great successes of postwar publishing, Paul Brickhill's The Dam Busters. When he complained that his secretary was coming in late to work, she confessed that she had been staying up typing her boyfriend's manuscript. Barrie failed to ask what it was.

By the mid-1950s, James Barrie Books merged with the Rockliff Publishing Corporation, which was known for its theatre list, to become Barrie & Rockliff. Within a few years, it had taken under its wing other imprints, such as Hammond, Hammond and the Cresset Press. Finally, the firm acquired PG Wodehouse's publishers, Herbert Jenkins Ltd. In the 1980s, it became part of a larger group, Century Hutchinson, which, in turn, merged with the Random House group. Nonetheless, the name of Barrie survived in the imprint Barrie & Jenkins, although the founder had long since left the firm.

Barrie was the son of Charles Barrie, a journalist on the Morning Post. He was named after his great uncle and godfather, the playwright JM Barrie, creator of Peter Pan. After John's father was killed on the first day of the battle of the Somme in 1916, JM became his guardian, paying for his education at St Paul's school.

He discovered a love of reading at an early age and, despite a family wish that he should pursue a "safe" career - agriculture was mentioned - he went to work on the literary journal John O'London's Weekly, and then the Sunday Express, where he wrote a gossip column about books and authors. He got to know the aspiring paperback publisher, Allen Lane, the founder of Penguin, and his claim to have suggested André Maurois's Ariel as one of the first six Penguin titles was never refuted.

Barrie next had a spell with the literary agent Curtis Brown, managing the sale of serials to newspapers and magazines. The full Curtis Brown stable of authors then included Winston Churchill, who put steel into the young manager's negotiating muscle when Barrie told him that an American magazine had made an offer for one of his articles. Churchill rejected the offer as derisory; Barry returned to the magazine - and got the offer doubled.

During the second world war, Barrie served with the London Scottish, his father's regiment. He then tried his hand as an executive with an Australian magazine group before, in 1947, setting up his own publishing house. He struggled on for a dozen years, but kept in touch with old friends in Fleet Street. In 1959, he rejoined the Express, working on the management side of Beaverbrook Newspapers, where he stayed until 1979.

Barrie retired to Polruan, on the Fowey estuary in Cornwall, and was clerk to the Polruan town trust. His first wife, by whom he had three daughters, was Nesta Reid. After her death in 1981, he married Marjorie Caton Jones, who, with his daughters, survives him.

 James Matthew Barrie, publisher, born July 29 1913; died May 2 2000

webTitle: Carlton's new boss seeks Granada link

fields.headline: Carlton's new boss seeks Granada link
fields.trailText: Carlton's new chief executive, Gerry Murphy, made it clear yesterday that the company would prefer it if the ITV network were carved up between itself and its main competitor, Granada.
fields.body:
Carlton's new chief executive, Gerry Murphy, made it clear yesterday that the company would prefer it if the ITV network were carved up between itself and its main competitor, Granada.

Mr Murphy, the new head of the television group, told The Guardian that "the important outcome of the current round of ITV consolidation was ... a workable result. That, in all likelihood, is a partnership between Granada and Carlton".

Mr Murphy said that franchises should remain within the "current ITV family", a rebuff to overseas groups such as Bertelsmann and RTL who have been circling United News & Media.

United effectively put up for sale last Friday its three franchises - Meridian, Anglia and HTV - as well as its 35% stake in Channel 5.

The rapid appointment of Mr Murphy, the former chief executive of freight distribution group NFC, will underline Carlton's commitment to play a full role in the negotiations over the next two weeks, the outcome of which is likely to be the winnowing of the number of companies controlling ITV from three to two.

Mr Murphy, 44, will fill the post vacated by Steven Cain, who left the media concern shortly after the merger with United was announced last November. Under the proposed merger he would have lost his job to United chief executive Lord Hollick.

The introduction of Mr Murphy to Carlton chairman Michael Green was made by BBC chairman Sir Christopher Bland, who used to occupy the same role at NFC.

In February, the freight business was merged with rival Ocean and Mr Murphy stepped aside, leaving him free to take up the reins at Carlton with immediate effect. A Carlton insider said he had been lined up as "Plan B" depending on the outcome of the competition commission inquiry into the United deal.

Mr Murphy will be thrown straight into the ITV merger negotiations. Conversations will begin this week between Carlton bosses and their opposite numbers at United and Granada to work out how best the consolidation of ITV might be achieved.

"All media businesses face dramatic change," Mr Murphy said. "Carlton is very well placed, and I'm really looking forward to working with Michael and his team to realise the company's full potential."

Carlton pulled out of its merger with United after trade secretary Stephen Byers demanded the sale of the Meridian licence as a condition of the deal 10 days ago.

On Friday, United raised the for sale sign over either the entire business or its television interests, and Carlton insiders indicated that the company may be content to pick up HTV, leaving Granada with Meridian and Anglia.

Mr Murphy joined NFC in 1995 from the Dublin-based food business, Greencore, where he was chief executive. Before that he worked at what was then known as Grand Metropolitan - now Diageo -for 12 years.

Mr Murphy, 44, will fill the post vacated by Steven Cain, who left the media concern shortly after the merger with United was announced last November. Under the proposed merger he would have lost his job to United chief executive Lord Hollick. The introduction of Mr Murphy to Carlton chairman Michael Green was made by BBC chairman Sir Christopher Bland, who used to occupy the same role at NFC. In February, the freight business was merged with rival Ocean and Mr Murphy stepped aside, leaving him free to take up the reins at Carlton with immediate effect. A Carlton insider said he had been lined up as "Plan B" depending on the outcome of the competition commission inquiry into the United deal. Mr Murphy will be thrown straight into the ITV merger negotiations. Conversations will begin this week between Carlton bosses and their opposite numbers at United and Granada to work out how best the consolidation of ITV might be achieved. "All media businesses face dramatic change," Mr Murphy said. "Carlton is very well placed, and I'm really looking forward to working with Michael and his team to realise the company's full potential." Carlton pulled out of its merger with United after trade secretary Stephen Byers demanded the sale of the Meridian licence as a condition of the deal 10 days ago. On Friday, United raised the for sale sign over either the entire business or its television interests, and Carlton insiders indicated that the company may be content to pick up HTV, leaving Granada with Meridian and Anglia. Mr Murphy joined NFC in 1995 from the Dublin-based food business, Greencore, where he was chief executive. Before that he worked at what was then known as Grand Metropolitan - now Diageo -for 12 years.

webTitle: Leader: Exposing paedophiles is no protection

fields.headline: A tabloid horror story
fields.standfirst:
Exposing paedophiles is no protection

More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText: The News of the World believes it knows better than parliament, police or probation officers. In the wake of the murder of eight-year-old Sarah Payne, it has decided to reveal the identity of all 110,000 known child sex offenders.
fields.body:
The News of the World believes it knows better than parliament, police or probation officers. In the wake of the murder of eight-year-old Sarah Payne, it has decided to reveal the identity of all 110,000 known child sex offenders. It began yesterday with the photographs of 49 of them and the towns or districts where they are living. At that rate it will take them 40 years to reveal the identities of all existing offenders, let alone new ones. Some protection. And this ignores the awkward fact that the News of the World will not know the vast majority of offenders and would have to break the law to obtain their names.

The tabloid tried desperately to dress this up as a child protection campaign, rather than a cheap publicity stunt to increase falling sales. It talked of the right of every parent to know where paedophiles are living. But this difficult issue was debated at length in 1997, when the paedophile register was introduced. With the consent of the police and probation services - and even hardline Michael Howard - it was agreed that disclosure should be confined to people who needed to know (headteachers, youth group organisers, community leaders) but that in exceptional circumstances the community would be warned. The reason for these restrictions was the vigilante action, which had followed earlier revelations of paedophiles' whereabouts. This had not just led to several mistaken attacks on wrongly identified suspects or homes (including an arson attack in which an innocent 14-year-old was killed), but had prompted several paedophiles to go to ground, making it much more difficult for the police to monitor and track them. Far from increasing child protection, it had made them more vulnerable.

Lamely, having set out six stark pages of brutal mixed up facts, the tabloid urged its readers not to indulge in vigilante activity. That's as good as giving children matches, lighter fuel and tinder, but telling them not to start a fire. A better informed public would provide more protection to children, but yesterday's hysterical outpourings will only have increased public anxieties, rather than reduced them. The chances of a child being abducted and killed by a stranger are remote: about seven a year compared to the 80 killed by family members. Child sexual abuse has a similar pattern. We do need to be vigilant, but the last thing we need is more vigilantes.

fields.headline: Livingstone plans £7.50 traffic charge
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: In a key test of how cities tackle congestion, the mayor of London, Ken Livingstone, is planning to introduce congestion charging of up to £7.50 a day from 2002 and to widen the area in which the charging will be enforced.
fields.body:
In a key test of how cities tackle congestion, the mayor of London, Ken Livingstone, is planning to introduce congestion charging of up to £7.50 a day from 2002 and to widen the area in which the charging will be enforced.

Mr Livingstone is about to issue a consultation paper setting out his plans for charging, backed by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, who sees it as the first step in a plan which could be copied by at least another 12 cities in Britain over the next few years.

London will become the test bed for a scheme which will be initially as unpopular as parking meters when they were first introduced in Britain, in Leicester nearly 40 years ago.

Mr Livingstone is likely to go much further than his original plan, which helped him secure an overwhelming majority in his election as mayor.

The area to be covered is now said to stretch from Battersea Bridge in the west to Tower Bridge in the east.

This four by two mile rectangular area covers parts of Wandsworth, Notting Hill Gate, Chelsea, Bayswater, Westminster, the West End, Islington, Edgware Road, Marylebone, the Elephant and Castle, and Southwark.

A number of London boroughs, including Westminster, Kensington and Chelsea, and Wandsworth have already expressed strong opposition, although they have no veto on the plan since Mr Livingstone has been given considerable powers over transport, with a budget from the government of £3.2bn over the next three years. His plan could only be overturned by the new Greater London assembly.

The £7.50 daily charge on which Mr Livingstone may be prepared to negotiate, will cost all motorists coming into central London an average of an extra £2,000 a year.

Residents living within the rectangular box will almost certainly have to be issued with permits excluding them from the charge. Many already hold permits for residential on-street parking.

The charges are only expected to apply during peak hours like parking meter charges and will not be enforced at weekends.

Revenue will go to improving public transport in London. A large proportion will be needed for the administrative costs of the scheme.

Mr Livingstone is still considering what method to use to collect charges. He is thought to favour a system in which permits would be attached to car windscreens. Congestion charging would provide more jobs for traffic wardens, who would police the scheme.

The government's view is that if congestion charging is introduced in London other cities will gradually follow. Some have expressed an interest and have carried out pilot schemes.

The first batch of applications is due to be received by the Department of Transport in the autumn. Mr Prescott's transport plan published last week envisages that in 10 years, 80 cities will have congestion or workplace charging.

webTitle: Analysis: How Blair and the American right are both promoting education

fields.headline: In the know
fields.standfirst: Education, education, education is as much a mantra for the American right as it is for Blair - both are promoting the joys of self-realisation
fields.trailText: Education, education, education is as much a mantra for the American right as it is for Blair - both are promoting the joys of self-realisation
fields.body:
What could Tony Blair and Gordon Brown have in common with George W Bush, the American presidential contender? The answer is education and, counter-intuitive as it sounds, a kind of egalitarianism. Social democracy and Republican individualism converge at the chalkface in pursuit of equality of opportunity.

We know about New Labour's neo-egalitarianism. Political realism (as interpreted by Philip Gould) says that taxes and benefits cannot be used to redistribute income. Instead, low incomes are to be combated by raising school attainment and college enrolment - in a knowledge economy you need more people with the knowledge.

Mr Bush is an egalitarian of sorts because he has to be. A tenet of the American right, especially its Christian fundamentalist element, is individual self-realisation. Its rock is equality of opportunity - to sin, be redeemed, make a million bucks. Education plays a major part in that, even if the schools can't teach Darwin. So spiritual renewal (plus all its pro-family attachments) becomes the friend of social progress.

That is a severe reduction of a subtle argument advanced in a new book* which says with aplomb that "the egalitarian tradition in the United States is alive and healthy" - despite growing income inequality. The yen for equality is as American as apple pie, says economic historian and Nobel winner Robert Fogel. He sees successive revolutions in religious and social sentiment since the 18th century - awakenings is the term he uses - which powered reform legislation on public health, income distribution and workers' rights, the New Deal, Great Society and all.

The 20th century saw huge improvements in the quality of life of ordinary people. The mean height of American men rose by 7cm between 1910 and the 80s. Life expectancy, which fell during industrialisation in the 19th century, has since pushed on and up. Recent years have seen a fourth great awakening, a phase of religious intensification which started in the late 50s when church membership began to grow across all denominations. From the mid 60s on, growth has been concentrated on the "enthusiastic" churches. By the 90s charismatic, pentecostal, evangelical and similar congregations had 60m members, a third of the US electorate. These have become the bases of the Christian coalition, pro- family, anti-abortion, keen on prayer in state schools, antagonistic to welfare spending and instigators of the tax revolt that began in California in the late 70s.

But Professor Fogel argues that this ostensibly rightwing formation has more in common with liberalism than either side recognises. Material deprivation remains but increasingly they both have to address another dimension of inequality, to do with "spiritual equity". This is culture, knowledge, attitude - human capital, to use the economists' phrase. Liberals and the religious right can both line up behind the project of seeking to maximise life chances, notably through education. "For those in poverty, particularly the young, education that provides the technical and spiritual (immaterial) endowments needed for successful competition in the rapidly changing economy is a necessary condition for self-realisation."

Given his record as governor of Texas, Mr Bush might well sign up for that. In the Fogel argument the right has to give on who pays - government, mostly. Liberals will have to give up their antagonism to what he calls the spiritual dimension, including pro-family policies.

We have all got more time for life's "immaterial" dimension. In 1880, four-fifths of the time left after life's necessities of sleeping, eating etc were attended to was spent earning a living. Today the lion's share of such "discretionary time" is available for leisure and it is going to grow, as the chart shows. Abundant leisure time will promote the search for deeper understanding of life's meaning - fuelling the religious impulse but also freeing people for voluntary work, for example, in schools.

That could sound panglossian. Professor Fogel does not address the problem of how human capital gets reproduced unfairly between generations. The Fogel call for spending on education to expand to 12% of GDP is nothing short of revolutionary. His attempt to argue that Americans will have to get to grips with "international inequity" rings hollow as a Republican-controlled Congress further shrinks American contributions to multilateral bodies.

Yet his figures for the expansion of free non-work time hold on this side of the Atlantic. Although we would not use his "spiritual" phraseology, his attempt to identify culture, belief and knowledge as the well springs of equality rings Blairite bells. "Self-realisation is not something that can be provided to the weak by the strong; rather it involves individual choice. However, choices made and the range of available opportunity depend critically on how well endowed an individual is with spiritual resources. The transfer of spiritual resources begins at very early ages and takes place largely outside the market place. It is therefore necessary to develop forms of intervention that make it possible to remedy the maldistribution of spiritual resources early in life." It could almost be a quote from a Gordon Brown speech extolling such (still tiny) Labour initiatives as Sure Start for under-fives from poor families.

*Robert Fogel, The Fourth Great Awakening (University of Chicago Press)

fields.headline: Memories of the Maze
fields.standfirst: With its hunger strikes, sectarian murders and spectacular escapes, the Maze became a powerful symbol of Northern Ireland's 'Troubles'. As the infamous H-Blocks are finally closed down this week,  John Mullin  talks to some of the men who spent years inside them
fields.trailText: With its hunger strikes, sectarian murders and spectacular escapes, the Maze became a powerful symbol of Northern Ireland's 'Troubles'. As the infamous H-Blocks are finally closed down this week,  John Mullin  talks to some of the men who spent years inside them.
fields.body:
On day 68, Laurence McKeown needed to go to the toilet. He knew immediately what it meant. His first bowel movement in eight weeks signalled that his death was at hand. He had noticed it happening with the others, and knew he had at most two days left to live.

McKeown was 24, and had been lucky. He was 6ft 2in, but weighed less than 11 stone when he started his protest; with almost no body fat, few toxins leaked into his body to destroy his kidneys, and he relied on muscle tissue for energy. He managed to keep drinking water all the way and had remained lucid throughout.

He had suffered none of the pain which had racked Martin Hurson, 27, who was convulsing so severely before he succumbed - after 46 days - that two men had struggled to hold him down on his hospital bed.

McKeown's final wish was to bow out like Tom McElwee, 23, who was smoking a cigarette and chatting about inviting his Protestant neighbours to his wedding just before he passed away. He had lasted 65 days.

Ten fellow IRA prisoners had already died, and after an hour in the toilets McKeown returned to bed, exhausted. He apologised to his mother, never a republican, and lapsed into unconsciousness.

The IRA hunger strikes of 1981 were a turning point at the Maze - and also in the Troubles, because the story of the Maze is the story of the Irish conflict itself. Nothing was to be the same again, in any area of life in Northern Ireland. Republicans lost the battle for political status at the prison, yet were somehow to emerge even stronger.

The Maze itself, still known among republicans and loyalists by its original name, Long Kesh, was to change radically. Gradually, terrorists won the political status they had been denied, via a combination of threats - 29 prison officers have been murdered during the Troubles - and mind games. In just four days, however, an era will draw to a close as more than 80 terrorists walk to freedom through a rickety turnstile that leads into the Maze car park. These men will include some of Northern Ireland's most notorious killers. Among them will be Sean Kelly, who murdered nine Protestants in the IRA bombing of the Shankill Road in Belfast less than seven years ago, and Torrens Knight, guilty of 11 murders, including seven in the trick-or-treat Hallowe'en shootings at the Rising Sun pub in Greysteel, County Londonderry, which were a response to the Shankill slaughter.

Also walking out of the 130-acre jail will be three of the IRA's south Armagh sniper unit, who in February 1997 shot dead Stephen Restorick, the last British soldier murdered in Northern Ireland, in February 1997. Believed guilty of eight more murders, they smiled as they were jailed last year; they understood exactly what the early release scheme meant.

Michael Stone, the wild-eyed loyalist, will precede them today. He was jailed in 1988 for six murders, including those of three mourners who died in his gun and grenade attack on the funerals of the trio of IRA volunteers shot dead by the SAS in Gibraltar.

And so a jail which once housed 1,700 men will on Friday be left with precisely 16 prisoners, guarded by a staff of 750 (whittled down by 300 through a voluntary redundancy package). Most of those remaining officers will pick up their goodbye cheques within two months, and then the last inmates will be transferred to nearby Maghaberry Prison.

The men from the Maze are returning to a world transformed from the one they left. McKeown is 43 now, a father of two daughters, Caoilfhioinn, four, and one-year-old Orlaith. He is now almost twice the weight he was during his hunger strike, but is still lean. He owes his survival to his mother, Margaret, who intervened when he lapsed into unconsciousness on the 70th day of his fast. His was the second family to insist that their son was treated, and he feels no guilt.

Jailed for life for the attempted murder of an RUC man and several bombing offences, he arrived at the Maze in 1977, just after the eight H-shaped blocks were opened, and soon after the beginning of the blanket protest (prisoners refused to wear prison clothes, covering themselves with blankets instead). The Nissen huts - "cages" - for internees were still in use, but political status was gone for the newly sentenced. Those involved in the blanket protest stepped up their battle for political status by smearing excrement on cell walls and refusing to wash, and this campaign evolved into the hunger strike.

Now the IRA embarked on a completely new political strategy, an about-turn which involved working the system from the inside. The aim, though, was to collapse it from within, and - while some IRA men thought it a sell-out - the policy proved highly effective. There were stunning escape bids (in September 1983, no fewer than 38 IRA prisoners broke clear of the jail: 19 got away; two are still fighting extradition), one involving the construction of a large tunnel (the cells where the soil was dumped were never searched). Step by step, they succeeded in turning a fearsome prison regime into the most liberal in western Europe, where the prisoners effectively ran the show.

"I would have preferred to have grown up without having to go through prison, but it was one of the best experiences of my life," says McKeown now. "Life can be an anti-climax after everything we went through.

"The authorities achieved the opposite of what they were trying to achieve through the five years of protests. If we had political status, we would never have developed as quickly. But we were always being challenged and we had to dig deep to find out about ourselves and to analyse. It made us continually evaluate tactics."

Thomas Quigley, 44, jailed for life with a recommendation that he should serve 25 years for the Chelsea barracks bombing in London in 1982, says: "I was in the cages, which were there before the H-Blocks, in 1972, and we had political status then. I was transferred back to Long Kesh in 1996 after 11 years in English jails and two years at Maghaberry, and the regime had come full circle.

"We had control of our own wings again. We had more authority than we did even in the days of the cages."

Their cells were unlocked for 24 hours from 1994, allowing free association, the last of the five demands denied 13 years earlier. Each wing enjoyed high levels of autonomy, and prison officers, many disenchanted, were gradually pushed to the periphery. The regime could only operate with paramilitary assent. When journalists were allowed to visit the Maze in January 1998, on the eve of the then Northern Ireland secretary Mo Mowlam's crucial meeting there with the leadership of the Ulster Defence Association, prisoners and management denied lurid tales of sex and drugs being freely available. But smuggling was rife, with one leading loyalist said even to have had a pet dog brought in.

Loyalist wings were decorated with gaudy sectarian murals. Feared terrorist Johnny Adair was photographed alongside one reading: "Kill 'em all and let God sort them out."

Republicans posters were more overtly political. They seemed to be more interested in education, formal and informal.

Loyalists taking classes focused on technical subjects, and the television blared constantly. Republicans opted for social sciences, and group discussions were the usual form of entertainment. McKeown says: "Republicans tended to be more disciplined. We saw jail as an extension of the struggle and could adapt. They saw themselves as acting in defence of the state and were locked up by that state, and that was difficult for them."

UDA member Billy McQuiston, 43, given jail sentences totalling 21 years, says: "Back in the 70s, it was a real spit-and-shoeshine operation, and we were regularly beaten severely. We were getting smashed around by screws who had Ulster tattoos on their arms. It was hard to understand, but they thought we were scum."

There were, though, common goals. Loyalists had to be ordered off the blanket protest by the leadership on the outside because it looked as if they were acting in support of republicans, and McQuiston went on hunger strike to push for segregation in 1982.

He came off after 31 days, when apparent concessions led to another of the five demands of the previous year being met. McQuiston says: "The IRA hunger strikes were very confusing. You had all these Protestants singing songs like 'Do You Want a Chicken Supper Bobby Sands?' but we supported what he was doing. It would have meant our comrades getting what we wanted them to get, and you had to respect what the Provos went through."

Harry McIlvenna, 28, sentenced to 15 years in 1992 for the attempted murder of a leading republican, ben efited from early release in November 1998, one of 339 prisoners so far to do so. Three years were sliced off the term he would have served.

McIlvenna was talking of the good times, as prisoners on both sides do. He loved July 12 inside, when each wing on a block would compete to come up with the best band uniforms, mocked up with tape and card, and best drums, made from greaseproof paper and waste paper bins or, for the Lambeg, a five gallon water container. They brewed hooch, marched about the yards and had parties. Then, mirroring what happens on the outside, they would get in line and march again, as if coming back from the field.

McIlvenna was wed in the Maze in 1997. He had what is called a box visit later, allowing him to consummate the marriage, but the relationship, he says, survived just three days after his release.

McQuiston was married to Lizzie 10 days before he first went in. Julie was born a couple of weeks later, and is 23 now. He says his marriage survived because he was never around.

These ex-prisoners are unable to agree on what happens next to the Maze. Republicans want to create a museum, highlighting the hunger strikes and marking prison life at the height of the Troubles. McQuiston thinks not. "Shut it up and knock it down, and let's put it behind us. It's the only way we can go on."

He apologised to his mother, never a republican, and lapsed into unconsciousness. The IRA hunger strikes of 1981 were a turning point at the Maze - and also in the Troubles, because the story of the Maze is the story of the Irish conflict itself. Nothing was to be the same again, in any area of life in Northern Ireland. Republicans lost the battle for political status at the prison, yet were somehow to emerge even stronger. The Maze itself, still known among republicans and loyalists by its original name, Long Kesh, was to change radically. Gradually, terrorists won the political status they had been denied, via a combination of threats - 29 prison officers have been murdered during the Troubles - and mind games. In just four days, however, an era will draw to a close as more than 80 terrorists walk to freedom through a rickety turnstile that leads into the Maze car park. These men will include some of Northern Ireland's most notorious killers. Among them will be Sean Kelly, who murdered nine Protestants in the IRA bombing of the Shankill Road in Belfast less than seven years ago, and Torrens Knight, guilty of 11 murders, including seven in the trick-or-treat Hallowe'en shootings at the Rising Sun pub in Greysteel, County Londonderry, which were a response to the Shankill slaughter. Also walking out of the 130-acre jail will be three of the IRA's south Armagh sniper unit, who in February 1997 shot dead Stephen Restorick, the last British soldier murdered in Northern Ireland, in February 1997. Believed guilty of eight more murders, they smiled as they were jailed last year; they understood exactly what the early release scheme meant. Michael Stone, the wild-eyed loyalist, will precede them today. He was jailed in 1988 for six murders, including those of three mourners who died in his gun and grenade attack on the funerals of the trio of IRA volunteers shot dead by the SAS in Gibraltar. And so a jail which once housed 1,700 men will on Friday be left with precisely 16 prisoners, guarded by a staff of 750 (whittled down by 300 through a voluntary redundancy package). Most of those remaining officers will pick up their goodbye cheques within two months, and then the last inmates will be transferred to nearby Maghaberry Prison. The men from the Maze are returning to a world transformed from the one they left. McKeown is 43 now, a father of two daughters, Caoilfhioinn, four, and one-year-old Orlaith. He is now almost twice the weight he was during his hunger strike, but is still lean. He owes his survival to his mother, Margaret, who intervened when he lapsed into unconsciousness on the 70th day of his fast. His was the second family to insist that their son was treated, and he feels no guilt. Jailed for life for the attempted murder of an RUC man and several bombing offences, he arrived at the Maze in 1977, just after the eight H-shaped blocks were opened, and soon after the beginning of the blanket protest (prisoners refused to wear prison clothes, covering themselves with blankets instead). The Nissen huts - "cages" - for internees were still in use, but political status was gone for the newly sentenced. Those involved in the blanket protest stepped up their battle for political status by smearing excrement on cell walls and refusing to wash, and this campaign evolved into the hunger strike. Now the IRA embarked on a completely new political strategy, an about-turn which involved working the system from the inside. The aim, though, was to collapse it from within, and - while some IRA men thought it a sell-out - the policy proved highly effective. There were stunning escape bids (in September 1983, no fewer than 38 IRA prisoners broke clear of the jail: 19 got away; two are still fighting extradition), one involving the construction of a large tunnel (the cells where the soil was dumped were never searched). Step by step, they succeeded in turning a fearsome prison regime into the most liberal in western Europe, where the prisoners effectively ran the show. "I would have preferred to have grown up without having to go through prison, but it was one of the best experiences of my life," says McKeown now. "Life can be an anti-climax after everything we went through. "The authorities achieved the opposite of what they were trying to achieve through the five years of protests. If we had political status, we would never have developed as quickly. But we were always being challenged and we had to dig deep to find out about ourselves and to analyse. It made us continually evaluate tactics." Thomas Quigley, 44, jailed for life with a recommendation that he should serve 25 years for the Chelsea barracks bombing in London in 1982, says: "I was in the cages, which were there before the H-Blocks, in 1972, and we had political status then. I was transferred back to Long Kesh in 1996 after 11 years in English jails and two years at Maghaberry, and the regime had come full circle. "We had control of our own wings again. We had more authority than we did even in the days of the cages." Their cells were unlocked for 24 hours from 1994, allowing free association, the last of the five demands denied 13 years earlier. Each wing enjoyed high levels of autonomy, and prison officers, many disenchanted, were gradually pushed to the periphery. The regime could only operate with paramilitary assent. When journalists were allowed to visit the Maze in January 1998, on the eve of the then Northern Ireland secretary Mo Mowlam's crucial meeting there with the leadership of the Ulster Defence Association, prisoners and management denied lurid tales of sex and drugs being freely available. But smuggling was rife, with one leading loyalist said even to have had a pet dog brought in. Loyalist wings were decorated with gaudy sectarian murals. Feared terrorist Johnny Adair was photographed alongside one reading: "Kill 'em all and let God sort them out." Republicans posters were more overtly political. They seemed to be more interested in education, formal and informal. Loyalists taking classes focused on technical subjects, and the television blared constantly. Republicans opted for social sciences, and group discussions were the usual form of entertainment. McKeown says: "Republicans tended to be more disciplined. We saw jail as an extension of the struggle and could adapt. They saw themselves as acting in defence of the state and were locked up by that state, and that was difficult for them." UDA member Billy McQuiston, 43, given jail sentences totalling 21 years, says: "Back in the 70s, it was a real spit-and-shoeshine operation, and we were regularly beaten severely. We were getting smashed around by screws who had Ulster tattoos on their arms. It was hard to understand, but they thought we were scum." There were, though, common goals. Loyalists had to be ordered off the blanket protest by the leadership on the outside because it looked as if they were acting in support of republicans, and McQuiston went on hunger strike to push for segregation in 1982. He came off after 31 days, when apparent concessions led to another of the five demands of the previous year being met. McQuiston says: "The IRA hunger strikes were very confusing. You had all these Protestants singing songs like 'Do You Want a Chicken Supper Bobby Sands?' but we supported what he was doing. It would have meant our comrades getting what we wanted them to get, and you had to respect what the Provos went through." Harry McIlvenna, 28, sentenced to 15 years in 1992 for the attempted murder of a leading republican, ben efited from early release in November 1998, one of 339 prisoners so far to do so. Three years were sliced off the term he would have served. McIlvenna was talking of the good times, as prisoners on both sides do. He loved July 12 inside, when each wing on a block would compete to come up with the best band uniforms, mocked up with tape and card, and best drums, made from greaseproof paper and waste paper bins or, for the Lambeg, a five gallon water container. They brewed hooch, marched about the yards and had parties. Then, mirroring what happens on the outside, they would get in line and march again, as if coming back from the field. McIlvenna was wed in the Maze in 1997. He had what is called a box visit later, allowing him to consummate the marriage, but the relationship, he says, survived just three days after his release. McQuiston was married to Lizzie 10 days before he first went in. Julie was born a couple of weeks later, and is 23 now. He says his marriage survived because he was never around. These ex-prisoners are unable to agree on what happens next to the Maze. Republicans want to create a museum, highlighting the hunger strikes and marking prison life at the height of the Troubles. McQuiston thinks not. "Shut it up and knock it down, and let's put it behind us. It's the only way we can go on."

webTitle: Concorde grounded in wing crack scare

fields.headline: Concorde grounded in wing crack scare
fields.standfirst: BA Concorde site
fields.trailText: A British Airways Concorde has been taken out of service after a crack developed in its wings.
fields.body:
A British Airways Concorde has been taken out of service after a crack developed in its wings.

Despite the other six supersonic jets also having cracks in the rear of their wings, they have been deemed "no risk to safety" by the Civil Aviation Authority and British Airways, a BA spokeswoman said.

Initially, BA engineers discovered 60mm long cracks a few months ago in the rear wing spar - a beam that makes up part of the aircraft structure - of all seven planes.

But the crack in one of the planes grew to 76mm, forcing BA to ground it for maintenance repairs. "The cracks were detected a few months ago during maintenance checks. One has been taken out of service as the crack has grown, but the other six will continue to fly.

"They have all been checked by the CAA which is happy for them to fly and there is absolutely no risk to the public in the six other aircraft. We are hoping the one will be back in service by September.

"It's not a safety issue. We wouldn't fly if there was any risk to safety," she added.

Concorde's wings are manufactured by French company Aero Spatiale which has been notified about the problem. The supersonic aeroplanes can carry 100 passengers and fly at 1,336mph and at an altitude of 55,000 feet.

webTitle: Comment: The fate of Gaza City

fields.headline: Jonathan Cook @ Gaza City
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Tairif Abu Dayya has had a hectic month. In his PLO shop in Gaza City, amid dozens of inflatable Yasser Arafat dolls dangling from the ceiling, he and his family have been hurriedly sewing 3,000 flags.
fields.body:
Tairif Abu Dayya has had a hectic month. In his PLO shop in Gaza City, amid dozens of inflatable Yasser Arafat dolls dangling from the ceiling, he and his family have been hurriedly sewing 3,000 flags.

The order, placed by the Palestinian National Authority before the start of the Camp David summit a fortnight ago, should ensure there are enough flags to mark the declaration of Palestinian statehood, long threatened by Arafat for mid-September. Tairif has also made three giant flags - measuring 25 metres by 10 - for key sites at Gaza airport, Orient House in East Jerusalem and the West Bank city of Hebron, and created an equally large portrait of the Palestinian leader himself. "I am Arafat's biggest fan," Tairif says.

If a deal can be brokered at Camp David, the new flags will certainly be needed. Many of the ones lining the streets near Arafat's palace on Gaza seafront are barely recognisable: the harsh sun has bleached away the greens, reds and blacks, leaving what appear to be white flags of surrender. Their state - they have also been made ragged by time and the wind - neatly matches the forlorn, unloved condition of Gaza City. It may currently be the capital of Arafat's nascent state but his negotiators are working overtime to make sure that honour passes to East Jerusalem.

Gaza is a wretched place to live. More than one million Palestinians, the majority of them living in refugee camps, are squeezed into a tiny dusty strip of land 28 miles long and six wide between the Negev desert and the Mediterranean, creating one of the most densely populated areas on earth.

Adult unemployment has been estimated by the UN at 60%, and 90% of Gazans are said to live below the poverty line. Most water sources are contaminated with sewage or seawater, and the donkey and cart is still a major means of transport. Although Gazans have a reputation for being the most friendly of Palestinians, these pressures have created a palpable air of tension that all too readily surfaces in petty arguments and fights.

Life for another group of Gazans, however, is not so hard. Enjoying a hermetically sealed existence in 18 settlements dotted throughout the strip, 6,000 Israelis are supplied with water from private reservoirs and control most of the area's best arable land. A series of separate roads guarded by IDF troops connect them to Israel.

Palestinians also need to leave Gaza - either to visit loved ones in the West Bank or seek work in Israel. They have only one exit, at the Erez "security" border crossing which is controlled by Israel. Here thousands of Palestinians arrive each morning hoping to be let out. When the border isn't closed, as it can be unexpectedly, or their permits confiscated, they have to endure the indignity of being herded through a 500-metre long metal enclosure - a sort of cattle run - to be processed by the authorities.

Like many Palestinians, 32-year-old Manzur calls Gaza a prison, the biggest in the world. He lives a short distance from Gaza City in Beach Camp, home to 50,000 refugees. True to its name, the camp is by the sea but even the beach here is blighted by the squalor and overcrowding. Manzur is lucky to have a job, as a security guard at a hotel, but earns too little to buy a flat or hope to attract a bride. Instead he lives with his parents, four sisters, eight brothers and a grandfather. They share four rooms between them.

His grandparents fled from Jaffa, the Arab port south of Tel Aviv, in the 1948 war that established Israel. Manzur has never been there but says a few years ago his grandfather returned, to find the family home occupied by Israelis. "I know that I can never hope to live there," he says. "We have all given up dreaming. Gaza kills your dreams."

fields.trailText: At the end of a report headed Britons escape death in Indian air crash, page 11, July 20, we said that British diplomats had been told by the Foreign Office not to use Alliance Air after Rolls-Royce withdrew a service contract for its engines on safety grounds. In fact, Rolls-Royce had no contract with Alliance Air from which to withdraw.
fields.body:
At the end of a report headed Britons escape death in Indian air crash, page 11, July 20, we said that British diplomats had been told by the Foreign Office not to use Alliance Air after Rolls-Royce withdrew a service contract for its engines on safety grounds. In fact, Rolls-Royce had no contract with Alliance Air from which to withdraw.

In a report headed Volatile textile workers shake the calm of a French minister's summer, page 16, July 20, we referred to the textile mill at the centre of the story as Collatex. The company's correct name is Cellatex. We said the workers there had coined a new phrase to describe themselves - "jusq'a bout-ists" [sic], people who would go to the very end to make their point. In fact, they have simply adopted the phrase, which the dictionary spells jusqu'au-boutiste.

The picture on page 12, July 21, captioned the Al-Aqsa mosque, Jerusalem, actually showed the Dome of the Rock. It is part of the Temple Mount complex which also includes the Al-Aqsa mosque.

webTitle: A Country Diary: All thanks to the egret

fields.headline: All thanks to the egret
fields.trailText: Titchwell, Norfolk
fields.body:
Titchwell, Norfolk

Although it is an increasingly common sight in Norfolk, it still gives me pause for thought when I see an all-white bird, a third of the size of a swan, solitary and hunched in a dead tree. It is the little egret, a type of heron that is widely spread across temperate and tropical latitudes.

The European population, concentrated in the Mediterranean region, totals about 30,000 birds and normally crosses to north Africa for the winter. A small number deviated from this pattern in the 1950s. These birds steadily moved northward along the Spanish and French Atlantic coastline and established a breeding outpost in Brittany.

Western France was slowly colonised and this led to a further outward radiation that carried the egret to these shores. In 1989 Britain's annual average total of just 15 birds increased dramatically. Egrets were soon present on almost every estuary along the Channel coast and in 1996 the species was added to the breeding list. Today there are up to 1,000 egrets on British wetlands at any one time.

With their dazzling plumage and the specially elongated plumes of their breeding costume, egrets are an attractive addition to our native avifauna. However, there is another reason why they should be particularly welcome on many bird reserves.

During the 18th and 19th centuries, egrets were systematically harvested for their extraordinary lacy plumes, which were used as decoration for women's hats. The trade was worldwide and in 1913 a single salesroom in London auctioned off 12,840 ounces of feathers including 77,000 egret plumes. Globally this carnage amounted to an avian holocaust involving the slaughter of millions.

It was in reaction to this ghastly trade that a number of conservation organisations were created, including the International Council for Bird Preservation (now BirdLife International) and the owners of Titchwell, the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds. It is conceivable that without the egret issue, neither organisation would exist. Perhaps the staff of both, plus all the other birds on the RSPB's 144 reserves, should say a small prayer for the egret.

webTitle: Blair sees easy win for Labour

fields.headline: Blair sees easy win for Labour
fields.standfirst:
Party 'will be stronger at next election than in 1997'

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair launched a fightback yesterday after the worst month of his premiership when he declared that Labour would have an easier ride at the next election than in 1997, which saw the biggest landslide in the party's history.
fields.byline: Nicholas Watt  and  Mark Atkinson in Okinawa
fields.body:
Tony Blair launched a fightback yesterday after the worst month of his premiership when he declared that Labour would have an easier ride at the next election than in 1997, which saw the biggest landslide in the party's history.

In an attempt to bury the doubts raised in his leaked memo, the prime minister said that Labour was now "in a stronger position" because of the government's successful management of the economy.

"I think we are in a stronger position, because in 1997 on the economy we were having to say to people we are just going to have to be very cautious and very responsible," Mr Blair told Sky television at the G8 summit in Okinawa. "We can now say to people we have proved our responsibility. Now let us tell you about the radical changes that can be made."

His confident language contrasted with the nervous tone in his leaked memo, in which he said that the government appeared to be "out of touch with gut British instincts".

Mr Blair dismissed the furore over the leaked memos as "froth" which was exploited by the Tories who could not bear to see a successful Labour government. His remarks came after another leaked memo, by his pollster Philip Gould, appeared in the Sunday Times.

In the spoof note, which was sent to the prime minister's official spokesman Alastair Campbell, Mr Gould tells of a relative who had a nightmare about the Blairs coming to live in their house after Labour was defeated at the polls.

Mr Blair said the latest memo showed "how absurd the whole thing has become". Dismissing the leaks as "triviality", he added: "This is part of a very deliberate strategy on behalf of our opponents and parts of the media which are absolutely desperate to get off the policy agenda where they think they are very weak and onto all this nonsense about spin doctors and leaked memos."

Mr Blair's confidence in predicting that Labour will be in a stronger position at the next election than it was in 1997 will please MPs who were dismayed by his nervous tone in his memo. His remarks demonstrate that the prime minister believes last week's comprehensive spending review - in which Gordon Brown pledged an extra £43bn on public services - has been a success.

Labour last night attempted to turn the tables on the Murdoch press, to which the series of Labour memos was leaked, by demanding details of News International's links with a former trainee solicitor who rifles through people's bins. When Benjamin Pell, known as Benji the Binman, was arrested last year police confiscated a £2,500 cheque from News International.

Denis MacShane, the Labour MP for Rotherham and a former president of the National Union of Journalists, wrote last night to all News International editors demanding details of payments to Pell. "I am not asking for a breach of journalists' confidentiality," Mr MacShane said. "But there is a wide gap between good investigative reporting and paying money for criminal acts which involve an illegal invasion of privacy."

fields.headline: Section 28 could survive
fields.standfirst: More about section 28
fields.trailText: The government is to shelve plans to repeal the law forbidding local authorities from promoting homosexuality if the measure is roundly defeated in the House of Lords tonight.
fields.body:
The government is to shelve plans to repeal the law forbidding local authorities from promoting homosexuality if the measure is roundly defeated in the House of Lords tonight.

After months of bitter argument, ministers are expected to abandon their wrangle with peers determined to save section 28, which was introduced by Margaret Thatcher's government.

The decision will fuel speculation that Tony Blair is caving in to pressure from the rightwing tabloids to be more family oriented. In a memo leaked last week, the prime minister said that the government appeared to be weak on the family because of its stance on "gay issues". Downing Street refused to be drawn yesterday on what ministers will do tonight, when peers are expected once again to block action on section 28. "We are planning for success," said a spokesman who pointed out that the government had made a series of concessions to peers in recent months.

fields.headline: Blair risks GM foods backlash
fields.standfirst:
Britain backs US in rift over biotech advances
Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: Tony Blair risked an angry reaction from consumers by siding with Bill Clinton in a row over GM foods at the Group of Eight's annual summit in Okinawa, Japan - urging them not to be swayed by prejudice into damaging the prospects of an industry in which Britain is a world leader.
fields.body:
Tony Blair risked an angry reaction from consumers by siding with Bill Clinton in a row over GM foods at the Group of Eight's annual summit in Okinawa, Japan - urging them not to be swayed by prejudice into damaging the prospects of an industry in which Britain is a world leader.

The summit ended with a package of proposals to alleviate poverty in developing countries, including targets to reduce deaths from infectious diseases and spread literacy and new drives against money launderers and international drug cartels.

But there was nothing new in the final communique on alleviating the crippling debt burden in developing countries. And the rift between the continental Europeans and America over the safety of GM foods remained as wide as ever.

Acknowledging that his remarks might make him unpopular at home, the prime minister backed President Clinton by saying that decisions on GM food should be based on hard, scientific facts.

Standing alongside Mr Clinton at a news conference, Mr Blair said: "Consumers should, of course, know what it is they are eating and consuming. But for the consumers to make that judgment properly, they need the best science available. And that's what we've been looking for.

"It's not always popular to say that, but I think it's important because it's the right thing to do. And who knows what in 10, 20, 30 years' time will be the judgment about this new science. All I know is that our responsibility as leaders is to say to people, let's set up the best system, best process available so that you get the real facts - not the prejudices of one side or the commercial interests of one side, but the facts and the science."

He said the biotechnology industry, in which Britain was a leader, could be to the first half of the 21st century what information technology was to the last half of the 20th century.

Mr Blair's comments - accompanied by warm praise for President Clinton, attending his last G8 summit - contrasted sharply with those of Romano Prodi, the EU president, who had earlier claimed that all European governments were behind the "precautionary principle" - where GM food is considered off limits to consumers until enough information is gathered to vouch for its safety.

The US, the world's biggest GM producer and home to a $4bn-a-year GM food industry, is concerned that coordinating further research could be just another way of delaying acceptance of the technology.

But Mr Clinton denied he was simply backing big business. "The real issue is, how to get the best food to the largest number of people in the world at the lowest possible price. "

He added: "I would never knowingly let the American people eat unsafe food."

The G8 leaders said they supported the efforts of a food safety body "to achieve greater global consensus on how precaution should be applied to food safety in circumstances where available scientific information is incomplete or contradictory".

A set of reports drawn up by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development at the request of last year's G8 summit aimed to set out the state of debate on all GM organisms.

The OECD report's assertion that governments are confident in the safety of GM products they have already approved has proved controversial. Activists say the OECD excluded anti-GM opinion from the process while favouring the biotech industry and pro-GM scientists.

Nor does the report provide definitive answers on the murkier scientific and ethical problems posed by GM food.

As part of a decision by the leaders to endorse a goal of ensuring basic education to children across the globe by 2015, Mr Clinton said that he was putting $300m into a fund to provide children with free school meals as an incentive to get them into the classroom.

"That money is enough to give one good meal to 9m school children for a year in the developing world," he said.

Jubilee 2000, the coalition of charities campaigning for debt relief, jumped on Mr Blair's remarks on Saturday, when he said he wanted to do more than simply endorse the targets set last year in Cologne.

It said: "Today he can prove it and start to make up for the failure of Okinawa. Britain collects around £70m a year in debt from the poorest nations. We don't need it, and they do. Mr Blair should stop taking it now and instead ring-fence it for health and education in these countries."

fields.headline: Economics made easy
fields.trailText: What is resource budgeting?
fields.body:
What is resource budgeting?

The government has finally abandoned its system of accounting in cash term and replaced it with a system which accounts for public spending in a similar way to how businesses manage accounts. Last week's comprehensive spending review was the first to use resource accounting .

What's the difference?

Departments would record cash payments and receipts in the year in which they were received. Now what counts is when the resources are consumed. It's like the difference between counting the cost of shopping when you pay at the checkout versus counting it as you use it. So for example from now on, the ministry of defence will record the cost of a bomb when it is dropped, not when it is bought.

What's the point of it?

One of the problems with cash systems is that big capital items such as schools and hospitals appear in the accounts in one big lump, even though a building has a long lifetime. There was always a temptation to drop big capital projects in order to make the figures look better, and this is one of the reasons why the public sector has suffered from underinvestment.

Will it be easier for the public sector to invest under the new system?

While it was hard to get big capital spending projects under the old system because they were paid for up front, once departments had the asset it was free. The Treasury believes that as result, departments did not make best use of their property. Now they will pay an annual charge on all their assets, based on the replacement cost, so an empty office block will cost them money. The Treasury hopes this will encourage departments to make the best use of their assets.

Which departments are the most affected?

The ministry of defence will have to make the most changes to its accounts, because it has huge stockpiles of military hardware and lots of properties.

webTitle: Jamboree is over, so now we want results

fields.headline: Jamboree is over, so now we want results
fields.standfirst:
Special report: debt relief
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: After all the well-deserved flak over the extravagance of the summit, from the purpose-built facilities to the Philippe Starck notepads for the press, the Japanese hosts must be wondering whether anything of real value was achieved in Okinawa.
fields.body:
After all the well-deserved flak over the extravagance of the summit, from the purpose-built facilities to the Philippe Starck notepads for the press, the Japanese hosts must be wondering whether anything of real value was achieved in Okinawa.

Rather than impress, the lavish spending merely fuelled suspicion that the annual meeting of the leaders of the US, Japan, Germany, France, UK, Italy, Canada and Russia is no more than an elaborate jamboree.

The failures of the summit were certainly there for all the world to see. On trade, for example, there were some warm words in the communiqué about the G8's commitment to launching a new round of trade liberalisation talks with particular emphasis on making sure the benefits spread to the developing world. But there was no firm deadline set. Although the leaders said they would try to get one off the ground this year, that remains a pious hope given the imminence of the US presidential election in which Al Gore will be anxious not to upset the labour unions by threatening to expose their markets to greater competition.

Yet opening markets, such as textiles, in the developed world remains one of the surest way of helping developing countries claim a stake in global prosperity.

There was also a failure to settle the dispute over GM foods, with most of the European countries sticking to the so-called precautionary principle, whereby GMO's are considered guilty until proven innocent.

The most conspicuous failure, however, was over easing the crippling debt burden for the world's poorest countries. While conceding that "further efforts were required" to speed up debt relief, the G8 did no more than reconfirm the target set last year at Cologne.

Jubilee 2000, the coalition of charities which has turned the issue into a global movement, embracing the Pope, UN secretary general Kofi Annan, the Dalai Lama, Bob Geldof and Bono, was understandably disappointed, describing the G8's failure to agree any new initiatives as a "squandered" opportunity.

The lack of a new drive on debt relief places a question mark over the achievement of the other development goals which the leaders set themselves, welcome though they are.

Unable to reach agreement on debt relief despite the best efforts of Tony Blair to persuade them to respond to public opinion and take decisive action, the G8 leaders settled for: announcing targets on cutting preventable diseases, one of the major obstacles to growth in the Third World; severing the strings attached to aid; making sure extra resources are available for education; implementing measures to prevent conflict, another major blight on economic progress; and spreading the use of information technology.

The health targets of reducing the number of Aids victims by 25% by 2010 and TB and malaria-related deaths by 50% will be a useful yardstick against which progress can be measured. But sceptics will ask: where will the money come from if Africa is forced to continue spending more on debt servicing than healthcare? Britain is doubling its contribution to the cause, from £50m to £100m, but a lot more will be required from other countries.

On education, President Clinton announced that he was taking executive action to spend $300m from surplus farm crops to provide free school meals to up to 9m children as an incentive for their parents to ensure they get basic education. But with 120m children out of school, it will require a lot more money from elsewhere to make the initiative a success.

On IT, the G8 announced that it was setting up a taskforce of experts to support the development of sorely lacking infrastructure in the Third World, backed up by $15m from Japan. Amid all the hype surrounding the internet, there was a danger that the G8 would be seen to be getting its priorities wrong. After all, great swathes of Africa and other parts of the world don't even have electricity or roads let alone an information superhighway.

On untying aid, Britain helped to achieve a major breakthrough by persuading both Japan and France to sign up to an agreement to begin dismantling the system whereby aid is granted on the condition that it is spent on goods and services from the donor country, letting self interest triumph over effective development policy.

Mr Blair also secured agreement from the Russian president Vladimir Putin to co-host a conference on conflict diamonds, a worthy attempt to tackle funding of wars in Africa.

Together, all these commitments on the part of the G8 amount to considerable progress which should offset some of the disappointment felt over debt relief. But a comprehensive agenda means little if it is not implemented. The formidable task of next year's summit host, Italy, which is to ensure the promises made in Okinawa are honoured, has already begun.
