webTitle: Clinton returns to Camp David talks

fields.headline: Clinton returns to Camp David talks
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: President Bill Clinton landed back in the US last night and headed for Camp David to join the 13th day of peace talks between the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, and Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in Jerusalem and  Jane Martinson in New York
fields.body:
President Bill Clinton landed back in the US last night and headed for Camp David to join the 13th day of peace talks between the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, and Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak.

Israeli officials and cabinet ministers said that the outcome of their peace talks with the Palestinians could be decided within hours of President Clinton's arrival. But speaking later on Israel television, the Israeli spokesman, Gadi Baltiansky, admitted: "It would be easier to prophesy what will happen in 24 years than what will happen here in the next 24 hours."

Before leaving Okinawa, where he had been attending the G8 summit, Mr Clinton said the negotiators had made headway during his absence.

"They have not wasted their time. They have worked," he said, in spite of a news blackout. "Whether we get an agreement or not I can't tell, but they have really worked.

"Since I left, there has been a lot more sort of systematic effort in the groups on a lot of the issues. So whatever happens, I think they have continued to make headway."

Few commentators missed the opportunity of pointing out that the previous round of Camp David peace talks, brokered by President Jimmy Carter 20 years ago, had ended in agreement on the 13th day.

Reports from the summit said that both sides, accompanied by the secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, had used Mr Clinton's four-day absence to recuperate from their marathon bargaining sessions.

The Pope yesterday called for international guarantees of religious freedom in Jerusalem as the debate about the future of the holy city intensified.

In an address to pilgrims from his retreat at Castel Gondolfo, the Pope said measures were needed to assure freedom of worship for Muslims, Jews and Christians, and access to shrines inside the ancient city walls.

The square kilometre of land that lies within its gates contains hallowed ground for all three faiths. The most sacred relic of Judaism, the Wailing Wall, is located there, as is the Holy Sepulchre, where Christians believe Jesus was buried, and the al-Aqsa mosque, the third holiest shrine in Islam.

"The holy see continues to maintain that only a special statute, internationally guaranteed, can effectively preserve the most sacred areas of the holy city," the Pope said.

The intervention came amid anxiety among Arab countries that Mr Arafat, will come under heavy pressure this week from Mr Clinton and Mr Barak, to give ground on Jerusalem. Mr Arafat has yet to comment on reports that Mr Barak is prepared to accept Palestinian sovereignty over some areas of east Jerusalem occupied since 1967.

However, the Palestinians have said that such limited autonomy would stop far short of their demand for a fully sov ereign Palestinian capital on all of the occupied parts of Jerusalem for the state they want to declare in September, including the walled city.

"Jerusalem can't be claimed by one side," Jordan's foreign minister, Abdul-Illah Khatib, said in Alexandria, Egypt. "Besides its political and religious importance to the Palestinians, it directly involves Arabs, Muslims and Christians."

The Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, was also reported to be discussing the future of Jerusalem, and the progress of the talks, in a meeting with Saudi Crown Prince Abdullah at Taif.

In Gaza, Sheikh Ahmed Yassin, spiritual leader of the Hamas movement, which opposes a negotiated peace with Israel, called on the Palestinians to leave the talks, rather than give in on the holy city. "I ask the negotiators to pull out from this summit which would result in a great loss to the Palestinian people. No agreement could exclude a part of Palestine, and in particular Jerusalem which belongs to all Muslim generations."

Within Israel, the waiting game yesterday saw scuffles between Jewish settlers and Palestinians near the West Bank town of Hebron, and a new flicker of pessimism about the outcome of the talks.

Unless Mr Clinton can tug both sides towards an agreement on Jerusalem today, the whole peace process could come crashing down.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Sunday Times
fields.body:
Sunday Times

A flotation of the mobile telephone operator, Cellnet, and a demerger of its heavily regulated British wholesale operation are being considered by BT. Experts believe that the moves could come early next year as the next stage in BT's radical restructuring by Sir Peter Bonfield, its chief executive, and his management team.

The internet software company Mediasurface is set to appoint an adviser for a planned flotation that could see the company valued as much as £1bn. A beauty parade of investment banks is at present being conducted with Credit Suisse First Boston, Goldman Sachs and Robertson Stephens on the shortlist. Mediasurface will press ahead with plans for a dual listing in London and on the US's Nasdaq market at the end of 2000, once an adviser is selected.

Sunday Telegraph

Sir Ian Prosser, chairman and chief executive of Bass, the hotels and pubs group, is expected to split his boardroom roles with an official announcement possibly coming as early as the group's next annual meeting. Speculation among well-placed Bass executives is that Sir Ian will relinquish the title of chief executive as he restructures the company and focuses on hotels.

The world's fifth largest brewer, Interbrew, is set to sell Scotland's biggest alcohol brand, Tennent's Lager. An auction could raise as much as £250m.

The move will allow Interbrew to clear regulatory hurdles following its recent acquisition of Bass Brewers and the Whitbread Beer company.

Sunday Business

Anglian Water is working on a scheme to split its assets from its operating company - despite widespread opposition to the Kelda proposal to mutualise its Yorkshire Water assets.

If the regulators and shareholders approve the plan, Anglian Water is expected tofollow with takeover bids that would consolidate the water industry for the first time.

Jan Leschly, the former high-profile chief executive of SmithKline Beecham, is plotting a comeback to the corporate world just months after announcing his retirement.

Sources in the City say that Mr Leschly, who retired from the pharmaceuticals group in April as part of the merger with Glaxo Wellcome, is planning to launch a venture capital company that will provide funding for start-up firms in the biotech and health care sectors.

Britain remains a great place for Japanese companies to invest in, according to Sir Stephen Gomersall, the diplomat whose pro-euro memo this month embarrassed the government.

Observer

fields.headline: Cigarette smuggling inquiry
fields.trailText: A federal grand jury is looking into charges that leading cigarette companies have ties to smugglers who move billions of dollars of cigarettes across international borders without paying taxes, Newsweek reported yesterday.
fields.body:
A federal grand jury is looking into charges that leading cigarette companies have ties to smugglers who move billions of dollars of cigarettes across international borders without paying taxes, Newsweek reported yesterday.

The World Bank and the World Health Organisation will release a report next week detailing a three-year investigation into whether the tobacco industry has blocked international efforts to control tobacco.

The magazine said it did not know the names of the companies being investigated by the grand jury in North Carolina. But it added that Leslie Thompson, a former executive with Northern Brands International, a now defunct export company owned by RJR Nabisco, was likely to be questioned by federal prosecutors.

Citing US and Canadian prosecutors, the magazine said Thompson was accused of working with smugglers who shipped billions of RJ Reynolds cigarettes to Canada, where black-marketeers awaited them.

Thompson is serving a six-year jail sentence after pleading guilty to money-laundering charges in connection with the smuggling case.

He was the only cigarette executive charged. Two years ago, NBI payed $15m in fines and forfeits under a plea bargain arrangement, according to the report.

Newsweek quotes RJ Reynolds officials as saying that the company had no knowledge that NBI or Thompson had been breaking the law.

A Philip Morris spokesman also denied that the company had any connections with smugglers.

A spokesman for British American Tobacco, meanwhile, said high taxes, not tobacco companies, were responsible for creating the conditions that encourage tobacco smuggling.

The report of the grand jury investigation comes days after American officials arrested alleged cigarette smugglers with links to Middle East rebels, including Hizbullah, and less than two weeks after a Florida jury ordered America's big tobacco companies to pay $145bn in punitive damages to smokers.

webTitle: Major might have had the charisma of a sheep, but he was believable

fields.headline: The lesson of the ordinary man's forgotten years
fields.standfirst:
Major might have had the charisma of a sheep, but he was believable
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Major might have had the charisma of a sheep, but he was believable.
fields.body:
He was there again for a few hours last week, floating at the very edge of public life (otherwise known as a hearing of the public administration select committee). And he was in every respect unchanged. Quiet, contained, a trifle prissy - but unfailingly polite. A gentle man with a long lease on a winsome grin.

"No," he said, trawling through the messes of Mellor and Yeo and Aitken, "on occasions ministers would do something foolish, but I knew the private strain and difficulty which had clouded their judgment... Not everything is a hanging offence." And yes, he added, "I tried to leave them with a shred of dignity and not to say: You've mucked up". The heroic benignity of the unperson. Welcome back, John Major.

It is almost eccentric to mention the seven Major years now. William Hague has forgotten them entirely - except as a dim time when people who tend to criticise him committed their own follies. Tony Blair remembers them only tactically in a blur of old statistics and scorn. Academic wisdom is limited to compiling lists of the departed century's worst prime ministers. The memory hole yawns wide.

And yet, in truth, it's difficult to work your way through Blair's worst month in Blair's worst year without thinking about John Major - because New Labour, in so many ways, was constructed as the antithesis of Major governance. For an absence of spin by a civil service press secretary (Gus O'Donnell) substitute vicious turn off the wicket from Alastair Campbell. For a supposedly mild, self-effacing family man, substitute a vibrant, powerful family man who pays due tribute to Margaret Thatcher.

Where there was once no team playing, let there henceforth be scant pretence of a team - just a strong leader. Where there was doubt, let there be certainty. Where there was parliament, let there be executive rule. Where there was cricket, let there be football.

Little of that construct looks quite so shiny today. Indeed, much of it has worked its own self-destruction. Mr Campbell, in his cocky belligerence, was always going to be vulnerable once the tide turned and popularity had to be won, not commanded. The allegedly powerful have further to fall when they stumble. A captain without much of a team has nobody else to blame. Cricket has supporters; football has hooligans.

What was good about John Major? He knew about ordinary people, because he was one of them. He was a great, doggedly pleasant negotiator: his Maastricht days stand any examination of history. He was in no sense overshadowed on the world stage. I recall early on, just after the Gulf war, watching Major and President Bush give their post-war press conference and thinking how much terser and clearer our boy seemed.

One bookcase at my home is stuffed with books too magnificently out-of-time to throw away. After Nehru, Who? by Welles Hangen. Divided Berlin, by Hans Speier. The Future of Socialism, by Stuart Holland. And from 1991, John Major, by Bruce Anderson, in which the Spectator's current political scribe strove to show how the new leader's "beliefs, values and personality were in tune with the temper of the times". A PM for the 90s, said Bruce - just as Margaret Thatcher had been for the 80s.

As quickie hagiographies go, it wasn't a bad effort. Anderson was tougher on the Lady than might have been expected, and softly understanding of what came to be seen as Great Mistakes. Chancellor Major didn't love the exchange-rate mechanism - but the pound had become "ridiculously vulnerable to rumours about British membership". The markets had concluded that while the British government "was hanging back from ERM, its commitment to counter-inflation could not be taken seriously". Mrs T, meanwhile, "could recognise the moment when it was no longer possible to defend a lost cause".

Make that ERM decision what it in fact was - pragmatic, consensual, shared - and the history of the seven lean years changes. Prime Minister Major was handed more than his share of hospital passes. Falling out of the ERM effectively wrecked him and his government. But make the recovery from that debacle an achievement, reckon that the economy he passed to Gordon Brown was already set for continuing success, and the rest of the record is bathed in a kindlier light.

Education by national curriculum and relentless testing, snappily tended by Chris Woodhead? Health with market pressure, league tables and endless comparisons, watched over by the notably expert Stephen Dorrell? Michael Howard locking crime away, out of sight and out of mind? Let's be neutrally honest about all that. New Labour's first three years is virtually a continuum. It wasn't only the spending targets which stayed in place: the essential thrust of policy was constant, too.

Even the small eccentricities prime ministers permit themselves are bizarrely similar. Mr Blair wants to frogmarch drunks to the nearest cash machine; Mr Major wanted chartered citizens to call Whitehall and get cones on clogged motorways removed. Who's dafter?

The abiding charge against John Major was that he had all the platform charisma of a tranquillised sheep - but even that cuts two ways. He made many boring speeches, but he was never booed by the Women's Institute. His loathing of spin, manifest as he carted his soapbox from hustings to hustings, was both a handicap and a strength. At least he never looked cynically calculating; at least he was believed; at least he was real.

The epitaph is simple enough. Wrecked by the bastards, wrecked by a party which couldn't be led, wrecked by the failure to give a lead on Europe. Well, we can leave the bastards and the corruption to one side. They exist willy-nilly, whatever the time, whatever the party. But can we also acknowledge that - for any British prime minister - Europe is the very devil of an issue. Is Tony Blair making a better fist of it? He doesn't - yet - have his party on his back, merely the Daily Mail. But leading? That is a sorrier story.

As the new millennium dawned and ministers danced in the Dome, John Major wrote a telling piece in the Spectator. They're not being candid, he said. "Tax is going up. They deny it. Transport is in a muddle. They deny it. "Facts" used by ministers to argue that case are often as fictional as Marley's ghost. The "third way" is a political South Sea Bubble.

Who needs memos from Philip Gould or editorials in the Mail? John Major was spot on, just as he was dead right to go on to warn Hague against his loony right. The record, in practice and in courage, holds well. What should Tony Blair be doing as the going gets rough? He could do far worse, in chastened humility, than seek to remember and learn from the forgotten years.

fields.headline: Welsh farm minister sacked
fields.trailText: Wales's controversial agriculture secretary, who is a vegetarian, has been suddenly sacked on the eve of the Royal Welsh agricultural show and replaced by her deputy.
fields.body:
Wales's controversial agriculture secretary, who is a vegetarian, has been suddenly sacked on the eve of the Royal Welsh agricultural show and replaced by her deputy.

Rhodri Morgan, first secretary of the Welsh assembly, announced yesterday that Carwyn Jones will take over from Christine Gwyther.

Ms Gwyther has faced three censure motions, losing one of them, since she was controversially appointed to the job 15 months ago by Mr Morgan's predecessor, Alun Michael.

She was expected to be replaced later in the year in a wider reshuffle. However, Mr Morgan has timed his announcement so that Mr Jones, not Ms Gwyther, would accompany him to the region's farming showcase, which opens at Builth Wells today.

Mr Morgan said: "The time has come for a change. Carwyn Jones is the right choice for the job. There is no criticism of Christine who has done a very good job in very trying circumstances. It is the agriculture show tomorrow, therefore it is the right time to introduce Carwyn Jones. Some political careers come to an end. Others have a hiccup. This is a hiccup for Christine."

Ms Gwyther's departure was welcomed by Alan Morris, spokesman for the Farmers' Union of Wales. He said that she should never have been appointed.

However, the timing of the decision was criticised by Mr Morris and Nick Bourne, the leader of the Welsh assembly's Conservatives. Mr Bourne, who was one of Ms Gwyther's fiercest critics, described it as a cynical move.

He said: "It is sad that it takes the Royal Welsh show to concentrate the mind of the first secretary to do something that he should have done a long time ago."

Ms Gwyther said: "While I am naturally disappointed to be replaced, I wish my successor well in what is sometimes a difficult but often a rewarding brief."

Mr Morris welcomed Mr Jones's appointment. He said: "We have met him on several occasions and, as a barrister, he has a keen mind, a keen intellect and a grasp on the problems that are facing agriculture in Wales."

webTitle: Blair pledge to patients on cancelled ops

fields.headline: Blair pledge to patients on cancelled ops
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will this week give a cast-iron commitment of treatment within four weeks for any patient whose operation is cancelled on the promised day of surgery at an NHS hospital.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will this week give a cast-iron commitment of treatment within four weeks for any patient whose operation is cancelled on the promised day of surgery at an NHS hospital.

As a demonstration of patient power in the national plan for health to be published on Thursday, he will guarantee that any cancellation for non-medical reasons must be accompanied by the offer of a binding date for performing the operation within 28 days.

NHS hospitals which are unable to give this undertaking will be obliged to fund the patient's treatment "at the time and hospital of the patient's choosing". The patient would be able to opt for the private sector if it offered appropriate facilities.

The goverment expects to deliver the guarantee within two years and progressively reduce the 28-day delay thereafter.

Ministers think the move will address one of the most serious flashpoints of frustration with the NHS among thousands of patients whose operations are cancelled at the last minute - particularly during winter periods of pressure on beds and staff.

The guarantee will form part of a step-by-step programme to slash waiting times. Ministers and their advisers were still wrestling last night with recruitment forecasts for doctors and nurses which will determine how fast a £13bn package of extra NHS spending can be converted into firm promises of reduced delays.

The likely outcome is a commitment by 2005 to reduce the maximum wait to nine months from seeing a GP to a hospital operation. This backstop guarantee for non-urgent cases compares with the current target of 24 months.

Although the target is less ambitious than ministers hoped when they began the NHS review, it appears to be the most they can deliver in the medium term until 1,000 extra places at medical schools start producing more doctors. The abolition of waiting lists remains a long-term aspiration.

Sources at the Department of Health said the plan would "recast the 1948 settlement that established the NHS" by unscrambling the compromises that its founder, Aneurin Bevan, was obliged to make with doctors and other interest groups.

The document will aim to break down professional boundaries between doctors, nurses and other health service professionals to create a faster, more consumer-oriented service.

A team of patient advocates will be appointed to every hospital with authority to sort out problems and handle complaints from patients or their relatives. The Patient Advocacy and Liaison Service (Pals) will have desks in hospital reception and a hotline to senior management.

The system will be supported by undercover squads of former patients who will be recruited to carry out spot checks on ward hygiene and staff attitudes.

Lay inspectors, including at least one elderly patient, will be appointed to the teams carrying out the full four-yearly inspections for the commission for health improvement.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, said: "We have got to change the way that the whole system works, to genuinely centre it around the patient."

He told BBC1's Breakfast with Frost: "We have got to do away with these absurd demarcations between staff, where nurses are prevented from doing some jobs because they have been regarded as jobs that only doctors can do. That's ridiculous.

"We have got to do away with the divisions between health services and social services, because that means that elderly people don't get out of hospital quickly enough when they are ready to leave.

 Incentives for GPs to practise in deprived areas to tackle inequalities in health demonstrated in a study published today by the independent King's Fund. They would get NHS salaries, topped up by bonuses for meeting health targets;

 A £400m scheme to modernise crumbling GP surgeries and build a network of one-stop centres in deprived neighbourhoods with doctors, social services, opticians and pharmacists under one roof;

 Increased priority for mental health, including recruitment of 1,000 clinical psychologists to help people suffering short-term crises of anxiety or depression, a crisis resolution service for those with acute mental illness, and "assertive outreach" teams to ensure that potentially violent patients are taking medication.

The arithmetic may be recast before the plan goes to the printers tomorrow. The current draft is also understood to be about twice as long as intended and some proposals are likely to be lost in the last-minute slimming down.

fields.headline: £600m to end asylum backlog
fields.standfirst:
Election fear forces Labour to act

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The government is to pump an emergency £600m into the Home Office so that it can make decisions on an unprecedented 150,000 asylum cases in the next eight months.
fields.body:
The government is to pump an emergency £600m into the Home Office so that it can make decisions on an unprecedented 150,000 asylum cases in the next eight months.

The extra injection of funds will more than double the budget of the immigration and nationality directorate overnight in an attempt to kill off asylum as a politically damaging issue in the run-up to next year's general election.

In his leaked memo Tony Blair identified asylum as one of two "touchstone issues" on which the government was seen as being "soft".

A Home Office spokesman confirmed that the money to finance the programme, designed to bail out the asylum system by clearing a backlog of nearly 100,000 cases by next March, is part of the Treasury's comprehensive spending review. Full details of the review, which was outlined last week by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, have yet to be announced.

The £600m comes on top of the £400m a year over the next three years that was announced in the comprehensive spending review.

The massive scale of the rescue operation ordered by Mr Blair and Jack Straw shows the depths of the crisis facing Britain's asylum process.

A botched computerisation project and an ill-timed move of the directorate's headquarters led to one of the biggest bureaucratic breakdowns in the history of Whitehall.

At one point the number of decisions taken each month fell to 800 and the backlog soared from 50,960 in February 1998 to a peak of 104,000 earlier this year.

At the height of the crisis rotting case files were discovered dumped in a car park underneath the Croydon headquar ters of the immigration and nationality directorate.

A Home Office spokeswoman confirmed that large-scale recruitment campaigns were already under way to hire and train the extra staff needed.

It is thought that the overall number of staff is to increase from about 6,500 earlier this year to more than 11,000 over the next two years. Around 9,000 staff should be in place by next March.

"This year's budget is more than doubling. It was £590m and now it is going to be £1.2bn. By March 2001 we want to clear the backlog," she added. "We want to make between 130,000 and 150,000 decisions in this financial year. That covers the backlog of 90,000 cases and the number of new asylum applications we expect to get."

She said that two new targets were being set for the asylum system. The first was to ensure that by January next year that 70% of all new asylum claims had an initial decision within two months. The second was longer term and aimed for 75% of all asylum decisions to be taken within two months. A further four months is to be allowed for appeals.

It currently takes 13 months on average for an asylum case to be resolved.

The immigration minister, Barbara Roche, believes that the fact that new asylum applicants have gone to the back of a very long queue has been a major factor in the rise in numbers of asylum applicants to Britain and that quicker decisions will prove an effective deterrent.

As the speed of asylum decision-making is stepped up, so ministers expect the number of removals of failed asylum seekers to grow as well.

An extra £100m is being made available to build three new detention centres to ensure that those who face deportation do not disappear.

It is planned that the 8,000 removals carried out last year will rise to 12,000 in this financial year and reach 30,000 in 2001/2002.

Although stepping up the scale of removals is thought to be popular with former Tory voters, Home Office ministers are nervous that a single controversial case could suddenly undermine public support for such a programme.

Nick Hardwick, the chief executive of the Refugee Council, said news of the emergency money had come as a shock but he thought it could succeed. "The reason why they could not keep up with the backlog was because the cases are particularly complex or anything but because the files were put on shelves and left there for years and years," he said. "It is procedural delays and administrative chaos they have to deal with.

"It is not outside the bounds of possibility that with such an injection of finance and staff you could clear the backlog. That is what Germany did."

fields.headline: US Democrats copy Blair tactics
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's advisers may believe that New Labour has become "contaminated", but the prime minister has just been paid the ultimate compliment. His tactics are being pinched by the Americans.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle  in Washington and  Nicholas Watt
fields.body:
Tony Blair's advisers may believe that New Labour has become "contaminated", but the prime minister has just been paid the ultimate compliment. His tactics are being pinched by the Americans.

Bill Clinton's Democratic party has decided to print thousands of pledge cards modelled on the credit card-size cards deployed by Labour at the last general election.

Dick Gephardt, Democratic leader in the House of Representatives, was so impressed by Labour's "five key pledges" that he has ordered his party's candidates to hand out similar cards during November's congressional elections.

His enthusiasm for a British campaign tool turns conventional political wisdom on its head, demonstrating that for once America may have something to learn from this side of the Atlantic. Until now, campaigners have always assumed that the traffic in new political ideas travelled in one direction, across the Atlantic from west to east.

The Democrats' pledge cards will be a lot lighter on specifics than the British version.They will spell out more general aims, including pledges to hire a million new teachers over the next 10 years, to introduce a new benefit for the poor and elderly to cover prescription medicines, and to pay off the US national debt by the year 2012.

Unlike New Labour, there will be three different forms of the US cards, featuring a white, black or Latino family according to the area in which candidates campaign.

"The card is an encapsulation of the primary areas that you are going to try to spend your time and your efforts on," said Rose de Lauro, a Democratic congresswoman whose husband, Stan Greenberg, is a colleague of the New Labour pollster Philip Gould.

Mr Gould will be delighted that one of Labour's main campaign tools has been adopted by the Americans because he makes no secret of his admiration for the techniques of the Democrats. In one of his leaked memos, Mr Gould lavishes praise on the controversial US pollster Dick Morris, who is credited with securing Mr Clinton's second victory in 1996 after advising the president to tilt to the right.

Mr Gould's use of focus groups and Labour's rapid rebuttal media campaign techniques were also picked up from Washington.

webTitle: There's still time for a real Labour party

fields.headline: There's still time for a real Labour party
fields.standfirst:
Gould has done us a service by exposing a shabby sales policy
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Gould has done us a service by exposing a shabby sales policy.
fields.body:
It should not have come as a surprise. Philip Gould's memorandum to the prime minister - which discussed politics and government in the language of a door-to-door brush salesman - was not significantly more demeaning than the book in which he described how "the modernisers saved the Labour party".

But when he published that self-aggrandising account of how he guided Tony Blair to Downing Street, the prime minister was at the height of his popularity. So any suggestion that principle was more important than presentation was dismissed as the sour grapes of socialists who had grown so accustomed to defeat that they resented victory. Now nobody can doubt that what Gould stands for cannot even guarantee unprincipled re-election.

Much attention has been focused on the trivial shortcomings of the Gould memorandum - its grandiloquent language, risible title and reckless willingness to put on paper judgments which glorified the author at the government's expense. Its real importance is the exposure of the superficiality that has so damaged Labour's reputation. By setting out so clearly the strategy of shabby failure, Gould has done the party a historic service.

Tony Blair has always been a lucky party leader and it is his good fortune that the shortcomings of Gould's pseudo-philosophy have been exposed at a moment when he can easily turn his back on "the project" and rebuild a party of conscience and compassion. The foundations are already there.

The comprehensive spending review offers more than an opportunity to proclaim Labour's belief in public expenditure as a vehicle for redistribution. It provides the chance to insist that the government always intended an assault on inequality but was prudent enough, in the words of George Bernard Shaw, to grow the apples before it attempted to bake apple pies. If the prime minister chooses to pretend that the critics of earlier prudence have been proved wrong, I - as one of them - will not complain.

Mr Gould will argue that a belated espousal of honest, democratic socialism will offend the target voters on whom the second term depends. But what do his focus groups tell him about the re-electability of a party which believes that successful government is built on the lowest common denominator of human expectation? His memorandum describes the contempt which follows the rejection of ideology. But incredibly that remains the stratagem which he proposes.

Stripped of its pretentious language, the theory of "direct democracy" which wins "a daily mandate" from a fickle public is just vulgar populism. The floaters want to treat asylum seekers as if they are criminals. So that is what they must be given.

Gould quotes, as his inspiration, Dick Morris, President Clinton's discredited adviser. George Stephanopoulos, the former White House press secretary, immortalised him with the phrase, "Spare me the unctuous bullshit, you insincere prick". He does not seem the natural replacement for RH Tawney.

Knowing the prime minister's faith in the efficiency of the market, I wonder if he has considered how a private corporation would react to the Gould memorandum and the sales policy it has revealed. Because of Gould's belief that politicians must sway with every gust of public opinion, much of what is best in the government's record has been obscured. Indeed it has been intentionally hidden. Labour will win the next election on the back of William Hague's unpopularity. But a combination of Philip Gould and Kenneth Clarke might well have been fatal. I do not expect Tony Blair to give the focus-group man his well-deserved cards. That would be out of character. I simply beg him to stop taking Gould's advice.

There is plenty of time for the prime minister to put "the project" behind him and drop, as well as the name New Labour, the political cynicism which the adjective embodies. Harold Wilson said that Labour was a party of principle or it was nothing. Repeating that view today would (thanks to Gouldism) produce the horse laugh of the century.

But Tony Blair does have principles. Together with his instinct for self-preservation they should encourage him to rise above distasteful notions like "the brand being contaminated" and prove that adjective-free Labour stands for something. If, as Gould implies, Labour has an identity crisis, it is because, thanks to him, it has chosen to hide the ideals which still inspire most of its members.

There is plenty of time. Two years is an infinity in politics. But the prime minister must decide now the direction in which his government travels. If he devotes the talent that surrounds him to bringing democratic socialism up to date, rather than searching for an alternative philosophy, and forgets the headlines for a month or two he will lead a deservedly popular government. And we will have a Labour party again.

webTitle: Woods joins the ranks of sports legends

fields.headline: Woods joins the ranks of sports legends
fields.trailText: Playing the game of golf better than it has ever been played, Tiger Woods won the 129th Open championship at St Andrews in Scotland yesterday.
fields.body:
Playing the game of golf better than it has ever been played, Tiger Woods won the 129th Open championship at St Andrews in Scotland yesterday.

On a course where golf has been played for 600 years, according to legend, the 24-year-old overcame the distractions of the crowd spilling on to the fairways on the final holes and of a female streaker dancing around the flag as he walked up to the 18th green to become the youngest man ever to win all four of golf's grand slam tournaments.

Only four other golfers - Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player and Jack Nicklaus - have achieved the feat. But Woods, who was introduced to the game by his father when he was six months old, is on his way to joining a select band of athletes, such as Pele, Michael Jordan and Carl Lewis, whose celebrity ranges far beyond the confines of their chosen sports.

His domination threatens to become absolute, leading Jack Nicklaus to suggest last week that Woods's competitors have run up the white flag in the face of his brilliance.

The Open completes a sequence of titles which began with the US Masters in 1997 - his first major tournament as a professional - and continued with the 1999 PGA championship and the US Open, which he won by a record 15 strokes earlier this summer

As well as the historic claret jug held by the Open champions, Woods also takes a cheque for £500,000 home to Florida, lifting his earnings since he turned professional in 1997 to £10.9m.

Even that sum is dwarfed by his earnings from personal endorsements for a variety of products, including sportswear, credit cards, watches and breakfast cereals, which brought him an extra £30m last year alone.

As a top golfer's life is a long one - Nicklaus, Player, Lee Trevino and Bob Charles, all in their 60s, were competing alongside Woods this week - there will be billions more in the years to come.

Woods started the final round with a six-stroke lead and finished it eight shots ahead of his nearest challengers, Ernie Els of South Africa and Thomas Bjorn of Denmark. His four-round total of 269 strokes, 19 under par, beat the previous record for the Open at St Andrews.

The course had been lengthened specifically to counter the phenomenal length of Woods's driving - uselessly, as it turned out. Others have been able to propel the ball as far from the tee, but none of those could equal his mastery of the subtle arts which move the ball from fairway to cup.

Throughout the entire tournament he stayed out of the Old Course's notoriously vicious bunkers, which pock the greens like snipers' dugouts on the western front.

Record crowds flocked to the course to watch him throughout the four days, creating huge jams. As he arrived on the first tee yesterday afternoon he was watched by a gallery including one boy with tiger stripes painted on his face and another with the swoosh emblem of Nike, Woods's principal sponsor, cut and dyed into the hair on the back of his head.

Those boys will probably be parents themselves by the time Tiger Woods decides to call it a day.

fields.headline: Working through the pain
fields.standfirst: Each week thousands of British employees are written off through long-term illness. Now the government aims to give them another chance.  Ian Boughton  reports
fields.trailText: Each week thousands of British employees are written off through long-term illness. Now the government aims to give them another chance. Ian Boughton reports.
fields.body:
Fifteen hundred small business managers are about to find themselves at the head of a campaign to drag British staff-care into line with the rest of the world. This month, they will be the first of 100,000 companies to be questioned about their ability to bring long-term sick or injured staff back into work. And it is generally expected that they will have no imaginative answers.

People in the UK who struggle with long-term sickness are often as good as discarded, because the mechanisms for helping them back to work are patchy. Three thousand workers every week move from long-term sick leave to incapacity benefit (effectively saying they are unfit to work), and 90% will not return to their jobs.

It's a huge drain on the country's working population - 750,000 experienced workers are already excluded from the job market. The great irony about long-term sick leave is that the three major causes of early retirement - RSI, back pain and stress - are the ones most likely to respond to well-planned rehabilitation programmes. It's just a matter of showing the will to get them back to work.

Now the government is finally recognising that with a little effort the skills and experience of sick workers can continue to be used. Government minister Margaret Hodge will shortly introduce four pilot projects that she hopes will bring 21,000 long-term sick back to the workforce. Their absence from work, she acknowledges, is "a needless waste of skills and experience".

But the TUC believes this does not go far enough. It plans to use its millennium congress in September to call on the government to introduce a statutory duty on employers to help long-term sick staff back to work.

Many of those who leave every year because of long-term illness are women: 10m of them suffer from back pain, 80% of whom have struggled with the condition for more than a year. For too many workers, long-term pain can prompt them to take early retirement, with little support from their bosses. But these staff would be protected, the TUC believes, if employers had a rehabilitation policy, backed by support workers in every NHS region, which would allow them to spot an employee's sickness turning long-term, and put early plans in place for support and recovery.

"Rehabilitation", in the TUC's view, means any method by which people disabled by sickness or injury can be returned to work - through medical treatment, retraining, or by adapting the work environment or working patterns.

Britain has been demonstrably behind the rest of the world in understanding this. In Sweden, a worker disabled by sickness or injury has a 50-50 chance of getting back to work - here, it's 10 to one against.

"In some countries, occupational rehabilitation is work-directed from a very early stage," says Trish Thornton, senior research fellow in social policy at the University of York. Many European employers are obliged to put rehab plans into effect as soon as an employee's illness looks like being long-term - the Swedish have to do it after eight weeks, the Dutch after 12. And once that plan is in place, the worker is protected: a Swedish employee cannot be dismissed while receiving national insurance sickness benefit, and in Germany a disabled worker returning under rehabilitation cannot be dismissed without permission from the authorities. The Americans with Disabilities Act gives similar protection in the US; in Australia, a case-manager "buddy" is appointed, whose first loyalty is to the returning worker, not the employer.

Although it costs an employer to keep a disabled employee's job open, Thornton has discovered several imaginative solutions. The French have devised a subsidy which reimburses supportive employers using money collected from levies on firms that have not met their quota of disabled staff. In New Zealand, the accident compensation corporation supports the wages of the returning person. The disability services in Bavaria are thinking of paying the wages of the "buddies".

By contrast, British rehabilitation schemes can founder because it is not possible to claim sickness benefit and work at the same time. But armed with evidence from around the world, the TUC expects to lay into the subject in September on the theme of "get your rehabilitation in first".

"We believe employers ought to have an action plan ready, should the worst happen," says a spokesperson. "All the evidence suggests that early support maximises the chances of a successful return to work." For employers, who are continually hunting for skilled, experienced staff, this can only be a good thing.

fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.trailText: • Small but influential
fields.body:
 Small but influential

Do you work for a dynamic small firm? The Parcelforce Worldwide small business awards were set up to recognise the contribution of small companies to the UK economy, offering prizes worth £24,000 to the winning firm. Judges will look at financial success, but also communication with customers, commitment to the environment, and the firm's position in its local community. Firms employing up to 30 people can enter by calling 0800 919989 or registering online at www.parcelforce.com/awards before 30 September.

 Access for all

New legislation that forces employers to make workplaces accessible to disabled people must be extended to small firms if employment is to be properly open to people with disabilities. That's the message from the TUC, which sees no reason why companies with fewer than 15 staff (around 90% of UK businesses) should be exempt from the disability discrimination act. "Only when the DDA applies to all UK workplaces will disabled people start to experience those civil rights we all take for granted," says TUC general secretary John Monks.

 Hunt the files

If you're looking for a lost file, look on the boss's desk! That's the advice from document management specialist Kardex. In a national survey, it was told by secretaries that disappearing files are more likely to be found at colleagues' workstations than in their own drawers, and often end up on the manager's desk. The survey found that one in 12 firms spend more than an hour a day looking for lost paperwork, and blue-chip companies are the worst, racking up a daily 96-minutes hunting down files. Kardex estimates British businesses are losing £1.2m every day tracking down bits of paper.

 Message mania

We know we're suffering from "message overload" at work, trying to cope with email, fax, voicemail, mobile phones and the post. But research suggests that 90% of the messages office workers receive are irrelevant. Nearly a fifth of employees questioned by business communications firm Mitel said sorting out their messages was as stressful as dealing with their boss, and a quarter spend an hour or more a day on communications. To help beleagured staff, Mitel has produced a guide called The Messaging Etiquette Guide. For a free copy, call 0870 9093030.

 Personnel know-how

If you have moved from an essentially secretarial position to a role that involves more personnel management, a two-day course from the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development aims to help you develop the skills you'll need. See www.cipd.co.uk/directory2k/ for more information.

Compiled by Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine.

webTitle: Hague in trouble as MEP backs Danish 'no' campaign from central office

fields.headline: Hague in trouble as MEP backs Danish 'no' campaign from central office
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague faced embarrassment last night when it emerged that Tory eurosceptics have raised £100,000 for the "no" campaign in the Danish referendum on the single currency from an office at Conservative Central Office.
fields.body:
William Hague faced embarrassment last night when it emerged that Tory eurosceptics have raised £100,000 for the "no" campaign in the Danish referendum on the single currency from an office at Conservative Central Office.

In a clear breach of the convention that British political parties do not interfere in the internal in the affairs of another country, a Tory Euro-MP based at central office has placed himself in charge of fund-raising for the British end of the Danish "no" campaign.

Daniel Hannan, MEP for south-east England, raised the money after sending out emails to sympathisers. In the email, he asks for cheques to be sent to a postal box number - 31070 - which is registered at his address in Marsham Court, round the corner from central office, where Mr Hague has given Mr Hannan an office for use when he is in London.

Mr Hannan's direct involvement in raising money for the Danish "no" campaign was condemned last night by the foreign secretary, Robin Cook.

He said: "What these Tory anti-Europeans are doing is indefensible. This is a case of Tory double standards. They should respect the Danish people's right to make their own decisions free from external influence. Just as they rightly demand that right for Britain."

Mr Hannan denied that he was interfering in the affairs of another country, insisting that the money would fund newspaper advertisements telling Danes why his group would vote no in a British euro referendum.

"We are not going to tell Danes how to vote," the MEP said. "But it is legitimate for us to explain in the Danish press why we will be voting no in Britain. That will answer the claims of Yes campaigners who say that the Danes would be isolated outside the euro."

His remarks were contradicted by his email, a copy of which has been passed to the Guardian, in which the eurosceptics appeal for money for the "no" campaign. "I think it would be very worthwhile if we were all to donate money to the Danish referendum campaign," the email says.

The disclosure of Mr Hannan's direct role in fund-raising will come as an embarrassment to Mr Hague, who knows that the Tory party should not allow itself to be openly associated with one side of a referendum campaign in a friendly country. The Tory involvement was seized on last night by Mr Cook who called on Mr Hague to crack down on the eurosceptics.

"William Hague must now make it clear that this activity is unacceptable," the foreign secretary said.

"He should prevent Dan Hannan from using central office. If he does not it will be clear that Mr Hannan is operating with his leader's approval." The latest polls show that Denmark is split over the single currency ahead of the referendum in September. European leaders fear that a "no" vote could have a "domino effect" throughout Europe which would lessen the chances of Britain joining the single currency.

Labour will use the disclosure of the eurosceptic fund-raising as another example of Tory extremism over Europe, which shows how out of touch the party is with the rest of the EU. Mr Hague is chairman of the International Democrat Union, a group of centre right parties, most of whose European members are in favour of the euro.

These include the Danish Conservative People's Party which is campaigning for a Yes vote in the referendum which is to be held in September. John Bruton, the leader of Ireland's main opposition Fine Gael party, recently called for the Tories to be expelled from the European People's Party group in the European parliament because of Mr Hague's hardline stance on the EU.

fields.headline: Tell us the truth
fields.standfirst:
Ten years ago, Tony Alliss was killed after a long feud with his neighbour. Was it murder, an accident or self-defence? A trial in 1991 acquitted those accused, but his family still want answers. Sally Weale reports

Special report: gun violence in Britain
fields.trailText: Ten years ago, Tony Alliss was killed after a long feud with his neighbour. Was it murder, an accident or self-defence? A trial in 1991 acquitted those accused, but his family still want answers.  Sally Weale reports.
fields.body:
Disputes between neighbours have become the stuff of light entertainment. Like quiz shows and hospitals, joy riders and vets, rows between people who live next door to each other are deemed perfect material for prime-time television.

But such disputes can become deadly. On Wednesday it will be exactly 10 years since Tony Alliss, a father of four, was shot dead after a long dispute with neighbours over a boundary between their land. Two men, a father and son who lived next door, were accused of his murder but were acquitted after the judge ruled there was insufficient evidence.

The Alliss family has been left feeling doubly aggrieved. As well as losing a husband at father at the age of 40, they believe that the legal system has failed them. The true facts of the case, they say, never came out at the original trial; they feel let down by the Crown Prosecution Service and their former solicitors. They have been striving for justice as they see it for 10 years and they will not rest until justice has been done.

Having been let down by the criminal justice system, they are now bringing a civil action on behalf of Alliss's son, Leigh, who was also shot on the night his father died. They want to prove that the killing was unlawful and they are claiming aggravated damages for the physical injury Leigh suffered, the trauma of the incident itself and subsequent post-traumatic stress disorder. But it is not money the Allisses are after. They want what they say is the truth to come out, finally, in a court of law.

In 1980 Tony Alliss bought a cottage near the village of King's Stanley in Gloucestershire, not far from where he had grown up as a child. Beechwood Cottage was beautifully situated on the south-west-facing lower slopes of the Cotswold hills. An existing kennels business was included in the deal.

There was just one problem: although there was access on foot to the cottage, there was no access for cars - all vehicles had to be left on the side of the road and then there was an uphill walk across a field to the house. Early on, Alliss went to see his neighbour, Terence Maule, a retired merchant seaman, to ask if he would sell him a right of way across his land. Maule refused.

Instead, Alliss, who had a smallholding and worked with heavy plant machinery, reached an agreement with the owners of an area of woodland, Penn Wood, next to his house. He would look after the day-to-day running of the forest, and in return could have the use of a track which ran through it to his cottage.

The arrangement worked well. Then, in 1987, Alliss heard a whisper that the wood was going to be put on the market. He was worried it could mean he would lose vehicle access to his cottage again, so with the help of a friend he raised £175,000 and in 1990 bought the wood. His right of way was once again safe.

A different dispute with Terry Maule then flared up, this time over a boundary between Maule's property and the woodland which now belonged to Alliss. According to the Alliss family, Maule had put up a fence in the woodland, claiming a chunk of land for himself.

After the purchase, Alliss's solicitor wrote to Maule asking him to move his fence back to the true boundary. The Alliss family says Maule ignored the request and claimed the boundary had existed since he bought his property more than 20 years earlier.

The dispute deteriorated. Alliss took the fencing down. Maule re-erected it. Alliss took it down again. There were allegations and counter-allegations. According to Maule, Alliss threatened him and his family on several occasions and once beat him up.

On the night of July 26 1990, Terry Maule and his 19-year-old son Graig decided to guard the fence. They each went armed with a shotgun. According to interviews read out during the aborted trial at Bristol Crown Court in 1991, the Maules came across Alliss taking down the fence. Terry Maule claimed that Alliss tried to grab the gun and there was a struggle between them, during which Graig Maule was pushed to the ground. His gun went off, hitting Alliss, who staggered down the track for about 30 yards before he collapsed and died. Terry Maule ran to call for an ambulance.

Alliss's son, Leigh, who was 14 at the time, was walking the family's dogs on land surrounding the cottage when he heard what sounded like a loud gunshot. He says he ran to the spot where he thought the sound came from and there was another bang. A single pellet clipped him on the arm, causing a minor injury. In interviews with the police read out in court, Graig Maule said he had put his gun down, and when he picked it up again it went off accidentally.

The Maules told police they had taken the guns into the woods in self-defence. "I wouldn't intentionally shoot anyone," Graig Maule told police. "But, you know, I shot Mr Alliss because I was just frightened of him shooting my dad, and I accidentally hit this kid, and I wouldn't do that, of course I wouldn't. I'm not some sort of monster."

The Maules were jointly charged with murder but the judge directed the jury to return not-guilty verdicts. Mr Justice Schiemann told the jury: "Having considered the evidence over the course of a week or so, I am satisfied that you could not possibly properly come to the conclusion that there was evidence here which could make you sure that there was an agreement to murder Mr Alliss - which is effectively what is charged in the first count of the indictment - or that you could be sure that Graig, when discharging that firearm, was neither acting in defence of his father nor doing it by accident, or something in between."

Terence Maule was also cleared of possessing a firearm with the intention of endangering life, and both were given an absolute discharge after pleading guilty to having a shotgun without a licence.

Mr Justice Schiemann then went on to praise the way in which Graig Maule acted "in the circumstances". His father, said the judge, could be "proud of him". The Alliss family could barely believe their ears.

Bob Alliss, Tony's brother, did not sleep for a year after his brother died. He still doesn't sleep well. He has not worked since, and has instead devoted his life to trying to achieve what the family regard as justice. He does not believe that the gun was fired in self-defence; he hopes that the civil hearing, which is listed for January, will establish with evidence from a ballistics expert that the Maules were lying in wait for his brother and that they unlawfully killed him. The Maules' solicitor declined to comment last week.

"For his life to be snuffed out in the way it was and for the so-called facts of his death to be presented as they were in that court was totally beyond belief," says Bob Alliss. His brother, he says, was grossly misrepresented in the trial. He was portrayed as an enormous, physically powerful man of 6ft 4in weighing 18-20 stone who was always fighting. In fact, according to his brother, he was a far less intimidating 5ft 11in and 14 stone, a family man described in witness statements as conscientious, honest, generous, kind and hard-working.

"I've gone through life without even a parking ticket, and then to be confronted with something like this is a joke," says Bob Alliss. "People say, 'You've got to get on with your life.' But that was my only brother. I thought we would, with luck, get to old age together. No one can bring back life. Once life is declared extinct, that's it. But there's a need for the truth to play some part in life as a whole."

Leigh Alliss, now 24, is restless, the tragic death of his father unresolved. "Right from primary school, you get the local copper coming in and teaching you what's right and what's wrong, then something like this happens. I can't settle until it's sorted out. It's like a millstone around your neck. I feel like I'm stuck. You can't move forward. It affects everything in your life.

"We want the truth out. At the end of the day I can't live with this. I will never be able to live the rest of my life until it's sorted out. If we don't get to court, it will have to be sorted another way." Leigh Alliss has already been convicted of assaulting Terence Maule on the fourth anniversary of his father's funeral. The Allisses and the Maules are no longer neighbours, Tony Alliss is dead, but the resentments and grievances will continue until the Alliss family get what they believe is a fair hearing.

The Maules were jointly charged with murder but the judge directed the jury to return not-guilty verdicts. Mr Justice Schiemann told the jury: "Having considered the evidence over the course of a week or so, I am satisfied that you could not possibly properly come to the conclusion that there was evidence here which could make you sure that there was an agreement to murder Mr Alliss - which is effectively what is charged in the first count of the indictment - or that you could be sure that Graig, when discharging that firearm, was neither acting in defence of his father nor doing it by accident, or something in between." Terence Maule was also cleared of possessing a firearm with the intention of endangering life, and both were given an absolute discharge after pleading guilty to having a shotgun without a licence. Mr Justice Schiemann then went on to praise the way in which Graig Maule acted "in the circumstances". His father, said the judge, could be "proud of him". The Alliss family could barely believe their ears. Bob Alliss, Tony's brother, did not sleep for a year after his brother died. He still doesn't sleep well. He has not worked since, and has instead devoted his life to trying to achieve what the family regard as justice. He does not believe that the gun was fired in self-defence; he hopes that the civil hearing, which is listed for January, will establish with evidence from a ballistics expert that the Maules were lying in wait for his brother and that they unlawfully killed him. The Maules' solicitor declined to comment last week. "For his life to be snuffed out in the way it was and for the so-called facts of his death to be presented as they were in that court was totally beyond belief," says Bob Alliss. His brother, he says, was grossly misrepresented in the trial. He was portrayed as an enormous, physically powerful man of 6ft 4in weighing 18-20 stone who was always fighting. In fact, according to his brother, he was a far less intimidating 5ft 11in and 14 stone, a family man described in witness statements as conscientious, honest, generous, kind and hard-working. "I've gone through life without even a parking ticket, and then to be confronted with something like this is a joke," says Bob Alliss. "People say, 'You've got to get on with your life.' But that was my only brother. I thought we would, with luck, get to old age together. No one can bring back life. Once life is declared extinct, that's it. But there's a need for the truth to play some part in life as a whole." Leigh Alliss, now 24, is restless, the tragic death of his father unresolved. "Right from primary school, you get the local copper coming in and teaching you what's right and what's wrong, then something like this happens. I can't settle until it's sorted out. It's like a millstone around your neck. I feel like I'm stuck. You can't move forward. It affects everything in your life. "We want the truth out. At the end of the day I can't live with this. I will never be able to live the rest of my life until it's sorted out. If we don't get to court, it will have to be sorted another way." Leigh Alliss has already been convicted of assaulting Terence Maule on the fourth anniversary of his father's funeral. The Allisses and the Maules are no longer neighbours, Tony Alliss is dead, but the resentments and grievances will continue until the Alliss family get what they believe is a fair hearing.

webTitle: Tabloid's naming of paedophiles condemned by police chief

fields.headline: Tabloid's naming of paedophiles condemned by police chief
fields.standfirst: More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText: A police chief yesterday condemned a tabloid newspaper's naming of suspected paedophiles, saying it risked endangering rather than protecting children's lives.
fields.body:
A police chief yesterday condemned a tabloid newspaper's naming of suspected paedophiles, saying it risked endangering rather than protecting children's lives.

Child welfare groups joined penal groups and police forces in condemning the News of the World, which published the names and photographs of 49 child sex offenders.

The paper claimed its decision reflected public outrage at the murder of eight-year-old Sarah Payne in Sussex and called its campaign "For Sarah". But Tony Butler, spokesman on sexual offenders for the Association of Chief Police Officers, said the paper's action was opposed by top police officers.

Mr Butler, chief constable of Gloucestershire, said he had tried to dissuade the paper from launching the campaign, adding it was irresponsible journalism. "I have had two lengthy conversations with senior News of the World staff during the past week and on both occasions they failed to convince me that what they intended to do would benefit children's safety.

"Anonymity is an essential element of the sex offenders register and I strongly pointed out what the possible pitfalls of publication were. I am saddened they have ignored my advice and published without any evidence that by doing so children's safety would be enhanced.

"Their actions will, I believe, have the opposite effect and put children's lives at risk by driving sexual offenders underground. Past evidence suggests that the publication of such information causes serious breaches of child protection."

The National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders said that the move was "grossly irresponsible". Policy director Paul Cavadino said: "It could drive these offenders underground. Past experience shows that when paedophiles are publicly identified in this way some of them go to ground fearing vigilante attacks."

The paper claimed the Scout Association had opened its files naming 40,000 offenders to its reporters and supported its campaign. But John Fogg, association spokesman, said it took no view of the News of the World's decision and had only provided access to its press clippings on paedophiles.

The News of the World stuck by its promise to name 110,000 child sex offenders. A spokesman said: "We talked to many organisations about what we are doing. Some supported us and some did not. The important thing is that the vast number of people believe what we are doing is right."

A Scotland Yard spokeswoman said: "We are concerned that the publication of details of paedophiles could lead to vigilante acts."

In the past, vigilante action has led to the murders not just of paedophiles but also of innocent people.

A Home Office spokesman said the naming of offenders should be a decision made by the police alone. "There are occasions when they will decide it is in the public interest to name individuals but it is a matter for their professional judgment."

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, was also unhappy with the News of the World. "On the whole I don't think it is good news."

Meanwhile, Sussex police revealed yesterday that a fragment of blue cloth that may have come from Sarah Payne's dress had been found about 12 miles from where her body was discovered a week ago. It was being examined by forensic officers.

fields.headline: Clubbing for a living
fields.standfirst: Karen Porter works in an accounts department with a difference. She's more likely to be dealing with crumpled tenners than chasing company cheques.  Dolly Dhingra  reports
fields.trailText: Karen Porter works in an accounts department with a difference. She's more likely to be dealing with crumpled tenners than chasing company cheques. Dolly Dhingra reports.
fields.body:
Egos, liggers and clubland "personalities", Karen Porter knows them all well. As business manager for Kiss Promotions, an offshoot company of the once-pirate radio station Kiss 100, she spends her life juggling administrative and accounting duties in the hippest nightclubs in the UK, and occasionally in the hedonist's holiday resort of choice, Ibiza.

Based at the Kiss offices in north London, Porter, 29, has worked for the company for five years, after falling by accident into accounting work. "I did a degree in geography, which is not really related I know, but when I moved to London I needed the work."

Her first job was in the accounts department at the fashion company Browns, where she gained the skills of processing payments and dealing with the financial side of the business. But it was the glamorous youth market that she found addictive.

"I always knew that I could never do accounts in a sober environment - it had to be somewhere funky. When an accounts job came along at Kiss, I knew it was a foot in the door of an exciting industry."

After spending 18 months in the accounts department, the company realised it needed someone to ensure that all accounting transactions were carried out in a systematic fashion and Porter was promoted to her current position. Her role was to introduce strict systems and procedures to reduce the risk of dodgy dealings. "Notoriously, clubland is a cash industry and can have a lot of loopholes. Revenue comes in £10 notes at the door on the night of a club. It's difficult and risky and can sometimes be ugly. You need to keep a close eye on things," she says.

But this way of working does have its advantages - there's little time spent chasing invoices or insisting that "the cheque's in the post". "There are not many people within the clubs industry who deal with invoicing and cheques. On the night, you are paying people in cash. It's a raw industry and that's what gives it a buzz. Some people would consider it to be underground. But it's part of my job to ensure everyone follows the rules."

One of the greatest challenges of the job is being versatile. "One minute you can find yourself dealing with very street, very raw club promoters from Manchester, Liverpool or London and you have to speak their language. You have to be able to communicate with them and feel at home. The next day you can be in a meeting with magazine editors and programme directors from Kiss and it's a very, very different environment," she says. "I don't suddenly go all Ali G the minute a club promoter walks into the room. I think it might be a bit obvious to those around me if I did and I don't think I'd retain an awful lot of credibility!"

The company also offers package tours to clubbing mecca Ibiza, and Porter sorts out payments for the big name DJs flown out to perform. This year she will be bagging up payments for DJs such as EZ, Tall Pall, and Graham Gold, who will all be playing at Privilege, the largest club on Ibiza, which holds around 12,000 clubbers.

Porter hadn't been to the island until she flew out last year to find out what all the hype was about. She admits to being blown away by its energy. "They've got purpose-built clubs with palm trees, swimming pools, trapeze artists, fire-eaters, the lot. There's no way that Ibiza can fail to leave an impression," she says.

So what about the island's reported debauchery and excess? "The people who go to Kiss in Ibiza are between 18 and 24, and of course some of them don't exactly pace themselves. But I think that's the appeal in a funny sort of way, they haven't learnt the lessons of life or learnt to be restricted. I guess Ibiza is one of the first places they start learning them," she says.

Back home in London, Porter rarely goes to clubs socially. "Clubbing feels like work. If I went, I would just sit there wondering how much they would have made on the door, how successful the night was, what the production values were like, how much security there was on the door - I'd rather have a quiet meal and a drink and not worry about it."

fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.trailText: "There are few people on the planet more crafty than salesmen," believes Sally Gordon. As PA to Alexander van der Hooft, managing director of Pink Elephant UK, a company which supplies IT staff and services, she has to fend off the queries and patter of numerous salespeople and head-hunters every day.
fields.body:
"There are few people on the planet more crafty than salesmen," believes Sally Gordon. As PA to Alexander van der Hooft, managing director of Pink Elephant UK, a company which supplies IT staff and services, she has to fend off the queries and patter of numerous salespeople and head-hunters every day.

"Everyone wants to speak to Alexander, and a lot will try anything to get through to him, from saying they've spoken to him the previous day, to telling me he'll be furious if I don't put them through."

Gordon balances fighting off the advances of salesmen with more conventional PA duties, but her boss's busy schedule means that she often works quite autonomously. "I screen Alexander's post and email and his calls, and try to deal with as much as possible myself. I manage his schedule and often take on larger projects, such as organising our annual international conference or sorting out the location and catering for the staff spring ball."

Gordon believes that knowing how to be assertive without being aggressive is essential to her work as a PA. "Everything to do with Alexander comes through me," she says, "and I'll often get other people from within the company ringing me to see if he is available, trying to see him as soon as possible. I have to judge when is a good time and often have to be quite firm with people."

But it is external calls that cause the most problem. "I have had people hang up on me or become rude or aggressive simply because I won't put them through to Alexander. One of the best techniques is simply to keep on repeating the same phrase - I always say he is out of the office and that I can't put them through. People do tend to get quite shirty and I think its often based on snobbery - they can't believe that a PA has the authority to deal with them. But Alexander would be furious if I put cold calls through to him so I am genuinely following his wishes."

Not everyone finds dealing with pushy callers so easy. "When I first started here, there were a couple of receptionists who were quite timid," says Gordon. "I'm responsible for the support staff and I decided they should undertake some training to increase their assertiveness on the telephone. If you're young and not very experienced, it can be hard to know how to deal with people who just ring up and will happily lie to get through."

Having the full backing of her boss means that Gordon is confident in her role. "Alexander will always back me up: we present a very united front," she says. "It's great to have such a supportive boss and one who respects my abilities. I feel a bit like a gatekeeper because I am constantly defending him from people who want to see him and speak to him. It does give me satisfaction to get rid of cold callers and salesmen - although they probably think I'm a bit of a Rottweiler."
