fields.headline: School holiday headache
fields.standfirst: As the children race gleefully from their classrooms on the last day of term, working parents face the stress of finding full-time childcare for six weeks.  Kate Hilpern  reports
fields.trailText: As the children race gleefully from their classrooms on the last day of term, working parents face the stress of finding full-time childcare for six weeks. Kate Hilpern reports.
fields.body:
School's out and stress is in. Not for kids, who look forward to the end of term for months, but for parents, who can dread it for every bit as long. "The holidays are hell," sighs Elaine Richmond, a 39-year-old mother of three and PA for a large insurance company in the City. "You'd think that all the recent talk about family-friendly workplaces would make big employers help working mums with the summer break. Not a hope. For the first two weeks, my kids will go to friends and relatives. The next week I've taken off. Then they're on camp, then on a playscheme. All that planning and I'm still left with a week to fill."

Recognising the difficulties faced by parents in the school holidays is a blind spot among employers, even those that are otherwise enlightened on issues of work/life balance. "Care from employers is a patchy, piecemeal service," says Sarah Jackson, chief executive of Parents at Work, a charity that campaigns on behalf of working mums and dads. "It's something that needs improving - and fast."

The summer juggling act so familiar to working parents has, if anything, got more difficult. Gone are the days when grandma and a multitude of aunts and cousins lived down the road; a culture of "presenteeism" means that working from dawn until dusk is now considered normal; and increasingly security-conscious parents daren't risk leaving their kids alone for a minute, let alone half an hour until the childminder turns up.

In addition, says mother-of-two Megan Stewart, a secretary at an advertising firm in Glasgow, kids are more demanding these days. "If you don't arrange something that involves money, they're not interested. And they're so used to be continuously stimulated by computers and televisions that they constantly ask what there is to do next."

Organising full-time care for six weeks is the only answer if you want to keep working in your children's holidays, but this can be crippling financially. Local authority play-schemes can cost as little as £6 a day, and provide supervised activities such as sports, but they often finish at 3pm and access can be severely limited. Full-day alternatives can cost up to £60 a day and even the cheapest summer camps cost around £200 per child per week.

Tempted to despair? There are small signs of improvement. Although still tiny, the number of employers addressing this issue is on the increase, according to Parents at Work. Not surprisingly, the larger the company, the bigger your hope of hands-on help. "These are the companies that have done the research and realise that recognition of the school holidays results in lower absenteeism and increased loyalty," explains Jackson.

Electronics firm Motorola is one such enlightened firm. The company's Scottish headquarters in Edinburgh has a child development centre on-site, where children are entertained and kept out of mischief, but activities have an educational slant. The scheme is open all year, closing just for a week at Christmas.

Carole McKellar, managing director of a business resources firm, came up with her own solution to the childcare problem. "When I was on maternity leave with my first child in 1993, I realised there were no companies that allowed working mums time off when they needed it," she says. "So I set one up." Every contract of employment at McKellar's firm is tailored to an individual's needs, be that term-time working, flexible working, or time off for emergencies. "In return, I get unrivalled staff motivation and loyalty, and when I need them to work extra hours, they're more than willing."

Another option is that offered by some branches of Boots, Tesco and Lloyds TSB, which work in partnership with local daycare schemes to provide available and affordable (often subsidised) places for school-age children. A spokesperson for the London borough of Hounslow, which helps set up such links, explains, "We're just one of the councils around the country working with employers to promote childcare and build links with providers. It's early days, but it will undoubtedly change employers' attitudes to after-school care as well as care in the summer holidays in the future."

"At the very least, companies should give out information on local play schemes that still have places," says Anne Longfield, chief executive of Kids Club Network, a membership and lobbying organisation representing more than 5,000 after-school and breakfast clubs, many of which run activities through the summer. "Employers such as HSBC provide staff with constantly updated information on local schemes."

Some companies are even offering formal breaks to parents who want to spend the entire summer holiday with their offspring. According to recent research, a quarter of US organisations now offer the option of sabbaticals (paid breaks) or career breaks (unpaid). And some British firms are catching on: supermarket chain Asda offers staff the chance to take the odd summer holiday off as unpaid leave. Little surprise that the company was voted family-friendly employer of the year in 1998.

Depressingly for many, provision for working parents is patchy and depends on where in the country you live. Kids Club Network found that children in the south and south east stand the best chance of finding a school holiday place, but even in London where provision is relatively high, there are vacancies for under 4% of children. Research also shows that the majority of schemes do not cater for children over 12.

It all seems a remarkably unenlightened state of affairs. Employers - your end of term report reads an emphatic "could do better".

Some companies are even offering formal breaks to parents who want to spend the entire summer holiday with their offspring. According to recent research, a quarter of US organisations now offer the option of sabbaticals (paid breaks) or career breaks (unpaid). And some British firms are catching on: supermarket chain Asda offers staff the chance to take the odd summer holiday off as unpaid leave. Little surprise that the company was voted family-friendly employer of the year in 1998. Depressingly for many, provision for working parents is patchy and depends on where in the country you live. Kids Club Network found that children in the south and south east stand the best chance of finding a school holiday place, but even in London where provision is relatively high, there are vacancies for under 4% of children. Research also shows that the majority of schemes do not cater for children over 12. It all seems a remarkably unenlightened state of affairs. Employers - your end of term report reads an emphatic "could do better".

fields.headline: School's out - don't panic
fields.standfirst: What can I do?
fields.trailText: What can I do?
fields.body:
* As early as the interview stage, ask employers whether they have provisions for a crèche. Be aware, however, that many run for short working days, close during the summer and take only very young children.

* Find out your company's policy on flexible working hours. Point out to your boss that non-rigid hours suit employers as well as employees.

* Get together with other working parents and request that your company, at the very least, offers information on local schemes that may still have places.

* Find out your company's policy on career breaks or links with daycare schemes. If there isn't one, suggest they consider drawing up one.

* Use your local authority. Most offer a range of activities including sports and crafts-based courses from one-day to week-long events at libraries, leisure centres and local recreation grounds. Many publish holiday activities booklets, free from the library or town hall.

Where can I get advice?

* British Activity Holiday Association publishes a free guide to holiday camps for children and some for adults and children (tel: 01932 252994, www.baha.org.uk).

*Kids' Club Network holds information on more than 5,000 after-school and breakfast clubs, some of which run activities throughout the summer (tel: 020 7512 2112).

* Daycare Trust advises employers and employees on childcare options (tel: 020 7739 2866, www.daycaretrust.org.uk).

*National Association Of Clubs For Young People. Formerly the national association of boys' clubs, it now caters for both girls and boys and has become the umbrella organisation for a network of 2,500 clubs nationwide, many of which run during the holidays (tel: 020 7793 0787, www.nacyp.org.uk).

*The National Trust is a surprising source of inspiration for holiday activities, offering many activities for children at its properties around the country (tel: 020 8315 1111, www.nationaltrust.org.uk).

webTitle: Desktop icons No 29: The water cooler

fields.headline: Desktop icons No 29: The water cooler
fields.trailText: It's mid July and the office is scorching. Fifty sweaty colleagues are crammed into one jam-packed, open-plan birdcage, the air-conditioning is bust and tempers are about to go the way of temperatures. Then you spot it, like a palm-fringed oasis in the hostile office desert. The water cooler.
fields.body:
It's mid July and the office is scorching. Fifty sweaty colleagues are crammed into one jam-packed, open-plan birdcage, the air-conditioning is bust and tempers are about to go the way of temperatures. Then you spot it, like a palm-fringed oasis in the hostile office desert. The water cooler.

Now the much-awaited summer hot spell is finally upon us, visits to the water cooler are becoming more and more frequent. During the winter months, only the two-litres-a-day health freaks and the hungover can be spied imbibing water on tap in squeaky polystyrene cups. Now the entire office convenes in front of the cooler, manager and minion. Thirst, after all, is a great professional leveller.

But thirst alone, of course, does not fully explain the water cooler's appeal. As well as an aqua pick-me-up, the cooler is as close as one comes in the office to a village camp-fire, where information is shared and gossip exchanged. The cup of water, in fact, can be an incidental quest - far more rewarding is the important news one gleans about Ally McBeal's ever-decreasing waistline, the tap-dancing dog on the Big Breakfast and the progress Darren has made with Mel on Big Brother. With topics on tap, the water cooler is the hub of all office activity, the nerve centre of the organisation and the source of considerably more than just H2O.

As well as answering those essential need-to-know questions, the water cooler also throws up queries of its own. Like how does the humble, frail-fisted office employee change the barrel without re-enacting the 100-foot waves from The Perfect Storm? It's a toughie, almost perplexing enough to take one's mind off the Eastenders omnibus. Almost, but not quite.

fields.headline: Desk-bound dogs
fields.standfirst: Do you have to wave a sad goodbye to your poodle or guinea pig each morning? In a bid to lure skilled staff, some employers have thought up a new perk - allowing pets in the office.  Hilary Whitney  reports
fields.trailText: Do you have to wave a sad goodbye to your poodle or guinea pig each morning? In a bid to lure skilled staff, some employers have thought up a new perk - allowing pets in the office. Hilary Whitney reports.
fields.body:
We Brits are renowned for our love of animals - indeed it's often said that we prefer them to people. But Americans may be in danger of becoming equally besotted. As the US economy continues to boom and skilled staff become increasingly sought after, Stateside companies are having to think imaginatively about how to attract and keep the best employees. The answer for a growing number of firms is to allow staff to bring their pets into work.

According to a poll by human resource consultants William M Mercer, 3% of IT firms now have a policy allowing pets in the workplace. It's a small percentage, but translated to the huge internet market could represent a startling number of firms.

Such policies, says a spokesman, are seen as "a low-cost attraction-and-retention technique that can distinguish the employer from competitors". They hope, in other words, that you'll accept their job offer over that of another company if you can park your pooch under the photocopier while you work. And while the consultancy firm insists it's too early to draw definite conclusions from the survey, its analysis does suggest that firms with a pets' policy have a lower rate of employee turnover than those without one. A happy pet, it seems, means a happy employee.

So why are we so keen to take our bulldog or budgie to the office? Pet-sitting issues aside, there is evidence that animals (as long as they are domesticated) can bring benefits to the workplace. If you take your dog, for instance, into work, you will occasionally have to nip outside to take it for a walk - giving an enforced break from the computer screen and a whiff of fresh air. Some companies believe that just the presence of an animal can be soothing and reduce stress levels.

Animals can also be tremendous ice-breakers. Carol Osborne used to work for a large publishing company and one of the directors would often bring her black labrador to the office. "The dog was beautiful, very gentle, and everybody adored her," says Osborne. "She'd lie quietly under Jane's desk and was no trouble. Our office was near Kensington Gardens and if Jane couldn't take her for a walk, the other staff would be practically fighting each other to do so."

But even adorably fluffy little things have their downsides. Sue Emmas, artistic associate at the Young Vic theatre, shared her office for nearly two years with a white rabbit. "Harry was originally one of the cast in a production of Hamlet, but he kept jumping onto the back of Gertrude's train when she walked across the stage, which was obviously quite a nuisance. It was great having him in the office, but he had a habit of chewing the computer wiring which sometimes made the box office computers go down, and after a while it was decided he was too smelly to be in the office."

And this is the (rather obvious) drawback of workplace pets - for every worker who delights in cooing over big brown doggy eyes, there is likely to be a colleague who breaks out in an allergy when the animal is even brought up in conversation. Sadie Sharpe, for instance, used to share a small open-plan office with the MD's good-natured but energetic Alsatian. "It was awful. I love dogs but this one was always jumping up or dribbling onto your lap. I used to go home with dog hairs all over my clothes. The worst thing was that sometimes he was a bit too friendly and he'd shove his nose into your crotch, which was mortifying, particularly if he did it to a client."

There are also important health and safety issues to be considered. How does the presence of a pet affect the company's fire drill? What is the policy on animals in the canteen? A pets policy may have been introduced to encourage some employees to sign on the dotted line, but what happens if new staff join who have a violent dislike to animals?

Osborne's company finally put a stop to its pet-friendliness when it realised that allowing one animal in the building could be the thin end of the wedge. "I suppose they thought that if one person was allowed to bring a pet into work, other people would start to do the same and the building would turn into a menagerie," she says.

Employers eager to add to their perk portfolio should take note. However elusive those skilled staff, it is important to remember that you are hiring them to work as IT professionals, not zoo-keepers.

fields.headline: Vigilance - or vigilante justice?
fields.standfirst: Professionals say 'naming and shaming' of paedophiles puts potential victims in greater danger
fields.trailText: The decision by the News of the World yesterday to publish names and photographs of 49 convicted sex offenders in the wake of the murder of eight-year-old Sarah Payne has reignited the row over the media's role in exposing paedophiles and provoking vigilante attacks.
fields.body:
The decision by the News of the World yesterday to publish names and photographs of 49 convicted sex offenders in the wake of the murder of eight-year-old Sarah Payne has reignited the row over the media's role in exposing paedophiles and provoking vigilante attacks.

Children's charities and chief probation officers attacked the campaign for what they described as "creating a permissive climate for vigilante action".

The newspaper did not give precise addresses but it did list the town or district in which each lived and said it would not stop its campaign until all 110,000 child-sex offenders in Britain had been "named and shamed".

Although it insisted that it was "absolutely not a charter for vigilantes", the paper met a storm of criticism that it was in danger of driving known paedophiles underground and destroying the current official arrangements for monitoring released sex offenders. Last night it was being seen as an attempt to import "Megan's Law" - an American system of public disclosure of the whereabouts of convicted sex offenders - into Britain.

Dangerous

Valerie Howarth, chief executive of the charity Childline, said: "The police and social services have programmes for handling paedophiles in the community and they inform communities when they feel there is a danger to them.

"It is concerning when laws and provisions put in place to deal with this situation are bypassed or risk people taking the law into their own hands.

"You risk innocent members of the public being wrongly identified and targeted and you risk driving paedophiles to move from place to place, possibly becoming more dangerous."

Evidence that such "outing" operations by newspapers can actually increase the risk to children is contained in a dossier compiled by the Association of Chief Officers of Probation. It lists 40 cases of "lynch law" in which released sex offenders went underground or innocent people were attacked as a result of mistaken identities after newspaper "pervert watch" campaigns.

Most of the cases cited happened in the wake of the outrage that accompanied the release of the predatory paedophile Sidney Cooke, and before the introduction of the sex offenders register. At the same time the Sunday Express ran a similar campaign: "Could these evil men be living next door to you?" - giving their photographs and last known addresses.

The Acop survey includes a case where an elderly man was severely beaten after being mistaken for a paedophile "outed" by a local newspaper and the accidental death of a 14-year-old girl after an arson attack on a sex offender that targeted the wrong address.

In some cases offenders had been driven out of the areas in which they were living. In one instance the home of a sex offender was burned down leaving the children in the family, who had been his victims, homeless as well.

"When offenders are driven from their homes, they do not disappear off the face of the earth. They are still in a town or city full of children," the chief probation officers point out. "But they are now living anonymously, perhaps moving from place to place and changing their names to avoid being identified. In these circumstances it is harder for the police to exercise surveillance, or to involve them in treatment programmes which can control their deviant sexual tendencies. The result therefore is more, not less, risk to the public."

The attacks and vigilante action diminished in late 1997 after the Home Office introduced the sex offenders register and a system for limited notification under which headteachers, doctors, youth leaders, sports club managers and others, including landlords, are notified on a confidential basis of the existence of a local convicted sex offender. This is now done in all cases where a professional risk as sessment indicates that parents should be warned.

George Barrow of Acop said yesterday that the association would monitor the impact of the publication of the details of the first 49 offenders by the News of the World. A complaint to the press complaints commission would be lodged if the disclosure of any case had made these arrangements for public protection more difficult or impossible.

"If you are a parent then vigilance must centre on your child and not the person you might suspect. Know where your children are and whom they are with. It is often the person you trust rather than those you suspect who is the abuser." It is this system that the News of the World is challenging, claiming that the Sarah Payne case is proof that it has failed. But the last lord chief justice, Lord Bingham, recently ruled that general community notification, along the lines used in some parts of the United States and urged by the News of the World, could never be justified in British law.

In a case brought by two convicted sex offenders who were identified to a third party by North Wales police, Lord Bingham ruled: "It is not only in the [offenders'] interests but in the interests of society as a whole that they should be enabled, and if need be helped, to live normal, lawful lives. While the risk of repeat offending may in some circumstances justify a very limited measure of official disclosure, a general policy of disclosure can never be justified."

It is a view that the home secretary, Jack Straw, endorsed when he said: "It is vitally important that dangerous paedophiles should be supervised adequately and that the public should be protected from possible further offending by them. This is of course made far more difficult if the effect of the reaction by some members of the public, or some sections of the media, is to drive paedophiles underground."

Anxiety

Although the introduction of the register led to a reduction in vigilante action, ministers are conscious that public anxiety about paedophiles remains high. A review of the effectiveness of the register was announced last month to plug any loopholes such as abuse of a 14-day "holiday" period under which offenders do not need to register changes of address.

It is hoped that a new generation of "tracker tags" soon to come into use will enable police to be alerted when known sex offenders approach a school playground or park at certain times of day.

Underlying the News of the World's campaign is a demand that paedophiles should be locked up for life. Only about 50 of the 110,000 men regarded as convicted sex offenders fall into the category of predatory paedophiles who abduct children such as Sidney Cooke. Most are minor offenders, such as "flashers", or are members of the same family.

Ministers have avoided ruling on whether to bring in such indeterminate sentences and instead have suggested that "tagging for life" might improve public confidence.

In some states in America where the names, addresses and photographs of violent sex offenders have been posted on the internet by the police since 1998 it is also a crime to use such information to harass or intimidate a sex offender, but civil liberties groups remain concerned.

The American civil liberties union said: "The next step would be for the sheriff to go around and rally the neighbours to run somebody out of town."

webTitle: Innocents suffer when law of the lynch mob takes hold

fields.headline: Innocents suffer when law of the lynch mob takes hold
fields.trailText: Fears that the News of the World's naming of paedophiles will lead to vigilante attacks are based on a string of violent incidents across Britain.
fields.body:
Fears that the News of the World's naming of paedophiles will lead to vigilante attacks are based on a string of violent incidents across Britain.

Action by mobs has killed and maimed the innocent and, in cases where those targeted were child-sex offenders, led to lynch mob rule.

Scotland Yard is still hunting the killers of William Malcolm, 47. In February he answered a knock at the door of his east London home and was shot in the head.

Malcolm had been convicted twice for attacks on a six-year-old girl and her brother. He served two years in jail for assaulting the girl, and on release, his abuse resumed.

Neighbours reportedly celebrated the murder of Malcolm, who was linked to a paedophile ring including the notorious child-killer Sidney Cooke.

In March a 24-year-old man was abducted by vigilantes in the Midlands. They beat and tortured him for a week.

The fury unleashed by the thought of paedophiles living in communities has repeatedly led to cases of innocent people suffering.

Francis Duffy, 67, was beaten and severely injured by vigilantes after being mistaken for a paedophile, Brynley Dummett, who had been named by the Manchester Evening News, the Guardian's sister newspaper.

In the West Midlands, a 14-year-old girl was killed when her home was firebombed in an arson attack intended for a paedophile.

Some, such as Paul Webster, could not take the pressure of false accusation. An inquest heard that the 38-year-old unemployed musician from Plymouth drank himself to death after neighbours accused him of being a child abuser.

Webster, who had been giving children guitar lessons, was threatened with a knife and harassed constantly for three weeks. "Beware nonce lives here" was sprayed on the door of his flat.

In some cases, offenders have been repeatedly driven out of the areas in which they try to settle. In one instance the home of a sex offender was burned down, leaving the children in the family - who had been his victims - homeless as well.

Frank Revill, 55, was one person targeted by vigilantes who falsely believed he was a paedophile.

Three years ago, word spread that a child abuser was due to move into his neighbourhood in Folkestone, Kent. Mr Revill was spotted moving things into a house belonging to his daughter. "The vigilantes saw me, put two and two together and got five," he said.

Mr Revill was verbally abused, had windows smashed and received threatening phone calls.

Yesterday Mr Revill said: "The thought of paedophiles abhors me, but at the other extreme, vigilantes should be stopped from taking the law into their own hands."

webTitle: Global battle rages over GM crops as biotech revolution ploughs on

fields.headline: Global battle rages over GM crops as biotech revolution ploughs on
fields.standfirst:
Out of chaos come international biosafety rules, signed but still to be ratified

Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: When Professor Howard Atkinson and colleagues at Leeds University genetically modified a potato to be pest-resistant without the use of chemicals, it was decided to test it in Bolivia, one of the world's poorest and most malnourished countries and the place where the potato originated. The Bolivian government gave permission, and if the trial proves successful Prof Atkinson will not benefit financially.
fields.body:
When Professor Howard Atkinson and colleagues at Leeds University genetically modified a potato to be pest-resistant without the use of chemicals, it was decided to test it in Bolivia, one of the world's poorest and most malnourished countries and the place where the potato originated. The Bolivian government gave permission, and if the trial proves successful Prof Atkinson will not benefit financially.

The grassroots reaction surprised Prof Atkinson. Instead of the experiment, part-funded by the Department for International Development, being welcomed as an attempt to counter a dietary problem, activists went to the village near the proposed trial site and, he said, "provided them [the locals] with misinformation".

The trial has now been delayed for more than a year. The local groups feared that any genetic contamination could never be put right and argued that Bolivia should not risk its most important resource, its biodiversity.

Hundreds of such skirmishes are being fought around the world. While activists try to destroy the credibility of GM crop trials in Britain by trashing sites, scientists, lawyers, politicians, consumer and environment groups, corporations, ethicists, the popular press, international bureaucrats, academics, farmers, food companies, consumers and traders are involved in a global battle over a technology which has been on the market only five years.

Twelve countries are growing GM crops commercially, four more than last year. More than 100m acres are grown worldwide. In the US, where 72% of the crops are grown, more than 30 crops and hundreds of varieties are now sold.

Across the world, thousands of varieties are being tested. Within a few years most of the world could be awash with GM food. In Europe it is another story. Applications to start commercial growing of the crops are caught in the paralysed regulatory system, where there has been a moratorium - which the European commission is now to scrap, to the fury of anti-GM groups.

The industry has invested heavily in the technology and is only beginning to see the returns. The global market is worth about $3bn (£2bn) and should be worth $25bn by 2010. But the shift in public perception has also cost hundreds of millions of dollars in lost markets.

The stakes are equally high for the activists, who see GM food as a social, ethical and ecological cause. Their greatest success is still in Europe, where powerful pressure groups say demand for the food has all but dried up, consumer resistance is as strong as ever, farmers are confused and wary of testing the crops, and big food companies are getting the message. As in Britain, many supermarket chains and food processors are committed to GM-free food, at least in their own brands.

Scientists developing the second generation of GM crops hope that by building in health benefits such as added vitamins or low fat oils they will persuade consumers. Much hinges on what happens in the US. Sweetcorn and sugar beet growers scaled down GM plantings, but soya and cotton are reported to be well up. Polls indicate that support for the crops among US consumers and food and drink companies has slipped.

Seven major GM companies, fearing that the home market could implode, as in Europe, are spending $50m to "build public support for GM". Their campaign seeks to distance these foods from environmental or safety issues and link them to the benefits of GM developments in medicine.

Marketing challenge

"In the past," said David Rowe of DowAgro Sciences, a subsidiary of the GM company Dow Chemicals, "agribusiness has spent only trivial amounts on marketing, compared with the billions spent on developing the technology. The greatest challenge is not in the technology, but the marketing."

In Japan, the leading importer of GM products, a petition of more than 23m names asking US farmers not to plant GM crops chivvied the government into introducing strict labelling.

US embassies and trade missions promote the technology. International scientific bodies, world agriculture bodies and the UN system are moving strongly behind its potential, with caveats about safety and regulation. The World Bank is looking at ways it could assist the development of agricultural genetic engineering in the third world.

"The bank has provided hundreds of millions of dollars to develop agriculture, including biotech, in countries such as Kenya, Zimbabwe, Indonesia, and Mexico, and has asserted that feeding the world is 'inconceivable' without genetic engineering," said Luke Harding, a British activist and author.

Biotech is also becoming an "aid" component. Western governments, together with multilateral donors such as the EU, are beginning to allocate public money to its development in poor countries.

"Intellectually the debate is becoming polarised, with positions hardening," said a South American analyst. "You have powerful northern groups linking with southern organisations pumping out their propaganda, and a frenzied defence of the technology from governments, corporations and scientists. It is becoming a global faultline."

Opponents argue that the revolution is happening too fast to assess its effects properly and that the strict science and safety approach adopted by proponents is too narrow. In rich countries most debate has been about food safety and pollution; in developing countries the concerns are often about socio-economic issues, such as who owns the technology, the potential dependency of farmers and debt.

Uncertainty

Many countries fear going down the route of full-scale GM planting while there is so much uncertainty. Thailand turned down the opportunity to grow GM rice for fear it would be unable to export it. Greece and Brazil say the way forward may be to designate entire regions as GM-free. Tasmania is proposing to use its quarantine laws to ban the foods.

Meanwhile, the trend for the large GM companies to buy up conventional seed companies in developing countries is continuing. The industry is accused of taking advantage of places where there is little or no regulatory control. The companies say they work within existing laws and in some cases help draft biosafety legislation.

In Colombia protesters say that GM trials of cotton, rice, potatoes and tomatoes are taking place without full biosafety laws, and that people have been eating, without their knowledge, imported GM foods.

Olga Berlova, of the Socio-Ecological Union in Moscow, said: "In Russia we know from UN organisations that GM soybeans are growing, yet even Russian officials are unable to get information from companies. The corporations are paying Russian institutes directly to do the trials and bypassing the regulatory system."

In China, where GM cotton and tobacco are grown, a new law will require labelling of GM seeds, the country's first restriction of the crops. Brazil broadly opposes GM crops, mainly for pragmatic reasons, having benefited from selling conventional soya to Europe. The state of Rio Grande do Sul has declared itself GM-free, but the policy is not popular with all farmers, especially those short of feed grain for their livestock after drought.

The GM company Monsanto has faced long delays in introducing its crops in many countries after opposition in the courts and communities. It has now been allowed to undertake large-scale field trials of its cotton in India, but is caught up in a legal battle in Brazil.

Tony Coombes, director of corporate affairs for Monsanto UK, said the growing proportion of neutral and positive news about GM developments bore out what had been happening in the world recently. Acreage was "flat to up", compared with last year, which itself saw a 44% increase on 1998. "With Brazilian ministers listening hard to farmers' demands, China racing to make sure it can feed its population, academics in developing countries asking to be free to make their own minds up, global GM now seems to be taking two steps forward for every one step back.

"Confusion in the debate seems to originate from failure to distinguish what is fact, hypothesis, speculation, opinion and fear of the unknown. There now seems global acceptance that the science isn't perfect, but it is better than the alternative, which is guesswork and stargazing."

Opponents do not see it that way. Greenpeace France said this week: "We are in the middle of a huge fight. It is difficult to predict what will happen."

Out of the chaos, international rules are emerging. This year the first treaty regulating the trade in GM products was signed. The biosafety protocol should, if ratified, allow nations to bar imports of the crops and other GM organisms based on social, environmental, health and social risks. But it could take years to translate into national laws.

webTitle: Straw urges India to speed up appeal by Briton jailed for arms smuggling

fields.headline: Straw urges India to speed up appeal by Briton jailed for arms smuggling
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, is to make a personal appeal on behalf of a former British army officer jailed for life for smuggling guns to rebel groups fighting the Indian government.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, is to make a personal appeal on behalf of a former British army officer jailed for life for smuggling guns to rebel groups fighting the Indian government.

Mr Straw is to urge Indian ministers to speed up the appeal by Peter Bleach against the sentence, which was imposed in Calcutta in February.

Bleach was convicted of parachuting crates of Bulgarian weapons over the eastern Indian village of Purulia in December 1995.

Indian police said the arms, including 500 AK-47 rifles, 250,000 rounds of ammunition, 12 rocket launchers and 100 anti-tank grenades, were for the Hindu cult Ananda Marga.

The obscure revolutionary group is fighting a guerrilla war against the communist government of West Bengal.

Five Russians, members of Latvia's large Russian minority, were convicted with Bleach, whose home is in Howdale, north Yorkshire. The judge said all the accused deserved exemplary punishment and should remain in prison for the rest of their lives.

The Russians were crew members on the plane which made the arms drop but denied knowing anything about the contents of the crates. Bleach claimed he was helping British intelligence set up a sting. He said he assumed Indian authorities had been tipped off by British agents and would arrest the real culprit, who fled after the plane landed.

Bleach also claims that documents showing he alerted the British ministry of defence to the planned operation were not considered at his trial and that parts of a key document -a record of a meeting with special branch officers at his home - were removed.

The five Russian crew members were freed on humanitarian grounds on Saturday by the Indian President, K.R. Narayanan following pressure from the Russian government. They were granted Russian citizenship last year. Russian ministers had repeatedly raised the issue of a pardon for the crew.

But until yesterday's announcement, the British government had chosen not to intervene on Bleach's behalf and the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, did not mention the case during his visit to India in April.

"Our policy is not to intervene until all legal avenues are exhausted," said a Foreign Office spokesman. "The reason why Robin Cook did not raise the issue in April was that the appeal was still pending and it would amount to sub judice."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Man on triple murder charge
fields.body:
Man on triple murder charge

A 31-year-old Northampton man was in police custody yesterday, charged with murdering Claire Austin, 31, and her children, Keiran, eight, and Jade, seven, who were found dead at their home on Monday. He will appear before Northampton magistrates today.

Police refused to name the man, but confirmed they had called off their hunt for the dead woman's husband, Philip Austin.

New Channel safety move

A new ship-reporting system in the Channel - one of the world's busiest waterways - is to be introduced after the sinking of the tanker Erika off the French coast last year.

The new system is due to come into effect next year. All ships over 300 tonnes will be required to give coastal authorities details of position, destination and cargo.

Man dies after cliff fall

A man died and a second was injured after falling 50ft from a cliff in East Yorkshire yesterday. Coastguard watch manager Steve Kinrow said it appeared the injured person had been trying to help his friend at North Landing near Flamborough.

Dead whale on Kent beach

Council workers and Dover coastguards were yesterday trying to decide how to move a 50ft whale washed up on a beach at Warden Bay, Kent.

Three share rollover jackpot

Three ticket holders shared Saturday's £13m national lottery rollover jackpot. The winning numbers were 13, 16, 43, 45, 47 and 48 and the bonus ball 36.

fields.headline: Vanilla dulls sweet craving
fields.trailText: After nicotine patches for people who want to quit smoking come vanilla patches for chocolate addicts who want to lose weight.
fields.body:
After nicotine patches for people who want to quit smoking come vanilla patches for chocolate addicts who want to lose weight.

A study at St George's hospital in Tooting, south London, has found that vanilla-scented patches can significantly reduce the appetite for chocolate and sweet foods and drinks.

Volunteers, all at least a stone overweight, had the patches stuck on the back of their hands. Another group had lemon-scented patches and a control group had no patches.

Within a month, the vanilla group's appetite for sweet foods and drinks, particularly chocolate, had dwindled. They also lost an average of 2.2kg, while volunteers in the lemon group lost 1.4kg, and those without a patch lost 1.1kg.

Catherine Collins, chief dietician at St George's, who led the study, said: "The most interesting thing we found was that the chocolate score was halved for people wearing the vanilla patch."

But the patches failed to affect the volunteers' appetite for savoury snacks, alcohol or boiled sweets.

Ms Collins said it was possible that the scent of vanilla had altered levels of the chemical messenger serotonin in the brain. Chocolate contains a chemical that is converted to serotonin, which is thought to play a role in appetite. A serotonin deficiency can cause depression.

"These are preliminary findings. It needs further investigation," said Ms Collins.

The results of the trial, which involved between 50 and 55 people in each group, will be presented at the International Congress of Dietetics in Edinburgh this week.

The vanilla patches are due to be launched as slimming aids this year by the Aromacology Patch Company in Ilkley, West Yorkshire.

webTitle: Leader: As peers vote on section 28, bigotry must not win

fields.headline: Bigotry must not win
fields.standfirst:
Peers face a crucial vote against prejudice

More about section 28
fields.trailText: Five months ago, almost one third of Labour peers abstained when the Tories successfully moved an amendment to retain the notorious section 28 of the local government act, banning the promotion of homosexuality by schools or local councils. Tonight there can be no excuse for a repeat of such detachment.
fields.body:
Five months ago, almost one third of Labour peers abstained when the Tories successfully moved an amendment to retain the notorious section 28 of the local government act, banning the promotion of homosexuality by schools or local councils. Tonight there can be no excuse for a repeat of such detachment. A series of concessions has been made by ministers to win over evangelical doubt to the section's repeal. Even the bishops are now on side. With changes to both sex education guidelines and the law - under which children will now be taught about "the nature of marriage and its importance for life and the bringing up of children" - no progressive government should make any further concessions to the fundamentalists. The chief fundamentalist, Baroness Young, will remain dissatisfied. She would have only been content with an unequivocal clause celebrating marriage as the only right and proper relationship, with all other stable relationships not just relegated to a second division, but labelled "wrong". If she is opposed to the government's position, as she is, then it is worth the support of progressives. She tried last week to further water down the bill, but failed. She must be defeated again today. Backbench Labour MPs were right to insist that eliminating discriminatory legislation cannot be a matter of private conscience. Labour promised to pursue progressive policies. Tonight peers can ensure the elimination of section 28, giving teachers much more flexibility in combating homophobia in the classroom.

It still won't be easy in many schools. Teenage boys, particularly those who are insecure about their own sexuality, frequently embrace homophobia in self-defence. But a decade ago, conservative teachers were insisting it was impossible to tackle racial and gender prejudices in class. Once section 28 is removed, homophobia should be challenged with as much energy as the best teachers tackled racial and sexual prejudice.

webTitle: Leader: Okinawa was a talking and eating shop

fields.headline: Disdain for the poor
fields.standfirst:
Okinawa was a talking and eating shop

Special report: debt relief
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: If words could repay debts then the world summit in Okinawa would have been less of a shambles than it was. Failure to make any significant progress on debt reduction for developing countries, despite agreement a year ago, casts a dark shadow across the prospects for new initiatives agreed this year.
fields.body:
If words could repay debts then the world summit in Okinawa would have been less of a shambles than it was. Failure to make any significant progress on debt reduction for developing countries, despite agreement a year ago, casts a dark shadow across the prospects for new initiatives agreed this year. The summit committed the US, Britain, Japan, Canada, Germany, France, Italy and Russia to a 25% reduction in the number of HIV-infected young people by 2010 and a 50% reduction in tuberculosis and malarial deaths by the same time. The rich countries also promised to set up a task force to "bridge the information and knowledge divide between the rich and the poor". Noble aims - but what do they amount to beyond being aspirations without a delivery mechanism behind them and with the US Congressional axe poised over anything that costs money? The summiteers supported universal primary education for every child in the world by 2015. This is a vital need at a time when 100m children in developing countries are not in school at all. But willing the end doesn't will the means. The most indebted countries know this to their cost because barely $15bn of the $100bn that rich nations promised to forgive last year has actually been cancelled. Jubilee 2000, the anti-debt lobby, even scorned the G8 plan to bridge the digital divide on the grounds that providing basics such as housing, electricity and telephones were priorities before talking about computers.

Well, maybe. One of the attractions of the information age is that laying down expensive infrastructure for telephones is no longer necessary because the wireless revolution means that information can be beamed down to basic computers (maybe powered by solar energy or even clockwork) with internet access without spending billions on land lines. This can enable parts of Africa which have barely experienced the fruits of the industrial revolution, to leapfrog over it into the internet age. Knowledge, freely available on the web, can help educate poor children in Africa and even contribute to improving farming technology and food production. But it won't be possible unless the poorest countries can escape from the scourge of debt and illiteracy.

Unless something is done quickly, developing countries will fall even further behind. Most new jobs in the west require varying degrees of computer or keyboard skills. Poor people in the third world will increasingly miss out out on this kind of job while feeling the shock waves from US digital dominance which reinforced itself at the weekend when the summit fell in with an American corporate agenda to start new trade talks and to observe intellectual property rights. Developing countries could also suffer from lower prices for primary goods as electronic markets for basic products (like bananas) are established, aggravating the deflationary effects of the info-revolution. There is also evidence of investment being pulled from poor countries in pursuit of dot.com companies in the US and Europe.

If the G8 is going to deal with these problems, rather than a more representative body like the UN, then it will have to reorganise drastically and provide itself with an effective delivery system. At the moment the annual summit is little more than an expensive talking shop. This year it cost an astonishing £500m, a sum big enough to have saved an entire African country. An organisation that spends that much on an event that ignores the desperate plight of the third world is dangerously out of touch with the real needs of the world.

fields.headline: Silencing the left
fields.standfirst:
The one constitutional reform Blair has not delivered is the one that would bolster opposing voices
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: There was always a sneaking doubt that New Labour could be so decent as to create electoral space for would-be political competitors. But now it's official.
fields.body:
There was always a sneaking doubt that New Labour could be so decent as to create electoral space for would-be political competitors. But now it's official.

If there is eventually a referendum on electoral reform the only alternative will, most likely, be the "alternative vote"; a system which would only increase the power of the executive and continue to disenfranchise minority voices.

Naively, I had taken it for granted that New Labour's much vaunted modernisation would include reforming an electoral system rooted in the pre-modern politics of Whig and Tory cliques; and where Blair wavered, the Lib Dems would insist.

But as is the way of all reforms that are not pressed for by a powerful and vigilant movement, secret wheeling and dealing has put pluralism on ice.

The Downing Street mole responsible for the leaked memos of Blair and Gould has given us a vivid glimpse of politics without pluralism: essentially a court from which courtiers are sent out to gauge the feelings of the peasants and then organise pageants to show that the king has their innermost needs at heart.

It's not that before New Labour, democracy ruled whenever Labour occupied No 10. It didn't. But so long as Labour leaders managed, or manoeuvred, the party as a coalition - the late lamented "broad church" - there was at least a veneer of pluralism. Now that the party is run like a public relations consultancy, the truly anti-democratic character of our winner-takes-all electoral system is laid bare.

On reflection, it is not surprising that an electoral system which would extend people's political choices - and in doing so would face Labour with competitors on their left as well as the right, open up the framework of political debate, and strengthen dissenting voices within our culture - is the one constitutional reform that New Labour has not delivered.

They had no idea how devolution would set off a dynamic out of their control - the prime minister imagined that the Scottish parliament would be about as little threat as a big parish council. But as electorally obsessed politicians, New Labour knows perfectly well the consequences of electoral reform. Especially the consequences for them.

Indeed the political pluralism now opening up in Scotland, Wales and London gives them a glimpse of a nightmare from which they want to protect the mother of parliaments and above all, its executive.

Last month, New Labour looked like a shaking building without "give" in a country prone to tremors. But it has a steel protection which in the end will prop it up: an electoral system to which party members react with almost military discipline. Eyes to the right and no talking out of turn.

Already we can see the pressures at work. Talk of an early election, some unfavourable polls, William Hague getting chirpy and the party faithful - those who are left - begin, understandably, to respond to criticism by saying, "Well, yes, you're right but we mustn't let in the Tories". A vicious downward spiral sets in as the spin doctors are allowed to set the agenda: first, they were allowed to get away with Tory spending limits, then with effectively privatising NHS hospitals and a growing number of schools.

Protest is muted as the assiduous work of the social exclusion unit is undermined by policies on benefits and taxation that increase the number of excluded and further line the nest of the comfortably included.

And as the spiral reaches rock bottom, they blame people seeking freedom and security for dying in the effort.

A proportional electoral system is not, of course, a magic antidote to rightwing policies. But at least it would mean that the voices of the large majorities who oppose privatisation, the voters who welcome asylum seekers, the active and armchair protesters who oppose capitalist globalisation would become an unsilencable political force, a persistent day-to-day focal point in public debate.

What is to be done now that the government has put the Jenkins report and its modest move towards political pluralism in Downing Street's capacious bin?

There is still time to build up political pressure for a democratic electoral system. The libertarian pressure group Charter 88 for instance, is in an increasingly militant mood, frustrated by ministers' deaf ears; reclaiming the power of the suffrage is too important to leave to the anoraks.

But at the same time, we need confidently to revive our ability to protest, to act as if we did have political choices; to counter the logic of the electoral system, to take responsibility for public life, to speak out loudly - and to as wide an audience as possible, not just, as so often happens, to those on the left.

In other words, we need to make resistance to the numbing, dumbing consequences of our restrictive electoral system part of our everyday lives.

 Hilary Wainwright is editor of Red Pepper

webTitle: More holiday Britons end up in prison

fields.headline: More holiday Britons end up in prison
fields.standfirst: Charity reports rising number of travellers getting into trouble through naivety, stupidity or villainy, with drugs one of the main pitfalls
fields.trailText: The summer holiday should be the highlight of a gruelling year, the chance to escape humdrum life for a week or two.
fields.body:
The summer holiday should be the highlight of a gruelling year, the chance to escape humdrum life for a week or two.

But for an increasing number of Britons, the trip is becoming the stuff of nightmares. According to the charity Prisoners Abroad, a record number of holidaymakers have found themselves in trouble with police on their travels this year, victims of naivety, stupidity, and plain villainy.

The organisation is dealing with the cases of 1,152 Britons languishing in foreign prisons. It is estimated that another 800 Britons are in jail but have not asked for help, and several thousand are arrested and released without consular involvement. Foreign office officials made nearly 7,000 prison visits last year.

Most of those arrested are men - 1,127, although in the Caribbean the majority of Britons detained are women. A quarter of British prisoners in South America are women.

Nearly all have been charged with drug offences, and many claim they became unwitting "drugs mules" after being tricked into holiday romances.

"A lot of single women go to places like Jamaica, fall in love with someone they meet, and the next thing they know, they are being arrested at the airport or in a hotel accused of drug smuggling," said a spokeswoman for the charity.

"This type of incident is more and more common. It is amazing how many women get caught up in the scam. Drug offences account for 60% of the cases we deal with, but there has been a rise in violent incidents too.

"We now have the highest number of clients that we have ever had, and that figure will rise through the summer as more people go on their holidays."

The countries where Britons regularly get arrested are the United States, France, Spain, Germany and Australia. Thailand and Morocco are also trouble zones.

The charity says while the number of Britons travelling off the beaten track rises every year, many backpackers suffer from "a cultural elitism". Britons are often guilty of not researching their trips thoroughly and not respecting local customs. Carlo Laurenzi, director of Prisoners Abroad, said: "For example, in the Yemen there are strict rules about how you can approach women. Stopping a woman in the street to ask directions could be breaking protocols.

"You can't have a few drinks and then start chatting up a woman. Britons tend to think 'if we do it at home, we can do it abroad'. It gets them into all kinds of difficult positions."

Britons also tend to be ignorant of the severity of local laws.

In India, there is a mandatory 10-year prison sentence for anyone caught with more than 10 grams of cannabis.

The death sentence is automatic in Thailand for drug trafficking. In Spain, anyone caught with cocaine can expect between nine and 14 years in jail. In Nepal, if your visa runs out, it is punished by a £2,600 fine or 10 years in jail.

Photographing shrines, temples and other places of worship is allowed in Sri Lanka with prior permission, but posing with religious statues is not .

A key piece of advice for travellers who find themselves in trouble is - don't argue with the police. "Saying you didn't realise it was illegal is no excuse," a charity spokeswoman said. "It is surprising how many people say 'if only'."

There are more than 20 countries on the Foreign Office "don't visit at any cost" list.

It advises travellers to look at the department's website, at www.fco.gov.uk/travel.

Women at risk

Rachel McGee is serving a 15-year sentence in the Occident women's prison near Havana, Cuba, for drug trafficking.

In October 1998 she was invited by her new boyfriend to join him on a three-week trip to Cuba. During the holiday, friends of the man were arrested and charged with attempting to smuggle 15kg of cocaine. Ms McGee, 24, was not given a separate trial, even though the co-defendants said she had nothing to do with the crime.

Sandra Gregory was freed on Friday after serving seven years of a 25-year sentence for drug smuggling. She was caught with heroin inside a condom in her body at Bangkok airport in 1993.

She returned to the UK to complete her sentence and was freed after the king of Thailand granted her a royal pardon.

Rhana Khalifa , 25, was stopped at Heathrow on December 13, 1997, after a holiday to Jamaica. Customs officials found £260,000 of cocaine in sealed bottles of rum she had agreed to bring back for a friend who was also on the flight.

She denied drug smuggling but was convicted at Isleworth crown court and sentenced to 11 years.

fields.headline: Louis Quilico
fields.standfirst: Baritone with a fine sense of Verdian style
fields.trailText: The Canadian baritone Louis Quilico, who has died aged 75, was much admired at Covent Garden during his few seasons in London during the early 1960s. Both here and in other leading houses round the world, he was particularly noted for performances of Verdi.
fields.body:
The Canadian baritone Louis Quilico, who has died aged 75, was much admired at Covent Garden during his few seasons in London during the early 1960s. Both here and in other leading houses round the world, he was particularly noted for performances of Verdi.

Quilico made his debut at Covent Garden in 1959-60, as Amonasro and Germont, and immediately impressed with his strong, forthright interpretations. He sang Demetrius in the first London performances of Britten's A Midsummer Night's Dream at Covent Garden, in 1961. The same year, his Amonasro, in a revival of Aida, was a virile, impassioned interpretation, praised as "excitingly sung and acted", and he was admired as Sharpless, in Madama Butterfly. That season he also sang Thoas, in Gluck's Iphigénie En Tauride, a role he recorded at about the same time. He was the very epitome of the crazed, vengeful King of Scythia.

The following year his Rigoletto combined fatherly concern with the rage of the frustrated jester to the Duke of Mantua. In other words, his firm tone was tempered by a fine sense of Verdian style. Rigoletto became his calling-card throughout the operatic world; by the end of his career he had performed the part more than 500 times. Also in 1962, at Covent Garden, he sang Father Germont to Sutherland's first Violetta, in La Traviata, when the revered critic of this newspaper, Philip Hope-Wallace, wrote that Quilico afforded "the rarest of operatic joys, the sense of security of a voice firmly and roundly based". That was also my experience at the time.

Why Quilico was not immediately engaged by the then resident company at Covent Garden on a permanent basis is unclear, but it may have been because of the presence of another Australian of the same generation with the company. At any rate, Quilico went off to other pastures. Eventually, he returned, in 1975, to sing Germont, once again to Sutherland's Violetta in La Traviata. His saturnine voice and imposing presence were always an asset in other Verdian parts, such as the Count of Luna (Trovatore), Posa (Don Carlos), Iago and Falstaff.

Quilico was born in Montreal, where his father owned the city's first bicycle shop. He studied at the Montreal Conservatoire, the Santa Cecilia Academy in Rome and the Mannes School in New York, before making his debut with the Opera Guild of Montreal. He first appeared with the New York City Opera Company in 1953, as Germont in La Traviata.

He did not sing at the Metropolitan Opera in New York until 1972, when he made a great impression as Golaud in Pelléas et Mélisande. From then on he appeared regularly with the company. He was also in demand at the Vienna State Opera, the Paris Opéra, the Bolshoi in Moscow, the Teatro Colón in Buenos Aires and throughout Italy. In his homeland, he was long a principal with the Canadian Opera Company and the Opera de Québec.

Quilico was not a subtle artist, but was always a figure to watch on stage because he had a strong sense of what would make an impression on an audience. His commitment to his roles was never in question.

His son, Gino, followed him on to the stage, also as a baritone, but with a lighter voice than his father's. In 1988, in Canada, Gino sang Ford to his father's Falstaff, a jovial, unexaggerated portrayal, and in 1987 they performed together at the Metropolitan. Quilico is survived by his wife, the pianist Christina Petrowska, his son and a daughter.

 Louis Quilico, baritone, born 1925; died July 15 2000

fields.headline: Hubert Maga
fields.standfirst: Extravagant African leader in and out of power in Dahomey
fields.trailText: Hubert Maga, who has died aged 83, became president of the west African republic of Dahomey (now Benin) at its independence in 1960, and was deposed in an army coup in October 1963, a victim of his country's early instability. A tall, placid figure, he got by partly because he was a northerner in a southern-oriented system, but also because he caused little offence. He was naive, and, in power, made classic mistakes, notably thoughtless extravagance while presiding over an unworkable economy.

He trained as a teacher, one of the first northerners in the country to do so, and returned, in 1935, to work in the far north, in the secondary school in Natitingou, of which he became headmaster in 1945.

Until then, he had only been interested in the scout movement, but the postwar upsurge of nationalist activity put him, as one of the few qualified northerners, in the forefront of politics. In 1947, he was elected to the local assembly of Dahomey, and that of the French West African Federation (AOF). In 1951, he sat in the French national assembly as leader of the Dahomeyan Democratic Movement (MDD), a northern-based political party.

Maga was one of the few African politicians to hold a ministerial position in the French fourth republic, as secretary of state for labour from November 1957 to May 1958 - and was inordinately proud of the achievement as the only one among his countrymen to do so. He often wore the Homburg hat and patent leather shoes affected by Parisian politicians of the time.

Back in Dahomey in 1959, Maga played his usual role as flexible man-in-the-middle between two feuding southern politicians, Sourou Migan Apithy and Justin Tometin Ahomadegbe, and became head of government and then president of the republic. His regime soon became the target of the southern political classes, especially the trade unions. He gave them plenty to grumble about, having built a $3m presidential palace in Cotonou, whose reception rooms resembled the film set for Cleopatra.

Maga, who had jailed Ahomadegbe in 1962, was fond of foreign travel, and it was characteristic that, when the demonstrations which led to his fall began, he was on a tour of the far east. The army, under General Soglo, took power and, although Maga was technically to become part of a ruling triumvirate, he was arrested two months later for "embezzlement of public funds" and put under house arrest. He was never prosecuted, and spent the next five years in Paris.

In 1970, however, a new crisis in Dahomey brought back the old politicians to stand in elections, which, because of the three-cornered nature of the country's politics, almost plunged it into civil war. Negotiations between Maga, Ahomadegbe and Apithy finally led to the establishment of a Roman-style triumvirate, with Maga as the first president.

It was an unworkable arrangement. I recall being in the capital, Cotonou, in May 1972, when the triumvirate rotated. All three presidents, clad in frock-coats and top-hats, solemnly changed seats in a movement of musical chairs, while a brass band played. Then their wives did the same. Nothing could have more symbolised the farce that Dahomeyan politics had become, and it was all swept away six months later in the coup of Colonel Kerekou, which changed the country's name to Benin, launched a Marxist revolution, and ushered in 15 years of one of the world's more unlikely peoples' republics.

Benin was the first African country to plunge into the post-cold war democratisation process. A national conference in 1990, however, proscribed anyone over the age of 70 from standing for election - so Maga continued in retirement, moving between his homes in Dahomey, Paris and Nice. He also became as a judge of the constitutional court and an adviser to President Kerekou. It was a final rehabilitation for one who had once been so reviled.

fields.headline: John Lust
fields.standfirst: Dedicated student of ancient and modern China
fields.trailText: The librarian John Lust, who has died aged 81, built up Britain's largest collection of 20th-century Chinese books and periodicals, at the School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS), London University. He also produced two key bibliographical works: Index Sinicus (1964) and Western Books On China Published Up To 1850 (1987). These are essential research tools, which bear his characteristic signature in their highly original subject indices and descriptions. His other works included a translation of an early 20th-century political tract, Zou Rong's Revolutionary Army, an important background document to SunYat Sen's 1911 revolution.
fields.body:
The librarian John Lust, who has died aged 81, built up Britain's largest collection of 20th-century Chinese books and periodicals, at the School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS), London University. He also produced two key bibliographical works: Index Sinicus (1964) and Western Books On China Published Up To 1850 (1987). These are essential research tools, which bear his characteristic signature in their highly original subject indices and descriptions. His other works included a translation of an early 20th-century political tract, Zou Rong's Revolutionary Army, an important background document to SunYat Sen's 1911 revolution.

John was brought up in a conventional Jewish family in Islington, north London. His father was a tailor, and John always looked back nostalgically to the days when the district of his childhood boasted a strong artisan population, its streets home to a string of furniture workshops. He grew up with a strong aesthetic sense, and deplored the excesses of modern mass production.

On his own initiative, he applied for a place at Haberdashers Askes school, a move which opened up the possibility of the scholarly career he was to follow. During the second world war, he served with the Royal Artillery in France and Germany, and subsequently took a degree in French at University College, London. In 1949, he was appointed assistant librarian in the far eastern section of the SOAS library.

At that time, the library still reflected the traditional idea of oriental studies as primarily the study of ancient civilisations. It had few modern Chinese books and, before he could embark on expanding the collection, John had to gain a working knowledge of written Chinese, a task that involved memorising several thousand characters, including those used in both modern and classical Chinese.

Although he was never much good at speaking Chinese, John acquired a good working knowledge of classical and modern syntax. In his study of China, he was drawn to popular culture, rather than the official Confucian culture of the elite. He was especially interested in traditional Chinese handicrafts and popular beliefs.

The collection he built at SOAS was impressive. It had a solid classical base and, in its coverage of 1950s material, outshone most of the better-endowed American libraries. When Leiden University decided to develop its sinological library in the mid-1970s, it promptly dispatched researchers to London to organise mass-photocopying and microfilming of John's collection.

John had a strong social conscience, and his politics were decidedly leftwing. The approaching communist victory in China had first stimulated his interest in the country and, soon after the foundation of the people's republic, he joined the Britain-China Friendship Association, headed by Dr Joseph Needham, which campaigned for China's acceptance into the United Nations. He was an active member of its arts and sciences committee. As time went by, his enthusiasm for such organisations waned, but he always remained suspicious of authority and of official ideologies, both religious and secular.

His retirement years were devoted to his groundbreaking work, Chinese Popular Prints (1966). Published in Leiden, this scholarly book covers the history of the prints themselves, and their methods of production and sale; it also includes a wealth of information on their complex imagery.

John was a shy and sensitive man who could sometimes appear brusque. He valued his independence and never married. In his younger days, one of his great joys was long cycling trips with his brother, Tony. He avoided meetings and conferences, but still enjoyed the occasional concert and lunch with friends. Throughout his life he continued to support worthy causes, and was both loyal and generous to his friends and family, both old and young.

 John Lust, librarian, born September 25 1918; died June 30 2000

webTitle: Cricket hero's child claims share of match

fields.headline: Cricket hero's child claims share of match
fields.trailText: It is billed as a chance to remember one of cricket's greats and to raise money for the family he left behind. This Thursday some of the best cricketers ever to cross a boundary rope, including Ian Botham and Sir Vivian Richards, will gather to play a match in memory of the peerless West Indian fast bowler Malcolm Marshall, who died of cancer in November last year.
fields.body:
It is billed as a chance to remember one of cricket's greats and to raise money for the family he left behind. This Thursday some of the best cricketers ever to cross a boundary rope, including Ian Botham and Sir Vivian Richards, will gather to play a match in memory of the peerless West Indian fast bowler Malcolm Marshall, who died of cancer in November last year.

But as the game's greats prepare to emerge from retirement, a row over Marshall's estate threatens to overshadow the match.

The proceeds of the match, which could be as much as £100,000, will go to the Mali Marshall Trust, a fund set up in the name of Marshall's seven-year-old son by his widow, Connie.

Marshall, however, had two other children by different women, and the mother of Benjamin Parker-Marshall, 8, is demanding that her son be recognised as a rightful beneficiary of the match proceeds and Marshall's estate.

Elizabeth Adegboyaga, a care worker who had a 10-year relationship with Marshall from 1987, was last week granted emergency legal aid to make an application for maintenance out of the estate in Barbados, Marshall's home, and the UK.

While Mali and Marshall's daughter Shelley, born to a third woman, are both beneficiaries of his will, there is no provision for Benjamin.

"All I want is the best for my son, what Benjamin deserves," said Mrs Adegboyaga."I need to make sure he is financially secure, and I feel that as far as this match is concerned, Benjamin and Malcolm's daughter Shelley should be treated the same as Mali, and receive an equal share.

The match has been organised by the Professional Cricketers' Association (PCA), White Sports Management (WSM) and the Bunbury Cricket Club, a charity side run by cricket enthusiast David English, which has raised £15m for charity to date.

Mr English said he did not know of Benjamin's existence when he decided to arrange the match.

"When Macca [Marshall] passed away, I wanted to get some finance into the family and remember a wonderful man and a great cricketer. I think it's probably up to Connie to sit down and see if she wants to make a donation to Benjamin."

Advance ticket sales to corporate customers and the public have already brought in £77,500, and more money will be raised on the day.

Marshall, who was West Indies coach when he was struck down by cancer midway through the cricket World Cup last summer, married Connie six weeks before his death on November 4th. The couple had begun a relationship in the mid 1980s and Mali was born in 1993.

In his will, amended eight days before he died, Marshall left his estate, worth 1,150,453 Barbadian dollars, to Connie, and bequeathed $100,000 and a life insurance policy to his daughter Shelley.

Although there is no provision for Benjamin in the will, Marshall did pay £350 a month in maintenance to him under a court order until his death.

Lawyers acting for Connie Marshall offered Mrs Adegboyaga a lump sum of £30,000 which she did not think sufficient.

That sum is equal to the proceeds of the sale of a house Marshall owned in Hampshire.

webTitle: Auditors accused of failure over quango fraud

fields.headline: Auditors accused of failure over quango fraud
fields.trailText: Senior auditors at Britain's biggest quango are accused today of allowing a criminal ring inside one of the country's largest housing associations to get away with a £1.6m fraud, because they failed to act fast enough after a whistleblower tipped them off.
fields.body:
Senior auditors at Britain's biggest quango are accused today of allowing a criminal ring inside one of the country's largest housing associations to get away with a £1.6m fraud, because they failed to act fast enough after a whistleblower tipped them off.

The housing corporation, which hands out £660m a year to 2,200 housing associations, is condemned by the national audit office for failing to tackle a scandal inside Focus Housing Association - one of the biggest providers of homes for the poor in the west midlands.

When the serious fraud office was finally called in, three people were charged and later jailed for between nine and 18 months for a bribery and corruption ring that involved a property dealer, Darshan Ram, and two housing association development staff, John Hartshorn and Keith Hinson.

The scandal involved bribes worth £22,000 being paid to the two Focus staff members by the property developer to "oil the wheels" of the purchase of nearly 50 overvalued homes. Focus overpaid nearly £1.1m for 220 properties and then had to pay £500,000 to renovate another 96 that were supposed to be in good condition.

The national audit office, which sought to investigate the housing corporation's failure to check the accounts, was blocked from access for six months by officials who feared they could be blamed for incompetence.

Details of the scandal are published on the day Andrew Smith, chief secretary to the Treasury, proposes to reverse a Lords defeat which would allow Sir John Bourn, the comptroller and auditor general, instant access to the accounts of housing associations and other large quangos.

He will be challenged today in the Commons by David Davis, Tory chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, and Labour backbench MPs who believe the government could be accused of making life easy for people who want to defraud public bodies.

Mr Davis said yesterday: "The findings in this report show exactly what happens if similar problems arise elsewhere. The NAO's investigation was delayed while the watchdog had to negotiate separately its right to investigate Focus with the corporation, and then the association itself. This is pointless, wasteful and absurd. It shows all too clearly the need to ensure the NAO has automatic powers to investigate such risks to public money immediately."

The investigation into the scandal at Focus - revealed in the Guardian in 1996 - was originally much wider. More than 500 property transactions involving seven housing associations were investigated.

A confidential report examined 116 property deals in Birmingham, Wolverhampton, Sandwell and Coventry where it was alleged nearly 30% of the sale price had been creamed off to the cartel.

Other allegations of mortgage fraud, corruption, and lavish lifestyles financed by public money in a defunct Birmingham housing association, Shape, which specialised in looking after single homeless people, were also investi gated by the police and auditors. This association was taken over by Focus.

The NAO admits that by the time it was able to get access to files that may have been held at the housing corporation to look into these allegations, they were no longer available and there was not enough evidence to investigate further.

Richard Clark, the chief executive of Focus, welcomed the report, since his organisation originally reported the scandal to the housing corporation which led to the imprisonment of two of his staff.

He said a new management team had been brought in and "the association is no longer a cause for concern".

The housing corporation says it has overhauled its management since the scandal and issued new guidance to housing associations.
