fields.headline: Barbosa Lima
fields.standfirst: Intrepid spokesman for democracy and press freedom in Brazil
fields.trailText: The grand old man of Brazilian journalism, Barbosa Lima, who has died aged 103, dedicated his life to the cause of democracy, not always a soft option in his homeland. A fervent nationalist, he wrote more than 3,000 articles and 70 books - and himself became a living history book. Lucid until the end, his last article was published in the newspaper Jornal do Brasil the day he died.
fields.body:
The grand old man of Brazilian journalism, Barbosa Lima, who has died aged 103, dedicated his life to the cause of democracy, not always a soft option in his homeland. A fervent nationalist, he wrote more than 3,000 articles and 70 books - and himself became a living history book. Lucid until the end, his last article was published in the newspaper Jornal do Brasil the day he died.

Lima was born only five years after slavery had been abolished in Brazil. It was four years since the abdication of the emperor and the proclamation of the republic. The Brazilian 20th century was one where oligarchic presidents gave way to revolutions, civil war, populism, military dictatorship and democracy. Lima played an active part in many of these episodes and, as his country entered the new millennium, he was still writing furious articles, criticising its "government of pigmies" for supporting privatisation, globalisation and the demands of the International Monetary Fund.

The son of a traditional family in the northeast state of Pernambuco, Lima began his career at 15, on the newspaper A Provincia, in his hometown of Recife. In 1926, he became the youngest ever president of the Brazilian Press Association (he died the oldest).

He was initially a supporter of Getulio Vargas, who overthrew the oligarchies of Brazil's various states in 1930 to become president and then dictator. In 1938, Lima was made president of the Sugar And Alcohol Institute, where he took steps to improve the social conditions of the workers and encouraged the first successful experiments in the use of gasohol, a fuel mixture of alcohol and petrol.

Between 1935 and 1964, he was active in party politics, and in 1948 was elected governor of Pernambuco. He also became a federal congressman for the state, although he lived most of the time in the then capital, Rio de Janeiro.

A fierce opponent of the generals who seized power in 1964, Lima - then aged 76 - stood for vice-president in the 1973 campaign of the opposition leader Ulisses Guimaraes. They knew their campaign did not stand a chance against the repression and censorship of the military, who had already chosen their next presidential general.

When asked why he took part in a lost cause, Lima said that if anyone could prove to him that inertia was better than protest, he would give up. For him, it was important to show that the will for democracy existed, and that one day the military regime would end.

In 1992, at the age of 95, he headed the signatures on the petition requesting the impeachment for corruption of President Fernando Collor, and was one of those who delivered it to the national congress. For many, Lima had become "the moral reserve of the nation", a man whose lifelong defence of democracy, press freedom and Brazil's interests was matched by his personal probity and honesty. He lived so long he seemed eternal.

Lima was married for 67 years to Maria Jose, aged 92, who survives him, together with three children, seven grandchildren and four great grandchildren.

 Alexandre Jose Barbosa Lima Sobrinho, journalist, born January 22 1897; died July 16 2000

Between 1935 and 1964, he was active in party politics, and in 1948 was elected governor of Pernambuco. He also became a federal congressman for the state, although he lived most of the time in the then capital, Rio de Janeiro. A fierce opponent of the generals who seized power in 1964, Lima - then aged 76 - stood for vice-president in the 1973 campaign of the opposition leader Ulisses Guimaraes. They knew their campaign did not stand a chance against the repression and censorship of the military, who had already chosen their next presidential general. When asked why he took part in a lost cause, Lima said that if anyone could prove to him that inertia was better than protest, he would give up. For him, it was important to show that the will for democracy existed, and that one day the military regime would end. In 1992, at the age of 95, he headed the signatures on the petition requesting the impeachment for corruption of President Fernando Collor, and was one of those who delivered it to the national congress. For many, Lima had become "the moral reserve of the nation", a man whose lifelong defence of democracy, press freedom and Brazil's interests was matched by his personal probity and honesty. He lived so long he seemed eternal. Lima was married for 67 years to Maria Jose, aged 92, who survives him, together with three children, seven grandchildren and four great grandchildren.  Alexandre Jose Barbosa Lima Sobrinho, journalist, born January 22 1897; died July 16 2000

webTitle: Comment: The final stretch of the US presidential election race

fields.headline: High noon in Texas
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore went to San Antonio last week, which is the equivalent of saying Gary Cooper took a walk down Main Street at high noon.
fields.body:
Al Gore went to San Antonio last week, which is the equivalent of saying Gary Cooper took a walk down Main Street at high noon. Gore packed heat. The Lone Star state put a weapon in his hand by confessing it had overspent its budget by $650m. Gore was eager to add that evidence of fiscal indiscipline to a fusillade about his presidential rival GW Bush presiding over a backwater state.

He smiled when he said it. He told Texans he understood their governor to be "a warm and engaging personality", but the presidency was more than a popularity contest. The nice guy was running the most polluted state in the nation, the second worst for the number of people below the poverty level, the worst for families without health insurance. Of course, smiled Gore, GW had been a short-term governor with limited powers. Texas's dismal rankings weren't all his fault, but how come his tax cuts put oil companies first and poor kids a bad second?

Governor GW gave Gary Cooper a miss. He made a quip about the budget shortfall -"I hope I'm not here to deal with it" - and stayed cool for all of 24 hours. He took the teeth out of his prepared remarks which asserted that Gore should be "ashamed" for presenting a "travesty" of the Texas budget - even with the overruns it is in surplus with $1.4bn in reserve. Instead, he said, "I welcome him here", then got four friends to front up a Proud of Texas committee. That will play well in Texas, which has long known it is the Most Misunderstood State in the nation.

High noon suggested the strengths of both men as we head for a tense home straight. Bush ducks well, and his charm has captivated the media. According to the Centre for Media and Public Affairs, he's had 357 network TV stories since January compared with 198 for Gore. He is grilled once over lightly; Gore is burnt toast. But Gore seems to have been charged up by the inequities in his treatment by the mainstream press. He is going for broke, no pussyfooting trying to please all the people all of the time.

T he risky foray into Texas was the climax to an all-guns- blazing week. He made an electrifyingly emotional speech to the National Association for Coloured People, obliterating the memory of a whimsical appeal to them by GW. Then, in a televised town-hall meeting from Iowa, he sturdily told ques tioners that no, he wouldn't match the Republican pledge to abolish estate duties and no, he wouldn't make the same tax cuts for married couples. Next question.

It seems to be working. He has closed a polling gap that had opened up to nine points. Now it is GW's turn. We have had months of striptease about whom he will choose as his presidential running mate, and the stage is set for the seventh veil to drop. His choice will show how big a man he is, as they like to say in Texas. Is he big enough to take on his right wing?

He has two ways he can do that. One is to name Tom Ridge, governor of Pennsylvania. Ridge is a Vietnam war medallist and a Catholic, and he and GW are friends. But Ridge favours abortion rights and the right wing has said it will desert en masse if he's chosen. The power of the right must be judged considerable if Bush turns away from his friend since putting Ridge on the ticket would probably assure him Pennsylvania's important 22 electoral votes.

Naming Senator John McCain would send an even clearer signal. It would suggest GW can set aside personal feelings for the good of the party, that he's confident enough to handle the toughest guy around. McCain has endorsed Bush but made it clear he does not rate or like him or his advisers. McCain is trouble. Could Bush keep him in his basket? After the election, he could dispose of him as John Kennedy disposed of Lyndon Johnson once he had served to pull in Texas in 1960, but there's the risk of a row as the campaign hots up.

Yet McCain would draw millions of swing voters to Bush and pretty well guarantee him the White House. Sixty House Republicans have been lobbying for McCain, with their own skins in mind, and McCain has now - typically - recanted from his earlier sulk that he would refuse to be nominated. Like the other half-dozen potentials, he has dutifully given his phone numbers for the next few days to Wyoming's Dick Cheney who is heading the VP search team.

In the frenzy of speculation, Cheney's own name is now mooted as the front runner. Bush may surprise us all, as his father did when he named James Danforth Quayle (who?) in 1988. Naming the loyal Cheney, his Dad's defence secretary, would be safe and sound. Naming either Ridge or McCain would mark the emergence of George Walker Bush on Main Street.

webTitle: Comment: Why the NHS needs more than cash

fields.headline: Faith healing
fields.standfirst:
The NHS needs more than an injection of cash. Private-sector concepts have eroded goodwill

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The NHS needs more than an injection of cash.
fields.body:
What happens this Wednesday will determine Labour's fate at the next election. That's a heavy load for Alan Milburn, the health secretary, to have on his shoulders when his boss ("I want to be personally associated with this") stands up in the Commons to deliver the NHS national plan which Milburn has been cooking up in recent months.

Forget the brouhaha over leaked neurotic memos which so intrigue the armchair psychologists. It is the state of the NHS which has the potential to warm chilled hearts to New Labour. It is the one issue over which the British public never lost faith; throughout the darkest Kinnock days, they always believed that Labour, whatever else it could or couldn't do, would do right by the NHS.

Nothing more damages New Labour now than the ebbing of that faith. Has Milburn managed to devise a scheme to deliver tangible improvement by the next election? That is the kind of political challenge which makes fighting a war in Kosovo look easy.

Suspicion about how this crushing political imperative will distort the national plan (which is dangerously being spun as the most radical overhaul of the NHS since Bevan) seems to be part of what lies behind healthworkers' strangely muted response to Gordon Brown's largesse last week. One would have expected more euphoria from an organisation which has suffered from chronic underfunding for two decades. Instead, there seems to be pervasive anxiety about the many strings attached to the extra billions, and more pessimism than ever about the chances of marrying the founding ideals of the NHS (free, equal healthcare) to higher standards of delivery. Morale is bumping along at rock bottom.

Some of this Mr Milburn may dismiss as the neuroses of professionals, particularly doctors, fearful of losing their fiefdoms (the widely heralded onslaught on the consultant-is-king culture) and fearful accountability in careers built on a paternalism veering between the benign and the arrogant. But there are wider anxieties where, worryingly, Milburn appears to have got the wrong end of the stick.

In many of the carefully placed leaks at the weekend, patients are referred to as consumers and the NHS as a "modern service-sector industry". The language is absurdly inappropriate. Healing cannot be industrialised. The central shibboleth of consumerism is choice; when you're ill, you don't have the strength to make complicated choices. You want a relationship of trust and mutual respect in which someone very experienced and knowledgeable helps to make you better. When I was in the agonies of childbirth, the important issue was not whether they were offering me the full range of pain relief (the excellent midwife quite rightly said no to my request for an epidural, and a few minutes later I delivered the baby) but the quality of my relationship with the midwife.

This is not new to thousands of health workers (particularly women) who understand that the quality of relationship underpins healing. Nor is it new to the NHS patients who can gratefully recount how in their moment of vulnerability and fear, a harassed, tired nurse, doctor or ancillary found the time and generosity to attend to them as people, not just throughput statistics.

It is those millions of acts of human kindness which are so often taken for granted or ignored while the focus is on fancy machines and ground-breaking operations. This tradition of generosity and goodwill has been dangerously corroded by Tory and now Labour's application of private-sector concepts which no doubt make sense when selling insurance policies or double glazing but when applied to healthcare, dehumanise both healer and patient.

This is most apparent when Mr Milburn repeats his mantra that the patient must come first. A wholly admirable ideal is in danger of going adrift here. Most accept there has been a lack of accountability in the NHS: unchecked rogue doctors such as Richard Neale and Rodney Ledward are only the most egregious cases. The balance of power between patient and doctor needs to shift.

But the idea that one or other must come first, and that their interests are in conflict isn't helpful. The job satisfaction of nurses or doctors is not in opposition to the patients but usually coincides with their interests: they want to heal you, you want to be healed. Another Milburn mantra is that the NHS must be consumer-led. But a consumer-rights culture is corrosive in healthcare; you burden staff with mounds of paperwork and bureaucracy in complaints procedures, and it costs billions to settle medical negligence cases.

More disturbingly, many doctors justifiably suspect that the government is using what it sees as a fortuitous string of doctor scandals for its own ends. The fear is that, like the Tories, the government is undermining the power of the professionals, purportedly to empower patients, but in fact to strengthen its own centralising power.

The oddest tendency of government policy throughout the public sector is centralisation. There's a common management blueprint being applied to teachers and police as much as healthworkers, and it is simply carrying on where the Tories left off. First, set targets; second, monitor and evaluate progress (which generates huge quantities of paperwork and bureaucracy); third, reward achievement of targets, or punish failure. What teachers, policemen and doctors hate about this is most obviously the bureaucracy, but also a) the restrictions on their autonomy, b) the implied lack of trust in which big brother at the centre has to keep looking over your shoulder to see whether you're doing your job and c) the blaming when targets are not matched.

This theory went out of fashion in the private sector about a decade ago. Big corporations realised the heavy-handed carrot and stick approach created a culture of compliance. As Stalin and Mao Zedong discovered, this breeds a myriad of ingenious ways to cook the books. Teachers drill their pupils in Sats, doctors fiddle about with waiting lists, all so the politicians can flourish their triumphs. Companies realised in the 90s that management structures had to be flat and decentralised. What motivated people was autonomy. The management gurus sounded like 60s radicals when they talked about empowerment. It's the shape of many new dot.com companies, and it is arguably more important than the dream of stock options (which look wobbly now anyway) in attracting so much young talent.

Already, plenty of posts can't be filled in the NHS, and as demographics make the labour market more competitive, this will get worse. Mr Milburn's plans depend on recruiting more highly motivated, dedicated staff. But it isn't just more money which will attract them - it is a rewarding job instead of the stress experienced by many in recent decades of failing to do the impossible.

webTitle: Police issue computer 'aged' photo in hunt for missing boy

fields.headline: Police issue computer 'aged' photo in hunt for missing boy
fields.trailText: A new picture showing how Ben Needham, who went missing as a toddler, could look now is posted on a website today, the ninth anniversary of his disappearance from a Greek island.
fields.body:
A new picture showing how Ben Needham, who went missing as a toddler, could look now is posted on a website today, the ninth anniversary of his disappearance from a Greek island.

Ben, his mother and grandparents had moved from Sheffield to Kos, and he was last seen on July 24 1991 near the farmhouse which the family was renovating. No trace of him has been found since, despite a big publicity campaign.

The computer-generated image has been produced using an American technique adopted for the first time by British police to help trace a missing person.

It shows Ben as a smiling 10-year-old with blue eyes and blond hair cut in a fringe. It resembles a family snapshot.

The picture has been posted on the UK Missing and Exploited Children web site, set up in March by police forces around the country. It is hosted by the computer company Computer Associates, and has the support of several charities. South Yorkshire police spokesman Jim Greensmith said: "We are hoping this image might just throw up new information which will help our inquiry.."

The website can be found at www.missingkids.co.uk.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Kohl's missing papers turn up
fields.body:
Kohl's missing papers turn up

A cache of files whose disappearance from the German chancellery helped raise suspicion about Helmut Kohl's 16 years in power is in the hands of a foundation affiliated to his party, a newspaper said yesterday.

A report in the Bild am Sonntag newspaper quoted the head of archives at the Konrad Adenauer Foundation as saying that many of the files presumed missing were in the foundation's possession and it would allow the government to see them sometime next month.
AP, Berlin

Ban on Sharif holding office

A special court set up by the Pakistani military regime has sentenced the ousted prime minister Nawaz Sharif to 14 years' hard labour and banned him from politics for 21 years, on charges of corruption. He is already serving two life sentences passed in April.

But it is unclear whether Saturday's ban will be considered legal if and when constitutional democracy is restored. Mr Sharif refuses to recognise the court.
Reuters, Attock

Children held in Florida siege

An armed ex-convict wanted for allegedly killing a shop assistant and wounding a sheriff's deputy is holding five hostages, four of them children, in a house near Orlando, the police said yesterday.

Jamie Dean Petron, 41, of Plantation, Florida, is suspected of a weekend crime spree in which four people have been shot.
Reuters, Orlando

Berlusconi says he beat cancer

The Italian opposition leader Silvio Berlusconi said in a newspaper interview published yesterday that he had won a battle against prostate cancer.

The billionaire media mogul, who was prime minister in 1994, told La Repubblica newspaper that he had had surgery in May 1997 and was now cured.
Reuters, Rome

Ivory Coast extends poll

Voting in yesterday's constitutional referendum in Ivory Coast will go into a second day because of severe organisational problems, the communication minister, Henri Cesar Sama, said. Voting would continue until 6 pm today.

The ballot should have ended at 6 pm yesterday but many polling stations opened late and voting was delayed in others by a lack of ballot papers or equipment.
Reuters, Abidjan

North Korea and US to meet

The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, and North Korea's foreign minister, Paek Nam-sun, will meet this week in Bangkok, to discuss "issues related to bilateral relations", the Korean Central News Agency reported yesterday.

The meeting, the highest level of contact between the two countries, will take place before the Associa tion of Association of South East Asian Nations' regional forum.
AP, Seoul

Pumping begins on oil tanker

Pumping out an estimated 6,000 tonnes of fuel from the stern of the Erika, the tanker which leaked oil on to France's Atlantic coast last winter after splitting in two, began yesterday, officials said.

The two halves of the vessel are on the sea bed six miles apart.
AP, Paris

Surgery under the hammer

A South African private hospital will open an internet auction today offering a range of plastic surgery operations with a starting price of one rand (10p).

"The bidding will be open-ended for one operation per day. The operation will go to the highest bidder," Jack Shevel, chief executive officer of Netcare, South Africa's biggest private hospital group, said.

He denied that the auction was a publicity stunt, but said he expected the South African Medical Association to be less than supportive.
Reuters, Cape Town

webTitle: VIPs shun inauguration of Peruvian president

fields.headline: VIPs shun inauguration of Peruvian president
fields.trailText: Up to 300,000 people are expected to protest in Lima later this week against President Alberto Fujimori's election victory, which has been criticised by the international community for gross irregularities.
fields.body:
Up to 300,000 people are expected to protest in Lima later this week against President Alberto Fujimori's election victory, which has been criticised by the international community for gross irregularities.

The demonstrations, which organisers hope will be the biggest in recent years in Peru, are being timed to coincide with Mr Fujimori's inauguration on Friday.

Protesters started leaving coastal shantytowns and villages from the Andes to the Amazonian jungle last week. The organisers are predicting that 100,000 people will arrive in the capital to add to the 200,000 residents they expect to take to the streets to accuse the president of winning a third term illegitimately.

Street vendors have started selling homemade masks for use if the police fire teargas.

webTitle: Racists regard Buchanan as path to power

fields.headline: Racists regard Buchanan as path to power
fields.trailText: White supremacist groups are being attracted to the Reform party - until now known for its centrist stance - by the presidential campaign of the former rightwing Republican Pat Buchanan.
fields.body:
White supremacist groups are being attracted to the Reform party - until now known for its centrist stance - by the presidential campaign of the former rightwing Republican Pat Buchanan.

Far-right organisations such as the National Alliance, the Liberty Lobby and League of the South, and American fans of the British National party have pledged Mr Buchanan their support at rallies and on websites.

They have also held fundraising events and collected petitions for the "gopatgo2000" campaign, according to the Washington Post.

Mr Buchanan is a practising Roman Catholic who frequently denounces homosexuals and the "Israel lobby". He is widely expected to beat John Hagelin, a little-known physicist, for the Reform party nomination at next month's party convention.

But evidence of far-right support for Mr Buchanan is likely to worry members of the Reform party, an umbrella organisation which has largely eschewed involvement in social policy debates in order to focus on campaign-finance reform and free-trade issues.

Mr Buchanan, who tried to win the Republican presidential nomination in 1992 and 1996, has already clashed with Reform party members over his stand on many social issues.

He has insisted that he is neither racist nor anti-semitic. But his attacks on third-world immigration, and talk on his website of restoring "traditional American values" have attracted extremist support.

An editorial in a newsletter of the American Friends of the British National party said that a Buchanan-led nationalist party was the closest thing America had to the BNP.

"Our type of people - nationalists - have been joining the Reform party all across America and this is going to almost guarantee that Buchanan will be its candidate in November," it said. "The Reform party could soon become an American nationalist party in all but name."

Buchanan supporters are reported to have solicited petition signatures at "white rights" meetings.

Will Williams, a leader of the National Alliance movement, wrote in an email to a US reporter that he was "interested in the Reform party becoming the party of the white".

Mr Williams, who has become active in the North Carolina branch of the Reform party, had rallied his alliance supporters in an earlier email, saying: "It's our job to get out there in our areas, to raise consciousness, attract and radicalise 'those very people' - OUR people - then organise them into a majority.

"Many good people will have joined a much more radicalised, white-friendly Reform party come November... It is going to be a very interesting year with the Jews constantly screaming 'NAZI!' at PB [Pat Buchanan]."

The Liberty Lobby, an anti-semitic organisation, is understood to have established a fundraising committee called Independent Americans for Pat Buchanan.

There was no response from the Buchanan campaign team yesterday but Angela Buchanan, his sister and senior campaign adviser, issued a statement.

It said: "My brother Pat does not now and has never belonged to any organisation or group that preaches or practises intolerance or hatred... And if any member of any such group has gravitated to our campaign, it was without our knowledge, or consent.

"But if they have, they probably did so because they came to believe the malicious lies about my brother spread by such institutions as the Washington Post."

The Post had reported that Mr Buchanan was supported by Don Wassell, campaign manager for David Duke's far-right presidential bid in 1988 and head of the American Nationalist Union.

Mr Wassell wrote in the Nationalist Times: "It's now or never for rank-and-file conservatives to prove they are patriotic Americans first, and party supporters second.

"Pat Buchanan has methodically and effectively... taken over the Reform party with the intention of making it into a genuine America First alternative to the two-party tyranny."

webTitle: US astronomers discover new moon of Jupiter

fields.headline: US astronomers discover new moon of Jupiter
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: US astronomers have discovered a new moon of Jupiter. The mysterious little satellite joins a family of 16 moons, but it is the first to be discovered in a quarter of a century.
fields.body:
US astronomers have discovered a new moon of Jupiter. The mysterious little satellite joins a family of 16 moons, but it is the first to be discovered in a quarter of a century.

The new moon, S1999/J1, was formally discovered last October but was mistaken for an asteroid. An astronomer spotted it using an 80-year-old telescope at Kitt Peak, Arizona, when Jupiter was as close to the earth, 370m miles away, as it ever gets on its journey round the sun.

What was first called asteroid 1999UX18 moved in an unusual manner. For a while astronomers took it for a comet. Then they calculated that the best explanation for its trajectory was to assume that instead of orbiting the sun it was orbiting Jupiter.

Astronomers at the minor planet centre in Cambridge, Massachusetts, who keep the official records of such celestial discoveries, checked their sky records for possible previous sightings before pronouncing it a new moon.

The first moons of Jupiter were spotted by the Italian astronomer Galileo. The last Jovian moon was discovered in 1974. It was a lump of rock about five to 10 miles across and was christened Leda.

The latest find has yet to be named. It is about three miles across and orbits the planet, the biggest in the solar system, at a distance of 15m miles and takes two earth years to make one round trip.

webTitle: Town where a Soviet dream turned sour

fields.headline: Town where a Soviet dream turned sour
fields.standfirst:
Its scientists were the envy of the world. Now some of the top brains are manual workers. Our three-part series on the decline and rebirth of Russian science begins in Siberia
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Beneath the streets of Akademgorodok a maze of tunnels links key buildings so that academics in Russia's science town never need emerge into the harsh Siberian temperatures outside.
fields.body:
Beneath the streets of Akademgorodok a maze of tunnels links key buildings so that academics in Russia's science town never need emerge into the harsh Siberian temperatures outside.

In winter, workers at the institute of nuclear physics make their way along curving dimly lit walkways. The rationale of the underground system, one scientist explained, was to prevent research time being wasted in the rigmarole of wrapping up against the cold.

When Akademgorodok was created from nothing in 1957, its founders spent considerable time assessing how to make life easier for the thousands of scientists who were to abandon their comfortable lives in Moscow to labour for the good of Russian science in bleak Siberia.

On a site 30 miles south of the polluted industrial city of Novosibirsk, trees were planted, flats were built and spacious, well-equipped laboratories were set up. Academics were given a concert hall and a club - the House of Scientists - where they were to spend sober evenings together discussing research developments.

Hundreds of tonnes of sand were imported at great expense and scattered on the stony shores of the nearby Ob sea to create the illusion of a beach on which the scientists could relax at weekends.

For the first 30 years the town - with its 37 institutes and thousands of researchers working together to push back the boundaries of knowledge - was a symbol of the grandiose intellectual ambition of the Soviet regime.

Scientists were treated with deference in the USSR. Lenin began to promote their interests immediately after the revolution, aware of their importance in the creation of a powerful new society. In the lean years they received extra rations.

Later, under Stalin, a sense of national insecurity boosted the state's devotion to science. Most scientists escaped the repressions because they were needed to develop the country's ability to make weapons. Even those who were imprisoned continued to work in specially developed research camps.

"We were slaves to the totalitarian state, but we didn't mind because we were doing interesting work and we felt that the state needed and respected us," said Vitaly Ginzburg, a physics professor, who worked during the 1940s to develop the Soviet atom bomb.

Science was not a mere adjunct of Soviet life - it was at its core, the key to transforming Russia from a backward agricultural country into an industrialised mighty world power, equipped to defend itself against the capitalist enemy.

The government poured large measures of the budget into cultivating this scientific base, squeezing ideological pride from internationally acclaimed - and feared - advances: pioneering aeroplanes, and later rocket technology; the first man in space; the first atomic power station; the hydrogen superbomb.

For most of the 20th century the Soviet Union raced on, matching the achievements of America.

Akademgorodok - meaning small town of academics - was part of that tradition. Sophisticated space technology was developed in one institute, while down the road mathematicians pioneered computer technology and biologists wrestled to make Russia's crops sturdier, using new genetic engineering techniques.

But in the past 10 years it has come to symbolise the disastrous decline of Russia's academic tradition.

It is generally accepted that there are two reasons why Russians move to Siberia - either they are romantics or they come as prisoners. The scientists who founded Akademgorodok in 1957 were romantics. Many who remain see themselves as the prisoners of their own shattered project.

No one has forgotten the early optimism. Towards the end of the 50s it had become obvious that Siberia had massive natural resources: petroleum, gas, coal, timber, diamonds and minerals. But with the country's brainpower concentrated in Moscow and Leningrad - now St Petersburg - there was nobody to exploit its potential, so President Nikita Khrushchev backed a scheme to move leading scientists and research students from western Russia to the Siberian wilderness.

Just 12 years after the ravages of the second world war, the state somehow found enough money to establish the science oasis. The scale of the project was phenomenal. The main street, Lavrentiev Prospect, named after the town's founder Mikhail Lavrentiev, was once listed in the Guinness Book of World Records as "the most scientific street in the world", because of its high concentration of institutes.

As well as undertaking research aimed at developing Russia's conventional and nuclear military potential, scientists were encouraged to focus on pure science, to find answers to the big questions, simply for the sake of academic advancement.

Today the institutes - physics, chemistry, genetics, biochemistry, mathematics, electronics and more - all remain. A few, run by energetic directors, have transformed themselves into profitable enterprises by winning lucrative research contracts from western companies.

But they are a minority. As their funding dwindles, the rest have had to abandon research projects and survive on a fraction of their former income. Many are dusty shells, virtually abandoned by their scientists, some of whom have been forced to turn to manual labour to supplement their miserly or non-existent income. Meanwhile the most talented of the younger generation have slipped abroad and students, disheartened by poor job and salary prospects, stay away.

With a shortage of money for laboratory equipment, there is no question of even attempting to keep up with developments in Europe and America. And with the influx of rich communiting businessmen, many young scientists can no longer afford the rents.

The privations suffered by scientists in this town echo the hardships of colleagues throughout the country since the collapse of the Soviet Union. In real terms Russian science now receives a seventh of the government funding it did in 1990, leaving hundreds of institutions struggling to survive.

Genady Kulipanov, vice-chairman of Akademgorodok's governing body and a professor of nuclear physics, said: "In the late 1980s I found it hard to explain to friends in the west what the process of perestroika [rebuilding] really meant. Now I tell them perestroika - it was destroyka. We didn't really rebuild anything, we just destroyed a great deal.

"The government stopped funding pro jects. There were no new institutes. A lot of the more energetic and best-qualified people left and went abroad or went into business. The spirit of the town changed."

Scientists here remember the lean years from 1991 to 1996 with horror, proferring graphs with drooping curves -testimony to the funding collapse and - charts with soaring curves to demonstrate the flow of scientists abroad.

Desperate to approach the future with optimism, many of Akademgorodok's workers are hopeful that Vladimir Putin is the man to restore the prestige of Russian science. They interpret the new president's commitment to restoring a powerful Russian state as an indirect pledge to boost their funding.

Mr Putin's advisers are making all the right noises - stressing the urgency of developing Russia's scientific, technological base to revitalise the economy. But the president does not have long to contemplate the disarray he has inherited. Academics agree that an increase in funding must begin immediately, before the crumbling structures of Russia's scientific base disintegrate.

"It is impossible to go on like this. If the process of the last 10 years continues for another 10 years then there will be total collapse," said Professor Vladimir Likholobov, deputy director of one of Akademgorodok's more succesful institutes, the Institute of Catalysis.

But for men such as the founder of the town's medical institute, Professor Vlail Kaznacheev, 75, who devoted their lives to developing the Soviet scientific dream, the changes have come too late. Sitting in the bare lobby of the House of Scientists Mr Kaznacheev is despairing about the events of the last 15 years.

"Our salaries have dropped radically, but we've lost everything else too. We used to get money for animals, laboratories, materials, equipment, expeditions and flats," he said.

"Without expeditions and new equipment, we can't continue the research. The process has been devastating."

Tomorrow: The virtual brain drain .

fields.headline: Russia comes in from the cold
fields.standfirst: Diplomatic Putin impresses in debut that makes no mention of loan terms
fields.trailText: Russia edged closer to joining the select club of leading industrialised countries with an impressive display of diplomacy by its new president, Vladimir Putin.
fields.body:
Russia edged closer to joining the select club of leading industrialised countries with an impressive display of diplomacy by its new president, Vladimir Putin.

Despite his countries parlous economic plight, Mr Putin made his summit debut and immediately established himself as a rising star in the G8 firmament.

The ex-KGB spy's polished performance was the talk of the summit and some leaders said it was time to make Russia a full member. "Before he was more a guest and a protagonist. Now he's one of the eight," said European Commission president Romano Prodi.

For now Russia is excluded from pre-summit talks that the G7 - the US, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada - holds on financial and economic issues.

What appeared to please G7 leaders was the fact that Russia's debt was the dog that did not bark in Okinawa. Mr Putin could have put G7 countries in a difficult spot by asking for easier terms on $42bn of loans to western governments that Russia inherited when the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991.

But Mr Putin, determined to confirm Moscow's status as equal partner, never raised the question. Indeed, he insisted that the final communiqué have no separate reference to Russia. "Putin asked us not to mention a single country in the G8 final document and we did that," said Italian prime minister Giuliano Amato.

On the core issues of the summit, the G8 was upbeat about the recovery in growth since a financial crisis swept Asia, Russia and many parts of the developing world in 1997 and 1998.

"The world economy will grow strongly this year, and we are particularly encouraged by the strength of recovery in crisis-affected countries," the leaders' communiqué said.

The leaders were particularly impressed by Putin's account of a trip he made last week to North Korea, the Stalinist hermit state now slowly opening up to the outside world. German chancellor Gerhard Schröder called it "brilliant".

Mr Putin's predecessor, Boris Yeltsin, had been more of a "guest performer", said another G8 leader, whereas Mr Putin was "one of the G8 club".

It could be that this summit will be remembered not only for what it did and did not do on poverty, but for the way Russia came in from the cold.

Mr Putin reported back on an offer made to him by enigmatic North Korean leader Kim Jong-il to scrap his state's missile programme in return for help on space exploration.

The proposal was the main foreign-policy talking point of the summit, with leaders unsure what to make of it.

"It's not clear to me what the offer is [and] what is being requested in return for it," said President Clinton, whose administration is debating whether to build a national missile defence shield to ward off attacks from states such as North Korea.

The Russian leader encouraged the rest of the group to reach out to Kim to help to defuse Cold War tensions on the Korean peninsula, where he said conditions were still potentially explosive.

"I have the impression the leader of North Korea knows how to hear and to listen... It is possible to do business with him," he said.

What appeared to please G7 leaders was the fact that Russia's debt was the dog that did not bark in Okinawa. Mr Putin could have put G7 countries in a difficult spot by asking for easier terms on $42bn of loans to western governments that Russia inherited when the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991. But Mr Putin, determined to confirm Moscow's status as equal partner, never raised the question. Indeed, he insisted that the final communiqué have no separate reference to Russia. "Putin asked us not to mention a single country in the G8 final document and we did that," said Italian prime minister Giuliano Amato. On the core issues of the summit, the G8 was upbeat about the recovery in growth since a financial crisis swept Asia, Russia and many parts of the developing world in 1997 and 1998. "The world economy will grow strongly this year, and we are particularly encouraged by the strength of recovery in crisis-affected countries," the leaders' communiqué said. The leaders were particularly impressed by Putin's account of a trip he made last week to North Korea, the Stalinist hermit state now slowly opening up to the outside world. German chancellor Gerhard Schröder called it "brilliant". Mr Putin's predecessor, Boris Yeltsin, had been more of a "guest performer", said another G8 leader, whereas Mr Putin was "one of the G8 club". It could be that this summit will be remembered not only for what it did and did not do on poverty, but for the way Russia came in from the cold. Mr Putin reported back on an offer made to him by enigmatic North Korean leader Kim Jong-il to scrap his state's missile programme in return for help on space exploration. The proposal was the main foreign-policy talking point of the summit, with leaders unsure what to make of it. "It's not clear to me what the offer is [and] what is being requested in return for it," said President Clinton, whose administration is debating whether to build a national missile defence shield to ward off attacks from states such as North Korea. The Russian leader encouraged the rest of the group to reach out to Kim to help to defuse Cold War tensions on the Korean peninsula, where he said conditions were still potentially explosive. "I have the impression the leader of North Korea knows how to hear and to listen... It is possible to do business with him," he said.

webTitle: New drive to fight illegal logging

fields.headline: New drive to fight illegal logging
fields.trailText: Leaders of the world's most powerful nations moved yesterday to tighten up the $70bn global timber trade in a renewed drive to combat illegal logging and protect the eco-system.
fields.body:
Leaders of the world's most powerful nations moved yesterday to tighten up the $70bn global timber trade in a renewed drive to combat illegal logging and protect the eco-system.

The G8 endorsed the need for sustainable forest management when they pledged in a final communiqué: "We will examine how best we can combat illegal logging, including export and procurement practices."

Environmentalists welcomed the fresh impetus for the campaign to conserve the world's ancient forests, being depleted at the rate of one football pitch every two seconds.

The G8 consume 74% of the world's forestry product exports, but they have been criticised for paying too little attention to where their timber comes from.

In Brazil, the government says illegal logging operations account for 80% of the trees chopped down in the Amazon rainforest.

But loose regulations and poor oversight make it almost impossible to assess whether a log has been obtained from a sustainable source or from ecologically precious forests.

Under a British initiative, the governments of the G8 agreed yesterday to set an example by considering ways to ensure that public purchases of timber come from approved businesses, such as those certified by the Forestry Stewardship Council.

By also promising to look into export practices, the G8 took a step further on the logging issue than in previous summits.

However, Canada, the main timber exporter among the group, and Japan, the main importer, remain reluctant to establish a new system of rules.

Conservationists welcomed the G8 move, but they said the words would have to be backed up by actions if they were not to suffer the fate of initiatives made at the Birmingham summit two years ago, which have made little progress.

"This is a welcome shift of direction," said Martin Kaizer of Greenpeace.

"We are very happy that procurement practices have been mentioned, but now we must watch carefully to ensure that this plan is implemented."

During the summit, four Greenpeace activists were arrested and the group's ship - the Rainbow Warrior - was raided by riot police after they tried to deliver eight logs to the G8 leaders.

fields.headline: Clinton blocks market access
fields.standfirst: Move to aid poor countries fails
fields.trailText: President Bill Clinton blocked G8 commitments to assist poor countries in securing greater market access, European officials said.
fields.body:
President Bill Clinton blocked G8 commitments to assist poor countries in securing greater market access, European officials said.

The Europeans had sought a deadline of between three to four years for granting the 48 poorest nations better market access for their food products in the industrialised world, a senior European official told news agency AFP.

The Canadian prime minister, Jean Chretien - backed by France - proposed an increase in aid of between five and 10% from developed countries but this too was blocked by the US, sources said.

"My proposal was well received but certain governments did not want to commit themselves to a certain figure," Mr Chretien told reporters after the summit in Okinawa.

European officials said Mr Clinton could make no such commitments due to his need for the support in November elections of special interests such as unions. "The failure of Seattle was not because of agriculture but was down to the refusal of developing countries to give in to US pressure to include labour issues in the trade talks," he said, referring to the WTO talks in that city.

"And Clinton came to Seattle to help Al Gore win the support of the unions. The same causes will produce the same effects," he added.

Despite the united front there remain deep disagreements. Sources say there were heated discussions over whether Japan's idea of exporting computers to poor countries is appropriate. UN secretary general Kofi Annan this weekend reproached G7 leaders for too many promises and too little action.

webTitle: We don't care where you come from because it's where you are going that counts

fields.headline: We don't care where you come from because it's where you are going that counts
fields.trailText: As a small company, the people we deal with expect a fairly homogenous group of people. In fact Rools - that's all 10 of us - has the cultural make-up of a global corporation. We already have seven different nationalities and the number is rising.
fields.body:
As a small company, the people we deal with expect a fairly homogenous group of people. In fact Rools - that's all 10 of us - has the cultural make-up of a global corporation. We already have seven different nationalities and the number is rising.

We have recruited two people who could have walked into practically any company: our marketing director, who used to work for one of the world's leading fast moving consumer goods manufacturer, and our operations director, who worked for one of the UK's biggest banks. Neither is British; one is Lebanese and the other a New Zealander.

They came to the UK because of opportunities both in the new and old economy. Of course, international finance has built a home here and that helps attract top talent, too.

One member of the team is an American. A question we often ask ourselves is why he is not working in Silicon Valley. The short answer is lifestyle.

He came to Europe because he thought he would enjoy the easier-going culture here. It's hard work, but perhaps the business environment is less uptight than that in the US. Anyway he liked it so much he stayed.

We like to think Rools offers him the excitement of a Palo Alto start-up company, but with a European-style atmosphere.

From the start, we knew that we wanted an international team. Rools needs the diversity of background and culture to enable us to expand effectively into other markets. However, we have surprised ourselves at the level of ethnic diversity we have already achieved.

Given our multicultural make-up, we like to think Rools would not indulge any national stereotypes. Working here gives you a globalised outlook.

Sometimes, however, national traits do shine through. The marketing director has surprised everybody in the office by her rather vigorous negotiations with one of our creative agencies. "I'm Lebanese," she tells us, "I have to feel I have got value for money."

Perhaps, surprisingly, it has not been a huge challenge to manage the diversity of cultural backgrounds in our small team. The team's international outlook coupled with their relaxed personalities means that we all get on. There is conflict, but it is the healthy kind that helps resolve issues.

Rools has two new members joining the technical team on Monday, both of whom are British. Where you come from is not going to bother us, it is where you are going to that counts.

Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are co-founders of Rools.com, a service that lets teenagers buy securely online without a credit card

fields.headline: Okinawa diary
fields.trailText: There is not much to be said for having more style than substance, but Tony Blair was voted the most fashionable leader at the G8 summit. Flying the flag for "Cool Britannia," the Prime Minister sported a blue suit, rather than the blacks and greys of his counterparts, which won him the votes of an electorate of the eight leaders and 600 journalists.
fields.body:
There is not much to be said for having more style than substance, but Tony Blair was voted the most fashionable leader at the G8 summit. Flying the flag for "Cool Britannia," the Prime Minister sported a blue suit, rather than the blacks and greys of his counterparts, which won him the votes of an electorate of the eight leaders and 600 journalists.

Bill Clinton had the last laugh, however, being voted the funniest G8 leader.

By arriving late and leaving early, Bill Clinton hardly endeared himself to his Japanese hosts, but did he really deserve the punishment he suffered during his keynote speech at the Okinawa peace park? Not only was the puffy president made to swelter without shelter under the midday sun for an hour, but he was seated close to a sign that read, "Beware of snakes", which was visible on millions of TV screens.

Irritated Japanese organisers threatened to pull the plug on their guests as protocol went out of the window on the final day. Traditionally, no leader should leave the summit venue or give a final press conference before the chairman, but the gaffe-prone prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, needed so long to prepare that the others grew tired of waiting. In a vain attempt to stop Jacques Chirac from speaking first, the organisers warned that they would cut the electricity to his microphone.

Okinawans may have felt put out by the bizarre catering arrangements at the summit. Instead of offering visiting leaders and journalists the chance to sample the local cuisine, the organisers opted to have all the food cooked at the posh hotel Okura in Tokyo and then flown 1,000 miles to the venue in refrigerated containers. A Japanese foreign office spokesman said this huge expense was necessary because "we didn't want the press corps and world leaders to suffer from stomach upset".

Seattle it wasn't. The placards read "Smash the summit", but the only threat from the protest by the Zengakuren revolutionary student movement was that one of the participants might die of embarrassment. Only 40 people took part in their march on the G8 venue and they were watched every inch of the way by 10 times as many riot police. Demonstrators could hardly have felt further removed from the riots of Seattle. Given the remote location and hotel prices of up to £320 a night, few could afford the journey to Okinawa and those that did were stifled by a staggering 22,000 police.

In thinking up a name of a new organisation to address the digital divide between technologically rich and poor nations, the G8 leaders almost adopted a barking mad idea. The first proposal for the panel of experts was Digital Opportunity Group, until officials realised that this would have had the cute, but not very flattering acronym DOG. At the last minute, this howler was avoided by settling on the "dot force" (Digital Opportunity Taskforce), which is definitely more PC.

Unlike the debt-strangled nations of the globe, the ranks of press corps who swelled Okinawa have not left empty handed. Journalists have been given a bag of treats, each containing a digital tape recorder, locally brewed sake, and tropical beachwear.

Never mind the big issues, the hottest ticket in town was a Saturday night gig by Japan's answer to Britney Spears, Namie Amuro. The diminutive popster enthralled the leaders of the world's richest countries during a reception hosted by the Okinawa State government with a rendition of the summit single entitled Never End. Luckily for those attending it did.

fields.headline: Airbus feud threatens UK jobs
fields.standfirst: European group may withdraw wing work from BAE's factories in Bristol and North Wales
fields.trailText: The European Aeronautic Defence and Space company, owner of 80% of Airbus, is threatening to exercise its right to take away lucrative work on wings for the Airbus fleet from BAE Systems, its partner, senior Eads executives made plain over the weekend.
fields.body:
The European Aeronautic Defence and Space company, owner of 80% of Airbus, is threatening to exercise its right to take away lucrative work on wings for the Airbus fleet from BAE Systems, its partner, senior Eads executives made plain over the weekend.

Rainer Hertrich, Eads co-chief executive, said at a series of briefings in Oxford the majority shareholder in Airbus could transfer production of wings for the entire range of aircraft, up to the planned $10.7bn A3XX superjumbo, and restructure BAE's activities in the UK under last month's deal to create Airbus Integrated Company.

Two large UK factories would be hit. BAE's operations at Filton, near Bristol, and at Broughton in North Wales make wings for the Airbus aircraft and would be devastated by any switch in production.

The threat to use its effective veto, agreed in talks with the Department of Trade and Industry, will overshadow this week's Farnborough Air Show where Airbus is to announce multi-billion orders for the A3XX and the A400M military transporter and step up its fight for supremacy with Boeing.

It illustrates continuing corporate and personal conflicts between Eads and BAE since the UK group opted early last year for a merger with GEC's Marconi defence arm rather than with DaimlerChrysler Aerospace (Dasa), the German arm of what is now Eads - despite public and private protestations of a thaw in top-level relations between the two.

BAE has privately cast doubt on the wisdom of setting up Eads, formed from the merger of Dasa, Aerospatiale Matra and Spain's Casa, and the Eads share price has stuck below the €19 offer price in the part-float two weeks ago. But Eads executives insisted at the weekend the group would be fully integrated by 2002.

Mr Hertrich, continually asserting Eads control over AIC, said: "We have full freedom to change anything in the UK but only if it is for the benefit of the shareholders. As long as wing development in the UK is profitable there's no need to change anything."

Andreas Sperl, AIC's chief financial officer, pointed out that if AIC took away BAE's agreed workshare on wings and built them elsewhere in the group - probably in Hamburg - it would spell the end of the partnership.

But the Eads executives made clear their determination to run AIC against BAE's assertion it is a stand-alone company. BAE gave up several key veto rights under the deal to set up Airbus as a fully-fledged plc but the UK company can still block the business plan, any new partners (such as Italy's Alenia) and any change of name.

BAE, which has the right to exit AIC after three years, has said its share of AIC's pro forma operating profits in 1999 of €1.033bn would have been €207m for its 20% stake. It expects bigger earnings from the plans to save €350m from Airbus annual costs by 2004.

Airbus, which aims to capture at least 50% of the global market for bigger jetliners and shove Boeing into second place after decades as world leader, is to announce at Farnborough firm orders for its planned superjumbo from Emirates, the Middle East airline, and possibly Singapore International Airlines in deals worth up to £3.9bn. Emirates is set to take 10 A3XXs and SIA a further 10, with six options.

Dr Sperl, confirming that AIC has so far 50 orders and 20 options for the A3XX, said Airbus needed to sell 230 to make the two-tier superjumbo profitable and expects to sell 780 by 2021. The first flight is due in 2004 and it enters service in October 2005.

The $10.7bn development cost, he said, covers four versions of the A3XX, including a 656-seater and a freighter. Governments will give a third of the cost in repayable launch aid, with a further 20% coming from "risk-sharing" partners such as Saab and around $1bn from suppliers. The two AIC partners will contribute around 40% while Boeing is thought ready to spend up to $5bn on its stretched jumbo, the 747X.

Adolfo Revuelta, Eads programme chief, said the A400M would enter service at the end of March next year. Orders for 220 versions of the European rival to Boeing's C17 and Lockheed Martin's C130J are due to be confirmed this week from seven governments.1919

webTitle: Second battle of Bannockburn to beat developers

fields.headline: Second battle of Bannockburn to beat developers
fields.trailText: The site of a defining event in Scotland's history, the Battle of Bannockburn, is facing a fresh conflict with a very modern adversary.
fields.body:
The site of a defining event in Scotland's history, the Battle of Bannockburn, is facing a fresh conflict with a very modern adversary.

After centuries of neglect, the battlefield where Robert the Bruce vanquished the army of Edward II in 1314 is under threat from encroaching industrial and housing estates on land where Scotland fought for its freedom.

A 20-year structure plan approved by local councils has identified parts of the site to the east of Stirling for large scale commercial and residential expansion.

There is no legislation protecting battle sites in Scotland, and while the exact parameters of Bannockburn have never been agreed, it is generally accepted that parts have already been developed.

There is only one memorial to the encounter, a statue of Robert the Bruce at Borestone in Stirling, where the Scottish army raised its standard. It was saved from a housing development by a wealthy benefactor, who gave it to the National Trust in the 1930s.

The flat land where the two armies met has no memorial and is made up of farm land, a disused council tip and a dual carriageway. A small circle within this area is marked on Ordnance Survey maps as the battle site, but military historians have recently identified the nearby Millhall area as the centre of hostilities. Under the council plans, Millhall is to become an industrial estate.

Archie Bone, a local historian who has launched a campaign to have the land preserved, said: "They can't build on a national battle site like this. It is outrageous.

"They keep saying the site is just this small circle on the map, but the battle took place over two days. There were thousands of people involved. It was spread over a wide area."

Mr Bone's contentions are supported by Peter Reese, a military historian and author who has also identified Millhall as the key area of conflict. "I was concerned before that no plaque or monument was in place to guard the real site against any future developments," said Mr Reese. "But now I'm told there isn't even any legislation protecting it, I'm totally shocked."

The Scottish National Party has added its voice to the outcry and a public meeting has been called for next month to organise opposition to the plans. "Any land of historical significance should be protected and the law should certainly be rectified," said Alex Neil, the SNP MSP for the area.

Stirling council planners, however, say the town is one of the fastest growing communities in the UK and the weight of history must be balanced against the need for more homes and businesses.

The battle was perhaps Scotland's greatest military victory. Outnumbered three to one, Bruce's men inflicted heavy losses on the English cavalry before launching an attack that drove the English army back and forced Edward from the field, finally securing the Scottish throne for Bruce.

"Stirling is very much a town that depends on tourism," said Mr Bone. "We should be beautifying these places instead of destroying them. It is our living now, not the factories or the pits that we once had.

" We've had so many calls of support. And at the end of the day you have to remember that people gave their lives here."

After centuries of neglect, the battlefield where Robert the Bruce vanquished the army of Edward II in 1314 is under threat from encroaching industrial and housing estates on land where Scotland fought for its freedom. A 20-year structure plan approved by local councils has identified parts of the site to the east of Stirling for large scale commercial and residential expansion. There is no legislation protecting battle sites in Scotland, and while the exact parameters of Bannockburn have never been agreed, it is generally accepted that parts have already been developed. There is only one memorial to the encounter, a statue of Robert the Bruce at Borestone in Stirling, where the Scottish army raised its standard. It was saved from a housing development by a wealthy benefactor, who gave it to the National Trust in the 1930s. The flat land where the two armies met has no memorial and is made up of farm land, a disused council tip and a dual carriageway. A small circle within this area is marked on Ordnance Survey maps as the battle site, but military historians have recently identified the nearby Millhall area as the centre of hostilities. Under the council plans, Millhall is to become an industrial estate. Archie Bone, a local historian who has launched a campaign to have the land preserved, said: "They can't build on a national battle site like this. It is outrageous. "They keep saying the site is just this small circle on the map, but the battle took place over two days. There were thousands of people involved. It was spread over a wide area." Mr Bone's contentions are supported by Peter Reese, a military historian and author who has also identified Millhall as the key area of conflict. "I was concerned before that no plaque or monument was in place to guard the real site against any future developments," said Mr Reese. "But now I'm told there isn't even any legislation protecting it, I'm totally shocked." The Scottish National Party has added its voice to the outcry and a public meeting has been called for next month to organise opposition to the plans. "Any land of historical significance should be protected and the law should certainly be rectified," said Alex Neil, the SNP MSP for the area. Stirling council planners, however, say the town is one of the fastest growing communities in the UK and the weight of history must be balanced against the need for more homes and businesses. The battle was perhaps Scotland's greatest military victory. Outnumbered three to one, Bruce's men inflicted heavy losses on the English cavalry before launching an attack that drove the English army back and forced Edward from the field, finally securing the Scottish throne for Bruce. "Stirling is very much a town that depends on tourism," said Mr Bone. "We should be beautifying these places instead of destroying them. It is our living now, not the factories or the pits that we once had. " We've had so many calls of support. And at the end of the day you have to remember that people gave their lives here."

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: The stars before they were famous
fields.body:
Liam Neeson in Krull

(Peter Yates , 1983)

Who? Beefy Irish actor, whose acting talent is routinely undermined by rumours about the size of his penis. Growing up in Ballymena, Neeson worked as a forklift operator until his breakthrough role as a deaf-mute in Suspect (1987). Americans, not shy about embracing the Irish, took Neeson to their heart, and he went on to work with the likes of Woody Allen (Husbands And Wives) and Spielberg (Schindler's List). But he didn't forget his roots, playing Republican leader Michael Collins (1996) alongside his decidedly non-Gaelic ex, Julia Roberts. After Star Wars: The Phantom Menace, Neeson unsurprisingly threatened to give up acting altogether, but was persuaded to star in Scorsese's upcoming Gangs Of New York - unfortunately, after fracturing his pelvis in a motorcycle accident, that one now looks to have bitten the dust.

The role: Kegan, one of a group of escaped convicts who live wild on the planet Krull.

Best line: When Prince Colwyn (Ken Marshall) stumbles across Kegan and his fellow ruffians, he tries to appeal to their sense of fair play and dignity in an effort to get them to join his battle against the evil Slayers. Kegan replies: "Noble sentiments, but we fight for profit - know what I mean?"

Cringe factor: Neeson is sufficiently rugged for the leather jerkin and pudding bowl haircut to make him look like a new-age traveller, rather than just an idiot.

Other wannabes: Kegan's band of thieves also includes Todd Carty, aka Mark Fowler in EastEnders.

Critical judgement: Leonard Maltin says that the "overly familiar story elements keep this traditional fantasy quest from going anywhere, despite its elaborate trappings".

Also not starring in: A 1984 episode of Miami Vice, entitled When Irish Eyes Are Crying.

Krull, Sci-Fi, Sat July 29, 8pm

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Composer Of The Week/Afternoon Play
fields.body:
Now we've reached the climax of the JS Bach (pictured) celebrations (the 250th anniversary of his death falls on Friday), he gets the well-deserved, if unusual, accolade of a return within six months as Composer Of The Week (9.0am, Radio 3). Not surprisingly, Donald Macleod is confined to a quick whip through the highlights of this musical genius's astounding output. He starts today with keyboard works, and then canters through instrumental, orchestral and cantatal, to wind up on Friday with choral. Phew!

Dan Rebellato's Afternoon Play Antique Silver (2.15pm, Radio 4) is a strange conceit, built around the unexplained disappearance in 1920 of the former Labour MP Victor Grayson. Parts are based on reality and the rest is speculative fantasy. There's nothing wrong with that except that the most probable explanation would surely have offered a better plot. It's widely believed that Grayson was murdered for trying to expose Maundy Gregory's corrupt sale of honours.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Face/Off/Day Of The Evil Gun/ Zardoz
fields.body:
Face/Off

(John Woo, 1997)

10pm, Sky Premier

High-octane, and then some, from the hotshot director of Mission: Impossible 2. Good guy John Travolta! Boom! Bad guy Nic Cage! Boom! Their faces get swapped! Ba-booom!! Incessant explosions fill the space where the plot usually goes, and it's terrific, the two leads - when not flying through the air with a blazing gun in each hand - comically aping each other's mannerisms with real panache. The finale comes about three showdowns too late, but who's counting?

Day Of The Evil Gun

(Jeremy Thorpe, 1968)

11pm, TCM

Glenn Ford's weary gunfighter returns home after years away to find Apaches have ridden off with his wife and children. Neighbouring farmer Arthur Kennedy, professing love for Ford's wife, joins him in the search and overtakes him in the killing of Indians. Kennedy'srelish for the slaughter, the torture, a nasty fight with renegade Confederates in a ghost town... it all adds up to a disturbing journey.

Zardoz

(John Boorman, 1973)

11.45pm, Carlton Cinema

Weird futuristic fantasy set in the year 2293, where exterminators dispatch wayward brutals in a post-holocaust wasteland while an elite lords it over all. Sean Connery's hairy exterminator upsets this new order when he ventures inside the godlike Zardoz. Pretentious, but well directed.

fields.headline: Profit and dross
fields.standfirst: Weekend TV:  Adam Sweeting
fields.trailText: When Will I Be Famous?/Dying Breed/Hollywood AD
fields.body:
So you thought television had degenerated into peeling wallpaper for the comatose viewer? Then you will have adored When Will I Be Famous? (C4, Sat), in which John Dower captured a year in the life of Ashley Revell, TV wideboy and Chingford man.

Revell's new brainchild is Flash TV, an online library of aspiring TV presenters, who hope TV companies will log on and check out their digitised video showreel. Smart idea, and one which has attracted substantial financial backing, but the interesting part was tracing the sleazy trajectory of Revell's career. Ashley is 21st Century Media personified, having kicked off his career with a stint as the News Bunny on the cretinous cable channel L!ve TV, then wallowed in notoriety as the man who supplied fake chat-show guests for Vanessa Feltz and Trisha. Ashley couldn't see anything wrong with what he'd done. "Getting rid of Vanessa Feltz - that's worth a bloody OBE, isn't it?" he queried. Good point, actually.

Revell revels in the shoddy allure of television, and he had thousands of naïve young hopefuls queueing round the block for auditions to join the Flash TV roster. The clips of their efforts were hilarious and squirm-inducing, and Revell's sales spiel about the wonderful service he provides for only 80 quid per successful applicant was a jewel of barrow-boy speak. Dower's hesitant but persistent interviewing and dogged pursuit of his quarry, all accomplished with a single lightweight digital camera, is the shape of TV to come. Tragic but true.

For a programme intended to enlist support for endangered farmers in north Yorkshire, Dying Breed (C4, Sun) couldn't have started more disastrously. A farmer was seen shooting calves through the head, since they were male and had no market value. As the corpses lay twitching in front of him, he explained: "That's the economics of farming today, I'm afraid. If these do-gooders want to come round, they can have these calves for nothing." There could have been no more vivid illustration of the cultural divide between town and country. Country folk are always complaining that we townies have no conception of life on the land, and mercifully they're right. This was like a trip back to the era of the Brontë sisters, when people spoke in picturesque local dialects and worked the land with primitive tools that were little changed since the War of the Roses.

None the less, the farmers had legitimate axes to grind. Hill farmers, who were already subsisting on pitiful incomes, have seen the prices of their sheep plummeting to a catastrophic £2.50 per animal. Pig farmers are infuriated that pig-meat from animals reared on European farms in conditions which would be illegal in the UK is sold over here at prices which undercut their own. Unfortunately, the farmers are unskilled in the black art of spin. When they staged a demonstration of Euro-style battery farming outside a supermarket, the shriekings of their terrified pig horrified passers-by, who angrily declared that this was no way to win public backing. There was more woe in store for the embattled government. The furious farmers want the head of agriculture minister Nick Brown, and while his shifty non-appearance in this film will have delighted the Tories, it was of no help to the pork-rearing community.

Hollywood AD (The X Files, Sky One, Sun) was written and directed by David "Mulder" Duchovny, and in place of the bleak menace of yesteryear there was campness, irony and facetious Tinseltown in-jokes. The plot featured a man convinced he was Christ being murdered by America's most distinguished cardinal, with Duchovny showing his baby-boomer roots in jokes about The Beatles and the 60s counter-culture. Still, all of this was incidental to the core of the piece, the shooting of a fictional X Files movie featuring characters "loosely based on" Mulder and Scully. While Scully was portrayed by flyweight comedienne Tea Leoni, Mulder was farcically impersonated by Garry Shandling, the latter being thwarted in his lascivious designs on Scully by the fact that she was in love with FBI assistant director Skinner. Spoof is stranger than fiction.

fields.headline: Short and sweet
fields.trailText: Mark Lamarr, who begins a new series (Lamarr's Attacks, Thursday, 9.30pm, BBC2) has gone for the high risk strategy of a haircut.
fields.body:
Mark Lamarr, who begins a new series (Lamarr's Attacks, Thursday, 9.30pm, BBC2) has gone for the high risk strategy of a haircut. Performers clearly believe they are more than the sum of their quiffs, but are they right? And can they ever have the confidence to drop their little trademark signatures?

Gabrielle, for instance, though a hugely successful singer-songwriter, has not yet dropped her pirate's eye-patch. There's no doubt she's now well beyond the stage of needing to be recognised with a gimmick, so why hang on to the damned thing? Is it a talisman, or, perish the thought, actually a genuine medical need?

When Mo Mowlam was attacked in certain quarters of the press (by Lynda Lee-Potter in the Daily Mail) for letting her image go, no one considered for one minute that she might be ill. Circumstances conspired to create an enhanced anti-image, whether intended or not.

While some image changes are foisted upon one, most are deliberate. For Lamarr, the removal, Samson-like, of his trademark quiff could be the moment at which he starts to become unfunny (or funny, as some might argue).

Last Thursday, I caught a glimpse of him behind an office door and, sad as it may seem, there were three other thirtysomething men attempting to peek a glimpse of the crest-free Lamarr.

How shallow have we become? That we judge a man not by his actions but by the gel in his hair? The Goebbels-esque image consultants would tell us that in the flat world of ubiquitous celebrity, gimmickry is the only way to stand out on the crowded pages of Vogue and Sky.

If this is the case, then Lamarr's haircut is a clever move. A statement of content over style. Of removing the gimmick in order to appear distinctive.

fields.headline: UN accused of illegal 'extradition'
fields.trailText: The United Nations police in Kosovo and an international body responsible for the repatriation of refugees have been accused of getting a Kenyan man illegally deported from his home in Nairobi to face a theft charge in Pristina.
fields.body:
The United Nations police in Kosovo and an international body responsible for the repatriation of refugees have been accused of getting a Kenyan man illegally deported from his home in Nairobi to face a theft charge in Pristina.

A report by the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe says that Moses Omweno, a former employee of the International Organisation for Migration (IOM) in Kosovo, was transferred to Pristina after the IOM accused him of stealing DM190,000 (£60,000).

It says Mr Omweno was deported on the orders of the Kenyan attorney general on June 6 at the request of the UN police and the IOM. He did not appear before a court and no international warrant was issued for his arrest.

In Pristina, the report says, Mr Omweno was questioned three times by an RUC officer serving with the UN in Kosovo without being informed of this rights.

A letter written by the RUC officer in charge of the opera tion to his commander before Mr Omweno's deportation said: "There will not be a problem with an appeal re the extradition."

The OSCE says the police did not consult lawyers, the office of the head of the UN mission in Kosovo, or the UN judicial affairs department before making their request.

The UN says it has launched an internal inquiry. The OSCE insists that Mr Omweno must be compensated for his unlawful detention in Kosovo.

Mr Omweno was released last Friday after a court hearing in Pristina. Pasquale Lupoli, head the IOM mission in Kosovo, denied doing anything wrong and said the cost of the operation to deport Mr Omweno was paid at the UN police request.

"It's a joke.We did not do any police work. We just provided what the authorities needed."

But Mr Omweno accused the IOM of going out its way to ensure he was deported from Kenya.

"What they actually did was extradite me by themselves... without any proper legal procedures," he said.
