fields.headline: Taking care of business
fields.standfirst: On Friday, Channel 4 takes us to Hawaii with Britney Spears. We can expect fun in the sun, right? Actually, no, says  Jacques Peretti - it's all part of the pop starlet's relentless quest for world domination
fields.trailText: On Friday, Channel 4 takes us to Hawaii with Britney Spears. We can expect fun in the sun, right? Actually, no, says Jacques Peretti - it's all part of the pop starlet's relentless quest for world domination.
fields.body:
How do you feel Hawaii?" Britney Spears is taking time out from her punishing schedule of jet-skiing and smiling to perform her hit single Oops, I Did It Again, before a gift-bearing beachful of screaming teenage girls.

Basically just concert footage, top-and-tailed with little skits round the island, Channel 4's Britney In Hawaii doesn't quite live up to the catastrophically camp title, but does something surprising instead. It goes a little way towards humanising the star, who in recent months has become a frightening augury to parents of what could happen if they send their daughter to stage school.

Since she stopped wearing nappies, Britney has shown the grim determination of a Soviet gymnast to get to the top. As pounding Madonna (Blonde Ambition era) echoes round the stage in Hawaii, one realises how totally Britney has fulfiled her dream. She is now light years from the saucy schoolgirl video for her debut hit, Hit Me Baby One More Time - a highly dubious procession of pop-sox fantasies for dirty old men ("something for the dads", as they used to say of Pan's People).

Nowadays, Britney is an armour-plated businesswoman, one of America's most successful entertainers, who rose to fortune in the space of three school terms, fast outstripping her mall-brat contemporaries (the 90s' equivalents of Tiffany). Probably only a tank could stop her from achieving the Madonna-stratosphere in a decade's time.

At the start of the programme, Britney begins her familiar and depressing whinge about working so hard. "I get up at the break of dawn to do radio interviews. I perform every night." "She always needs a coffee in the morning", her producer admits, hinting at the extremes Britney will go to in order to stay on top.

Quickly, the programme turns into an entertaining, even witty, series of grabbed footage sequences from cheesy photo-opportunities. The programme-makers have cleverly strung the whole desperate thing together by using the conceit of a hit on Britney's teeny-fan website.

Hence, we see: Britney Getting Personal (variations on "I love to go shopping" and "I love my work" as answers to the only question that matters: Do you have a boyfriend?); Dancing In A Waterfall (not as pornographic as some viewers might hope for), and Swimming With Dolphins (ditto).

Swimming with dolphins is one of the great clichés of the Stars In Paradise entertainment special. ITV tried it with David Jason, a star whom viewers normally associate with eating a solitary curry in A Touch Of Frost. The sight of a man who should permanently be seen in a raincoat splashing about, care-free, with his new-found aquatic friends made for liberating and oddly moving television.

It's amazing how swimming with dolphins causes even the most prosaic of prime-time stars to start spouting mystical mumbo-jumbo. But not Britney. It's a measure of how much of an anal control freak she is (and the cost of insuring her) that the closest Britney gets to mystical union with the dolphin is putting her hand over his blow-hole in the paddling pool and looking a bit nervous.

Britney's on firmer ground when visiting a teenage fan uninvited ("Britney Performs A Surprise!"). "Are you Jennifer?" "Aaaaaaargh! It's..." (yes, Britney Spears). The little girl, all teeth braces and embarrassment, was very sweet. But Britney soon pushed her aside to sign photos for the impromptu crowd of about 20,000.

It was disturbing to think that only a couple of years separate Britney and Jennifer. While Jennifer plays dolly tea party in her bedroom with her friends, Britney is banging her fists in a boardroom and demanding a better deal with the record company.

Britney's co-stars for the show were Destiny's Child, performing their girl-group feminist anthem Say My Name: ostensibly a plea to no-good boyfriends to show some commitment, but also a plea to the fans not to forget who they are, come next summer's crop of new girl groups.

In contrast to Britney's lifeless computer-generated pop routine, Destiny's Child had the novelty of appearing real. They also showed up how sexless and anaemic Britney is, which leads one to question how appropriate it is to be marketing a barely post-pubescent girl as a sexual object. And it's a measure of how sexualised young female pop stars are, and consequently, how fast the junking process is, that we already think of Britney, aged 18, as past it. How young does that have to make the next Britney Spears?

On a somewhat lighter note, Britney In Hawaii reminded me of Burt Bacharach's entertainment specials from the 70s. Here was the deal: Burt would invite a friend, say Chris Evert, to come to his fantasy island retreat and play tennis beneath the palm trees, before jumping over the net to serenade her with a daiquiri.

In Britain, we had Seaside Special and A Day With Dana: one of the great TV shows of all time. Britney Spears is taking time out from her punishing schedule of jet-skiing and smiling to perform her hit single Oops, I Did It Again, before a gift-bearing beachful of screaming teenage girls. Basically just concert footage, top-and-tailed with little skits round the island, Channel 4's Britney In Hawaii doesn't quite live up to the catastrophically camp title, but does something surprising instead. It goes a little way towards humanising the star, who in recent months has become a frightening augury to parents of what could happen if they send their daughter to stage school. Since she stopped wearing nappies, Britney has shown the grim determination of a Soviet gymnast to get to the top. As pounding Madonna (Blonde Ambition era) echoes round the stage in Hawaii, one realises how totally Britney has fulfiled her dream. She is now light years from the saucy schoolgirl video for her debut hit, Hit Me Baby One More Time - a highly dubious procession of pop-sox fantasies for dirty old men ("something for the dads", as they used to say of Pan's People). "She always needs a coffee in the morning", her producer admits, hinting at the extremes Britney will go to in order to stay on top. Quickly, the programme turns into an entertaining, even witty, series of grabbed footage sequences from cheesy photo-opportunities. The programme-makers have cleverly strung the whole desperate thing together by using the conceit of a hit on Britney's teeny-fan website. And it's a measure of how sexualised young female pop stars are, and consequently, how fast the junking process is, that we already think of Britney, aged 18, as past it. webTitle: Spanish left tries a fresh face

fields.headline: Spanish left tries a fresh face
fields.trailText: Desperate to find a leader with the comeback touch, the Spanish Socialist party elected a little-known MP at the weekend. It hopes Jose Luis Rodriguez Zapatero will fill the vacuum created when Felipe Gonzalez was defeated as prime minister in 1996.
fields.body:
Desperate to find a leader with the comeback touch, the Spanish Socialist party elected a little-known MP at the weekend. It hopes Jose Luis Rodriguez Zapatero will fill the vacuum created when Felipe Gonzalez was defeated as prime minister in 1996.

Mr Rodriguez Zapatero, 39, snatched the leadership from under the nose of a regional baron who was regarded as the favourite.

Promising "peaceful change" to integrate all strands of party thinking, he promptly put a new generation on the executive committee, excluding veterans and leftwingers.

"The only thing we have to fear is change," he told delegates at the party's conference.

His priority, he said, would be modernising the party so that it could carry out effective opposition.

The search for a new leader of the left has been traumatic. The party has had three in as many years, and lost a general election in March by 10 percentage points. It continues to trail badly behind the prime minister Jose Maria Aznar's centre-right People's party in the opinion polls.

That may now change. Despite several corruption scandals towards the end of the Socialist era in the mid-90s, and the party's ensuing internal power struggles, Spain still has a solid left-of-centre vote. Many sympathisers stayed home at the last election, no longer fearing that Mr Aznar was the reincarnation of the old Spanish right and angry at the socialists' disarray.

Mr Rodriguez Zapatero, a lawyer and an MP since 1986, is married and has two young children. The daily El Mundo called him "cold, astute and professional", yesterday, words that could apply equally well to Mr Aznar. They both come from Castile, the tough heartland of Spain; both are rather wooden figures, stronger in technocratic efficiency than charisma.

Differentiating himself may prove one of the new opposition leader's hardest tasks.

Mr Aznar has successfully occupied the centre ground. He sees Tony Blair as his closest ally in Europe and has brought several independents, many from the left, into his government.

Mr Rodriguez Zapatero's Nueva Via (New Way) policy also resembles Mr Blair's Third Way. But he is younger than Mr Aznar, now 47, and can push ahead with the swift generational turnover that distances Spain from its authoritarian past. Some on his executive were not yet born when General Franco died in 1975.

fields.headline: South Africa starts renaming megacities
fields.trailText: Pretoria, Durban and other big South African cities are to be absorbed in new metropolitan areas covering the adjacent black townships and given African names.
fields.body:
Pretoria, Durban and other big South African cities are to be absorbed in new metropolitan areas covering the adjacent black townships and given African names.

The black majorities on the city councils, mostly controlled by the African National Congress, are taking the opportunity offered by the new authorities, which will be elected in November, to scrap names with colonial origins.

Pretoria is to become part of a "megacity" called Tshwane - Sotho for "We are the same" - which will also include large townships such as Mamelodi and Atteridgeville.

Former president Nelson Mandela has given his approval to the creation of Nelson Mandela Metropole, which will suck in the southern city of Port Elizabeth, called after the wife of a former British colonial governor who never set foot in South Africa.

Further up the Indian ocean coast Durban, named in honour of a colonial governor, Sir Benjamin D'urban, has run a public competition in search of a new name.

Among the favoured proposals is adopting the Zulu word iThekweni, loosely meaning "place of the bay".

Cape Town has decided to keep its name, because it is internationally recognised.

One of the hottest debates is on what to call the megacity that will incorporate Johannesburg and Soweto. Although Johannesburg is widely known outside South Africa, many black residents call it eGoli - Zulu for "place of gold".

But while some argue that it is time to get rid of all names with colonial origins, others point out that the surrounding province has already had its name changed from Transvaal to Gauteng, which has a similar meaning in Tswana to eGoli.

The chairman of Johannesburg's transformation committee, Kenny Fihla, said the old name would probably stay for now but change was likely before long.

The scrapping of apartheid-era and colonial names in favour of African ones has been slow. Until now only one main town has changed: Verwoerdburg - which sits in the north-east near Johannesburg and Pretoria and was called after the most hardline of apartheid prime ministers- was renamed Centurian, to the disgust of many residents.

South Africa's main airports were stripped of their old names several years ago. But many streets in areas formerly reserved for whites still recall apartheid and colonial figures.

webTitle: Berlin's siesta saloon is not all it seems

fields.headline: Art of napping
fields.trailText: Berlin's siesta saloon is not all it seems
fields.body:
Ulrike Schlott said her friend had suggested she come along. "I decided that she was stressed out and needed a sleep," the friend explained.

Ms Schlott, who said she worked in advertising, was standing with her friend by the entrance to what is thought to be Germany's first siesta facility.

An attendant in a smart royal blue uniform hovered at her elbow, ready to escort her into the Schlafsaal - sleeping hall - set up in the stripped auditorium of an old theatre. On the back of the attendant's jacket were embroidered the words: "Midday calm in Berlin."

Since July 3 tired executives and foot-weary tourists and shoppers have been making their way in growing numbers to the shabby building in a courtyard off a quiet street in the Mitte district of town. For eight marks (£2.70) they buy the right to snooze for an hour in a dormitory. There are five sessions a day, beginning at noon.

The beds are laid out in rows. Each has a little bedside table in case the client wishes to read for a while before dropping off.

The attendants politely ask the sleepers to remove their shoes at the door, escort them to the beds they have chosen from a diagram at reception, and close the long with curtains. When the last of the attendants has retired, gently closing the high doors, there is an dense stillness in the big hall.

Yet there is also something not quite right.

The organisers could not possibly be covering the cost of fresh bed linen and the wages of so many employees at just eight marks a bed. What some of the sleepers do not realise is that they are taking part in a creative installation.

The sleeping room attendants are actors. The manager - a tousled figure with a dreamy smile who looks as if he himself might just have woken up - is the director, Holger Friedrich.

"Lying together in beds is a sort of lowest common denominator, an exercise in non-verbal communication," he said.

In the evenings his actors put on a conventional production in the theatre, but one with a plot written around the Schlafsaal which they themselves have helped to invent.

"We are trying not to copy reality but to create it," Mr Friedrich said.

Sleep and tiredness were among his chief fascinations, he said.

"The other being saying goodbye."

His latest venture, which runs until August 13, has attracted an impressively long list of sponsors, including the the federal German army - who supplied the beds.

fields.headline: Shameful foreign policy
fields.standfirst: The new British embassy has been unveiled in Berlin and the Queen is not amused. Jonathan Glancey asks why embassies always bring out the worst in architects
fields.trailText: The new British embassy has been unveiled in Berlin and the Queen is not amused. Jonathan Glancey asks why embassies always bring out the worst in architects.
fields.body:
There are few times that one would expect to be in agreement with the Queen or the Duke of Edinburgh on matters architectural. Yet one look at Her Majesty's face as she took a gander at the new British embassy on Berlin's Wilhelmstrasse last week made one feel that here was an unlikely soul mate. Taking a cue from her ancestor, the Queen was clearly not amused. "I understand that some people like it," she said. As for the Duke, he merely snapped "No" when reporters asked if he would offer an opinion on the design of the building.

Of course, there were excuses. This uncomfortable new building had to be squeezed into the suffocating corset of Berlin's old streets and planning guides. The architecture along these streets was better in the 19th and early-20th century, the days between Karl Friedrich Schinkel and Albert Speer, when architects knew how to get their buildings to stand to attention. There might be a hint of flamboyance in a doorcase or pediment but, on the whole, Prussian military manners held sway. Berlin, before Marshall Zhukov's capture in 1945, was a model of classical restraint.

Commissions to design embassies, if this new monument to the British abroad is anything to go by, are sullied chalices. With the best will in the world, neither Michael Wilford, architect of the British embassy, Berlin, nor Ahrends Burton Koralek (ABK), architects of the recently opened British embassy in Moscow, have come up with designs that match or mirror the country of Wren, Hawksmoor, Vanbrugh, Soane and Lutyens. But then even Sir Edwin Lutyens failed to cut the mustard with his design for the British embassy in Washington DC.

That bloodless, Neo-Georgian red-brick pile, completed in 1928, is one of the few real duds in Lutyens' portfolio. Was this wuss of a building really by the man who gave us the magnificent Viceroy's House in New Delhi, the heartwrenching war monument at Thiepval, and so many great Edwardian country houses in the home counties? It is meant to be a play on the work of Wren and the colonial homes Wren's designs influenced in Williamsburg in the days before the Revolution. It is, though, spineless, while its fey interior decoration smacks today of a "traditional English country house-style hotel".

Perhaps then, as now, embassy buildings were a compromise, a polite and formal way of expressing ideas about how we British wanted to present ourselves to foreigners. What sort of Britain is being presented - a tepid, public school, pin-striped Britain? A Britain where everyone is charming, plays safe, keeps mum? Even if this is an exaggeration, it's a feeling one gets in British embassies as far afield as Cuba, Russia and Germany.

The architecture and culture of such places are, aside from any serious, useful work carried out there, geared up to present a mythical image of Britain. Most British embassy buildings have been restrained, fey and old-fashioned. On a recent trip to Rio, I visited the city's mayor, Luiz Paulo Fernandez Conde, an architect and former dean of the university school of architecture, in his grand country house-style residence. Inside was an almost exact reproduction of the dining room and library of Kenwood House, Hampstead, built by Robert Adam in 1767-8. This, the mayor told me, was the former British ambassador's house. It was built in the 50s.

I shouldn't have been surprised. This was just the kind of architecture diplomats must have loved then, and still do. After all, if you were going to move abroad after an upbringing of home counties house, Oxbridge college and Georgian home-of-your-own, the least you could expect when posted overseas was an Adam-style residence. Or Lutyens at his most uninspired.

One big question remains: what is it that makes these buildings second rate? Is it the architects' failure of nerve, or the clients' desire for nothing too difficult or arty? Is it a bout of poet laureate syndrome when faced with designing for Britain? Think of John Betjeman and his dismal verses for Princess Anne's wedding, or Andrew Motion's awkward "God bless you ma'am" verses written on the occasion of the Queen Mum's centenary. Only Tennyson managed to get away with some memorable verse ("Half a league, half a league,/ half a league onward,/All in the valley of Death/ rode the six hundred"), but even the camp horror of The Charge of the Light Brigade isn't a patch on The Lotos-Eaters, The Vision of Sin or The Lady of Shalott.

It's more likely, though, that the client body - HM government - leeches the blood from these flag-waving projects. They must, like a diplomat's speech, aim to please everyone in general and thus, by default, no one in particular. In Berlin and Moscow, Wilford and ABK have tried to inject some energy into their buildings, but to little avail. Wilford's attempt to add a splash of uncertain colour - a variation of duck-egg blue and Biba-era mauve - into the stone facade of the German embassy seems misplaced. Berlin's grey climate warrants full-blooded colour, the deep ochres, blues and gold used by Prussian architects, for better or worse, from Schinkel to Speer. In Moscow, ABK have designed an articulated, three-dimensional jigsaw of a building that might look dramatic in Gori or Riga, but is dwarfed on the banks of the Moskva River by one of Stalin's post-Great Patriotic War towers and other heroic and not-so-proletarian city blocks. In trying to make a bit of a splash, both buildings remind me of classic pin-striped City chaps sporting discreetly loud ties, or waistcoats lined in jazzy silks.

We can rest assured, though, that other countries find the embassy lark just as difficult to transform into art as we do. The US embassy (1955-60) in London's Grosvenor Square is possibly the worst building by Eero Saarinen (1910-61), the innovative Finnish-American architect who is, rightly, much better known for his superb General Motors Technical Center in Warren, Michigan and his TWA terminal at JFK airport, New York, shaped like a concrete bird on the wing. The lightness and adventure of Saarinen's architecture were replaced in London by a dull leaden quality, a noticeable heaviness of heart. The Danish embassy (completed in 1977) in London's Sloane Street is equally uninspired. Is this kit of mud-brown parts really by the same architect as St Catherine's College, Oxford? Arne Jacobsen (1902-71) was a refined architect and designer, but this inoffensive building is way below par.

Embassies are meant to be good ambassadors for the countries they represent, yet as architectural ambassadors they do precious little good. Although, like the Queen, I understand that some people like them.

The Danish embassy (completed in 1977) in London's Sloane Street is equally uninspired. Is this kit of mud-brown parts really by the same architect as St Catherine's College, Oxford? Arne Jacobsen (1902-71) was a refined architect and designer, but this inoffensive building is way below par. Embassies are meant to be good ambassadors for the countries they represent, yet as architectural ambassadors they do precious little good. Although, like the Queen, I understand that some people like them.

webTitle: The M25 three are not guilty. Full stop

fields.headline: The M25 three are not guilty. Full stop
fields.standfirst: Marcel Berlins: Writ large
fields.trailText: Marcel Berlins: Writ large
fields.body:
When the three men convicted of the M25 murder won their appeals last week, their victory was considerably marred by the words of Lord Justice Mantell, who, after concluding that their convictions were "unsafe", went on, "This is not a finding of innocence. Far from it."

The meaning of those words is clear. But I do not think the judge ought to have said them. What was the point? In England and Wales, there's no halfway house verdict of "not proven", as there is in Scotland. Here, not proven is not guilty. But trial judges do not go around telling acquitted defendants, "The jury's not-guilty verdict is not a finding of innocence. Far from it." In an appeal, the judges have to decide whether the jury, if there had not been irregularities in the trial, and if they had known certain things at the time which had emerged since, would still have found the accused guilty. The judges in the M25 appeal could not go that far.

In other words, the jury might well have found the men not guilty. The appeal court's function is merely to decide whether or not there are good grounds for appeal. In the M25 case, there were. Full stop. It should not be the judges' job to tell us their opinions on guilt or innocence.

I went on a shopping spree the other day, seduced by the intense publicity surrounding the opening of the latest, coolest, most "now" store in town, the kiosk at the Royal Courts of Justice in London's Strand. There, I was assured, you could buy coasters, pencils, mouse mats, key-rings and address books, all bearing a pretty picture of the court building.

Funny that the publicity didn't mention two other items on sale, both, presumably, thought to be germane to the court. I can't quite work out the link between the dispensation of justice and a set of golf tees, obtainable for only £5.50. The other is more obvious: for only £16, there's a hip flask, engraved with the Royal Courts of Justice motif. After all, what lawyer, judge or witness can bear to be without one, during those longueurs that afflict even the most exciting trials? And what an appropriate memento for members of the public to remember our justice system by.

Also on sale is a selection of life-size, inflatable rubber dolls, uncannily accurate, of some of the great litigants of our times, including Neil Hamilton, Jonathan Aitken and Gillian Taylforth. An easy-to-assemble witness box is included in the price, but replicas of Mr Aitken's sword of truth and Mr Hamilton's brown envelope are extra. The previous two sentences are, I regret, untrue.

Last Thursday was an extra-ordinary day in the courts. Four important judgments, all asserting the rights of little individuals over big institutions. It's as if our senior judges had simultaneously drunk the same elixir of human rights from the stream of liberal thinking.

The relatives of possible victims of Dr Shipman will get their public inquiry; thousands of black South African miners harmed by asbestos have been given the go-ahead to sue the British parent company that owned the mines; policy-holders with Equitable Life will get the pensions that the company had guaranteed them; and people involved in civil and criminal trials will be entitled to sue barristers who make a mess of their case in court.

Good guys, 4; the forces of government, big business, insurance and the bar, 0.

Yes, I know it's pure coincidence that they all happened on the same day. But maybe it is a portent of a judicial wind of change.

Barristers, as a genre, are not enamoured of their erstwhile colleague David Lock, now a minister in the Lord Chancellor's department. They think (rightly) that he's trying to cut down their sometimes excessive incomes from public funds. But I wonder if they're using the correct tactics to try to win him over.

The other evening Lock was invited to speak at Lincoln's Inn. As his ministerial car drew up, Lock's driver informed the waiting official that this was a minister come to address the troops.

"Four pounds," the gatekeeper announced. No, you don't understand, the driver explained, it's a government minister on official duty, specially invited. "I don't care who he is, it's four pounds for a car to come in."

Which is why, rather than waste public money, Her Majesty's minister walked in the rain to the place of his talk, not necessarily convinced of the wonderfulness of the barristers' profession.

fields.headline: The age of dissent
fields.standfirst: Kathy stays
fields.trailText: Kathy stays.
fields.body:
Every now and again, the cleaning lady problem erupts. My mother or daughter suddenly becomes discontented with Kathy the cleaning lady and orders me to find someone more efficient. I absolutely cannot do this. After three years I am now friends with Kathy. We are au fait with each other's personal problems - I know all about her difficult son, that annoying fellow who won't leave her alone and her endless battle over the central heating - and there is no possible way I could sack Kathy.

My daughter and mother cannot get to grips with this. They see the dust nestling on surfaces and blinds, the spider webs draped about, the grungy carpet corners that are never hoovered, the crockery piled in all the wrong places and these little things grate on their nerves.

"What would you do if I said I'd found an excellent cleaning lady who could start tomorrow?" snaps daughter, with a fierce glint in her eye.

"I do not wish to discuss this - I cannot sack Kathy." "Why not?" "Because." "Because what?" "Because I like her." "Why do you like her?" On and on goes the daughter, like a hornet. She doesn't understand that Kathy is nervous and dare not move things in case she breaks, mislays or muddles them up, which means she can't clear any surfaces, which means that the surfaces cannot be cleansed.

This suits me. I don't want a strange bossy person stacking up my papers or throwing away vital scraps and bits by mistake. Much better to have a light layer of dirt about. At least the rising tide of filth in the kitchen is kept at bay and central areas Hoovered, by Kathy. And - very important - Kathy and the dog love each other.

In a fury, daughter whirls round the house like a tornado clearing surfaces. This is fabulous. Now Kathy can clean them without fear. But daughter is still not satisfied. She leaves a bossy list of tasks to be done. She was born to rule, like her grandma. "Why can't I have the job?" asks daughter fiercely.

She can. Then we shall have an extra super-efficient cleaning lady for free. Marvellous. There's only one snag. Daughter won't be around for long. Soon she'll be off, on holiday, or back at university. Kathy, on the other hand, isn't going anywhere. Ever.

fields.headline: Read it and sweep
fields.standfirst: A string of new books promise to help us rediscover the delights of being a housewife. But if housework really is the new sex, wonders  Joan Smith, how come men haven't discovered it?
fields.trailText: A string of new books promise to help us rediscover the delights of being a housewife. But if housework really is the new sex, wonders  Joan Smith, how come men haven't discovered it?
fields.body:
Do you know the difference between single and double damask? The correct distance between place settings at the dinner table? In the 21st century, you might imagine such questions are quaint reminders of a world in which men were men and women were clones of Martha Stewart. But you would be wrong. The housewife is on her way back, a trend confirmed by a publishing phenomenon in the US, where a modern version of Mrs Beeton is a runaway best seller. In Britain, women's magazines and weekend supplements are suddenly full of articles about the return of housework, characterising it not as the secret vice of intelligent women but something even scarier - a secret virtue.

Investment bankers and property consultants confess, a little shame-facedly, that they long to return from the office and get on with the dusting. "There's nothing more soothing than coming home after a day's work and doing a basket full of ironing," says one. Cheryl Mendelson, the American author of Home Comforts: The Art & Science of Keeping House, says that for years she felt she had to conceal such cravings. Not any more: 200,000 people have already staggered out of bookshops in the States clutching her 884-page volume. Her enthusiasm for knitting and making mental lists of when the carpets are due to be shampooed is now proudly out in the open.

It couldn't happen over here, could it? Think again. British housewives will soon be able to come out of the closet, thanks to Nigella Lawson. Already famous for her cooking and her cosmetic tips, Lawson's next book is entitled How to Be a Domestic Goddess. Her line is that you do not need to aim for perfection, and she boldly includes a photograph of a cake with a cracked top. Yes! Even beautiful columnists and food critics can make little mistakes! Indeed, for your domestic goddess, such charming home-made touches attest to her ease and confidence in the kitchen.

Lawson's title is at least a little bit ironic, which is more than can be said for Mendelson and her intensive programme to fill women's lives with sorting laundry, mopping floors and washing cats. (It doesn't matter that they hate water. They're unhygienic, for God's sake!) It's hard to see how Mendelson's best-selling regime is going to help women who already feel stressed and exhausted by the effort of combining motherhood, a career and housework. Marjorie Garber, an American academic celebrated in the past for her wry analyses of cross-dressing and bisexuality, goes even further, suggesting in a new book that our connection to our homes is positively erotic - a subject taken up and given serious consideration over four pages in this week's New Yorker.

So is housework the new sex, as the magazine Red asks on its cover this month? Are women getting an erotic frisson out of scrubbing sinks and spraying room freshener in newly dusted sitting rooms? Garber thinks so, suggesting that property is what the over-50s turn to when their enthusiasm for bodies becomes embarrassing. She suggests that prospective purchasers approach buying a house or apartment with a mixture of lust and shame, although this probably says more about her private insecurities than anything else. Few women have actually confessed that they get off on the scent of furniture polish instead of sweat and pheromones.

But that is not the point. The new housewife, as we might call her, is nothing to do with real life and everything to do with fantasy. And the question that is not being addressed is: if housework really is the new sex, why are men so reluctant to do it? I don't see them clamouring to starch sheets or getting erections at the prospect of dusting lampshades. Some do admit to being turned on by the sight of Annette Bening manically vacuuming in her underwear in American Beauty. But the point of the scene is that Bening is not a housewife but an estate agent, cleaning up one of the houses on her books in the hope of cleaning up metaphorically on its sale.

The word scrubber, which used to describe a woman performing that function, is now universally taken to mean a working-class woman who is sexually promiscuous. Another noun which derives from a domestic context, slattern, suggests a woman who does her work lazily and incompetently, as well as implying sexual availability. If there is a link between housework and sex, it involves class, disorder and sexual incontinence rather than Martha Stewart or Delia Smith in sparklingly clean kitchens.

So what lies behind this apparently concerted attempt to make housework sexy, exciting and fulfilling? One clue is the way women are suddenly being treated as housework virgins, previously unaware that butter should be kept in the fridge or why human beings need to eat breakfast. Since most of us have been grap pling with these tricky problems since childhood, it is obvious that what we are really being offered is a fantasy about a more traditional, and inevitably more gendered, way of life. Mendelson's index includes an astonishing 56 entries for laundering and laundry, and entire chapters on ironing and vacuuming. She tells readers how to put away linen and supplies three methods (with diagrams) of folding socks.

At first sight, it throws an ironic light on Shirley Conran's famous remark that life is too short to stuff a mushroom. But it seems unlikely that working women, already short of time, are about to squander it on cleaning ovens, washing the fridge every week, making their own clothes and learning how to turn napkins into amusing shapes. What is going on here is an outburst of nostalgia, which would be harmless enough if it did not contain subliminal messages about femininity and what women ought to be like. Less benignly, it also suggests that we live in cultures which have recognised the inefficacy of bullying women back into the kitchen and have consequently adopted a new method - seduction.

The message to working women is that you'd like it if you only tried it - or tried more of it, for every survey ever carried out confirms that men are still not doing their share of domestic chores. Some commentators even claim that men simply aren't biologically programmed to look after homes, as though ironing and cleaning those stubborn limescale stains off the loo are natural female functions. If that is the case, then some of us clearly lack the ironing gene; when a TV crew wanted to film me at home to make some arcane point about domesticity, one of them had to go up into the loft and bring down the ironing board left behind by the previous (male) owner of my house. The novelist Alice Walker seems to have a similar problem, thanking a couple of women in the acknowledgments to one of her novels for "representing the Goddess in my household". This is what the rest of us call employing a cleaner; it may be the first instance, dating back to 1992, of the current trend for recasting domestic drudgery as sacred duty. And sacred duties, as we all know, are performed out of love rather than money; as Marx pointed out in the 19th century, the world depends on unpaid domestic labour, an injustice that has yet to be redressed. Housework remains a low-status, badly paid, working-class occupation, when it is remunerated at all.

Yet the new breed of domestic goddesses and happy housewives are middle class to the core. Whether they pose fetchingly at home, surrounded by fresh herbs and bottles of balsamic vinegar, or go into rhapsodies about marketing (shopping to you), they assume they have choices. They have very little in common with mothers on council estates in Leeds or poor women in housing projects in Chicago, where Mendelson's advice to employ a "bonded maid service" must read like a bad joke. The truth about housework is that most of it is dull, repetitive and unrewarding: women's work, in other words. Feminism came along and said so, and many housewives gladly took the message to heart, allowing dust balls to accumulate under the beds and waiting to clean out the fridge until mould began to grow. What they discovered was that many traditional household chores are simply a way of filling up time, as well as filling up minds with trivia. No sensible human being, with an averagely interesting life, needs to sew her own napkins or dry dishes by hand.

But some housework is unavoidable, and there's the rub. Housework can be made more palatable in two ways, either by pretending it's fun or suggesting that it's somehow more womanly. "My own experience," writes Mendelson, "convinces me that there is still no other way to make a good home than to have attitudes toward home and domesticity modelled on those of [a] traditional woman." So there you have it: real women love housework. Let's hope they think it's worth it when they finally expire, as a friend's mother did, stretched across the bed with a duster in her hand.

webTitle: Down and out on Madison Avenue

fields.headline: Down and out on Madison Avenue
fields.standfirst: He was the archetypal Wall Street whiz kid, a billionaire by the time he was 40. But there was no place for Saul Steinberg's corporate raids in the dot.com era, and he has now been forced to sell his palatial apartment and art collection. Michael Ellison reports
fields.trailText: He was the archetypal Wall Street whiz kid, a billionaire by the time he was 40. But there was no place for Saul Steinberg's corporate raids in the dot.com era, and he has now been forced to sell his palatial apartment and art collection. Michael Ellison reports.
fields.body:
Saul Steinberg probably thought it couldn't get much worse but now it has. Steinberg, the fiscal behemoth from a bygone age, a bloater in a bowtie beached in a world where the waves are made by geeks in open-necked shirts, found out just how far he has fallen at the end of last week. That's when the reservoir of cash really started to run dry; when the failure of his latest, and possibly last, deal really started to bite.

Welcome to hard times for this character straight out of Oliver Stone's Wall Street or Tom Wolfe's The Bonfire of the Vanities, a corporate raider from the 80s all washed up in a dot.com decade.

But the meaning of hard times could hardly be more subjective than in this case. If your world must fall apart, then a three-bedroom apartment in the Helmsley Carlton House in New York City is not such a bad billet from which to survey the wreckage.

The hotel is tucked away in the most expensive neighbourhood in the US, just one block east of Central Park in Manhattan; it has Maxim's, a fine restaurant, down below; even the most modest accommodation costs $450 a night. And since it is mostly residential, with only four of the rooms on its 17 floors available for overnight rent, you are not too likely to be bothered by the riff-raff.

But it is not Park Avenue. Nor, specifically, is it the largest apartment in Park Avenue, and indeed all of New York City. For Steinberg's previous abode was just that: 19,000 sq ft divided into 34 rooms, walls dripping with Old Masters, floors supporting marble-topped tables, velvet sofas, a 21ft mahogany dining table with 23 matching chairs, porcelain jars on stands reaching almost 5ft high. Insurance meant ready cash, and with this he was able to terrify operations into opening their cheque books to get rid of him. I could even be the first Jewish president."

The fall, when it came, was swift. but it was a long time in the making. The climate was wrong for Steinberg's special skills after the crash of 1987 and in particular the collapse in the early 90s of the high-risk, high-yield junk bond market, the star of which was the crooked Michael Milken. Steinberg was a friend of Milken's and became a member of his inner circle, frequently employing junk bonds as well as less unsavoury methods to take over companies.

In the meantime he and the glamorous Gayfryd, previously a successful businesswoman in Louisiana, made the most of the celebrity they had purchased. She was on the board of the New York Public Library, and her interest in the written word extended beyond the institutional. Allen Ginsberg, the late Beat poet, and Carl Bernstein, half of the Watergate-busting team, became dinner guests.

At the suggestion of Norman Mailer, the couple were granted access to and became prominent sources of cash for PEN, the writers' group. Which was fine until they became a little too prominent, when the twice-divorced Gayfryd was appointed president of the organisation. Some members rebelled, and in 1990 she resigned.

There were selfless good works, too, such as the time they financed the college educations of 40 students from the South Bronx - a neighbourhood of New York whose inhabitants had only ever seen the inside of Park Avenue homes while in servants' garb.

Steinberg welcomed the new post-junk bond world by saying, "My motto for the 90s is that money is for lending, not spending." But five years later, he had a stroke which still afflicts the left side of his body. By the end of last year the injuries to his business - underwriting property, casualty and vehicle insurance - were likewise all too apparent.

The insurance industry was suffering generally, but Reliance had its own special woes: annual interest payments of $62m and big losses in its workers' compensation business. First to go was Steinberg's brother Bobby, the firm's president. Then Reliance reported a loss of $311m for 1999, and its credit rating tumbled. On top of that it has accrued huge debts, with $240m due to be paid next month and another $290m in November.

Steinberg had to do something, and he did. He struck a deal that would have been a gross embarrassment to the piratical raider of Wall Street lore of the 80s. Now it was a lifeline.

He agreed to sell the vehicle for his legend to Leucidia National, a financial services holding company, for $295m. Of that, $93m was to be Steinberg's - surely enough to sustain his recently reduced circumstances, even though it was stock for which he would have received $2bn 10 years earlier. George Baker, Reliance's chief executive officer, told a meeting of disgruntled shareholders: "There was nothing else on the table at the time."

But then Steinberg's salvation was revoked. Leucidia had reached the agreement on the basis of $2.55 for each Reliance share, more than $2 above the current price. The takeover collapsed and Leucidia walked away, leaving Reliance friendless and alone.

"Leucadia doesn't overpay," said analyst Blair Sanford, of Cochran Caronia Securities. "That's the bottom line. Leucadia is saying that Reliance equity isn't worth the total price of the deal. For Leucadia it's a matter of price." Steinberg has paid a price already, and there may be more to come.

But until then, there is still the second home 140 miles away from his imploded Manhattan empire, a beachfront retreat at Quogue in the Hamptons. Were the local library not shut for renovations, the tarnished emblem of 80s excess might pull down from its shelves a rumination on hope and loss by the novelist Larry McMurtry, one of Gayfryd's sympathisers during the PEN debacle: The Last Picture Show.

fields.headline: The lensman
fields.standfirst: He is recognised as one of the most important British photographers of the last century, has a devoted companion 54 years his junior and recently acquired full sight for the first time in his life. So why is  Humphrey Spender  so grumpy?
fields.trailText: He is recognised as one of the most important British photographers of the last century, has a devoted companion 54 years his junior and recently acquired full sight for the first time in his life. So why is  Humphrey Spender  so grumpy?
fields.body:
A hot summer's afternoon in an orchard in the middle of Essex. There are bees in the Hollyhocks, apples in the grass. Wood pigeons coo across a distant meadow. It is as close to paradise as one can imagine within commuting distance of London, but Humphrey Spender, the artist and photographer, is, at the age of 90, in a bit of a grump.

He is sitting under the trees in a rickety garden chair sipping a glass of ginger beer. He has already bemoaned the widespread disappearance of the puffball mushroom, the hacking down of hedgerows, the greed of modern farmers, the wastage of contemporary photographers, the indifference of local GPs. We have alighted briefly on the inefficiency of architects, including it must be said Richard Rogers, who in the 60s built Spender's orchard-house, two white boxes, rimmed with glass: "Too hot in summer, too cold in winter." We have been sidetracked into his brother Stephen Spender's knighthood: "He sent me a postcard saying 'You seem to be bemused by my acceptance.' Well, I wasn't. I disapproved." And we have tarried a while on the scandal of his own reputation: "I was not 'one of the most important pre-war documentary photographers' - there were plenty of other people doing it. I've been called 'the father of documentary photography'. It's been said that I 'gave ordinary man his place in history'. Absolute rubbish."

And then we arrive at the subject of his eyesight. Spender has been shortsighted all his life. Two years ago he developed a cataract and was given implanted lenses that have given him almost normal sight for the first time ever. "And in many ways," he says wryly, snapping in half a biscuit, "I'm not that pleased about it." It comes down to texture. Spender has always liked to look at things close up. With a Leica to his eye, in his remarkable work in the 30s as "lensman" for the Daily Mirror, or as a photographer for Picture Post or as a member of Mass Observation, that revolutionary exploration of "real life", it is the expressions on his subjects' faces - the unemployed of Tyneside, the housewives of Stepney - that tell you as much about the deprivation of their lives as the state of their clothes or houses. More recently, as an artist, he has dwelled on the texture of small things. For the prints in his current exhibition at the Mercury Gallery in Cork Street he created a method, using Plasticine and PVA, of taking rubbings from three dimensional objects - pine cones, shells, zips, key rings, nails. "It took enormous patience," Spender says. "I got very cross."

One of the prints in the show is of the Tortorosaurus, a lugubrious creature with a battered shell and a hanging head. In many ways, it reminds you of its creator. You could stare at Spender's face for hours and not get bored. His lines and facial pouches seem to have a life of their own. There is an unusual purpleness to his large lips. His nose is patrician. His ear lobes are enormous. One seems to glare while the other seems to smile out quite benignly. The Tortorosaurus is both a beautiful and a comic object, and you suspect that its creator may, for all his gloominess, be laughing at you, or at himself.

He has an extraordinary soft, clear voice. His elder brother may have been the poet, but the younger brother has a way with language too - conjuring his life in snapshots, unflinching in self-criticism, dispassionate in his observation of others. He was the youngest of four (only his sister Christine, 92, is still alive), far brighter and sportier than his brother Stephen. He spent his childhood trying to lose at battledore and shuttlecock: "My father's attitude was based on the fact that Stephen was no good at... well anything really and I hated underlining this." Both parents were dead before Humphrey was 16, the mother - "what was known as an invalid" - finally killed by the ministrations of a drunken doctor; the father, "who thought in dramatic cliches", pining away, despite plentiful leeches, soon after.

Spender trained to be an architect but his heart was never in it . Instead, he set up a photographic studio with a friend and did rather well drawing on the connections, via Stephen, with the Forsters and Isherwoods, the swinging London of the time. He and Stephen had "all kinds of ups and downs", but remained close, despite their differences of character. ("I'm much more parsimonious, much more careful. The more money Stephen had the more he would spend it all.") They grew apart a bit when Stephen went to America "and became very VIP" but in those days they were together a lot. He even accompanied him to Germany (Isherwood used Spender's 1933 image of Lutzowplatz as the cover for Goodbye to Berlin). "Stephen suddenly told me for rather obscure reasons I think you can probably guess, 'What you need Humphrey is to spend three or four weeks in Berlin."' You mean ... "Yes," says Spender drily. "I did. And I did."

And then the Mirror rang and a mission "to make the world a better place" began. Spender, forever carrying guilt about his privileged background, had already been photographing children in London's East End for a project about juvenile crime. "I was very friendly with the probation officer and she was convinced that bad housing - look, see that picture there -" He has been flicking through a book of his photographs and has stopped at a shot of crumbled sheets and bedsteads. "Seven people slept in that bedroom and that led to incest of course, these children were being abused, raped by their fathers and uncles, and that made for crime. So I knew the inside story and I thought it was a good idea to disclose it."

He doesn't think the Mass Observation project did much to disclose anything, most of his pictures sat, undeveloped in a drawer until the 70s. And he has always felt he failed in his fundamental aim to be invisible. Flicking further through the book, he intones: "She knows. They know. She doesn't. He does. We were always saying, 'We must get into families,' but then they'd always want to clean the room, rearrange the mantelpiece, get out the best china so you arrived at an untrue statement." He is still passing through the pages of the book and takes a sudden intake of breath. "Here I am - 'Tyneside, 1936, overcome by what I call the BP, the Beautiful Photograph, when what it should be is a rather dismal picture of unemployment." He gives a pregnant sigh. "The BP is a danger. Don McCullin, who is wonderful, wonderful, far, far better than me, sometimes his photographs are so so beautiful. He's photographing ultimate nightmare horror and the beauty does partly disguise that I think. Very interesting that he only takes BPs now."

Spender doesn't take photographs these days. He gave up after the war when the pressure to prettify got too much and became a lecturer in textile design at the RCA instead. There are too many photographs in the world he says. When he was at the RCA he would see a tourist coach stop every Friday outside the Albert Hall. "Thirty Japanese would jump from the coach and walk 15 paces. Standing in line they would raise their automated Minoltas and Mamiyas, Yashicas and Konikas, Praktikas and Pentaxes, Ricohs and Nikons and each expose five frames. One hundred and 50 excellent pictures of the Albert Memorial." But he does think it a pity that the Picture Post isn't still going today. "If there was I would do a feature on mobile phones or backpackers. They present such marvellous sort of visual things in mainline stations."

"But anyway," he says. "We must talk about the art. Rachel will be very cross if we don't dwell on that." He is a surprising cove. His first wife, Margaret, died, "her hands chasing imaginary butterflies", of cancer in 1946; his second, Pauline, has been in a home, suffering from Alzheimer's, "and in a way practically hardly exists; more or less vegetative" since February last year. Their son, Quentin, has now banned Spender from visiting her as he finds it too upsetting - "and guilt making," he adds. Which brings us to Rachel. Rachel is 36 and "we're very devoted". She turned up in the orchard 17 years ago, long bare legs on a bicycle "and said hello" and has been around ever since. It is, Spender says, "a rather on-off situation" because she has other obligations and disappears off from time to time, "but I am a great believer in absence being a valuable part of any relationship and we are," he says again with a smile, "very devoted".

Later this year they are off to California to an Isherwood seminar. Spender is to read out extracts from the diary he wrote when sharing a house with Isherwood and his brother and their two boyfriends in Portugal, "about the day to day squabbles of the boys and how Christopher and Stephen found them very boring and how rather out of it I was ..." A nice jaunt, I say. "Yes," he says with a glint "and free. I said, 'I can't go alone. Not at my age.'"

She turned up in the orchard 17 years ago, long bare legs on a bicycle "and said hello" and has been around ever since. It is, Spender says, "a rather on-off situation" because she has other obligations and disappears off from time to time, "but I am a great believer in absence being a valuable part of any relationship and we are," he says again with a smile, "very devoted". Later this year they are off to California to an Isherwood seminar. Spender is to read out extracts from the diary he wrote when sharing a house with Isherwood and his brother and their two boyfriends in Portugal, "about the day to day squabbles of the boys and how Christopher and Stephen found them very boring and how rather out of it I was ..." A nice jaunt, I say. "Yes," he says with a glint "and free. I said, 'I can't go alone. Not at my age.'"

fields.headline: No: 1683 Fred Flintstone
fields.standfirst: Fred Flintstone
fields.trailText: Fred Flintstone
fields.body:
Status: Rotund, intellectually challenged modern-stone-age rock-cutter.

Isn't he extinct yet? Despite having been born in distant prehistory (OK, 1960), Fred and his pals have outlived many a species of telly dinosaur, demonstrating a remarkable ability to evolve.

A case of survival of the fattest, perhaps? Possibly, although Fred's continuing popularity among students and children may have more to do with it. And now they've made a film about him, due to open here this week.

They did that years ago! Six years to be exact. But that's an entire Jurassic era in kiddie/student terms. And besides, the new film, The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas, is completely different from 1994's The Flintstones.

How so? Well, they go to Rock Vegas for a start. And it stars Mark Addy - last seen in clingfilm (and the nip) in The Full Monty - instead of "Mr Roseanne" John Goodman, who played Fred in the earlier film.

Colin Welland was right - the British are coming! Don't be sarky. Besides, who's to say the original Bedrock - before the shifting of the continental plates and so on - wasn't in Sheffield?

What can we expect? Rather more of the same. Lots of kiddie-pleasing slapstick and a some barely concealed innuendos to keep the mums and dads happy. Oh, and Joan Collins.

As menacing stone-age powerbitch Alexis Coalscuttle? As ageing totty Pearl Slaghoople - a role that demanded all of Elizabeth Taylor's experience in the 1994 film. See, I told you it was different.

But Steven Spielberg produced the first one, didn't he? I don't see his name on the credits. He produced this one as well, but curiously preferred not to lend his name to it. Passnotes wouldn't dream of speculating why.

What the critics say: "Creaks and groans on its laborious march through unspeakably obvious, laboured and idiotic humour" (Chicago Sun-Herald).

What someone should have said in 1994: Yabba-dabba-don't do it, Steven.

webTitle: Football: Celtic lose to Bordeaux in warm-up

fields.headline: Reality bites for O'Neill
fields.standfirst: Celtic 2 - 4 Bordeaux
fields.trailText: Celtic 2 - 4 Bordeaux
fields.body:
Martin O'Neill will not be burdened by expectation in his debut season as Celtic's manager. Unfortunately for the Ulsterman, he is burdened by an inheritance from John Barnes that does not allow the club's followers to countenance the next year being one of fulfilment.

The astonishing crowd of 47,224 who turned up here on Saturday to take in the first home outing of the O'Neill era were treated to a performance that laid bare the follies of the Kenny Dalglish-Barnes axis and which did little to encourage them that any dent can be made in Rangers' dominance.

The new Celtic manager will be absolved of any blame for a confidence-sapping pre-season, which has yielded one victory in four games so far, but he knows his state of grace is sure to be a short-lasting commodity.

Taking the mike in the centre circle pre-match to address the legions who had roared him on the pitch, O'Neill joked that he hoped the same people weren't booing him "by September".

They might consider doing so if the toe-curling defending that conspired to see Celtic concede three goals inside the last 25 minutes of an aggressively contested friendly against Bordeaux is repeated regularly in the next two months.

Despite the inadequacies of their three-man back line, one that had poor Alan Stubbs sweeping alongside the concentrationally challenged Barnes signings, Olivier Tebily and Rafael, O'Neill's men had manoeuvred themselves into a 2-1 lead, courtesy of goals from the strike pair Henrik Larsson and Mark Burchill, before their late collapse.

The subsequent transformation in the scoreline was all the more unforgivable because by this point they enjoyed a man advantage over their opponents after the aptly named Laurent Battles was sent off in the 65th minute for whacking Eyal Berkovic.

"If the same things continue it will be a crisis," O'Neill admitted afterwards and averting one in the short-term will require a victory in his side's opening Scottish Premier League game away to Dundee United on Sunday.

West Ham will visit Celtic Park tomorrow, but O'Neill's only addition to the squad thus far, the £6m buy from Chelsea, Chris Sutton, is unlikely to feature as the result of an ankle injury.

On the surface, the Irishman remains relatively sanguine about his side's prospects of presenting a greater challenge to Rangers than was the case when they finished 21 points behind the Ibrox side in last term's title race.

"I was pleased at the players' determination and willingness to adapt to my own philosophy, which means top-class talent working hard," he said.

"But the problems which have been there for quite some time are still prevalent. The fact we lost some poor goals is reminiscent of how the side have been for some time, but it's my team now and I have to rectify the problems, which I hope to do as soon as possible.

"I have a fair idea about certain individuals, but then I should do because I'm working here now. It's my job to try and rectify what went wrong."

Attempts to acquire the services of the Leicester City midfielder Neil Lennon, Joos Valgaeren, the Belgian centre-back with the Dutch club Roda Kerkrade, and Aston Villa's midfielder Alan Thompson have produced no concrete results, leaving the Celtic natives fearful, if not restless.

"Maybe the fans want 10 or 11 changes but that can't realistically happen," O'Neill added. Even if it is not realistic, it does not mean it may not be necessary.

webTitle: Football: Intertoto Cup: RKC Waalwijk 0 Bradford City 1

fields.headline: Fatigue fear for happy City travellers
fields.standfirst: RKC Waalwijk 0 - 1 Bradford City
fields.trailText: RKC Waalwijk 0 - 1 Bradford City
fields.body:
The blissful managerial baptism of Chris Hutchings continues as Bradford City's happy travellers won their fourth successive game on the journey to a possible Intertoto final with Aston Villa next month.

Bradford booked a semi-final place with Saturday night's success in the Netherlands but the prospect of burn-out even before the start of the Premiership season must be a concern. Hutchings's team, having already played in Lithuania, now head east again for Wednesday's first leg in Russia with Zenit St Petersburg. It will be their fifth Intertoto game in less than a month.

Though Bradford face a formidable Premiership start - Liverpool, Manchester United and Arsenal are three of their first five opponents - the chairman Geoffrey Richmond would not change a thing. "The players are enjoying it, the supporters are loving it, and if we have an opportunity to enter the competition next season then we will most certainly take it."

Bradford prevailed in this third-round return with a more pragmatic approach than England practised in the Low Countries last month, even if Dean Windass was wasteful with a 49th-minute penalty that rebounded to safety from an upright.

The striker was unfortunate not to see Lee Sharpe finish off his shrewd diagonal pass before half-time, but Windass then supplied the instant through-ball from which Lee Mills struck in the 81st minute.

Rob van Dijk had denied Sharpe but could not stop Mills slotting the ball home to the glee of the Bradford supporters massed at that end. It was Mills's third goal in his three Intertoto appearances.

Hutchings said: "It was a workmanlike performance, although we were not as positive as I would have liked in the first half." An ankle injury makes the defender David Wetherall a doubtful starter in Russia.

RKC Waalwijk (3-4-1-2): Van Dijk; Nascimento, Teixeira, Nwakire (Govedarica, 56min); Lamey, Gudjonsson (Redan, 68), Van den Berg, De Graef; Van Loenhout (Lanckohr, 75); Y Cornelisse, Hoogendorp.

Bradford City (4-3-3): Walsh; Halle, Wetherall (Westwood, 76), Atherton, Nolan; O'Brien, Whalley, Sharpe; Hopkin (Lawrence, 76), Windass (Blake, 86), Mills.

Referee : E I Gonzalez (Spain).

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Newcastle had an inauspicious start to their pre- season tour as a largely full-strength side lost 3-1 to DC United in an uninspiring match in Washington DC.
fields.body:
Newcastle had an inauspicious start to their pre- season tour as a largely full-strength side lost 3-1 to DC United in an uninspiring match in Washington DC.

Newcastle, who yesterday sold the striker Paul Robinson to Wimbledon in a deal worth £1.5m, looked sluggish for much of the game with their £7m signing Carl Cort especially guilty of missed opportunities. Their only goal came in the 66th minute from the Argentine striker Daniel Cordone, another summer signing.

A 75th-minute goal by Trevor Sinclair was enough to give West Ham victory over St Patrick's Athletic at Richmond Park in Dublin. Harry Redknapp's side looked dangerous with their French signing Freddie Kanouté particularly impressive.

Liverpool suffered an embarrassing 1-0 away defeat to Second Division Stoke City despite giving run-outs to their new signings Gary McAllister, Bernard Diomède and Pegguy Arphexad.

Their fellow Premiership contenders Leeds United had a healthier start as Mark Viduka marked his debut with a hat-trick in a 7-1 win over the Swedish side Lysekils . Viduka's £6m move from Celtic was completed only on Friday, when the 24-year-old striker was granted a work permit on appeal.

Sunderland began their build-up to the Premiership season last night with a 3-0 defeat away against Le Havre . Kevin Phillips and Niall Quinn were both rested while the new signing Don Hutchison made his debut.

Shaun Goater was quickly into his goalscoring stride when Manchester City beat Linfield 4-0 in the Premiership new boys' opening pre- season friendly. Goater fired City ahead against the Northern Irish champions inside two minutes.

Chelsea suffered an early scare when the £15m Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink hobbled off with an ankle injury be fore the end of the 3-1 win over Kingstonian . Hasselbaink scored within seven minutes. Chelsea's other goals came from Mario Stanic and Roberto Di Matteo.

The Tottenham manager George Graham insisted that there was room for improvement after his side won 4-0 against the Finnish second division side Tervarit with the help of a goal from their new striker Sergei Rebrov.

"We still have some work to do," Graham said. "We should have scored more than four."

Jermaine Pennant, 17, scored the only goal as Arsenal defeated Barnet in a game that saw Arsène Wenger's side so relaxed as to be almost comatose.

webTitle: Football: India's first visit to England kicks off with defeat at Fulham

fields.headline: Riedle brace fails to spoil India's day
fields.standfirst: Fulham 2 - 0 India
fields.trailText: Fulham 2 - 0 India
fields.body:
Fulham 2 Riedle 40, 81 India 0

In the end, it proved to be a case of men against boys with the brawn and technical know-how of Fulham proving too good for the enthusiasm and energy of an Indian team making history with its first match on English soil.

India have a long way to go if they are to fulfil their ambition of qualifying for a World Cup by the end of the decade, but just about held their own against a strong Fulham side that was playing its first home match under the former France midfielder Jean Tigana.

The Fulham fans in a crowd of just under 6,000 have to be commended for the generous reception they gave the Indian team and their fans and, in terms of community relations, the afternoon was clearly a success. Rarely have so many British Asians attended a football match and Fulham won many friends for the hospitable atmosphere the home fans created.

For the record, the match was won by two Karlheinz Riedle goals late in each half. India rarely threatened the Fulham goal but the captain and striker Bhaichung Bhutia, who currently plays for Bury, proved a handful for the Fulham captain Chris Coleman.

Bhutia's strike partner, IM Vijayan, went closest to hitting the back of the Fulham net with an overhead kick midway through the first half but the team lacked a cutting edge and were short on ideas and tactical awareness throughout the afternoon.

"We did our best but lacked experience," said Bhutia after the match. "But it was very exciting and I think we surprised some people."

The national team's historic tour is designed to raise the profile of Indian football and raise awareness about the lack of British Asians within the domestic game. India are ranked 115th in the world and football is hugely popular in some parts of the country.

At the final whistle, the Indian team did a lap of honour with players going over to their fans and shaking hands with scores of them. The players clearly enjoyed the adulation and the historic novelty value of the match was not lost on their supporters.

Fulham: Taylor; Finnan, Brevett (W Collins, 71min), Melville, Coleman, Davis, J Collins, Clark, Betsy (Goldbaek, 78) Riedle, Boa Morte (Cornwall, 64).

India: V Singh; P Singh, Gawli, Fernandes, D Singh, Ancheri (Jamil, 88), Mondal (Sangha, 46), Alberto (Saini, 46), R Singh, Vijayan, Bhutia.

India's fixtures: Wednesday July 26 v West Brom (7pm); Saturday July 29 v Bangladesh (Filbert Street, Leicester, 2pm)

webTitle: Football: Intertoto Cup: A Villa 3 - 1 Dukla Pribram

fields.headline: Southgate feels fans' backlash
fields.standfirst: Aston Villa 3 - 1 Dukla Pribram
fields.trailText: Aston Villa 3 - 1 Dukla Pribram
fields.body:
Gareth Southgate and his fellow malcontents, Ugo Ehiogu and Julian Joachim, were left in no doubt on Saturday how the club's supporters view their attempts to jump the good ship Aston Villa.

Indeed, there were times when urging Villa to victory in this tie, held at West Bromwich because of construction work at Villa Park, came a poor second to heaping abuse on the would-be defectors.

Villa huffed and puffed against a Czech side whose passing pleased the eye but rarely raised pulses in the home defence. It was left to Southgate to deliver the 56th-minute free-kick that set up Ian Taylor for the goal that put Villa on course for a semi-final against Spain's Celta Vigo.

After a goalless first leg, that had looked in doubt when Marek Kulic scored a vital away goal midway through the first half to cancel out Dion Dublin's headed opener.

The free-kick apart, there was an uncharacteristic uncertainty about Southgate's game. According to Villa's manager John Gregory, and despite the player's claims to the contrary, choosing which club to join cannot have been a distraction.

"We have not received any bids for Gareth Southgate," said Gregory. "I have had just one conversation about him. That was with Chelsea's Colin Hutchinson. He asked me if I would consider a swop for Southgate. That's been it - no one else has rung either me or the chairman about him. If Gareth thinks differently then he's having his head filled with complete garbage."

Gareth Barry delivered the cross for the Belgian striker Luc Nilis to add a debut goal to complete the scoring. Paul Merson was sent off three minutes from the end after being booked for a second time and will miss Wednesday's first leg in Vigo.

Aston Villa (3-4-1-2): James; Ehiogu, Southgate, Barry; Stone, Taylor, Boateng (Hendrie, 57min), Wright; Merson; Dublin (Vassell, 65), Nilis (Joachim, 80).

Dukla Pribram (1-2-5-2): Caloun; Schindler; Mynar (Nehoda, 84), Jarolim; Makh, Grlic, Smejkal, Novak (Otepka, 68), Rychlik; Kulic (Seman, 73), Kucera.

Referee: K Stadsgaard (Denmark).

fields.headline: BSkyB poaches Adidas chief
fields.trailText: BSkyB has poached the former British boss of sportswear group Adidas to build an online sporting goods retail business, selling everything from Manchester United strips to ice hockey pucks.
fields.body:
BSkyB has poached the former British boss of sportswear group Adidas to build an online sporting goods retail business, selling everything from Manchester United strips to ice hockey pucks.

Bob McCulloch, 52, has been hired to build Skysportsstore.com, which will be the company's first stand alone e-commerce venture.

Initially Skysportsstore.com will only be available via the internet, but BSkyB plans to make the service available through a broad base of distribution platforms.

Crucially, BSkyB's recent acquisition of a majority stake in Open, the interactive channel, removed a non-compete clause which prevented the broadcaster from offering e-commerce services through its channels. Other services planned include online betting.

"We want to out-Lillywhite Lillywhites," a spokesman said.

"The idea is that you will be watching Manchester United and can then go through to order the team's new strip."

webTitle: Yahoo! faces French fines for Nazi auctions

fields.headline: Yahoo! faces French fines for Nazi auctions
fields.standfirst: Special report: Free speech on the net
fields.trailText: Yahoo!, one of the world's leading internet service providers, faces daily fines of more than £100,000 if a court in Paris today finds that it has failed to stop French surfers accessing online auctions of Nazi memorabilia.
fields.body:
Yahoo!, one of the world's leading internet service providers, faces daily fines of more than £100,000 if a court in Paris today finds that it has failed to stop French surfers accessing online auctions of Nazi memorabilia.

It has been given until today to block the site, judged by an earlier ruling to be an "offence to the collective memory" of France. The auctions had already been removed from Yahoo! France, the French subsidiary, but the US web portal refused to block access, or put warning messages on its US site.

A search last night revealed 1,211 items of Nazi memorabilia for sale, including bayonets, medals and swastikas.

Recent court judgments have brought temporary relief to internet companies accused of giving access to offensive material. The US supreme court ruled in May that an internet service provider (ISP) bore no responsibility for the material it carried, and a court in Munich last year overturned the conviction of the former head of CompuServe in Germany for aiding and abetting the spread of child pornography.

The issue which has landed CompuServe and AOL in court in Germany in the past is the responsibility of an ISP for material provided to that country, but today's case in France is wider in scope.

If successful, it will make material in a foreign language and not specifically aimed at the population of another country actionable under that country's laws, simply because it is available there.

The case comes two months after the Paris court banned the site, ruling that it "constituted an apology for nazism and a contestation of Nazi crimes".

Yahoo! was told to "dissuade and make it impossible" for French users to access the site. It was further ordered to provide a warning on its search engine about the contents of sites for which it provided active links.

Yesterday the only visible warnings on the auction site informed collectors that items such as an identity book belonging to a member of the SS were "very rare" and would go under the hammer in five hours. Another entry read: "Postcard of Nazi Concentration Camp! LOOK!!!"

The case is being brought by the Union of Jewish Students and the International League Against Racism and Anti-Semitism (LICRA), whose honorary members include the French president, Jacques Chirac, and the prime minister, Lionel Jospin.

Marc Knobel, a historian involved in the action, said the organisations were first made aware of the site in February, when it carried links to sites involved in Holocaust denials and other neo-Nazi groups.

Mr Knobel said: "Should we have to accept this barbarism? Yahoo.com can sell things in America. That's fine. The Americans do what they want. But from Paris, I can consult these pages, and according to French law, that is illegal."

France prohibits the sale of goods inciting violence or racist sentiments.

Mr Knobel said: "Liberty of expression has its limits, according to the human rights charter. In America they have the first amendment, which makes legal action against such sites difficult. But in France, as in other countries, we have laws, and these laws must be respected.

"Even aside from technical difficulties [of blocking the site to French users] we don't expect Yahoo! to agree, which could mean a fine of over £100,000 a day until they do."

A spokesman for Yahoo! France would not say whether the company would appeal against the ruling, propose another solution, or ensure compliance with French law by removing the auctions from its US site, a step which would set a precedent.

Internet specialists claim it is virtually impossible to block access to such sites, because of the ease with which proxy addresses can be established and advertised without the ISP's knowledge.

"It's technically not in Yahoo!'s power to do this," Armando Fox, an assistant computer science professor at Stanford University, told the US magazine Business and Industry. "All Yahoo! sees is an address, and anyone can set up a proxy to change an address. There's no way to reliably map an incoming connection."

Lawyers too say that this is unchartered territory, potentially making internet bankers in one country liable for dealings which infringe the banking laws of another.

"It's a little bit as if we've all been transported to Mars and now have to figure out new rules of engagement," said Thomas Vartanian, chairman of an American Bar Association committee which spent two years examining jurisdictional issues posed by the internet.

"I see businesses spending a lot of money trying to figure out their liability all around the world," he said.

Web law: policing the internet

May 2000 US supreme court rules that internet service provides have full protection against libellous or abusive messages over the web. The court upholds a ruling against a former boy scout who sued the ISP Prodigy after an impostor used his name to send threatening messages to his neighbours

April 2000 A court in Munich holds AOL Europe liable for failing to prevent distribution of pirated music. An AOL spokesman said: "Nobody would have sued the Royal Mail or Deutsche Post for delivering a package that contained illegal CDs"

March 2000 In an out-of- court settlement, Demon pays university lecturer Laurence Godfrey £15,000 and legal fees of around £230,000 because he was the subject of allegedly libellous bulletin-board postings.

Within days British ISPs closed two websites, a gay site called Outcast and an anti-censorship site. Outcast appeals to the European court of human rights

May 1998 A former head of CompuServe in Germany, Felix Somm, is given a two-year suspended sentence and fined £33,000 in a landmark ruling that held him responsible for aiding and abetting the spread of child pornography. Ruling is overturned in 1999
