fields.headline: Go east, young man
fields.standfirst: He could be the heir to the vast Murdoch empire. He has just taken over at News Corp's Star TV, which broadcasts in 53 countries in Asia. And he's coming to Britain this summer to lecture at the Guardian Edinburgh International TV Festival. Rupert's youngest talks to  Jane Martinson
fields.trailText: He could be the heir to the vast Murdoch empire. He has just taken over at News Corp's Star TV, which broadcasts in 53 countries in Asia. And he's coming to Britain this summer to lecture at the Guardian Edinburgh International TV Festival. Rupert's youngest talks to Jane Martinson
fields.body:
Mao Zedong used to dominate James Murdoch's office in Manhattan, until someone decided to get rid of the two portraits of the Chinese communist leader that looked down at the youngest son of one of the world's most influential capitalists.

On his first day back in the office after his honeymoon last week, the 27-year-old son of Rupert admitted that he had no idea where the Mao posters had gone. Asked if they would reappear in Hong Kong, where he is to head Star TV, the Asian satellite television operation owned by the family's media empire, he smiled and said: "Er, no."

The baby of the Murdoch clan is likely to face more serious political and cultural challenges as the chief executive of a business that operates in 53 countries and seven languages and is at the heart of his father's digital media ambitions. His dad has famously dissed the Tibetans, the BBC and Hong Kong's last governor, Chris Patten, in comments widely seen as attempts to win the affection of the Chinese government.

James, who joined the family firm just three years ago, is already well schooled on the difficulties of doing business in a global empire. "We try to be very sensitive to political realities and very sensitive to cultural sensibilities in any country we're operating in - be it Australia or China." Or the UK, he might have added.

James, who is almost unknown in the country of his birth (he moved to the US when he was a toddler), is likely to reveal a genetic willingness to wade into some cultural sensitivities in the UK as early as next month, when he delivers the annual Alternative MacTaggart lecture at the Guardian Edinburgh International TV Festival. His views of the tightly-regulated UK media market - he uses epithets such as "draconian", "ridiculous" and "evil" - mark him out as his father's son more than almost anything else.

Yet of the three Murdoch siblings who have joined News Corporation - Elisabeth, Lachlan and James - the youngest had always seemed the least like the patriarch. Sweet-tempered, artistic James was the one who dropped out of Harvard after a year making puppet movies during his course in visual environmental studies. Before that, he had spent a year in Rome and contemplated a career as an archaeologist or an academic.

Both brothers - close in many ways - horrified their parents with their tattoos, but at least Lachlan completed his Ivy League degree before going to work in the group's Australian heartland operations. James dyed his hair blond, pierced his ears and clashed with the teachers at his conservative boys' school before starting his own business.

In a family renowned for high-level and heated discussions around the dinner table, sensitive James was the one who most often argued about politics with his famously libertarian father. Speaking now of his decision to join the family empire back in November 1997, he says: "I'd never felt that I would, but then it was a great opportunity."

The great opportunity was to sell Rawkus Entertainment, the fledgling music business he had started with two friends, to his father and to start News Corp's interactive publishing division in New York. College friends say they were less surprised than he was when he joined News Corp because he had always been interested in what they called the "whole business".

Once installed there, his role in developing the online interests of a company increasingly seen as an ink-stained relic was instrumental in changing internal perceptions of the youngest Murdoch.

While his official CV gives him credit for investing in several online companies as head of News Digital Media, he also sketched out last year's merger of TV Guide, the listings magazine, with Gemstar, a video technology company, on the back of a napkin.

He is remarkably charming and friendly, with a nice line in self-deprecation. He visibly suffered when required to pose for the Guardian photographer and seemed chuffed to have been asked to speak in Edinburgh.

"You think people will come?" he asks. "It's a Sunday night." He is likely to hate the personal tone of this article, having said at one point in the 90-minute interview: "Speculating about your personality seems to be a curious pastime - oh, that's journalism."

When asked if he is like his father, he stutters a bit. His friends say he seems to have the same knack for creative and lateral thinking. Robert Carlock, a friend from Harvard, calls him "intellectually omnivorous" and says he reads widely. Another college friend, Mark Roybal, says he was so impressed by Murdoch's firm handshake and textbook-devouring energy on their first meeting that he immediately thought: "I'm out of my league here."

Joe Keiner, a colleague from Gemstar, likens him to his father: "They are both very strategic, visionary thinkers and bold in their approach. And they both have the ability to look four steps ahead."

James does not appear to share his father's love of the newspaper business but he talks about networks and interactivity with some passion. "The thing that gets me up in the morning is the information business," he says.

His political beliefs also seem to have moved towards his father's in the past few years, although he refuses to talk in terms of left or right. "My father's politics and mine, which I think I understand better than many do, are probably reasonably close. I think he is vastly misunderstood politically."

James says that in Britain his father is vilified for being driven entirely by ideology whereas everywhere else in the world he is seen as a robber baron driven purely by the profit motive.

He says he is entirely apolitical at work but, for the record, he largely supports pro-market regimes and voted for an anti-taxation libertarian in the most recent US elections. He also calls President Bill Clinton "an awful scumbag" for his ability to lie and cheat.

He is close to his father and telephones him frequently. When asked whom he will turn to for advice in running Star, he says: "I know it sounds hokey, but I speak to my father." A framed picture of the two of them hangs behind his desk, above a tiny icon of Jesus.

His new job is a challenging one. Star, which has accumulated $1bn in losses since it was bought by News Corporation in 1993, is nevertheless considered the jewel in the crown of Sky Global, the new satellite company about to be spun out of the corporate behemoth with assets including BSkyB.

As chief executive, James is likely to negotiate a series of alliances from the Middle East to south-east Asia in order to accelerate the company's involvement in interactive television as well as the internet. He talks of Star being at the centre of a web of local operations.

Some of the difficulties of operating in the region were demonstrated when the company, which has contracts with 6,000 cable operators in Asia, broke off its eight-month relationship with Cable and Wireless HKT last month. News Corp had grown wary of the high costs involved in the video-on-demand service planned with Hong Kong's biggest telecommunications company, but is now faced with providing interactive services on its own. James says that his new company is "much better off" on its own.

As a member of the Sky Global board, James is likely to be instrumental in providing a launchpad for the interactive television services of Open, BSkyB's subsidiary.

He is also in charge of investing in Asian internet operations. Star has already invested $150m in more than 20 web-based businesses, from Chinese language chatrooms to an Indian general interest portal. If all goes well at Star over the next few months, analysts expect Sky Global to be valued at about $50bn when it gains a stock market listing later this year.

Having convinced his new wife, a former PR executive, to move to Hong Kong, he is looking forward to the new job. "It's the most exciting media marketplace in the world, hands down," he says. "I can't imagine a better spot to be trying to grow a business for any young executive in media."

Wall Street analysts, who have occasionally raised concerns about the dangers of nepotism in a company which is 30% owned by the Murdochs, seem genuinely impressed by what James has done in New York. Jessica Reif Cohen at Merrill Lynch, the US investment bank, says: "Star needs someone who cares and he does." She says that she is struck by how hard both Murdoch brothers work: "James may be young but he is really, really smart and very impressive."

The corporate structure of News Corp - a company with operations ranging from newspapers, such as the Sun and the Times, to film studios and satellite technology companies - is baffling to many outsiders. "Some people would say that we're not as well structured as we could be," James admits.

He will report to Chase Carey, the new chief executive of Sky Global, in his new job but will also continue to share responsibility for the group's interactive division with Peter Chernin, his father's designated number two, for the time being.

Showing a rare sign of overt ambition, he says that he "hopes to stay in the loop" when he moves to the Asian outpost of the empire. When asked the question that has dogged the company for years - what happens after his 69-year-old father goes? - James offers the standard corporate response: "God forbid when that happens, but he [his father] has been reasonably clear that Peter [Chernin] is there.

"Ultimately the board will decide. We're a public company with lots of shareholders. Really, people don't believe this, but we have a board and they talk about these things."

"We're not a monolith," he says. "There are so many things that happen in our company every day. It's very easy to personalise [it] but I think that's probably wrong."

He cites as an example the decision by HarperCollins, the company's book arm, not to publish Chris Patten's memoirs. He doesn't think his father had anything to do with it.

No instalment of our favourite corporate soap opera would be complete without sibling rivalry surfacing, but talking to James makes the Murdochs sound more like the Brady Bunch than the Borgias. When forced to discuss what he would do in the event of his older brother taking over, he says: "We're pretty close. We don't have any issues."

He refuses to comment on the rumour that he will soon join Lachlan on the main board ("You're asking the wrong person") and has given little thought to what he does next: "I'm going to China and we'll see how we go. I'll probably be there for a little while and there's a lot of work to do. I hope I don't screw it up too bad and they keep me on for a while."

Will he stay at the company for ever? "I hope so, God willing," he says, before adding with a nod to those ever-vigilant shareholders, "or the boss and the board willing."

He cites as an example the decision by HarperCollins, the company's book arm, not to publish Chris Patten's memoirs. He doesn't think his father had anything to do with it. No instalment of our favourite corporate soap opera would be complete without sibling rivalry surfacing, but talking to James makes the Murdochs sound more like the Brady Bunch than the Borgias. When forced to discuss what he would do in the event of his older brother taking over, he says: "We're pretty close. We don't have any issues." He refuses to comment on the rumour that he will soon join Lachlan on the main board ("You're asking the wrong person") and has given little thought to what he does next: "I'm going to China and we'll see how we go. I'll probably be there for a little while and there's a lot of work to do. I hope I don't screw it up too bad and they keep me on for a while." Will he stay at the company for ever? "I hope so, God willing," he says, before adding with a nod to those ever-vigilant shareholders, "or the boss and the board willing."
